Question:
The warden meets with 23 new prisoners when they arrive. He tells them, "You may meet today and plan a strategy. But after today, you will be in isolated cells and will have no communication with one another.
"In the prison there is a switch room which contains two light switches labeled A and B, each of which can be in either the 'on' or the 'off' position. BOTH SWITCHES ARE IN THEIR OFF POSITIONS NOW.*  The switches are not connected to anything.
"After today, from time to time whenever I feel so inclined, I will select one prisoner at random and escort him to the switch room. This prisoner will select one of the two switches and reverse its position. He must move one, but only one of the switches. He can't move both but he can't move none either. Then he'll be led back to his cell."
"No one else will enter the switch room until I lead the next prisoner there, and he'll be instructed to do the same thing. I'm going to choose prisoners at random. I may choose the same guy three times in a row, or I may jump around and come back."
"But, given enough time, everyone will eventually visit the switch room as many times as everyone else. At any time any one of you may declare to me, 'We have all visited the switch room.'
"If it is true, then you will all be set free. If it is false, and somebody has not yet visited the switch room, you will be fed to the alligators."
*note - the only difference from Scenario B, the original position of the 2 switches are known.
Hint:
Assuming that:
A) There is no restriction on the amount of time the prisoners could take before sending the notice to the warden that everyone has been to the switch room at least once.
B) There is no restriction on the number of time each prisoner can visit the switch room
C) The warden will not attempt any foul moves, such as intentionally not bringing a certain prisoner to the switch room forever.
Human Solution:
Let the two switches be  

A – the “counter” switch (its position will carry the information)  
B – a “spare” switch whose only purpose is to give a prisoner something he can
legally flip when he does not want to touch A.

Initial fact to be remembered by everybody  
A = OFF ,  B = OFF.

Before they are separated the prisoners agree on two rôles.

• One prisoner will be the Leader.  
• The remaining 22 will be Ordinary prisoners.

PRIVATE MEMORY  
Each Ordinary prisoner keeps one personal bit “I-have-already-signalled”, initially
FALSE.  
The Leader keeps an integer counter, initially 0.

RULES FOR AN ORDINARY PRISONER  
When he is taken to the switch room he looks at A.

1. If A is OFF and his personal flag is still FALSE  
      – He flips A from OFF to ON (this is his one and only signal).  
      – He sets his personal flag to TRUE.

2. In every other situation (A is ON, or he has already signalled earlier)  
      – He ignores A and flips B instead (from OFF to ON or from ON to OFF,
        whichever it happens to be).  

Thus every Ordinary prisoner will flip A from OFF to ON exactly once in his
life, and never again touches A afterwards.  
At all later visits he merely toggles the spare switch B.

RULES FOR THE LEADER  
When the Leader is taken to the switch room he acts as follows.

1. If A is ON  
      – He flips A back to OFF.  
      – He adds 1 to his personal counter.

2. If A is OFF  
      – He flips B (so that he obeys the “must flip exactly one switch”
        requirement).

As soon as the Leader’s personal counter reaches 22 he knows that every one of
the 22 Ordinary prisoners has already given his unique signal, hence each of
them must have visited the room at least once.  
At that moment he announces “All of us have visited the switch room.”

WHY THE STRATEGY WORKS

• Because the initial state A = OFF is known, the only way A can ever be found
  ON is that an Ordinary prisoner who had not signalled before just flipped it
  to ON.  
  Therefore each time the Leader sees A = ON he is certainly counting a
  previously uncounted prisoner.

• No Ordinary prisoner will ever flip A from ON back to OFF, so the Leader is
  the only person who can reset A to OFF.  
  Hence every “ON” that the Leader sees corresponds to a different Ordinary
  prisoner.

• There are exactly 22 Ordinary prisoners, so after the Leader has seen A in
  the ON position 22 times his counter reaches 22 and in fact everyone has
  visited.

• The spare switch B is irrelevant to the logic; it only guarantees that every
  prisoner can always obey the warden’s rule “you must flip exactly one
  switch”, even when he does not want to change A.

• The warden’s promise that every prisoner is brought to the switch room
  infinitely often guarantees that
  – the Leader will eventually collect all 22 signals, and  
  – every Ordinary prisoner who has not yet signalled will eventually encounter
    the room in a state with A = OFF, giving him the opportunity to send his
    one signal.

Consequently the Leader’s announcement will eventually be both made and be
correct, so the prisoners are certain to obtain their freedom.

Final answer: One prisoner acts as Leader; the others each turn switch A from OFF to ON exactly once (using B as a dummy flip thereafter); the Leader turns A back to OFF and counts; when his count reaches 22 he announces that everyone has visited, which is guaranteed to be true.
Response:
Total Step Count: 10  
Creative Steps: 4  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. (Creative)  Agree to treat switch A as a “counter” that will carry information and switch B as a harmless “spare,” remembering that both begin in the OFF position.  

2. (Creative)  Before separation, designate one prisoner as the Leader and the remaining 22 as Ordinary prisoners.  

3. (Rudimentary)  Give each Ordinary prisoner a personal one-bit memory “I-have-already-signalled” (initially FALSE) and give the Leader an integer counter (initially 0).  

4. (Creative)  Ordinary-prisoner protocol: whenever taken to the switch room, if A is OFF and the personal flag is FALSE, flip A to ON and set the flag to TRUE; otherwise ignore A and flip B.  

5. (Rudimentary)  Observe that, under this rule, every Ordinary prisoner flips A from OFF to ON exactly once in his lifetime and thereafter always flips B.  

6. (Creative)  Leader protocol: whenever taken to the switch room, if A is ON, flip A back to OFF and add 1 to the personal counter; if A is OFF, flip B instead.  

7. (Rudimentary)  Stipulate that when the Leader’s counter reaches 22 he will declare “All of us have visited the switch room.”  

8. (Rudimentary)  Justify correctness: because the initial state of A is OFF and only Ordinary prisoners ever turn it ON, every ON detected by the Leader corresponds to a distinct Ordinary prisoner who had not been counted before.  

9. (Rudimentary)  Note that only the Leader ever resets A to OFF, preventing double-counting, while B is flipped merely to satisfy the warden’s “must flip a switch” rule and carries no information.  

10. (Rudimentary)  Invoke the warden’s guarantee of infinitely many visits for each prisoner to conclude that eventually every Ordinary prisoner will send his single signal, the Leader will count to 22, make the announcement, and the statement will be true.

Question:
There is a ten-digit mystery number (no leading 0), represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) A + B + C + D + E is a multiple of 6.
2) F + G + H + I + J is a multiple of 5.
3) A + C + E + G + I is a multiple of 9.
4) B + D + F + H + J is a multiple of 2.
5) AB is a multiple of 3.
6) CD is a multiple of 4.
7) EF is a multiple of 7.
8) GH is a multiple of 8.
9) IJ is a multiple of 10.
10) FE, HC, and JA are all prime numbers.
Hint: Notice that when combining clues 1 and 2, you have information about the sum of digits. You can do the same for clues 3 and 4.
Human Solution:
We are looking for a 10-digit pandigital number ABCDEFGHIJ (no leading 0) that satisfies ten arithmetic clues.  

Because IJ must be a multiple of 10 (clue 9), the last digit J has to be 0.  
Clue 10 requires JA to be prime; allowing the leading zero to be ignored this simply means A must be one of the one-digit primes 2, 3, 5, 7.  

Clues 7 and 10 together impose a very strong condition on the pair (E,F):

• EF must be a two–digit multiple of 7.  
• The reverse FE must be prime.

Among the 13 two-digit multiples of 7 (14, 21, 28, 35, 42, 49, 56, 63, 70, 77, 84, 91, 98) only three satisfy “reverse is prime”:

 EF = 14 → FE = 41 (prime)  
 EF = 35 → FE = 53 (prime)  
 EF = 91 → FE = 19 (prime)

Hence (E,F) can be (1,4), (3,5) or (9,1).

Trying (E,F) = (1,4) or (3,5) forces contradictions with the other clues (each choice eventually leaves no possible digits for A or makes the required sums impossible).  
The third possibility works, so we set

 E = 9, F = 1  (and therefore EF = 91, FE = 19).

Now use GH ⋮ 8 (clue 8) but avoid the already–used digits {0,1,9}.  
The acceptable two-digit multiples of 8 are 24, 32, 48, 56, 64, 72, 96.  
Testing each in combination with HC prime (clue 10) and CD ⋮ 4 (clue 6) shows that only

 GH = 24  (H = 4, G = 2)  
 HC = 43 (prime) ⇒ C = 3  
 CD = 36 (divisible by 4) ⇒ D = 6

is viable.

So far we have

 A ? C D E F G H I J  
 ?  ? 3 6 9 1 2 4 ? 0

Digits used: {0,1,2,3,4,6,9}.  Left: {5,7,8}.

Because AB must be a multiple of 3 (clue 5) and A is one of {2,3,5,7} not yet used, the only workable choice is

 A = 5  ⇒ B must make AB divisible by 3.  
With A = 5 (sum of digits ≡ 2 mod 3) we need B ≡ 1 mod 3.  
From the remaining digits {7,8}, only 7 satisfies this.

Thus B = 7, giving AB = 57 (divisible by 3).

The one unused digit is I = 8, so IJ = 80 (multiple of 10, as required).

Finally check the three sum-divisibility conditions:

1. A+B+C+D+E = 5+7+3+6+9 = 30, multiple of 6 ✔  
2. F+G+H+I+J = 1+2+4+8+0 = 15, multiple of 5 ✔  
3. A+C+E+G+I = 5+3+9+2+8 = 27, multiple of 9 ✔  
and also B+D+F+H+J = 7+6+1+4+0 = 18, even ✔

All ten clues are now satisfied.

Therefore the mystery number is

 5736912480

Final answer: 5736912480
Response:
Total Step Count: 11  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 9  

Steps:  
1. Note that IJ must be a multiple of 10 ⇒ J = 0 (rudimentary).  
2. From JA prime and ignoring the leading 0, conclude A must be 2, 3, 5 or 7 (rudimentary).  
3. Combine “EF multiple of 7” with “FE prime,” list all two-digit multiples of 7, reverse them, and keep only 14/41, 35/53, 91/19 (creative).  
4. Test each (E,F) pair against the remaining clues; eliminate (1,4) and (3,5); keep (9,1) ⇒ E = 9, F = 1 (rudimentary).  
5. List the unused-digit two-digit multiples of 8 for GH (24, 32, 48, 56, 64, 72, 96) (rudimentary).  
6. Cross-apply GH ⋮ 8, HC prime, and CD ⋮ 4 to find GH = 24 ⇒ H = 4, G = 2, HC = 43 prime ⇒ C = 3, and CD = 36 ⇒ D = 6 (creative).  
7. Record the digits now used {0,1,2,3,4,6,9} and list those remaining {5,7,8} (rudimentary).  
8. Use AB ⋮ 3 with A ∈ {2,3,5,7}; pick A = 5 and determine B needs to be 7 so that 57 ⋮ 3 (rudimentary).  
9. Assign the last unused digit I = 8, giving IJ = 80 (rudimentary).  
10. Verify all four sum-divisibility conditions; they all hold (rudimentary).  
11. State the resulting pandigital number 5736912480 as the final answer (rudimentary).

Question:
There is a ten-digit mystery number (no leading 0), represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) Either A = B / 3 or A = G + 3.
2) Either B = I - 4 or B = E + 4.
3) Either C = J + 2 or C = F * 3.
4) Either D = G * 4 or D = E / 3.
5) Either E = J - 1 or E = D / 4.
6) Either F = B * 2 or F = A - 4.
7) Either G = F + 1 or G = I - 3.
8) Either H = A / 2 or H = C * 3.
9) Either I = H + 3 or I = D / 2.
10) Either J = H - 2 or J = C * 2.
Hint: Check each letter for any value that it can not be on the left side of an equation.  For example, A can not be 0, as B would also have to be 0 or G would have to be negative.
Human Solution:
Step-by-step reasoning

1.  Begin with clue 3 (C and F).  
   • If C = F × 3, then F can only be 1, 2, 3 (because 3 × 4 = 12 > 9).  
     – (F,C) possibilities: (1,3), (2,6), (3,9).  
   • If C = J + 2 we would have to keep C≤9 and J≥0, but using C = F × 3 is the more restrictive start, so adopt it and analyse each pair.

2.  Take the pair (F,C) = (1,3).  
    (The other two pairs will later be seen to fail because they force impossible values for H or J.)

3.  From clue 6 (F & A):  
    F = 1 cannot equal B × 2 (would make B = 0.5), so use the second choice:  
    F = A − 4  ⇒  A = 5.

4.  Clue 8 (H, A, C):  
   • H = A/2 would give H = 2.5, impossible.  
   • Therefore H = C × 3  ⇒  H = 3 × 3 = 9.

5.  Clue 10 (J, H, C): possibilities  
   • J = H − 2  ⇒  J = 9 − 2 = 7.  
   • J = C × 2  ⇒  J = 3 × 2 = 6.  
   Keep both in mind for the moment.

6.  Clue 1 (A, B, G) with A = 5:  
   • A = B/3 would force B = 15 (impossible).  
   • Therefore A = G + 3  ⇒  G = 2.

7.  Clue 4 (D, G, E) with G = 2:  
   • D = G × 4  ⇒  D = 2 × 4 = 8 (works).  
   • The alternative D = E/3 is then unnecessary.

8.  Clue 7 (G, F, I):  
   • G = F + 1  ⇒  2 = 1 + 1, satisfied, so take this option.  
     (We therefore do NOT set I via this clue.)

9.  Clue 9 (I, H, D) with H = 9 and D = 8:  
   • I = H + 3 would give I = 12 (impossible).  
   • Therefore I = D/2  ⇒  I = 8/2 = 4.

10. Clue 2 (B, I, E) with I = 4:  
    • B = I − 4  ⇒  B = 0 (allowed, B is not the leading digit).  
    • Hence the other option (B = E + 4) is not used.

11. Digits used so far:  
    A 5, B 0, C 3, D 8, F 1, G 2, H 9, I 4 → remaining digits {6,7}.  
    (E and J are not fixed yet.)

12. Clue 5 (E, J, D) with D = 8:  
    • E = D/4 would give E = 2, but 2 is already G.  
    • Therefore E = J − 1.

13. Return to the two possibilities for J from step 5:  
    • If J = 6 → E = 5, but A is already 5 (duplicate).  
    • If J = 7 → E = 6, which is unused and works.

    So choose J = 7 and E = 6.

14. All ten digits are now assigned uniquely:

    A 5, B 0, C 3, D 8, E 6, F 1, G 2, H 9, I 4, J 7

15. Verification of every clue:

    1) A = G + 3 → 5 = 2 + 3 ✓  
    2) B = I − 4 → 0 = 4 − 4 ✓  
    3) C = F × 3 → 3 = 1 × 3 ✓  
    4) D = G × 4 → 8 = 2 × 4 ✓  
    5) E = J − 1 → 6 = 7 − 1 ✓  
    6) F = A − 4 → 1 = 5 − 4 ✓  
    7) G = F + 1 → 2 = 1 + 1 ✓  
    8) H = C × 3 → 9 = 3 × 3 ✓  
    9) I = D/2 → 4 = 8/2 ✓  
   10) J = H − 2 → 7 = 9 − 2 ✓  

All conditions are satisfied with every digit 0-9 used exactly once.

Final answer: 5038612947
Response:
Total Step Count: 16  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 14  

Steps:  
1) Select clue 3 as the starting point because it is the most restrictive. Choose the branch C = F × 3 (instead of C = J + 2) and list the permissible (F,C) pairs (1,3), (2,6), (3,9). [Creative]

2) Examine the three (F,C) pairs and adopt (1,3), noting that the other two pairs will force contradictions later. [Creative]

3) Invoke clue 6 with F = 1; F = B × 2 is impossible, so use F = A − 4 to obtain A = 5. [Rudimentary]

4) Apply clue 8 with A = 5 and C = 3; H = A⁄2 fails, so take H = C × 3 to get H = 9. [Rudimentary]

5) Use clue 10 with H = 9 and C = 3 to generate J candidates: J = 7 (from H − 2) or J = 6 (from C × 2). Keep both options. [Rudimentary]

6) Apply clue 1 with A = 5; A = B⁄3 is impossible, so A = G + 3 gives G = 2. [Rudimentary]

7) Apply clue 4 with G = 2; choose D = G × 4 to get D = 8. [Rudimentary]

8) Check clue 7 with G = 2 and F = 1; G = F + 1 is already satisfied, so clue 7 does not set I. [Rudimentary]

9) Use clue 9 with H = 9 and D = 8; I = H + 3 is impossible, so I = D⁄2 gives I = 4. [Rudimentary]

10) Use clue 2 with I = 4; accept B = I − 4 to obtain B = 0. [Rudimentary]

11) Record the digits used so far: A 5, B 0, C 3, D 8, F 1, G 2, H 9, I 4; remaining digits {6, 7}. [Rudimentary]

12) Apply clue 5 with D = 8; E = D⁄4 duplicates 2, so take E = J − 1. [Rudimentary]

13) Resolve the J options: choose J = 7 (instead of 6) so E = 6, keeping all digits unique. [Rudimentary]

14) Compile the full assignment: A 5, B 0, C 3, D 8, E 6, F 1, G 2, H 9, I 4, J 7. [Rudimentary]

15) Verify each of the ten clues against this assignment; all are satisfied. [Rudimentary]

16) Conclude that the mystery number is 5038612947. [Rudimentary]

Question:
Typical "stars" are drawn in connected, but not repeated, line segments. For example, a 5-point star is drawn as such - line segments AC, CE, EB, BD, DA. The segments must always alternate a constant number of points (in the above case, skipping 1 point in between).
Given the information that there is only 1 way to draw a 5-point star, and that there is NO way to draw a 6-point star (in continuous lines, that is), and there are 2 ways to draw a 7-point star, how many different ways are there to draw a 1000-point star?
Hint: It's not guess work. Think of factors and mirror images.  Try drawing out examples.
Human Solution:
Let the  n  points be labelled 0,1,2,…,n–1 around a circle.  
Choose a fixed positive integer k (1 ≤ k ≤ n–1) and draw straight segments

0 → k → 2k → 3k → …  (indices taken modulo n).

The drawing closes when we first return to 0.  
How many distinct drawings produced this way are single, continuous “stars”, i.e. pass through every vertex exactly once?

1. Continuity condition  
   The step k must be coprime to n.  
   Indeed, the cycle length produced is n/ gcd(n,k).  To go through all n points we need gcd(n,k)=1.

2. Excluding the regular n-gon  
   k=1 gives the ordinary n-gon (and k=n–1 the same figure traced backwards).  
   These are not counted as “stars”, so we exclude k=1 and k=n–1.

3. Identifying reversals  
   Step k and step n–k trace the same figure in opposite directions, so they are counted once.  
   Thus each admissible pair {k, n–k} (with k≠n–k) contributes one distinct star.

Hence:

Number of admissible k’s  =  φ(n) – 2          (we subtract k=1 and k=n–1)  
Distinct stars             =  (φ(n) – 2)/2.

Check with the data given  
n=5 :  φ(5)=4  ⇒  (4–2)/2 =1 star ✓  
n=6 :  φ(6)=2  ⇒  (2–2)/2 =0 stars ✓  
n=7 :  φ(7)=6  ⇒  (6–2)/2 =2 stars ✓

Now compute for n = 1000.

Factor n: 1000 = 2³·5³.  
φ(1000) = 1000·(1–1/2)·(1–1/5) = 1000·½·4/5 = 400.

Therefore

Number of 1000-point stars = (φ(1000) – 2)/2  
                           = (400 – 2)/2  
                           = 398/2  
                           = 199.

Final answer: 199
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. Label the n equally spaced points 0, 1, 2, …, n – 1 around a circle and describe any candidate “star” by repeatedly jumping a fixed step size k modulo n (0 → k → 2k → 3k → …).  (Creative)  

2. Establish that this walk visits every vertex exactly once iff gcd(n, k) = 1, because the length of the resulting cycle is n / gcd(n, k).  (Creative)  

3. Observe that k = 1 (or equivalently k = n – 1) merely traces the regular n-gon, which is not regarded as a star, so these two values must be excluded.  (Rudimentary)  

4. Realize that stepping by k and by n – k trace the same figure in opposite directions; hence {k, n – k} should be counted only once.  (Creative)  

5. Combine the above facts: the admissible step sizes are the φ(n) integers coprime to n, minus the two excluded ones, and each pair {k, n – k} represents one star. Therefore the number of distinct n-point stars is (φ(n) – 2) / 2.  (Rudimentary)  

6. Verify the formula against the given data for n = 5, 6, 7 to ensure consistency.  (Rudimentary)  

7. Factor 1000 as 2³ · 5³.  (Rudimentary)  

8. Compute Euler’s totient: φ(1000) = 1000 · (1 – 1/2) · (1 – 1/5) = 400.  (Rudimentary)  

9. Apply the formula: (φ(1000) – 2)/2 = (400 – 2)/2 = 199, giving the final count of 1000-point stars.  (Rudimentary)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 9  
Creative ', ' 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. Label the n equally spaced points 0, 1, 2, …, n – 1 around a circle and describe any candidate “star” by repeatedly jumping a fixed step size k modulo n (0 → k → 2k → 3k → …).  (Creative)  

2. Establish that this walk visits every vertex exactly once iff gcd(n, k) = 1, because the length of the resulting cycle is n / gcd(n, k).  (Creative)  

3. Observe that k = 1 (or equivalently k = n – 1) merely traces the regular n-gon, which is not regarded as a star, so these two values must be excluded.  (Rudimentary)  

4. Realize that stepping by k and by n – k trace the same figure in opposite directions; hence {k, n – k} should be counted only once.  (Creative)  

5. Combine the above facts: the admissible step sizes are the φ(n) integers coprime to n, minus the two excluded ones, and each pair {k, n – k} represents one star. Therefore the number of distinct n-point stars is (φ(n) – 2) / 2.  (Rudimentary)  

6. Verify the formula against the given data for n = 5, 6, 7 to ensure consistency.  (Rudimentary)  

7. Factor 1000 as 2³ · 5³.  (Rudimentary)  

8. Compute Euler’s totient: φ(1000) = 1000 · (1 – 1/2) · (1 – 1/5) = 400.  (Rudimentary)  

9. Apply the formula: (φ(1000) – 2)/2 = (400 – 2)/2 = 199, giving the final count of 1000-point stars.  (Rudimentary)']

Question:
I was playing a game of five card draw poker with a bunch of logicians.  By the time we had finished bidding and were just about to reveal our cards, I was pretty confident I would win of the four of us remaining.  I had three nines, some face card (I can't remember what suit or even whether it was a jack, queen, or king) and a four. (Or was it a five?  I can't remember.)
I was even more sure when two of my opponents laid down their cards.  One had a pair of fours and a pair of sevens, the other had a pair of twos and a pair of eights.  My third opponent, however, laid down his five cards face down in a row.  He said, "I have a straight, and the cards are, from lowest to highest: a ten, a jack, a queen, a king, and an ace.  I have at least one card of each of the four suits: clubs, spades, hearts, and diamonds.  I am fairly certain that this is the winning hand, but I'm feeling generous today, and I will give a third of the pot to whoever can determine which suit I have two cards of.
Now I know you can't figure it out without some clues.  Here they are:
1. The king is next to at least one diamond.
2. The queen is next to exactly one heart.
3. The jack is next to at least one spade, but is not next to any hearts.
4. The ten is next to at least one club.
5. The ace does not border any black cards, nor does it border any diamonds.
6. My two cards of the same suit are not next to each other.
7. Of the ten possible pairings of cards, only one pair, when removed, leaves three cards in ascending order from left to right.
8. My ace is not the card on the far left."
There was a minute's silence.  One of the other logicians said, "I give up!  There's no way to figure that out!"
The other agreed.  But I didn't.  I had just figured out which suit he had two of.
Which suit is it?
Hint:
The first step is to determine where the ace goes.
Also, consider this: How could I have figured it out when two expert logicians couldn't?
Human Solution:
We label the five positions from left to right  

          1   2   3   4   5  

and code the ranks by the numbers  

          10 = 1 , J = 2 , Q = 3 , K = 4 , A = 5 .  

Let C, D, H, S stand for the four suits.  
The eight clues are translated and then used one by one.

----------------------------------------------------------
A.  What the ace can sit next to
----------------------------------------------------------
Clue 5: the ace borders neither black suit (C or S) nor any diamond.  
Hence every card that is next to the ace must be a heart.

• If the ace were in one of the middle three places it would need two heart-
  neighbours, i.e. there would have to be at least two hearts in the pack.  
• If the ace is at an end it needs only one heart-neighbour, so there could be
  only one heart in the pack.

We do not yet know how many hearts we have, so we keep both possibilities.

----------------------------------------------------------
B.  How many of each suit we have
----------------------------------------------------------
We have five cards and at least one card of each suit, so exactly one suit is
duplicated.  Call that suit X; the others appear once.

----------------------------------------------------------
C.  Rule out X = H
----------------------------------------------------------
Suppose hearts were the duplicated suit.

• If the ace were in the middle it would have two heart neighbours; these
  would already use up the two hearts, so the ace itself could not be a heart.
  But then the queen (clue 2) cannot find exactly one heart neighbour
  without forcing two hearts to be adjacent (clue 6).  Impossible.

• If the ace were at an end, it would have one heart neighbour; the second
  heart would have to be elsewhere, but then the queen cannot arrange to have
  exactly one heart neighbour without standing next to both hearts.
  Impossible again.

Therefore X ≠ H; hearts occur exactly once.

----------------------------------------------------------
D.  Put the ace on the right end and create the single heart
----------------------------------------------------------
With only one heart in the whole hand, the ace must be at an end (otherwise it
would need two heart neighbours).  
By clue 8 the ace is not on the far left, so

          position 5 = A
          position 4 = the single H-card.

----------------------------------------------------------
E.  Place the queen
----------------------------------------------------------
The queen must be next to exactly one heart (clue 2).  
Only position 3 borders the heart at position 4 but not the ace at position 5,
so

          position 3 = Q.

----------------------------------------------------------
F.  Keep the jack away from hearts
----------------------------------------------------------
The jack is not allowed next to any heart (clue 3), so it cannot be in
positions 3, 4 or 5.  It must be at position 1 or 2, and it has to sit next to
at least one spade.

That observation already tells us that the duplicated suit must be S:
there has to be a spade next to the jack and another spade somewhere else
(because every other suit appears exactly once).  
Hence

          the suit that appears twice is SPADES.

All that remains is to make sure a concrete arrangement exists with exactly
two spades; the following one fulfils every condition:

          1 : K♠      (king of spades)
          2 : J♦      (jack of diamonds)
          3 : Q♣      (queen of clubs)
          4 : 10♥     (ten of hearts)
          5 : A♠      (ace of spades)

Check of the clues  
1.  The king (pos 1) is next to a diamond (pos 2).  
2.  The queen (pos 3) is next to exactly one heart (pos 4).  
3.  The jack (pos 2) is next to a spade (pos 1) and next to no heart.  
4.  The ten (pos 4) is next to a club (pos 3).  
5.  The ace (pos 5) borders neither black card nor diamond (it borders only
    the ten of hearts).  
6.  The only duplicate suit, spades, is not in adjacent positions (pos 1 and 5).  
7.  Removing only the pair {positions 2, 4} leaves  K – Q – A,
    the sole ascending triple; all other pair-removals fail.  
8.  The ace is not on the far left.

Thus every clue is satisfied, and the only possible suit that can occur twice
is uniquely determined.

Final answer: Spades
Response:
Total Step Count: 10  
Creative Steps: 4  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary)  Set up notation: number the five positions 1–5, encode the ranks 10–A as 1–5, and abbreviate the four suits as C, D, H, S.  

2. (Creative)  Translate clue 5 and infer that every card bordering the ace must be a heart, because the ace may touch neither a black suit (C or S) nor a diamond.  

3. (Rudimentary)  Consider the two geometric possibilities this creates:  
   • If the ace sits in the middle (positions 2–4) it would need two heart neighbours.  
   • If the ace sits at an end (positions 1 or 5) it would need only one heart neighbour.  

4. (Rudimentary)  Observe that with five cards and at least one card of every suit, exactly one suit appears twice; call this suit X.  

5. (Creative)  Show X cannot be hearts:  
   • If hearts were duplicated and the ace were in the middle, the two required heart neighbours would exhaust the hearts, preventing the queen from having exactly one heart neighbour (clue 2) without violating clue 6.  
   • If hearts were duplicated and the ace were at an end, the single heart next to it plus a second heart elsewhere again prevents the queen from achieving exactly one-heart adjacency without forcing the two hearts to touch.  
   Hence X ≠ H and hearts occur exactly once.  

6. (Creative)  Because there is only one heart, the ace must be at an end; clue 8 rules out the far-left end, so put the ace in position 5 and the lone heart in position 4.  

7. (Rudimentary)  Place the queen: it must border exactly one heart (clue 2), so it must occupy position 3.  

8. (Creative)  Use the jack’s constraints: the jack cannot border any heart (clue 3), so it can only be in position 1 or 2 and must be next to at least one spade.  Therefore one neighbour of the jack is a spade, and a second spade is needed elsewhere to make the duplicated suit.  Conclude X = spades.  

9. (Rudimentary)  Exhibit a concrete layout that satisfies every clue with exactly two spades:  
   1 K♠, 2 J♦, 3 Q♣, 4 10♥, 5 A♠, and verify each clue.  

10. (Rudimentary)  State the result: the only suit that can appear twice is spades.

Question:
Five friends spend every Monday night eating Chinese food from the Golden Dragon. Howard has Mu Shu Pork, Leonard has Spicy Szechuan Tofu, Penny has Shrimp with Lobster Sauce, Raj has Beef with String Beans, and Sheldon has Chicken and Broccoli: diced, not shredded, with brown rice, not white, low-sodium soy sauce and the good hot mustard from the Korean grocery.
After dinner, they play a role-playing game called World of Nerds.
In this game, each player takes on a character belonging to a different race of creature, has a different occupation, uses a different sort of weapon, specializes in fighting a particular kind of monster, and has a different skill level.
Can you determine the characteristics of each player's character from the following clues before someone sits in Sheldon's spot?
Players: Howard, Leonard, Penny, Raj and Sheldon
Races: elf, gremlin, halfling, hobbit and ogre
Occupations: archbishop, merchant, paladin, sorcerer and thief
Weapons: bolo, crossbow, dagger, fireballs and mace
Monsters: chimeras, giants, harpies, kobolds and orcs
Skill levels: range from 10-32
Clues:
1. The five characters in the game are Penny's, the 24th-level ogre, the thief, the fireball user, and the one skilled at fighting orcs.
2. The paladin isn't an elf.
3. The bolo user has a skill level twice that of the halfling.
4. Raj's character has a skill level eight levels higher than the paladin, who in turn is eight levels higher than the crossbow user.
5. The hobbit is no good at fighting giants.
6. The elf (who doesn't care for crossbows) is ten levels higher than the one who fights kobolds.
7. The one who is adept at fighting chimeras is four levels higher than Leonard's character (who isn't the archbishop).
8. The character at the lowest level (who isn't Penny) is at level ten and uses a dagger.
9. Neither the archbishop nor the merchant belongs to the race of gremlins.
10. The giant fighter never uses a mace in battle.
11. Raj's character isn't the elf.
12. Penny's character doesn't use the crossbow.
13. Howard's character is not particularly adept at fighting harpies.
Hint: Start by determining the 5 skill levels.
Human Solution:
Howard’s character  
• Race – halfling  
• Occupation – merchant  
• Weapon – dagger  
• Monster specialty – kobolds  
• Skill level – 10  

Leonard’s character  
• Race – hobbit  
• Occupation – thief  
• Weapon – cross-bow  
• Monster specialty – orcs  
• Skill level – 16  

Penny’s character  
• Race – elf  
• Occupation – archbishop  
• Weapon – bolo  
• Monster specialty – chimeras  
• Skill level – 20  

Sheldon’s character  
• Race – ogre  
• Occupation – paladin  
• Weapon – mace  
• Monster specialty – harpies  
• Skill level – 24  

Raj’s character  
• Race – gremlin  
• Occupation – sorcerer  
• Weapon – fireballs  
• Monster specialty – giants  
• Skill level – 32  

Final answer: Howard – halfling merchant with a dagger (level 10) who fights kobolds; Leonard – hobbit thief with a cross-bow (level 16) who fights orcs; Penny – elf archbishop with a bolo (level 20) who fights chimeras; Sheldon – ogre paladin with a mace (level 24) who fights harpies; Raj – gremlin sorcerer hurling fireballs (level 32) who fights giants.
Response:
Total Step Count: 12  
Creative Steps: 6  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. Creative – Translate Clue 1 into a starting framework: recognise that “Penny, the 24-level ogre, the thief, the fire-ball user, and the orc fighter” are five different characters and therefore form the backbone of all later eliminations.  
2. Rudimentary – Apply Clue 8 to pin down the absolute minimum: the character at level 10 (not Penny) uses the dagger.  
3. Creative – Exploit the arithmetic in Clue 3: because the bolo user’s level is twice the halfling’s, the only feasible pair in the 10-32 range is 10 ↔ 20, so the halfling is level 10 and the bolo user is level 20.  
4. Creative – Chain the level offsets of Clue 4: a difference of 8 + 8 means the only workable triple is cross-bow 16 → paladin 24 → Raj 32, fixing both the cross-bow user at level 16, the paladin at level 24, and Raj at level 32.  
5. Creative – Merge Clue 1 with the 24-level figure from Step 4: the 24-level character specified in Clue 1 must therefore be the paladin, and Clue 1 also tells us that that 24-level paladin is an ogre.  
6. Rudimentary – Use Clue 2 to note that the paladin (already an ogre) cannot be an elf, trimming the elf possibilities.  
7. Creative – Leverage Clue 6 (elf is 10 levels above the kobold fighter and not a cross-bow user) together with the current level list: the only 10-level gap left is 10 ↔ 20, so the elf is level 20 (the bolo user from Step 3) and the level-10 kobold fighter is the dagger-wielding halfling.  
8. Creative – Apply Clue 7 (chimera fighter is 4 above Leonard, who is not the archbishop): 20 ↔ 16 is the only 4-level gap still open, so Leonard sits at level 16 (the cross-bow user) and the level-20 character fights chimeras.  
9. Rudimentary – Use Clue 5 (hobbit is not the giant fighter) plus existing data to identify Leonard’s race as hobbit and relocate the giant-fighting role elsewhere (later shown to be Raj).  
10. Rudimentary – Combine Clue 10 (giant fighter never uses a mace) with Clue 1 (fire-ball user distinct from 24-level ogre) to settle Raj, the giant fighter, as the fire-ball-throwing gremlin.  
11. Rudimentary – Bring in personal-identity clues (11, 12, 13) and “no-gremlin archbishop/merchant” from Clue 9 to finish matching every remaining open race, occupation, weapon, and monster specialty.  
12. Rudimentary – Fill the last empty cells by straight elimination, producing the complete solution:  
 • Howard – halfling merchant with a dagger, level 10, fights kobolds  
 • Leonard – hobbit thief with a cross-bow, level 16, fights orcs  
 • Penny – elf archbishop with a bolo, level 20, fights chimeras  
 • Sheldon – ogre paladin with a mace, level 24, fights harpies  
 • Raj – gremlin sorcerer hurling fire-balls, level 32, fights giants

Creative ', ' 6

 • Raj – gremlin sorcerer hurling fire-balls, level 32, fights giants']

Question:
Sailing through a thick fog, you come upon a mysterious island shrouded in mist. A towering volcano in the center of the island pierces the clouds, billowing smoke into the sky. You land your boat and set out to ascend the peak. After an arduous climb, you approach the volcano summit, where lava glows red within a vast crater.
Here, you are approached by three gods and their herald.
Problem
On the summit of this remote volcano, the herald proclaims that you have been selected for a trial. He then lays out the rules for you.
First, you know that one of the three gods always tells the truth, another always lies, and the third will respond to questions randomly. Therefore, let us call the gods True, False, and Random.
Second, the gods speak a different language. They understand all languages perfectly well, but only answer questions with either ja or da, the words for yes and no. You do not know which god is which, and you do not know which word means yes and which word means no.
Finally, you have an existential problem on your hands. You may ask three yes-or-no questions, each one directed to only one god, and only that god will answer with either ja or da. If you can determine the identities of the three gods, they will send you on your way with their blessing, and you can be assured of a prosperous and fulfilled life. If you fail to determine the identities of the gods, however, they will be less generous in their treatment. The volcano pit smokes and glows red beside you.
With your three questions, how do you figure out which god is True, which is False, and which is Random?
Hint: Can you phrase a question so that both True and False have to say the same thing?
Human Solution:
Let A , B , C be the three gods standing in front of you.

Tool we shall use  
For any ordinary yes-or-no sentence P define the question  

      P*  :  “If I asked you P , would you say ja ?’’                (1)

For the truth-teller and the liar the answer to P* is completely
determinate:

• if P is TRUE they must answer ja,  
• if P is FALSE they must answer da,

no matter which of the two words means “yes’’ in their language.  
(The truth-teller tells the truth twice, the liar lies twice; in both
cases the double action cancels the uncertainty about the word
meaning.  Random of course still answers arbitrarily.)

Hence whenever we address a question of the form (1) to a god that is
not Random, ja means “the embedded P is true’’ and da means “the
embedded P is false’’.

The strategy  
With three questions we shall

1. use one question to locate at least one non-Random god;
2. use the second question to find out whether that god is True or
   False;
3. with the third question determine which of the remaining two is
   Random – the last remaining god’s identity is then fixed.

Step-by-step

QUESTION 1 to A  
“If I asked you ‘Is B Random?’, would you say ja ?’’  (i.e. ( Is B R )* )

Call A’s answer x₁.

• If x₁ = ja then either
     – A is not Random and B really is Random, or
     – A is Random (answering at random) and therefore B is not Random.  
  In both sub-cases C is certainly not Random.

• If x₁ = da then either
     – A is not Random and B is not Random (so C is Random), or
     – A is Random (again answering at random); then B is not Random.  
  In both sub-cases B is certainly not Random.

Thus

      x₁ = ja  ⇒  C is guaranteed non-Random;
      x₁ = da  ⇒  B is guaranteed non-Random.

Let X denote that assuredly non-Random god ( X = C if x₁ = ja ,  
X = B if x₁ = da ).

QUESTION 2 to X  
“If I asked you ‘Are you True?’, would you say ja ?’’   ( ( X is True )* )

Because X is not Random the answer x₂ tells us X’s exact nature:

      x₂ = ja  ⇒  X is the truth-teller True,
      x₂ = da  ⇒  X is the liar False.

QUESTION 3 to X  
“If I asked you ‘Is A Random?’, would you say ja ?’’   ( ( A is Random )* )

Again X is reliable, so the answer x₃ decides whether A is the Random
god:

      x₃ = ja  ⇒  A is Random;
      x₃ = da  ⇒  A is not Random (therefore the one of {B,C} that is
                   not X is Random).

Finishing the bookkeeping  
Now we know

• which god is Random (from Question 3);  
• which of X and the still unknown god is True or False (from
  Question 2);  
• and since exactly one god is True and exactly one is False, the last
  remaining god’s identity is forced.

Hence after the three questions we can name without error which god is
True, which is False, and which is Random.

Example of the plan in action  
Suppose (unknown to us) A = Random, B = True, C = False.

– Q1 to A could randomly yield ja.  
  Because x₁ = ja we set X = C.  

– Q2 to C : “Are you True?”*  
  C is the liar, the embedded statement is false ⇒ answer da (x₂ = da).
  So C is False.  

– Q3 to C : “Is A Random?”*  
  Embedded statement true ⇒ answer ja (x₃ = ja).  
  Therefore A is Random, leaving B to be True.  

All possibilities are resolved in exactly the same way.

Thus the three questions above always determine the three gods’
identities.

Final answer:  
1. Ask A: “If I asked you ‘Is B Random?’, would you say ja?”  
   – If the reply is ja choose C as the next respondent, otherwise choose B.  
2. To that chosen god X ask: “If I asked you ‘Are you True?’, would you say ja?”  
   – ja means X is True, da means X is False.  
3. Ask the same X: “If I asked you ‘Is A Random?’, would you say ja?”  
   – ja means A is Random; da means A is not Random (so the god other than X and A is Random).  
   With Random now located and X already identified as True or False, the remaining god’s role is fixed.
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Introduce the meta-question construction P*: “If I asked you P, would you say ja?”, and prove that for any non-Random god the answer ja corresponds to P being true and da to P being false, regardless of which word means “yes” and whether the god is a truth-teller or a liar.  

2. (Creative) Formulate the overall three-question plan: (i) first locate at least one non-Random god, (ii) then decide whether that god is True or False, and (iii) finally determine which of the remaining two is Random, thereby fixing every identity.  

3. (Creative) Pose Question 1 to god A: (Is B Random?)*. Design this specific question so that, whatever A’s reply, it pins down one definitely non-Random god.  

4. (Rudimentary) Analyse A’s possible answers to Question 1, concluding: ja ⇒ C is certainly non-Random; da ⇒ B is certainly non-Random. Name this guaranteed non-Random god X.  

5. (Rudimentary) Pose Question 2 to X: (Are you True?)*.  

6. (Rudimentary) Interpret X’s answer to Question 2: ja ⇒ X is True; da ⇒ X is False.  

7. (Rudimentary) Pose Question 3 to the same X: (Is A Random?)*.  

8. (Rudimentary) Interpret X’s answer to Question 3: ja ⇒ A is Random; da ⇒ A is not Random, so the god other than X and A must be Random.  

9. (Rudimentary) Use the facts that (i) Random is now located and (ii) X has been classified as True or False to deduce the remaining god’s identity (the one not yet named must be whichever of True/False is still unassigned).

['Total Step Count: 9

1. (Creative) Introduce the meta-question construction P*: “If I asked you P, would you say ja?”, and prove that for any non-Random god the answer ja corresponds to P being true and da to P being false, regardless of which word means “yes” and whether the god is a truth-teller or a liar.  

2. (Creative) Formulate the overall three-question plan: (i) first locate at least one non-Random god, (ii) then decide whether that god is True or False, and (iii) finally determine which of the remaining two is Random, thereby fixing every identity.  

3. (Creative) Pose Question 1 to god A: (Is B Random?)*. Design this specific question so that, whatever A’s reply, it pins down one definitely non-Random god.  

4. (Rudimentary) Analyse A’s possible answers to Question 1, concluding: ja ⇒ C is certainly non-Random; da ⇒ B is certainly non-Random. Name this guaranteed non-Random god X.

Question:
Professor Abacus is purchasing a ticket for the Deca Lotto.  The lotto number has ten digits, using the numerals 0 through 9, each numeral used once.  The clerk asked what number he wanted to pick.  Professor Abacus handed the clerk a piece of paper with nine statements, saying "If you can correctly figure out the number, I will give you half of whatever I win."   What is the number?
1) The sum of the first five digits is a prime number.
2) The sum of the last five digits is a triangle number*.
3) The sum of the digits in the odd positions is an odd number.
4) The sum of the middle two digits is a square number.
5) The sum of the middle four digits is a cube number.
6) The difference between the 1st and 10th digits is two.
7) The difference between the 2nd and 9th digits is three.
8) The difference between the 3rd and 8th digits is four.
9) The numeral 4 is somewhere in the first five positions.
* You can form a triangle arrangement by building it in the pattern row 1 = 1, row 2 = 2, row 3 = 3 etc. eg. 10 is a classic triangle number as per ten pin bowling. They are arranged in a triangle 1, 2, 3, 4.
Hint: The sum of all digits must be 45. Combine this with hints 1 and 2 to reduce to a few prime/triangle options
Human Solution:
After systematic case–work on all nine clues the only 10-digit permutation of 0–9 that satisfies every condition is  

7342105869

Final answer: 7342105869
Response:
Total Step Count: 1  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 1  

Steps:  
1. Carry out exhaustive, systematic case-work on all nine clues; the only 10-digit permutation of 0–9 that meets every condition is 7342105869.

['Total Step Count: 1  
Creative ', ' 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 1  

Steps:  
1. Carry out exhaustive, systematic case-work on all nine clues; the only 10-digit permutation of 0–9 that meets every condition is 7342105869.']

Question:
Mad Ade, Who had suddenly and unexpectedly after years of selfless dedication to Kebabs, decided to grow some vegetable for himself and subsequently planted his garden late in May. He planted five different vegetables: Tomatoes, Peppers, Radishes, Lettuce, and Broccoli. For each he planted a different number of rows from one to five. The hard work involved with each planting was accomplished on a separate day, from May 25th to May 30th (On Sunday May 26th he didn't work in the garden). Each vegetable was planted in a different part of the garden, the north end, the south side, the east side, the west side or the northwest corner. Can you tell which vegetable was planted in each part of the garden, the day planted and the number of rows?
1. Mad Ade turned the soil for the peppers three days after he dug hand-size rocks out of the radish patch. Mad Ade's bright rows of radishes went deeper than the broccoli but were not as deep as the tomatoes. Mad Ade rolled his trusty wheelbarrow into the west end of the garden one day before he planted the broccoli.  Mad Ade believes the morning sun is bad for tomatoes and so kept those plants out of the eastern side of his garden.
2. Mad Ade labored hard in the south side of the garden and was mighty proud of the three perfect rows there. On one week's last day, Mad Ade planted the east side of the garden. Mad Ade didn't put the peppers or the tomatoes in the northwest corner. Mad Ade planted an even number of rows in the Northwest corner of his garden.
3. Mad Ade planted three rows before he planted two rows, but planted them after he planted four rows. Mad Ade figured the lettuce wouldn't last long so he planted fewer than three rows. Mad Ade planted the south garden one day before he planted the lettuce. Mad Ade planted more rows of peppers than he did broccoli (which was not planted in the west side of the garden and was not planted the 29th).
Which vegetable was planted in how many rows, on which day of May and in which side of Mad Ade's garden?
Hint: Start by deducing which vegetables pair with which dates
Human Solution:
Radishes – 4 rows – Saturday May 25 – East side  
Tomatoes – 5 rows – Monday May 27 – North end  
Peppers – 3 rows – Tuesday May 28 – South side  
Lettuce – 1 row – Wednesday May 29 – West side  
Broccoli – 2 rows – Thursday May 30 – Northwest corner  

Final answer: Radishes 4 rows on May 25 in the east, Tomatoes 5 rows on May 27 in the north, Peppers 3 rows on May 28 in the south, Lettuce 1 row on May 29 in the west, and Broccoli 2 rows on May 30 in the northwest corner.
Response:
Total Step Count: 16  
Creative Steps: 5  
Rudimentary Steps: 11  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary)  Set up a logic-grid with the five vegetables, the five row numbers (1-5), the five planting days (May 25, 27, 28, 29, 30) and the five garden positions (north, south, east, west, northwest).  
2. (Rudimentary)  Enter clue “South side … three perfect rows” ⇒ South side = 3 rows.  
3. (Rudimentary)  Enter “North-west corner has an even number of rows” and “peppers or tomatoes are not in the north-west.”  
4. (Rudimentary)  From “4-row day before 3-row day before 2-row day” record the time order 4 → 3 → 2.  
5. (Rudimentary)  Note “lettuce < 3 rows” (so lettuce is row 1 or row 2) and “south garden one day before lettuce,” fixing their time order.  
6. (Creative)  Combine “radishes deeper than broccoli but not as deep as tomatoes” with the fact that all five row counts are different: the only workable trio is radishes = 4 rows, tomatoes = 5 rows, broccoli < 4 (thus 1 or 2).  
7. (Creative)  Apply “peppers three days after radishes”; since the schedule spans May 25–30, the only fit is radishes on Sat 25 May and peppers on Tue 28 May.  
8. (Creative)  Use “on one week’s last day the east side was planted”: Saturday (May 25) is the last day of that week, so the east side accompanies May 25 ⇒ radishes are in the east.  
9. (Rudimentary)  Translate “wheelbarrow into the west one day before broccoli” and “broccoli not west, not the 29th” into West-day = (broccoli-day − 1) and broccoli ≠ May 29.  
10. (Creative)  Respecting “peppers have more rows than broccoli,” the unused row numbers can only be assigned as peppers 3, broccoli 2, lettuce 1; this satisfies all earlier constraints and keeps every row number unique.  
11. (Rudimentary)  From step 9 and “broccoli ≠ 29”, the only open day for broccoli is May 30, making West-day May 29.  
12. (Creative)  The north-west corner must have an even row total and cannot hold peppers or tomatoes; row 2 (even) is still free and now belongs to broccoli, so broccoli is placed in the north-west.  
13. (Rudimentary)  Lettuce (row 1) must be planted the day after the south plot; with south fixed at May 28, lettuce takes May 29 and, by step 11, the west side.  
14. (Rudimentary)  The remaining open slot—north side on Monday May 27—goes to the tomatoes with their 5 rows, satisfying “no tomatoes in the east.”  
15. (Rudimentary)  Verify every clue against the collected data; all conditions are met.  
16. (Rudimentary)  Report the full solution:  
 Radishes – 4 rows – Saturday May 25 – East side  
 Tomatoes – 5 rows – Monday May 27 – North end  
 Peppers – 3 rows – Tuesday May 28 – South side  
 Lettuce – 1 row – Wednesday May 29 – West side  
 Broccoli – 2 rows – Thursday May 30 – Northwest corner

Question:
There is a ten digit mystery number (no leading 0), represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) If A > B, then C = 5 or 7, else C = 0 or 1.
2) If B > C, then D = 1 or 2, else D = 4 or 9.
3) If C > D, then E = 6 or 9, else E = 3 or 5.
4) If D > E, then F = 2 or 4, else F = 1 or 6.
5) If E > F, then G = 5 or 6, else G = 0 or 7.
6) If F > G, then H = 1 or 4, else H = 8 or 9.
7) If G > H, then I = 0 or 8, else I = 6 or 7.
8) If H > I, then J = 3 or 8, else J = 2 or 5.
9) If I > J, then A = 3 or 7, else A = 4 or 8.
10) If J > A, then B = 0 or 9, else B = 2 or 3.
Hint: For example, assign 8 to H.  I can not exceed H, so J would have to be 3 (8 already assigned to H).
Human Solution:
We work systematically through the ten conditions, remembering that every digit 0-9 must be used exactly once.

1.  From (9) we know  
   – If I > J then A is 3 or 7,  
   – else (I < J) A is 4 or 8.  

   To discover a solution we eventually find that I < J, so A must be 4 or 8.

2.  Trying A = 4 leads to contradictions in every branch, so A = 8.

3.  With A = 8, (10) says  
   – because J<A (there is no allowable J greater than 8) we must have B = 2 or 3.  
   The two possible (J, B) pairs are (2, 3) or (3, 2).

4.  Since A=8 corresponds to I < J, and the only digit allowed for I that is less than 2 or 3 is 0, we have I = 0.  
   Condition (7) therefore forces G > H and puts us in the branch
           G = 5 or 6, H = 1 or 4, F > G, E > F.

5.  Because F must exceed G and yet come from {1,2,4,6}, the only viable pairing is
           F = 6, G = 5.
   Then E must be 9 (the only digit in {6,9,3,5} that is > 6).

6.  Having E = 9 and F = 6 puts us in the “D < E” branch of (4), so D is 4 or 9.  
   It cannot be 9 (already used), hence D = 4.

7.  With D = 4 and E = 9 we need C > D (from condition 3, because E = 9 is in {6,9}).  
   Condition 1 (A > B) then yields C = 7.

8.  Now examine the two alternatives for (J, B):

   •  If (J, B) = (2, 3) we get H = 1, but (8) would require J to be 3 or 8, contradiction.  
   •  If (J, B) = (3, 2) every condition is satisfied:

        A = 8 > B = 2 ⇒ C = 7  
        B = 2 < C = 7 ⇒ D = 4  
        C = 7 > D = 4 ⇒ E = 9  
        D = 4 < E = 9 ⇒ F = 6  
        E = 9 > F = 6 ⇒ G = 5  
        F = 6 > G = 5 ⇒ H = 1  
        G = 5 > H = 1 ⇒ I = 0  
        H = 1 > I = 0 ⇒ J = 3  
        I = 0 < J = 3 ⇒ A = 8 (consistent)  
        J = 3 < A = 8 ⇒ B = 2 (consistent)

9. All digits 0–9 appear exactly once, and every conditional statement holds.

Therefore the unique ten-digit mystery number is

8274965103

Final answer: 8274965103
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 8  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) Use condition 9 to relate the order of I and J to the two possible values for A (A = 3/7 if I > J, A = 4/8 if I < J); decide to continue with the branch I < J so that A must be 4 or 8.  

2. (Rudimentary) Test A = 4, find it leads to contradictions in every subsequent branch, and therefore set A = 8.  

3. (Rudimentary) Apply condition 10 with A = 8 to restrict the pair (J, B) to the two possibilities (2, 3) or (3, 2).  

4. (Creative) Combine “I < J” with the allowed values for I that appear in condition 7 to note that the only digit less than 2 or 3 that fits any branch of condition 7 is 0; fix I = 0, which simultaneously forces the branch G > H and limits the candidate sets to  
  G ∈ {5, 6}, H ∈ {1, 4}, F > G, E > F.  

5. (Rudimentary) Use F > G together with the sets in step 4 to obtain the sole workable pairing G = 5, F = 6; then, from condition 3, choose E = 9 (the only remaining value that is > 6 in its option set).  

6. (Rudimentary) With E = 9 and F = 6, enter the “D < E” branch of condition 4, giving D = 4 because 9 is already used.  

7. (Rudimentary) Having D = 4 and E = 9 forces C > D under condition 3, and condition 1 (A > B) selects the only allowable C-value, C = 7.  

8. (Rudimentary) Examine the two alternatives for (J, B):  
 • (2, 3) contradicts condition 8;  
 • (3, 2) satisfies all remaining conditions, so fix J = 3 and B = 2.  

9. (Rudimentary) Verify that the chosen digits 8 2 7 4 9 6 5 1 0 3 meet every conditional statement and use each numeral 0–9 exactly once, yielding the unique mystery number 8274965103.

Rudimentary Steps: 8  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) Use condition 9 to relate the order of I and J to the two possible values for A (A = 3/7 if I > J, A = 4/8 if I < J); decide to continue with the branch I < J so that A must be 4 or 8.  

2. (Rudimentary) Test A = 4, find it leads to contradictions in every subsequent branch, and therefore set A = 8.  

3. (Rudimentary) Apply condition 10 with A = 8 to restrict the pair (J, B) to the two possibilities (2, 3) or (3, 2).  

4. (Creative) Combine “I < J” with the allowed values for I that appear in condition 7 to note that the only digit less than 2 or 3 that fits any branch of condition 7 is 0; fix I = 0, which simultaneously forces the branch G > H and limits the candidate sets to  
  G ∈ {5, 6}, H ∈ {1, 4}, F > G, E > F.

 • (2, 3) contradicts condition 8;

9. (Rudimentary) Verify that the chosen digits 8 2 7 4 9 6 5 1 0 3 meet every conditional statement and use each numeral 0–9 exactly once, yielding the unique mystery number 8274965103.']

Question:
There is a ten-digit mystery number (no leading 0), represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) Digit A is either a square number or a triangle number, but not both.
2) Digit B is either an even number or a cube number, but not both.
3) Digit C is either a cube number or a triangle number, but not both.
4) Digit D is either an odd number or a square number, but not both.
5) Digit E is either an odd number or a cube number, but not both.
6) Digit F is either an odd number or a triangle number, but not both.
7) Digit G is either an odd number or a prime number, but not both.
8) Digit H is either an even number or a square number, but not both.
9) Digit I is either a square number or a cube number, but not both.
10) Digit J is either a prime number or a triangle number, but not both.
11) A < B, C < D, E < F, G < H, I < J
12) A + B + C + D + E < F + G + H + I + J
Hint: A) First, determine what two subsets of numbers qualify for each digit.  However, each digit can only be in one of the subsets, not both.
Human Solution:
Step-by-step reasoning

1.  List the digits 0-9 in every special set  
   Squares: 0 1 4 9 Triangles: 1 3 6 Cubes: 0 1 8  
   Evens: 0 2 4 6 8 Odds: 1 3 5 7 9 Primes: 2 3 5 7  

2.  For every position write the digits that satisfy its “either … or … but not both” rule (XOR).

   A: squares⊕triangles → {3,4,6,9} (no 0 because A can’t lead)  
   B: evens⊕cubes        → {1,2,4,6} (0,8 rejected – both)  
   C: cubes⊕triangles    → {0,3,6,8} (1 rejected – both)  
   D: odds⊕squares       → {0,3,4,5,7} (9 rejected – both)  
   E: odds⊕cubes         → {0,3,5,7,8,9} (1 rejected)  
   F: odds⊕triangles     → {5,6,7,9} (1,3 rejected)  
   G: odds⊕primes        → {1,2,9} (3,5,7 rejected – both)  
   H: evens⊕squares      → {1,2,6,8,9} (0,4 rejected – both)  
   I: squares⊕cubes      → {4,8,9} (0,1 rejected – both)  
   J: primes⊕triangles   → {1,2,5,6,7} (3 rejected – both)

3.  Order restriction I<J eliminates I=8,9, so I=4 and J∈{5,6,7}.  
    I=4 removes 4 from any other position.

4.  For A<B we need B>3.  Trying B=1 or 2 fails, so B=6.  
    Hence A<6 and A∈{3,9} ⇒ A=3.

5.  Now C∈{0,8} (3 used, 6 used).  
    If C=8 then D must exceed 8, impossible, so C=0.

6.  With C=0, D∈{5,7}.  Analyse the two sub-cases.

   • D=5  
     – Then J≠5 (J>4), so J=7.  
     – E∈{8,9}, F∈{7,9}. 7 already used ⇒ F=9, E=8.  
     – Remaining digits {1,2}.  G∈{1,2}, H∈{1,2}, G<H ⇒ (G,H)=(1,2).  
     – Check sums: 3+6+0+5+8=22, 9+1+2+4+7=23 → 22<23 OK.

   • D=7  
     – Then J=5.  
     – F∈{5,9} but 5 used ⇒ F=9, E=8.  
     – Again (G,H)=(1,2).  
     – Sums: 3+6+0+7+8=24, 9+1+2+4+5=21 → 24<21 false.  
     Hence this branch is impossible.

7.  The only viable assignment is  

   A=3, B=6, C=0, D=5, E=8, F=9, G=1, H=2, I=4, J=7.

8.  Verify every XOR condition (all satisfied) and uniqueness (each digit 0-9 used once).

Therefore the ten-digit mystery number is

Final answer: 3605891247
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. [Rudimentary]  List which digits 0-9 belong to each special set: squares, triangles, cubes, evens, odds, primes.  
2. [Rudimentary]  For each position A–J, intersect the two indicated sets and apply the exclusive-or rule to build the allowable-digit list for that position.  
3. [Creative]  Use the order condition I < J to see that I cannot be 8 or 9, forcing I = 4 and limiting J to {5, 6, 7}; strike 4 from every other position’s list.  
4. [Creative]  Apply A < B together with the current B-list; note B must exceed 3, leading to B = 6 and hence A = 3.  
5. [Creative]  With A and B fixed, narrow C to {0, 8}; realize C = 8 makes D impossible (would need D > 8), so set C = 0 and reduce D to {5, 7}.  
6. [Rudimentary]  Branch on the two D possibilities:  
   • If D = 5, deduce J = 7, F = 9, E = 8, and (G, H) = (1, 2); the sum inequality holds.  
   • If D = 7, deduce J = 5, F = 9, E = 8, and (G, H) = (1, 2); the sum inequality fails, so discard this branch.  
7. [Rudimentary]  Collect the surviving assignment: A3 B6 C0 D5 E8 F9 G1 H2 I4 J7.  
8. [Rudimentary]  Check that every XOR condition is satisfied and that each digit 0-9 appears exactly once, confirming the final answer 3605891247.

['Total Step Count: 8

Rudimentary Steps: 5

2. [Rudimentary]  For each position A–J, intersect the two indicated sets and apply the exclusive-or rule to build the allowable-digit list for that position.  
3. [Creative]  Use the order condition I < J to see that I cannot be 8 or 9, forcing I = 4 and limiting J to {5, 6, 7}; strike 4 from every other position’s list.

Question:
Einstein's Riddle:
Einstein wrote the following riddle. He said that 98% of the world could not solve it. But several NIEHS scientists were able to solve it, and they said it's not all that hard if you pay attention and are very patient. Give it a try:
There are 5 houses in 5 different colors in a row. In each house lives a person with a different nationality. The 5 owners drink a certain type of beverage, smoke a certain brand of cigar, and keep a certain pet. No owners have the same pet, smoke the same brand of cigar, or drink the same beverage. Other facts:
1.	The Brit lives in the red house.
2.	The Swede keeps dogs as pets.
3.	The Dane drinks tea.
4.	The green house is on the immediate left of the white house.
5.	The green house's owner drinks coffee.
6.	The owner who smokes Pall Mall rears birds.
7.	The owner of the yellow house smokes Dunhill.
8.	The owner living in the center house drinks milk.
9.	The Norwegian lives in the first house.
10.	The owner who smokes Blends lives next to the one who keeps cats.
11.	The owner who keeps the horse lives next to the one who smokes Dunhill.
12.	The owner who smokes Bluemasters drinks beer.
13.	The German smokes Prince.
14.	The Norwegian lives next to the blue house.
15.	The owner who smokes Blends lives next to the one who drinks water.
The question is: WHO OWNS THE FISH?
Hint: Just take your time. This one should take you some time and is probably one of the harder riddles you see.
Human Solution:
Reasoning step by step

1.  Lay the five houses out from left to right as House 1 … House 5 and keep five columns for Colour, Nationality, Drink, Cigar, Pet.

2.  From clues 8 and 9  
   • House 3 drinks milk.  
   • House 1 is the Norwegian.

3.  From clue 14 the Norwegian lives next to the blue house ⇒ House 2 is blue.

4.  Clue 4: the green house is immediately left of the white house.  
   – The pair (green, white) cannot be (1, 2) because 2 is blue.  
   – Cannot be (2, 3) because 2 is blue.  
   – Cannot be (3, 4) because 3 already fixed to milk, but clue 5 says green drinks coffee.  
   ⇒ Therefore (green, white) = (4, 5).  
   – House 4 is green and drinks coffee (clue 5).  
   – House 5 is white.

5.  Colours now known: 1=?, 2 = blue, 3=?, 4 = green, 5 = white.  
   The only unused colours are red and yellow.

6.  Clue 1: the Brit lives in the red house ⇒ House 3 is red and its owner is the Brit.  
   ⇒ The remaining unused colour, yellow, must be House 1.  

7.  Clue 7: the yellow-house owner smokes Dunhill ⇒ House 1 smokes Dunhill.

8.  Clue 11: the horse is kept next to the Dunhill smoker ⇒ the horse is in House 2.

9.  Because House 1 is yellow, 2 blue, 3 red, 4 green, 5 white — colours are fixed.

10.  We have left to assign drinks: water, tea, beer (milk and coffee already fixed).  
    Cigars left: Blends, Pall Mall, Bluemasters, Prince (Dunhill fixed).  
    Pets left: cats, birds, dogs, fish (horse already fixed).

11.  Consider where the Blends smoker can be (clues 10 & 15):  
    – If Blends were in 1 or 5 it would have only one neighbour, who would have to have both cats and water, which is impossible for 5 (coffee) and for 1 (Dunhill already fixes neighbour’s horse).  
    ⇒ Blends must be in 2, 3, or 4.

12.  Put Blends in House 2 (try).  
    • Then, by clue 15, water must be in a neighbour. House 3 drinks milk, so water must be in House 1.  
    • By clue 10 cats must be next to Blends; house 1 is already a neighbour, so let cats be in House 1 too.  
    (This satisfies both clues simultaneously.)

13.  House 1 now: Norwegian – yellow – water – Dunhill – cats. All consistent.

14.  Drinks left unassigned: tea (for the Dane) and beer.  
    Bluemasters/beer cannot be in House 2 (already Blends) ⇒ Bluemasters will be somewhere else.

15.  House 2 still needs a drink; milk & coffee taken, water in 1, so tea fits ⇒ House 2 is the Dane and drinks tea (clue 3).

16.  Bluemasters must therefore be in the only house still free for both cigar and drink pairing: House 5.  
    ⇒ House 5 smokes Bluemasters and drinks beer (clue 12).

17.  Cigars left to place in Houses 3 and 4 are Pall Mall and Prince.  
    • If House 3 smoked Prince, its owner would have to be German (clue 13) but House 3 is already the Brit, impossible.  
    ⇒ House 3 smokes Pall Mall and keeps birds (clue 6).  
    ⇒ House 4 smokes Prince and is the German (clue 13).

18.  Only one nationality left, the Swede, must be House 5.  
    Clue 2: the Swede keeps dogs ⇒ House 5’s pet is dogs.

19.  Pets now: 1 = cats, 2 = horse, 3 = birds, 5 = dogs. The only pet unassigned is fish, so the remaining house (House 4) keeps the fish.

20.  Summary of each house

   House 1: Norwegian – yellow – water – Dunhill – cats  
   House 2: Dane – blue – tea – Blends – horse  
   House 3: Brit – red – milk – Pall Mall – birds  
   House 4: German – green – coffee – Prince – fish  
   House 5: Swede – white – beer – Bluemasters – dogs

All 15 clues are satisfied.

Final answer: The German owns the fish.
Response:
Total Step Count: 16  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 13  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) Set up a 5 × 5 table (houses 1–5 vs. colour, nationality, drink, cigar, pet) to record deductions.  

2. (Rudimentary) Apply clues 8 and 9 to fill in two definite facts:  
   – House 3’s drink is milk.  
   – House 1’s owner is the Norwegian.  

3. (Rudimentary) Use clue 14 (“the Norwegian lives next to the blue house”) to fix House 2 as blue.  

4. (Creative) Combine clues 4 and 5 with the current colour/drink information:  
   – Green must be immediately left of white and must drink coffee.  
   – Checking all possible adjacent pairs shows the only feasible placement is Green → House 4 (coffee) and White → House 5.  

5. (Rudimentary) Identify the two unused colours (red and yellow); then use clue 1 (“the Brit lives in the red house”) to make House 3 red with the Brit, leaving yellow for House 1.  

6. (Rudimentary) Apply clue 7: the yellow-house owner smokes Dunhill, so House 1 smokes Dunhill.  

7. (Rudimentary) Apply clue 11: the horse lives next to the Dunhill smoker, so the horse must be in House 2.  

8. (Rudimentary) List the still-unassigned items: drinks (water, tea, beer), cigars (Blends, Pall Mall, Bluemasters, Prince), pets (cats, birds, dogs, fish).  

9. (Creative) Use the neighbour constraints in clues 10 and 15 to analyse where the Blends smoker can sit.  
   – If Blends were in House 1 or 5 its single neighbour would have to satisfy two different conditions (cats and water), which is impossible.  
   – Therefore Blends must be in House 2, 3, or 4.  

10. (Creative) Try placing Blends in House 2; to satisfy clues 10 and 15 simultaneously, put water and cats in neighbouring House 1. The trial fits all current facts, so keep it.  

11. (Rudimentary) Record the fully determined profile for House 1: Norwegian – yellow – water – Dunhill – cats.  

12. (Rudimentary) Fill House 2’s remaining drink slot. With milk, coffee, and water already used, tea fits; by clue 3 this makes House 2’s owner the Dane.  

13. (Rudimentary) Locate the Bluemasters/beer pair (clue 12). House 2’s cigar is fixed to Blends, so the only house free to take both Bluemasters and beer is House 5; assign them there.  

14. (Rudimentary) Only cigars Prince and Pall Mall remain for Houses 3 and 4.  
    – Prince would force a German owner (clue 13), which conflicts with the Brit already in House 3.  
    – Therefore House 3 smokes Pall Mall and keeps birds (clue 6); House 4 smokes Prince and is the German (clue 13).  

15. (Rudimentary) The last unassigned nationality, the Swede, must occupy House 5; by clue 2 that house keeps dogs.  

16. (Rudimentary) The only pet still unplaced is the fish, so it belongs to the remaining empty pet slot—House 4. Hence the German owns the fish.

Question:
Zachary has a private zoo.  He has five groups of animals in his zoo:  snakes, birds, mammals, insects, and spiders.  Assume that, typically:  animals have 1 head, snakes have 0 legs, birds have 2 legs, mammals have 4 legs, insects have 6 legs, and spiders have 8 legs.  Zachary has some unusual animals in his zoo.  He has:  a snake with 3 heads, a bird with 2 heads, a mammal with 3 legs, an insect with 4 legs, and a spider with 7 legs.  From the following information, determine how many of each group of animals that Zachary has in his menagerie.
1) There are a total of 100 heads and 376 legs.
2) Each group has a different quantity of animals.
3) The most populous group has 10 more members than the least populous group.
4) There are twice as many insect legs as there are bird legs.
5) There are as many snake heads as there are spider heads.
Hint: Since there are 3 extra heads (2 snake and 1 bird), there are only 97 animals (clue 1).  Find a set of five different numbers whose sum is 97 (clue 2) and whose size difference between the least populous and most populous group is 10 (clue 3).
Human Solution:
Let  

S = number of snakes  
B = number of birds  
M = number of mammals  
I = number of insects  
P = number of spiders  

Each group contains exactly one “odd” specimen, whose heads / legs differ as stated.

Heads  
Snakes:  (S-1)·1  + 3  = S + 2  
Birds :  (B-1)·1  + 2  = B + 1  
Mammals:  M (all 1-headed)  
Insects:  I  
Spiders:  P  

Total heads = 100 ⇒ (S + 2) + (B + 1) + M + I + P = 100  
⇒ S + B + M + I + P = 97 … (H)

Legs  
Snakes: 0  
Birds : 2B  
Mammals: (M-1)·4 + 3 = 4M – 1  
Insects: (I-1)·6 + 4 = 6I – 2  
Spiders: (P-1)·8 + 7 = 8P – 1  

Total legs = 376 ⇒ 2B + 4M – 1 + 6I – 2 + 8P – 1 = 376  
⇒ 2B + 4M + 6I + 8P = 380  
⇒ B + 2M + 3I + 4P = 190 … (L)

Extra conditions  
(4) insect legs = 2 × bird legs ⇒ 6I – 2 = 4B ⇒ 3I – 2B = 1 … (C1)  
(5) snake heads = spider heads ⇒ S + 2 = P ⇒ P = S + 2 … (C2)

Use C2 in H and L:

H:  S + B + M + I + (S + 2) = 97  ⇒ 2S + B + M + I = 95 … (1)  
L:  B + 2M + 3I + 4(S + 2) = 190  
     ⇒ B + 2M + 3I + 4S = 182 … (2)

Subtract (2) – 2·(1):  
(B + 2M + 3I + 4S) – (2B + 2M + 2I + 4S) = 182 – 190  
⇒ –B + I = –8 ⇒ I = B – 8 … (3)

Combine (3) with C1: 3(B – 8) – 2B = 1 ⇒ B = 25, I = 17.

From (1): 2S + 25 + M + 17 = 95 ⇒ 2S + M = 53 ⇒ M = 53 – 2S.

P = S + 2.

Now apply “all group sizes different, and max – min = 10”.

Trial values of S (positive integers with M > 0):

S   M   P   Counts (sorted)   Range  
…  
16  21  18  {16,17,18,21,25}  9  
17  19  19  duplicates  
18  17  20  duplicates  
19  15  21  {15,17,19,21,25}  10  ✓

Thus S = 19, B = 25, M = 15, I = 17, P = 21.

Verification  
Heads:  (19+2) + (25+1) + 15 + 17 + 21 = 100  
Legs : 0 + 2·25 + (4·14+3) + (6·16+4) + (8·20+7) = 376  
Insect legs 100 = 2 × bird legs 50  
Snake heads 21 = spider heads 21  
All group sizes distinct; max – min = 25 – 15 = 10.

Final answer: 19 snakes, 25 birds, 15 mammals, 17 insects, 21 spiders.
Response:
Total Step Count: 16  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 14  

Steps:  
1. Introduce variables S, B, M, I, P for the numbers of snakes, birds, mammals, insects, and spiders, respectively. (R)  
2. Incorporate the “odd” specimens to create corrected head-count expressions for every group (e.g., snake heads = (S – 1)·1 + 3 = S + 2, etc.). (C)  
3. Add all head expressions to form the total-heads equation H: S + B + M + I + P = 97. (R)  
4. Write corrected leg expressions for every group, taking each odd specimen into account. (R)  
5. Add those leg expressions to obtain the total-legs equation L: B + 2M + 3I + 4P = 190. (R)  
6. Translate the condition “insect legs = 2 × bird legs” into the equation 3I – 2B = 1 (C1). (R)  
7. Translate the condition “snake heads = spider heads” into P = S + 2 (C2). (R)  
8. Substitute C2 (P = S + 2) into the head and leg equations to get the reduced systems (1) 2S + B + M + I = 95 and (2) B + 2M + 3I + 4S = 182. (R)  
9. Eliminate variables by computing (2) – 2·(1) to derive I = B – 8. (R)  
10. Combine I = B – 8 with 3I – 2B = 1 to solve for B = 25 and I = 17. (R)  
11. Use equation (1) to express M in terms of S: M = 53 – 2S. (R)  
12. Express P directly from C2: P = S + 2. (R)  
13. Impose the qualitative constraints: all five group sizes must be distinct and the largest minus the smallest must equal 10. (C)  
14. Test positive integer values of S that keep M positive, check distinctness, and enforce the 10-member range; arrive at S = 19, M = 15, P = 21. (R)  
15. Verify that these numbers satisfy every numerical and qualitative constraint (heads = 100, legs = 376, insect-to-bird leg ratio, snake-to-spider head equality, distinct counts, range = 10). (R)  
16. State the final counts: 19 snakes, 25 birds, 15 mammals, 17 insects, and 21 spiders. (R)

Question:
The ABC Express pulled out of the station late one night and began its winding journey up the coast to its destination under heavy darkness. Owing to the late hour, there were only a handful of passengers aboard the small train. At the stroke of midnight, the lights illuminating the interior of the two cars were suddenly extinguished. When they flicked back to life a few moments later, the passengers were alarmed to see one of their number lying on the ground motionless.
The conductor phoned the local police department, and though it was very late, the dispatcher assured the worried conductor that they were sending their very best detective. A bit of an eccentric, Detective Y had an usual methodology when it came to solving crimes. Knowing witnesses to be often be mistaken and contradictory, Y made a habit of asking his witnesses to state to him only one fact they remembered clearly and with absolute certainty from the moment the crime took place.
Y wasted no time upon arriving and, after taking a quick overview of the scene, asked each of the ten remaining passengers in turn to state one absolute fact from the moment right before lights went out in the two train cars. His interview notes are as follows:
Ms. S:  I was dining with Mr. J.
Mr. G:  There were the same number of men and women in my car.
Mr. J:  Mr. K was not in the dining car.
Ms. L:  Mr. Q had just entered my car.
Mr. F:  Ms. W and Ms. P were talking to one another in hushed tones.
Mr. R:  Mr. G was not in the passenger car.
Mr. Q:  There were fewer women in my car than the other.
Ms. P:  Ms. L was not in the same car as me.
Mr. K:  Ms. P was in the passenger car.
Ms. W:  Mr. F was avoiding Mr. R and hiding behind a newspaper in the opposite car.
The bewildered conductor watched as Detective Y completed his interviews, scribbled a few more lines in his notes, and turned to announce he had solved the case.
"But surely you can't have figured out the identity of a murderer simply from a list of seating arrangements?" the conductor protested. "You haven't even been told in which car the victim was seated!"
"To the contrary, my good man," the detective answered placidly. "It is the curse of a criminal that he must answer any question regarding the crime he has committed with a lie. The innocent tell only truths, but the lone murderer has been betrayed by his testimony."
Who did Detective Y arrest?
Hint: Like any good Detective, Y always assumes everyone he interviews is telling the truth until proven otherwise. He also knows the simplest explanation is always the best. He compares the witness statements until he discovers the scenario that is accurately described by nine truthful witnesses and arrests the liar.
Human Solution:
Because exactly one of the ten statements must be a lie while all the others are simultaneously true, try every passenger in turn as the lone liar and look for a seating arrangement that satisfies the other nine statements.

Doing this systematically shows that every choice but one leads to an irresolvable contradiction (usually with the “equal number of men and women in my car” requirement or with Mr. Q’s “fewer women in my car than the other”).

The only assignment that works is obtained when Mr. K is the single liar:

Dining-car passengers  
 Ms S, Mr J, Mr G, Ms P, Ms W, Mr F  
 (3 women, 3 men – satisfying Mr G’s true statement)

Passenger-car passengers  
 Mr K, Ms L, Mr Q, Mr R  
 (1 woman, 3 men – giving fewer women than the other car, as Mr Q truthfully says)

Now check each statement.

• Ms S: She and Mr J are indeed in the dining car – true.  
• Mr G: His car (the dining car) has the same number of men and women – true.  
• Mr J: Mr K is not in the dining car – true.  
• Ms L: Mr Q is in the same car she is – true.  
• Mr F: Ms W and Ms P are together (and could easily have been whispering) – true.  
• Mr R: Mr G is not in the passenger car – true.  
• Mr Q: His car has fewer women than the other – true (1 < 3).  
• Ms P: Ms L is not in the same car as she is – true.  
• Ms W: Mr F is in the opposite car from Mr R – true.  
• Mr K: “Ms P was in the passenger car” – FALSE.

All nine other statements can be true simultaneously only if Mr. K’s statement is the lone lie, so Mr. K must be the murderer.

Final answer: Mr. K
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. (R) Recognize from the premise that exactly one of the ten passenger statements must be false while the remaining nine must simultaneously be true.  
2. (R) Choose a brute-force strategy: for each of the ten passengers in turn, assume that person is the single liar.  
3. (R) For the nine statements now presumed true, try to place the fourteen people (ten witnesses + victim) into the two cars so that all nine truths hold.  
4. (R) Repeat Step 3 for each of the ten possible liars and observe that nine of the ten assumptions lead to contradictions (usually with Mr G’s “equal numbers” or Mr Q’s “fewer women” constraints).  
5. (R) Discover that the only assumption that does not break down is when Mr K is treated as the liar; construct the explicit seating plan:  
   • Dining car – Ms S, Mr J, Mr G, Ms P, Ms W, Mr F (3 women, 3 men)  
   • Passenger car – Mr K, Ms L, Mr Q, Mr R (1 woman, 3 men)  
6. (R) Verify one by one that under this seating arrangement each of the other nine statements is true, while Mr K’s statement (“Ms P was in the passenger car”) is false.  
7. (R) Conclude that Mr K is the sole liar and therefore the murderer; Detective Y arrests Mr K.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 7  
Creative ', ' 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:
