Question:
Please do Military Fun and Military Fun 2 first before doing this teaser. This teaser continues on from the first and second times the friends got together, and will give away the answer to Military Fun and Military Fun 2. So, please do those teasers first.
This time the same 10 friends are going to go through a training camp so that they can be ready for their next pretend battle. More friends are finding out about this military fun and want to join, Private Brianna and Private Ben have come into this group too. Today the friends will be running 3 laps around the park. At the end of the race, the friends will move up or down in ranks according on how they did. If you can't move up or down any ranks, you will stay in the same rank that you are currently in. The scoring will be as follows
1st Place- Move up 5 ranks
2nd Place- Move up 4 ranks
3rd Place- Move up 3 ranks
4th and 5th Places- Move up 1 rank each
6th and 7th Places- Stay the same rank
8th and 9th Places- Move down 1 rank each
10th and 11th Places- Move down 2 ranks each
12th Place- Move down 3 ranks
The ranks people have right now:
Lieutenant General Stephen
Colonel Anna
Major Felicia
Captain Clark
Sergeant Abby
Sergeant Brad
Corporal Jessica
Private Paul
Private Kelsey
Private Luke
Private Brianna
Private Ben
This is a list of the ranks again, just in case anyone forgot it.
Ranks
1. Lieutenant General
2. Brigadier General
3. Colonel
4. Lieutenant Colonel
5. Major
6. Captain
7. First Lieutenant
8. Second Lieutenant
9. First Sergeant
10. Sergeant
11. Corporal
12. Private
The First Lap:
Stephen, Ben, Paul, and Jessica took off sprinting taking the top 4 spots. Felicia and Brianna aren't far behind though. Kelsey, Anna and Abby were bringing up the back as they had a late start.
In the top 4 runners, the bottom two ranked people were doing the best and the top ranked person was doing the worst. The Major was in 6th place as Brianna passed her for 5th. Luke was just about to pass Felicia, but tripped and fell back to 9th place as Clark and Brad passed him in that order. The back three girls were in their places according to their rank, the highest rank being 10th place and the lowest rank being 12th place.
The Second Lap:
Paul slipped on a water puddle and fell back to third place, leaving the person he was right by, way in front. Clark moved up 2 spots, pushing those two people back one place each. Then, Felicia and Anna switched places, and Luke and Brad switched places. The people in 11th and 12th ended up switching places just before the third lap as well.
The Third Lap:
The two people in 10th and 11th place switched spots, the two people in 5th and 6th places switched spots, and the two people in 7th and 8th places switched spots. Brad ended up getting passed by the two people directly behind him, and Jessica was passed by the person directly behind her. Everyone then finished in the order that they are currently in.
Can you figure out which place everyone is in, and what rank they will be after this race?
Hint: On the first lap the top 4 runners were Stephen, Ben, Paul, and Jessica. Felicia and Brianna weren't far behind which means they were in 5th and 6th place. With Kelsey, Anna, and Abby in the back (10th, 11th, and 12th places), that means Luke, Brad, and Clark were in 7th, 8th, and 9th.
Human Solution:
We begin with the starting ranks  

Stephen – Lieutenant General (1)  
Anna – Colonel (3)  
Felicia – Major (5)  
Clark – Captain (6)  
Abby – Sergeant (10)  
Brad – Sergeant (10)  
Jessica – Corporal (11)  
Paul – Private (12)  
Kelsey – Private (12)  
Luke – Private (12)  
Brianna – Private (12)  
Ben – Private (12)  

---------------------------------------------------
1.  End of the first lap  

• Top-4 sprinters: Ben, Paul, Jessica, Stephen. “Bottom two ranked did best, top ranked did worst” →  
   1 Ben, 2 Paul, 3 Jessica, 4 Stephen.  
• Brianna passes Felicia → 5 Brianna, 6 Felicia.  
• Luke trips; Clark then Brad pass him → 7 Clark, 8 Brad, 9 Luke.  
• Back three girls in rank order high-to-low → 10 Anna, 11 Abby, 12 Kelsey.  

Positions after lap 1  
1 Ben  2 Paul  3 Jessica  4 Stephen  5 Brianna  6 Felicia  
7 Clark  8 Brad  9 Luke  10 Anna  11 Abby  12 Kelsey  

---------------------------------------------------
2.  Second lap changes  

• Paul slips to 3rd; Jessica up to 2nd → 1 Ben, 2 Jessica, 3 Paul.  
• Clark moves up 2 (past Brianna & Felicia) → 5 Clark, 6 Brianna, 7 Felicia.  
• Felicia and Anna swap → 7 Anna, 10 Felicia.  
• Luke and Brad swap → 8 Luke, 9 Brad.  
• 11th & 12th swap → 11 Kelsey, 12 Abby.  

Positions after lap 2  
1 Ben  2 Jessica  3 Paul  4 Stephen  5 Clark  6 Brianna  
7 Anna  8 Luke  9 Brad  10 Felicia  11 Kelsey  12 Abby  

---------------------------------------------------
3.  Third lap changes (final)  

• 10th ↔ 11th → 10 Kelsey, 11 Felicia.  
• 5th ↔ 6th → 5 Brianna, 6 Clark.  
• 7th ↔ 8th → 7 Luke, 8 Anna.  
• Brad (9th) is passed by the two behind him → 9 Kelsey, 10 Felicia, 11 Brad.  
• Jessica (2nd) is passed by Paul → 2 Paul, 3 Jessica.  

Final finishing order  
1 Ben  
2 Paul  
3 Jessica  
4 Stephen  
5 Brianna  
6 Clark  
7 Luke  
8 Anna  
9 Kelsey  
10 Felicia  
11 Brad  
12 Abby  

---------------------------------------------------
Applying the promotion/demotion rules  

1st  (+5 ranks)   Ben: 12 → 7 (First Lieutenant)  
2nd (+4 ranks)   Paul: 12 → 8 (Second Lieutenant)  
3rd (+3 ranks)   Jessica: 11 → 8 (Second Lieutenant)  
4th (+1 rank)    Stephen: 1 → 1 (stays Lieutenant General)  
5th (+1 rank)    Brianna: 12 → 11 (Corporal)  
6th (no change)  Clark: stays Captain (6)  
7th (no change)  Luke: stays Private (12)  
8th (–1 rank)    Anna: 3 → 4 (Lieutenant Colonel)  
9th (–1 rank)    Kelsey: 12 → 12 (stays Private)  
10th(–2 ranks)   Felicia: 5 → 7 (First Lieutenant)  
11th(–2 ranks)   Brad: 10 → 12 (Private)  
12th(–3 ranks)   Abby: 10 → 12 (Private)  

---------------------------------------------------
Final standings and new ranks  

1. Ben – First Lieutenant  
2. Paul – Second Lieutenant  
3. Jessica – Second Lieutenant  
4. Stephen – Lieutenant General  
5. Brianna – Corporal  
6. Clark – Captain  
7. Luke – Private  
8. Anna – Lieutenant Colonel  
9. Kelsey – Private  
10. Felicia – First Lieutenant  
11. Brad – Private  
12. Abby – Private  

Final answer:  
Ben 1st (First Lieutenant), Paul 2nd (Second Lieutenant), Jessica 3rd (Second Lieutenant), Stephen 4th (Lieutenant General), Brianna 5th (Corporal), Clark 6th (Captain), Luke 7th (Private), Anna 8th (Lieutenant Colonel), Kelsey 9th (Private), Felicia 10th (First Lieutenant), Brad 11th (Private), Abby 12th (Private).
Response:
Total Step Count: 20  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 19  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) List the twelve friends together with their starting military ranks and their numerical rank values.  
2. (Creative) From the first-lap information, single out the four sprinters and, using the clue “the bottom two ranked did best and the top ranked did worst,” order them as 1 Ben, 2 Paul, 3 Jessica, 4 Stephen.  
3. (Rudimentary) Incorporate the statement “Brianna passed Felicia” to set 5 Brianna and 6 Felicia.  
4. (Rudimentary) Use “Luke tripped; Clark and then Brad passed him” to fix positions 7 Clark, 8 Brad, 9 Luke.  
5. (Rudimentary) Place the three remaining girls in the rear according to their rank order (10 Anna, 11 Abby, 12 Kelsey).  
6. (Rudimentary) Compile the complete order after Lap 1: Ben, Paul, Jessica, Stephen, Brianna, Felicia, Clark, Brad, Luke, Anna, Abby, Kelsey.  
7. (Rudimentary) Apply Paul’s slip at the start of Lap 2 so that the top three become Ben, Jessica, Paul.  
8. (Rudimentary) Move Clark up two spots, pushing Brianna and Felicia each back one.  
9. (Rudimentary) Swap Felicia and Anna as stated.  
10. (Rudimentary) Swap Luke and Brad as stated.  
11. (Rudimentary) Swap the runners in 11th and 12th (Kelsey and Abby).  
12. (Rudimentary) Record the full order after Lap 2: Ben, Jessica, Paul, Stephen, Clark, Brianna, Anna, Luke, Brad, Felicia, Kelsey, Abby.  
13. (Rudimentary) Start Lap 3 by swapping the runners in 10th and 11th (Felicia ↔ Kelsey).  
14. (Rudimentary) Swap the runners in 5th and 6th (Brianna ↔ Clark).  
15. (Rudimentary) Swap the runners in 7th and 8th (Luke ↔ Anna).  
16. (Rudimentary) Let Brad be passed by the two directly behind him, inserting them ahead of him and pushing Brad back two places.  
17. (Rudimentary) Let Paul pass Jessica, making Paul 2nd and Jessica 3rd.  
18. (Rudimentary) Write down the final finishing order: Ben, Paul, Jessica, Stephen, Brianna, Clark, Luke, Anna, Kelsey, Felicia, Brad, Abby.  
19. (Rudimentary) Apply the promotion/demotion schedule to each finisher’s starting rank to compute new ranks.  
20. (Rudimentary) Present the final standings with both finishing positions and new military ranks for all twelve friends.

Question:
In Numberrangements, you are given an arrangement of letters. The letters represent all of the whole numbers from 1 to the total number of letters used. Each letter represents a different number. Using the clues given, find which number each letter represents.
ABC
DEF
GHI
1. The sum of the top row is greater than the sum of the middle row, which is greater than the sum of the bottom row.
2. E is a prime factor of G.
3. F is greater than A.
4. The sum of B and G is equal to H.
5. I is not 1.
Hint: Start with casework on clue 2.
Human Solution:
We must assign the nine different whole numbers 1–9 to the letters  

ABC  
DEF  
GHI  

so that all five clues hold.

1) Row–sum order  
   A+B+C  >  D+E+F  >  G+H+I.

2) E is a prime factor of G.  
   The only primes ≤9 are 2,3,5,7; therefore the admissible (E,G) pairs are  
   (2,4),(2,6),(2,8),(3,6),(3,9),(5,5),(7,7).

3) F > A.

4) B+G = H, and H ≤ 9, so B+G ≤ 9.

5) I ≠ 1.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Step 1 – analyse (E,G).

Because of 4), G must be small enough that B+G ≤9.  
Among the admissible pairs above this leaves only (2,4),(2,6),(2,8).  
The pairs with E>G (5,5) or (7,7) are impossible (duplicate numbers), and with (3,6) or (3,9) the restriction B+G≤9 forces B≤3, which will be shown impossible.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Step 2 – try (E,G) = (2,4).

With G = 4, equation 4 gives H = B+4.  
Since H≤9, B can be 1,3,5.

• B = 3 or 5 leads to bottom–row sums so large that the inequalities in 1) cannot be satisfied (top and middle rows cannot both exceed the bottom while still totalling 45).  
• B = 1 works.

Thus let  
 E = 2, G = 4, B = 1, H = 5.

The bottom row is then 4 + 5 + I = 9+I, so
 G+H+I = 12,15,16,17,18,21,22 depending on I (I ≠ 1,2,4,5).

Row–sum inequality 1) forces the smallest possible bottom sum, hence I = 3, giving
 G+H+I = 12.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Step 3 – fill the remaining numbers {6,7,8,9}.

Numbers left to place: {6,7,8,9}.  
Top row now contains A,1,C; middle row contains D,2,F with F>A.

Testing the possibilities quickly yields a single working assignment:

Top row  (A,B,C) = (7,1,9) → sum = 17  
Middle row (D,E,F) = (6,2,8) → sum = 16  
Bottom row (G,H,I) = (4,5,3) → sum = 12  

All five clues are satisfied:
• 17 > 16 > 12.  
• E = 2 is a prime factor of G = 4.  
• F = 8 > A = 7.  
• B+G = 1+4 = 5 = H.  
• I = 3 ≠ 1.  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Step 4 – show uniqueness.

The other candidate pairs (E,G) = (2,6) or (2,8) make B+G too large, violating the row–sum ordering, and (E,G) = (3,6) likewise gives no feasible row sums; all other (E,G) are already impossible. Hence the arrangement found above is unique.

Therefore each letter’s number is:

A = 7  
B = 1  
C = 9  
D = 6  
E = 2  
F = 8  
G = 4  
H = 5  
I = 3  

Final answer: A=7, B=1, C=9, D=6, E=2, F=8, G=4, H=5, I=3
Response:
Total Step Count: 10  
Creative Steps: 5  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary)  Use clue 2 to enumerate every admissible (E,G) pair by listing the primes ≤ 9 and matching them with the multiples ≤ 9: (2,4), (2,6), (2,8), (3,6), (3,9), (5,5), (7,7).  

2. (Creative)  Combine clue 4 (B + G = H ≤ 9) with the list above to rule out pairs whose G is too large or duplicates a number, leaving only (2,4), (2,6), (2,8) as viable candidates (and noting why (3,6)/(3,9) would later fail).  

3. (Creative)  Select (E,G) = (2,4) as the most promising pair because the smaller G more easily keeps B + G ≤ 9 and helps satisfy the row–sum inequality.  

4. (Rudimentary)  With G = 4, translate B + 4 = H (from clue 4) and H ≤ 9 to deduce the three possibilities B ∈ {1, 3, 5}.  

5. (Creative)  Test B = 3 and B = 5 and reject them by showing their resulting bottom-row sums make it impossible to satisfy A+B+C > D+E+F > G+H+I while totaling 45; accept B = 1 instead.  

6. (Creative)  Having G = 4, H = 5, deduce the bottom-row sum is 9 + I. To keep it as small as possible (so the other two rows can both exceed it) pick the smallest unused value, I = 3 (not equal to 1 as required).  

7. (Rudimentary)  List the four unused numbers {6, 7, 8, 9} that remain to be placed in the top and middle rows.  

8. (Rudimentary)  Arrange those four numbers—while honoring F > A and the row-sum order—to find the single working placement: top row (A,B,C) = (7,1,9) and middle row (D,E,F) = (6,2,8).  

9. (Rudimentary)  Verify that all five original clues are satisfied by this arrangement.  

10. (Creative)  Argue that the other provisional pairs (2,6) and (2,8) (and the previously noted (3,6), (3,9)) cannot meet the row-sum ordering, establishing that the found arrangement is unique.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 10  
Creative ', ' 5  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary)  Use clue 2 to enumerate every admissible (E,G) pair by listing the primes ≤ 9 and matching them with the multiples ≤ 9: (2,4), (2,6), (2,8), (3,6), (3,9), (5,5), (7,7).  

2. (Creative)  Combine clue 4 (B + G = H ≤ 9) with the list above to rule out pairs whose G is too large or duplicates a number, leaving only (2,4), (2,6), (2,8) as viable candidates (and noting why (3,6)/(3,9) would later fail).  

3. (Creative)  Select (E,G) = (2,4) as the most promising pair because the smaller G more easily keeps B + G ≤ 9 and helps satisfy the row–sum inequality.  

4. (Rudimentary)  With G = 4, translate B + 4 = H (from clue 4) and H ≤ 9 to deduce the three possibilities B ∈ {1, 3, 5}.  

5. (Creative)  Test B = 3 and B = 5 and reject them by showing their resulting bottom-row sums make it impossible to satisfy A+B+C > D+E+F > G+H+I while totaling 45; accept B = 1 instead.  

6. (Creative)  Having G = 4, H = 5, deduce the bottom-row sum is 9 + I. To keep it as small as possible (so the other two rows can both exceed it) pick the smallest unused value, I = 3 (not equal to 1 as required).  

7. (Rudimentary)  List the four unused numbers {6, 7, 8, 9} that remain to be placed in the top and middle rows.  

8. (Rudimentary)  Arrange those four numbers—while honoring F > A and the row-sum order—to find the single working placement: top row (A,B,C) = (7,1,9) and middle row (D,E,F) = (6,2,8).  

9. (Rudimentary)  Verify that all five original clues are satisfied by this arrangement.  

10. (Creative)  Argue that the other provisional pairs (2,6) and (2,8) (and the previously noted (3,6), (3,9)) cannot meet the row-sum ordering, establishing that the found arrangement is unique.']

Question:
The boffins from NASA have received and decoded a digital message from the Galactic Council, informing them that four alien ambassadors from the solar system are due to visit Earth in the next 24 hours. The aliens are Agurgle from Uranus, Wym-Inar from Venus, ChimChim from Pluto and Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn. 24 hours later, they receive a mystery message saying that if any alien comes off the ship that is green, tentacled and slimy, then they are actually an undercover assassin from Neptune. By then, however, the aliens have all landed and are in adjacent decontamination booths, waiting to be let in to NASA Headquarters. One alien turns out to be green, tentacled and slimy!
From the clues below, who is the Neptunian Assassin?
1) Wym-Inar from Venus is the only ambassador in a booth next to exactly one tentacled alien.
2). Two of the ambassadors who are not green, are each in booths next to Agurgle from Uranus.
3) ChimChim from Pluto is the only ambassador not in a booth next to exactly one Un-slimy alien.
Who do the NASA boffins not let out of the booth?
Hint: Don't get too confused with the Un-slimy bit.
Human Solution:
Reasoning in detail  

Step 1 – Place Agurgle (Uranus)  
Clue 2 says that two non-green ambassadors are each next to Agurgle.  
That is only possible if Agurgle is in one of the two middle booths (2 or 3), because only there can he have two neighbours.

Step 2 – Count tentacled neighbours to locate Wym-Inar (Venus)  
Clue 1: “Wym-Inar is the ONLY ambassador who has exactly one tentacled neighbour.”  
If Wym-Inar sat in a middle booth he would have two neighbours, and it would be very difficult to keep every other ambassador from also having exactly one tentacled neighbour.  
Put Wym-Inar at an end (booth 1).  Then he has just one neighbour, so we can give him exactly one tentacled neighbour by making booth 2 tentacled and arrange the others so that nobody else has exactly one tentacled neighbour.

So far we have  

booth 1 : Wym-Inar (Venus) – not tentacled  
booth 2 : Agurgle (Uranus) – tentacled  
booth 3 : unknown – not tentacled  
booth 4 : unknown – tentacled  

(The two tentacled aliens are in booths 2 and 4; Wym-Inar is the only one who sees exactly one of them.)

Step 3 – Colours around Agurgle  
Because of Clue 2, the two neighbours of Agurgle (booths 1 and 3) must be non-green.  
Thus booths 1 and 3 are not green; booth 4 may or may not be green.

Step 4 – Deal with sliminess (Clue 3)  
Clue 3: “ChimChim is the ONLY ambassador NOT next to exactly one unslimy neighbour.”  
That means every ambassador except ChimChim must see exactly one unslimy neighbour; ChimChim must see either 0 or 2.

Put ChimChim at the other end (booth 4).  
For an end booth to have “not exactly one” unslimy neighbour it has to see 0 unslimy neighbours.  
Therefore the occupant of booth 3 must be slimy, so ChimChim’s only neighbour is slimy and ChimChim sees 0 unslimy neighbours.

Assign sliminess so that the other three ambassadors each see exactly one unslimy neighbour:

booth 1 (Wym-Inar): unslimy  
booth 2 (Agurgle): unslimy  
booth 3 (Mr Arthur Johnson): slimy  
booth 4 (ChimChim): slimy  

Now  
• Wym-Inar sees one unslimy neighbour (Agurgle) – good.  
• Agurgle sees one unslimy (Wym-Inar) and one slimy (Johnson) – good.  
• Johnson sees one unslimy (Agurgle) and one slimy (ChimChim) – good.  
• ChimChim sees 0 unslimy – good (the exceptional case required by Clue 3).

Step 5 – Who can be the green tentacled slimy alien?  
Only the two tentacled aliens (booths 2 and 4) qualify.  
But booth 2 (Agurgle) is unslimy, so cannot be the assassin.  
Booth 4 (ChimChim) is tentacled, slimy, and may be coloured green; that choice satisfies every clue (booths 1 and 3 are already fixed as non-green, and nothing restricts booth 4’s colour).  

Thus we set ChimChim to be green, tentacled and slimy – the Neptunian assassin.

No other placement of the four aliens can satisfy all three clues simultaneously; in every valid arrangement the only possible assassin is the occupant of booth 4, ChimChim.

Final answer: ChimChim from Pluto is the undercover Neptunian assassin – NASA must not let ChimChim out of the booth.
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 2  

Steps:  
1. (Creative)  Apply Clue 2 (“two non-green ambassadors are each next to Agurgle”) to see that Agurgle must occupy one of the two middle booths (2 or 3) so that he can have two neighbours.  

2. (Creative)  Use Clue 1 (“Wym-Inar is the only ambassador in a booth next to exactly one tentacled alien”) to decide that Wym-Inar must be at an end booth; place him in booth 1 and make only booth 2 tentacled, ensuring no one else can also have exactly one tentacled neighbour.  

3. (Rudimentary)  Finish applying Clue 2 by marking the two neighbours of Agurgle (booths 1 and 3) as non-green, leaving booth 4’s colour unrestricted.  

4. (Creative)  Turn to Clue 3 (“ChimChim is the only ambassador not next to exactly one unslimy neighbour”) to put ChimChim in the opposite end booth 4, then assign sliminess so that booths 1 and 2 are unslimy, booths 3 and 4 are slimy, giving every ambassador except ChimChim exactly one unslimy neighbour.  

5. (Rudimentary)  Check which tentacled aliens can also be green and slimy; Agurgle (booth 2) is unslimy, so only ChimChim (booth 4) can satisfy “green, tentacled and slimy,” making ChimChim the Neptunian assassin.

Question:
Four men are in a line at the Madadian Police station, charged with unlicensed kebab breeding.
The men are Mad Ade, Buster Artery, Cliff Hedge and Donny Moe - and they are standing in a straight line.
One man is fair, handsome and unscarred.
Two men who are not fair, are each standing next to Mad Ade
Buster Artery is the only man standing next to exactly one handsome man.
Cliff Hedge is the only man not standing next to exactly one scarred man.
Who is fair, handsome and unscarred?
Hint: From (2), both the men standing next to Mad Ade are not fair. Also, exactly one man is fair, handsome and unscarred. Hence, there are two cases:
Human Solution:
Reasoning

1.  Place Mad Ade  
   • Because “two men who are not fair are each standing next to Mad Ade”, Mad Ade must have two neighbours, so he is in position 2 or 3 in the line.

2.  Place Buster Artery  
   • Only Buster “is standing next to exactly one handsome man”.  
   • If Buster were at an end of the line (positions 1 or 4) he would have just one neighbour; any other man who happened to be at an end would also have exactly one neighbour, and could easily end up with exactly one handsome neighbour too, breaking the uniqueness condition.  
   • Therefore Buster must be in the other middle place – if Mad Ade is at 2, Buster is at 3; if Mad Ade is at 3, Buster is at 2.

   We examine the first of these possibilities; the second is its mirror-image and leads to the same conclusion.

   So far:
           1        2        3        4
                    Mad Ade   Buster
                    (A)       (B)

3.  Handsome/not-handsome distribution  
   Let H(x) be “x is handsome”.

   • Buster (position 3) has neighbours Mad Ade (pos 2) and whoever is at pos 4.  
     H(2)+H(4)=1   (exactly one handsome neighbour) … (1)

   • The man at position 1 is not Buster, has only Mad Ade beside him, and must NOT have exactly one handsome neighbour.  
     Therefore Mad Ade cannot be handsome:  H(2)=0.

     From (1) we get H(4)=1 (the man at position 4 is the only handsome man).

   • Because H(2)=0, the neighbour counts of the others force
     H(1)=0 and H(3)=0.

   Conclusion: the only handsome man is the one at the extreme right (position 4).

4.  Fair/not-fair   
   • From the first clue, the two neighbours of Mad Ade (positions 1 and 3) are NOT fair.  
     Therefore positions 1 and 3 are “not fair”; positions 2 and 4 may be fair.

5.  Scarred/unscarred and Cliff Hedge  
   Let S(x)=1 mean “x is scarred”.

   Everyone except Cliff Hedge stands next to exactly one scarred man; Cliff stands next to either none or two.

   Put Cliff at position 4 (the handsome man).  Since position 4 has only one neighbour, to avoid “exactly one scarred neighbour” that neighbour (position 3) must be unscarred:

        S(3)=0 ,   S(4)=0.

   Now force the other three men to have exactly one scarred neighbour:

        Position 3 (Buster): neighbours are 2 and 4 → S(2)=1.
        Position 2 (Mad Ade): neighbours are 1 and 3 → S(1)=1.
        Position 1: neighbour is 2, which is scarred → requirement already met.

   The scar pattern is therefore

        S(1)=1 , S(2)=1 , S(3)=0 , S(4)=0,

   giving each man except Cliff (position 4) exactly one scarred neighbour, and Cliff none.

6.  Check all statements

   • Exactly one man is fair, handsome, unscarred:  
     position 4 is handsome and unscarred, and may be taken as the fair one; nobody else is handsome, so the condition holds.

   • “Two men who are not fair are each standing next to Mad Ade”:  
     positions 1 and 3 are not fair and are Mad Ade’s neighbours.

   • “Buster Artery is the only man standing next to exactly one handsome man”:  
     Buster (position 3) is next to the single handsome man at position 4; every other man is next to no handsome men.

   • “Cliff Hedge is the only man not standing next to exactly one scarred man”:  
     Cliff is at position 4, next to 0 scarred men; the others each stand next to exactly one.

   All four clues are simultaneously satisfied.

Since the man in position 4 is Cliff Hedge, Cliff is the unique fair, handsome and unscarred person.

Final answer: Cliff Hedge
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. Use the fact that Mad Ade must have two neighbours to place him in one of the two middle spots (position 2 or 3). – Rudimentary  

2. Use Buster Artery’s “exactly one handsome neighbour” uniqueness to deduce that he must occupy the other middle spot (the ends would let someone else share the same property). – Creative  

3. Invoke mirror-symmetry and fix one concrete orientation: Mad Ade in position 2, Buster in position 3. – Rudimentary  

4. Translate Buster’s handsome-neighbour condition into an equation H(2)+H(4)=1. – Rudimentary  

5. Observe that the man at position 1 must not have exactly one handsome neighbour, forcing Mad Ade to be non-handsome, hence only position 4 is handsome; positions 1 and 3 are not. – Rudimentary  

6. Apply the “two men who are not fair are each next to Mad Ade” clue to mark positions 1 and 3 as not fair (positions 2 or 4 could be fair). – Rudimentary  

7. Place Cliff Hedge at position 4 (the lone handsome man) so that, with only one neighbour, he can be the single person not adjacent to exactly one scarred man. – Creative  

8. Assign scarred/unscarred status to meet every man’s neighbour requirements: make position 3 unscarred, positions 2 and 1 scarred, yielding the needed pattern. – Rudimentary  

9. Check all four original clues with the obtained arrangement and conclude that Cliff Hedge (position 4) is the unique fair, handsome, unscarred man. – Rudimentary

Question:
Mad Ade's rich uncle "Uncle Rich" owned the famous Madadian Race horse breeding stables "The Gluepot".
It has a private race track that has five lanes.
Uncle Rich has 25 horses and wishes to know which are the three fastest.
What is the least number of races needed to be run to find the answer?
Note that it is only the ranking of the horses being found not the actual timings.
Hint: Subgroups!
Human Solution:
Reasoning in full

1.  Divide the 25 horses into five groups  
   A = {A1 … A5}, B = {B1 … B5}, C = {C1 … C5}, D = {D1 … D5}, E = {E1 … E5}.  
   Race each group once.  
   • 5 races have now been run and every group is internally ordered, e.g.  
     A1 < A2 < A3 < A4 < A5 ( “<” means “faster than”).

2.  Race the five winners A1 , B1 , C1 , D1 , E1.  
   Call the order obtained
        A1 < B1 < C1 < D1 < E1.                     (6-th race)

   What this tells us
   – A1 is faster than every horse in B, C, D, E, so A1 is certainly the overall No. 1.  
   – Any horse in D or E is beaten by at least three horses (A1 , B1 , C1), so no-one from D
     or E can be in the overall top three; they are discarded.

3.  Which horses might still be 2-nd or 3-rd overall?

   • From A we must still consider A2 and A3 (the two that have lost only to A1).  
   • From B we must consider B1 and B2 (B1 lost only to A1, B2 lost only to A1 and B1).  
   • From C we must consider C1 (lost only to A1 and B1).  

   These are exactly five horses:         A2 , A3 , B1 , B2 , C1.

4.  Race those five horses.                               (7-th race)

   The winner of this race is the 2-nd-fastest overall,  
   the runner-up is the 3-rd-fastest overall,  
   and together with A1 (already known to be the fastest) we have the complete top three.

Hence the three fastest horses are known after 7 races.

Why 7 races are the minimum

• The first five races are unavoidable: with only five lanes every horse must run at least once before any eliminations can be made.  
• After those five races you still know nothing about how the five group winners compare with each other, so a sixth race that puts the five winners together is unavoidable.  
• After that sixth race there remain at least five plausible candidates (A2 , A3 , B1 , B2 , C1) for the 2-nd and 3-rd places, and they have never met each other. One more race is therefore essential.  

Consequently no procedure can guarantee the answer in fewer than 7 races, and the procedure above achieves it in exactly 7.

Final answer: 7
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Split the 25 horses into five groups of five and run five separate races—one per group—to establish the internal ranking of each group. (Rudimentary)  
2. Stage a sixth race among the five group winners (A1, B1, C1, D1, E1) and record their finishing order. (Rudimentary)  
3. From the winners’ race conclude that A1 outruns every horse in B, C, D, E and that any horse in groups D or E is beaten by at least three others, so none of them can still reach the overall top three. (Creative)  
4. Combine all known rankings to identify the only horses that can still be 2nd or 3rd overall: A2, A3, B1, B2, C1. (Creative)  
5. Run a seventh race among those five candidates; the first-place finisher is the overall 2nd-fastest horse and the runner-up is the overall 3rd-fastest. (Rudimentary)  
6. Declare A1 together with the two best from the seventh race as the three fastest horses overall. (Rudimentary)  
7. Argue minimality: five initial heats are mandatory given the five-lane track; a sixth race is required to compare the heat winners; after that, at least one more race is needed because five horses still plausibly vie for the remaining two spots—hence no method can do better than seven races. (Creative)

Question: In a wood-cutting factory, five large sawing machines stand in a windowless room. Each machine has an on/off switch attached, there being no doubt as to which switch controls which machine. Outside the door to the room are five back-up on/off switches, one for each machine inside. The power for each machine must first pass through the back-up switch, and then the machine switch before reaching the saw. The problem is, the new manager cannot decide how these back-up switches match with the machines inside the room. One day, the manager's brother visits. The manager takes him inside the sawing room where all five machines are at work and explains the problem. The brother announces that he intends to leave the room and that when he returns he will be able to match correctly the five switches outside the room to the five machines inside. The brother works alone, cannot see the machines from outside the room and solves the problem purely by operating switches. How is it possible?
Hint: Aside from sight, use other senses.
Human Solution:
Inside the saw-room the brother is first shown all five machines running.  
He now knows that every machine switch (the switch fixed to the machine) is in the ON position – the only thing that can stop a machine is its own back-up switch outside the door.

Step 1 – cancel every earlier “heat record”.  
Before leaving the room he does nothing to the machine switches but, the moment he is outside, he snaps ALL FIVE back-up switches to OFF.  
Every saw stops and all the motors begin to cool from exactly the same temperature.

Step 2 – give every back-up switch a different running time.  
Still standing outside, he now works with a watch and one switch at a time.

 • switch A   ON for 32 minutes, then OFF  
 • switch B   ON for 16 minutes, then OFF  
 • switch C   ON for  8 minutes, then OFF  
 • switch D   ON for  4 minutes, then OFF  
 • switch E   never switched on at all  

At the end of this 60-minute programme every back-up switch is OFF again, so every saw is motionless and the room is safe to enter.

Step 3 – read the “thermometer”.  
He immediately re-enters the room.  
Although no machine is turning, their motors are at five quite distinct temperatures:

 very hot  → machine that ran 32 min → switch A  
 hot     → machine that ran 16 min → switch B  
 warm   → machine that ran  8 min → switch C  
 slightly warm → machine that ran  4 min → switch D  
 cold    → machine that never ran  → switch E  

By merely feeling each motor casing he can put the machines in that temperature order and at once knows which outside back-up switch is wired to which machine.

Thus, after only one visit outside and one return to the room, he can name the correct pairings of all five switches and saws.

Final answer: he stops all the saws, then, while outside, lets each back-up switch feed its machine for a different length of time (e.g. 32, 16, 8, 4 and 0 minutes).  When he goes back in, none of the machines is running, but their different residual temperatures uniquely identify which machine was connected to which outside switch.
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Note that every machine-mounted switch is already ON, so the only way to start or stop a saw is with its corresponding outside back-up switch; therefore the pairing can be discovered using only the outside switches.  

2. (Rudimentary) Turn all five outside back-up switches OFF at once, stopping every saw and letting every motor begin cooling from the exact same initial temperature.  

3. (Creative) Devise a unique “heat signature” for each switch by assigning it a distinct running time (e.g., 32, 16, 8, 4, 0 minutes), guaranteeing five different residual motor temperatures later.  

4. (Rudimentary) While remaining outside, operate the back-up switches according to the chosen schedule—switch A ON 32 min then OFF, switch B ON 16 min then OFF, etc.—ending with all switches OFF and all saws stationary.  

5. (Rudimentary) Re-enter the room immediately, feel each motor casing to rank the five distinct temperatures, and match each temperature to its predetermined running time, thereby identifying which outside switch controls which machine.

Question:
There had been a break in at the "Sweaty Chef" Kebab shop, and the new owner, Mustapha Bettaname, had been robbed of his secret kebab recipe. The police had one eye witness, Al Kaholic, the local wino and world champion turps nudger.
A Police line up of 11 suspects was made to stand in a straight line to have an Identity Parade. The main culprit was asked to stand in the center of the line-up.
1) Barb Dwyre and Chris Mass stood to the right of the main culprit
2) Two suspects stood between Ewan Watarmy and Lou Stooth
3) Seven suspects stood between Mike Rhosopht and Phil Mypokits
4) Gerry Atrick stood to the right of Hugo Phurst
5) Robin Banks and Polly Ester-Phants stood either side of Ewan Watarmy
6) Diddy Dewit and Polly Ester-Phants stood to the left of the main culprit
7) Six suspects stood between Chris Mass and Ewan Watarmy
8) Two suspects stood between Ewan Watarmy and Diddy Dewit
Who is the main culprit?
Hint: Start with clues 7, 5, 2 and 8 together
Human Solution:
Let the 11 positions in the line-up be numbered 1 (left end) through 11 (right end).  
The centre position, 6, is occupied by the Main Culprit (MC).

Write the position of each suspect as an integer 1–11.

1. Barb Dwyre, Chris Mass  > 6.             (1)  
2. |Ewan – Lou| = 3.                 (2)  
3. |Mike – Phil| = 8.                 (3)  
4. Gerry  >  Hugo.                  (4)  
5. Robin and Polly are immediately either side of Ewan. (5)  
6. Diddy, Polly  <  6.                (6)  
7. |Chris – Ewan| = 7.                (7)  
8. |Ewan – Diddy| = 3.               (8)

------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 1 – Locate Ewan.

From (7) Chris = Ewan + 7 (because Chris > 6).  
Hence Ewan can only be 2, 3 or 4 (so that Chris ≤ 11).

Step 2 – Test Ewan = 2.

Diddy is 5 (from (8)); Lou must be 5 (from (2)); impossible (two people in one spot).  
Therefore Ewan ≠ 2.

Step 3 – Test Ewan = 3.

Diddy would be 6 (from (8)), but Diddy must be left of MC (6) by (6).  
Impossible.  So Ewan ≠ 3.

Step 4 – Hence Ewan = 4.

Then  
Chris = 11     (from (7))  
Diddy = 1     (from (8), must be < 6)  
Lou   = 7     (from (2): 4 + 3)  
Positions 3 and 5 are Robin & Polly (order still open).

------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 5 – Place Mike and Phil.

The only free pair with a gap of 8 (rule 3) is positions 2 and 10.  
So {Mike, Phil} = {2, 10} in either order.

------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 6 – Remaining open positions.

Occupied so far:

1 Diddy 2 Mike/Phil 3 ? 4 Ewan 5 ? 6 MC 7 Lou 8 ? 9 ? 10 Phil/Mike 11 Chris

The unused names are Barb, Gerry, Hugo plus whichever of Robin/Polly is not yet fixed.

Open positions are 6, 8, 9.

------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 7 – Satisfy the remaining rules.

• Barb must be to the right of MC (rule 1) ⇒ Barb = 8 or 9 (not 6).  
• Gerry > Hugo (rule 4).  
• Polly is already left of MC (rule 6) because Polly is either at 3 or 5 (< 6).

Try the possible identities for the MC:

(a) MC = Barb – violates rule 1 (Barb must be right of MC).  
(b) MC = Gerry – then Hugo must be left of 6, but every place left of 6 is taken.  
(c) MC = Hugo  – works: Gerry can be 8 or 9, Barb the remaining 8 or 9.

Thus the only consistent choice is

Position 6 = Hugo Phurst.

All rules are now simultaneously satisfied, e.g.

1 Diddy 2 Mike 3 Polly 4 Ewan 5 Robin 6 Hugo 7 Lou 8 Barb 9 Gerry 10 Phil 11 Chris  
(or with Mike/Phil swapped in 2 and 10, and Robin/Polly swapped in 3 and 5).

In every valid arrangement, the suspect standing in the centre (position 6) is Hugo Phurst.

Final answer: Hugo Phurst
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. Set-up the framework: number the eleven positions 1–11, place the main culprit (MC) at the centre position 6, and translate every verbal clue into the eight algebraic/positional rules (1)–(8). (Rudimentary)

2. Combine rules (1) and (7) to pin down where Ewan can stand.  
   • Chris must be to the right of MC (rule 1) and seven places away from Ewan (rule 7).  
   • Therefore Chris = Ewan + 7 and must still be ≤ 11, leaving Ewan only at 2, 3, or 4. (Creative)

3. Case-check Ewan = 2.  
   • |Ewan–Diddy| = 3 ⇒ Diddy = 5.  
   • |Ewan–Lou| = 3 ⇒ Lou = 5 → clash, impossible. (Rudimentary)

4. Case-check Ewan = 3.  
   • Diddy would have to be at 6, but Diddy must be left of MC (rule 6) → impossible. (Rudimentary)

5. Accept the only remaining value Ewan = 4 and propagate all direct consequences:  
   • Chris = 11 (rule 7)  
   • Diddy = 1 (rule 8, plus “left of MC”)  
   • Lou = 7 (rule 2)  
   • The two immediate neighbours of Ewan (positions 3 and 5) are Robin & Polly (rule 5, order still open). (Rudimentary)

6. Place Mike and Phil using the “gap of eight” rule (3).  
   • Among the still-empty slots, only 2 and 10 are eight apart, so {Mike, Phil} = {2, 10}. (Rudimentary)

7. Take stock: filled positions are  
   1 Diddy 2 Mike/Phil 3 ? 4 Ewan 5 ? 6 MC 7 Lou 8 ? 9 ? 10 Phil/Mike 11 Chris.  
   Unused names: Barb, Gerry, Hugo plus whichever of Robin/Polly is not yet fixed.  
   Open positions: 6, 8, 9. (Rudimentary)

8. Apply the last unsatisfied clues to decide who is MC.  
   • Barb must stand to the right of MC (rule 1) ⇒ Barb cannot be MC.  
   • If MC were Gerry, Gerry > Hugo would force Hugo somewhere left of 6, but every slot there is already occupied ⇒ impossible.  
   • Therefore MC must be Hugo, leaving Barb and Gerry for positions 8 and 9 in either order, with Gerry > Hugo automatically satisfied. (Creative)

9. Finalize the line-up (one example):  
   1 Diddy 2 Mike 3 Polly 4 Ewan 5 Robin 6 Hugo 7 Lou 8 Barb 9 Gerry 10 Phil 11 Chris.  
   All eight original rules hold, so the main culprit is Hugo Phurst. (Rudimentary)

['Total Step Count: 9  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. Set-up the framework: number the eleven positions 1–11, place the main culprit (MC) at the centre position 6, and translate every verbal clue into the eight algebraic/positional rules (1)–(8). (Rudimentary)

2. Combine rules (1) and (7) to pin down where Ewan can stand.  
   • Chris must be to the right of MC (rule 1) and seven places away from Ewan (rule 7).  
   • Therefore Chris = Ewan + 7 and must still be ≤ 11, leaving Ewan only at 2, 3, or 4. (Creative)

3. Case-check Ewan = 2.  
   • |Ewan–Diddy| = 3 ⇒ Diddy = 5.  
   • |Ewan–Lou| = 3 ⇒ Lou = 5 → clash, impossible. (Rudimentary)

4. Case-check Ewan = 3.  
   • Diddy would have to be at 6, but Diddy must be left of MC (rule 6) → impossible. (Rudimentary)

5. Accept the only remaining value Ewan = 4 and propagate all direct consequences:  
   • Chris = 11 (rule 7)  
   • Diddy = 1 (rule 8, plus “left of MC”)  
   • Lou = 7 (rule 2)  
   • The two immediate neighbours of Ewan (positions 3 and 5) are Robin & Polly (rule 5, order still open). (Rudimentary)

6. Place Mike and Phil using the “gap of eight” rule (3).  
   • Among the still-empty slots, only 2 and 10 are eight apart, so {Mike, Phil} = {2, 10}. (Rudimentary)

7. Take stock: filled positions are  
   1 Diddy 2 Mike/Phil 3 ? 4 Ewan 5 ? 6 MC 7 Lou 8 ? 9 ? 10 Phil/Mike 11 Chris.  
   Unused names: Barb, Gerry, Hugo plus whichever of Robin/Polly is not yet fixed.  
   Open positions: 6, 8, 9. (Rudimentary)

8. Apply the last unsatisfied clues to decide who is MC.  
   • Barb must stand to the right of MC (rule 1) ⇒ Barb cannot be MC.  
   • If MC were Gerry, Gerry > Hugo would force Hugo somewhere left of 6, but every slot there is already occupied ⇒ impossible.  
   • Therefore MC must be Hugo, leaving Barb and Gerry for positions 8 and 9 in either order, with Gerry > Hugo automatically satisfied. (Creative)

9. Finalize the line-up (one example):  
   1 Diddy 2 Mike 3 Polly 4 Ewan 5 Robin 6 Hugo 7 Lou 8 Barb 9 Gerry 10 Phil 11 Chris.  
   All eight original rules hold, so the main culprit is Hugo Phurst. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
One of the most famous logic puzzles is the "Eight Queens puzzle".  The object of this puzzle is to place 8 chess queens on a standard 8x8 chessboard so that no queen can be captured by any of the other queens.
Logically, no queen can share the same row, column, or diagonal with any other queen.
Can you discover an arrangement that works?
Hint: Queens placed, separated like knights, cannot see each other.
Human Solution:
We need to place eight queens so that no two share a row, column, or diagonal.  
Because there are exactly eight rows, we may decide to place exactly one queen in each row (and hence also in each column).  
So the task reduces to finding a permutation of the column numbers 1–8 such that no two queens lie on the same diagonal.  
Two positions (r₁,c₁) and (r₂,c₂) are on the same diagonal precisely when either  
• r₁ − c₁ = r₂ − c₂  (main ↘︎ diagonal), or  
• r₁ + c₁ = r₂ + c₂  (anti ↙︎ diagonal).  
Thus we must find a permutation (c₁,…,c₈) of (1,…,8) for rows r = 1,…,8 such that all eight values r − cᵣ are distinct and all eight values r + cᵣ are distinct.

One well-known solution that satisfies these conditions is:

Row 1 → column 1  
Row 2 → column 5  
Row 3 → column 8  
Row 4 → column 6  
Row 5 → column 3  
Row 6 → column 7  
Row 7 → column 2  
Row 8 → column 4  

Written on the board (Q = queen, . = empty square):

Row 1: Q . . . . . . .  
Row 2: . . . . Q . . .  
Row 3: . . . . . . . Q  
Row 4: . . . . . Q . .  
Row 5: . . Q . . . . .  
Row 6: . . . . . . Q .  
Row 7: . Q . . . . . .  
Row 8: . . . Q . . . .  

Checking the diagonal criteria:  
r − c values = {0, −3, −5, −2, 2, −1, 5, 4} — all different.  
r + c values = {2, 7, 11, 10, 8, 13, 9, 12} — all different.  

Therefore no two queens attack each other, so this configuration solves the Eight Queens puzzle.

Final answer: Place queens at (row,column) = (1,1), (2,5), (3,8), (4,6), (5,3), (6,7), (7,2), (8,4).
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 5  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Observe that an 8×8 board has exactly eight rows and eight columns, so decide to place one queen in every row (and therefore also one in every column).  (Creative)  
2. Encode this idea by letting a permutation (c₁,…,c₈) of the numbers 1–8 give the column cᵣ in which the queen in row r is placed.  (Creative)  
3. Translate the diagonal-attack rule into arithmetic: two queens at (r₁,c₁) and (r₂,c₂) share a diagonal exactly when r₁−c₁ = r₂−c₂ (same ↘︎ diagonal) or r₁+c₁ = r₂+c₂ (same ↙︎ diagonal).  (Creative)  
4. Reformulate the puzzle as: “Find a permutation (c₁,…,c₈) such that the eight numbers r−cᵣ are all distinct and the eight numbers r+cᵣ are all distinct.”  (Creative)  
5. Produce one concrete permutation that satisfies these conditions, namely (1,5,8,6,3,7,2,4).  (Creative)  
6. Draw the corresponding chessboard diagram, marking each queen’s square.  (Rudimentary)  
7. Compute the list of r−cᵣ values for this placement: {0, −3, −5, −2, 2, −1, 5, 4}.  (Rudimentary)  
8. Compute the list of r+cᵣ values for this placement: {2, 7, 11, 10, 8, 13, 9, 12}.  (Rudimentary)  
9. Verify that both sets contain eight different numbers, conclude that no two queens attack each other, and state the final positions (1,1), (2,5), (3,8), (4,6), (5,3), (6,7), (7,2), (8,4).  (Rudimentary)

Question:
Three Paley brothers and three Thomson brothers operate a company that manufactures lie detectors.  Three of these six men always tell the truth, and three always tell lies; neither set of brothers consists exclusively of liars.  Some recent statements from the six men are recorded below.  Can you find the six men's full names, and tell which men tell the truth and which tell lies?
1.  Alan:  "Both my brothers tell lies."
2.  Boris:  "Both my brothers tell the truth."
3:  Chuck:  "Alan and Boris are both liars."
4.  Dalman:  "Chuck and I are brothers."
5.  Edwin:  "Boris and I are brothers."
6.  Finney:  "Edwin tells the truth."
7.  Finney:  "Boris is one of the Paleys."
Hint: Can Boris' statement be true?
Human Solution:
Alan Thomson – liar  
Boris Paley – liar  
Chuck Thomson – truth-teller  
Dalman Paley – liar  
Edwin Paley – truth-teller  
Finney Thomson – truth-teller  

Final answer: Alan Thomson (liar); Boris Paley (liar); Chuck Thomson (truth-teller); Dalman Paley (liar); Edwin Paley (truth-teller); Finney Thomson (truth-teller).
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 7

1. Conclude that Alan is a Thomson and labels him a liar. (Rudimentary)  
2. Conclude that Boris is a Paley and labels him a liar. (Rudimentary)  
3. Conclude that Chuck is a Thomson and labels him a truth-teller. (Rudimentary)  
4. Conclude that Dalman is a Paley and labels him a liar. (Rudimentary)  
5. Conclude that Edwin is a Paley and labels him a truth-teller. (Rudimentary)  
6. Conclude that Finney is a Thomson and labels him a truth-teller. (Rudimentary)  
7. Present a final consolidated answer listing each man’s full name and whether he is a truth-teller or liar. (Rudimentary)

Question:
A canal in UK has 13 locks and no water supply at the top.
Each lock loses 7000 L of water when used.
A truck capable of carrying 22 tons of water is rented to bring water from the bottom to the top.
Is the contract reasonable, and why?
Hint: Where are the water losses?
Human Solution:
Think of the flight of 13 locks as a staircase of buckets.

• To raise (or lower) a boat, one “bucket­ful’’ of water (≈ 7 000 L) is let out of the pound immediately above the lock, through the lock chamber, into the pound below.

• That same 7 000 L then becomes the water that will later be used by the next lock down, and so on.

Hence, while the water steps down lock after lock, only the very first pound – the summit pound, above the top lock – finishes the passage with 7 000 L less than it started, and only the very last pound – the bottom pound – finishes with 7 000 L more.  
All of the intermediate pounds both lose and gain exactly one lockful, so their net change is zero.

Therefore

net water lost from the summit when one boat travels the whole flight  
  = one lockful  
  = 7 000 L ≈ 7 t of water

A road tanker that can carry 22 t ≈ 22 000 L can deliver

 22 000 L / 7 000 L ≈ 3 boat-passages’ worth of water

each time it goes up to the summit and tips its load into the top pound.

So one load from the tanker makes good the deficit caused by roughly three complete passages of the flight.  
Provided the traffic is not heavier than that – and canal traffic seldom is – the arrangement will keep the summit pound full.

Thus the haulage contract is perfectly reasonable: a single 22-ton load more than replaces the water actually lost when a boat works through the 13 locks.
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Model the flight of 13 locks as a “staircase of buckets,” creating an analogy to visualize how water moves from pound to pound. – Creative  
2. State that operating one lock requires releasing one lock-ful of water (≈ 7 000 L) from the pound immediately above the lock into the pound below. – Rudimentary  
3. Point out that the same 7 000 L becomes the working water for the next lock down, so after one whole flight only the summit pound is down one lock-ful and the bottom pound is up one; all intermediate pounds break even. – Creative  
4. Deduce that the net loss from the summit per complete boat passage is exactly one lock-ful, i.e. 7 000 L. – Rudimentary  
5. Convert this volume to mass: 7 000 L ≈ 7 t of water. – Rudimentary  
6. Note the tanker’s capacity of 22 t, equivalent to about 22 000 L. – Rudimentary  
7. Calculate how many passages that volume can replace: 22 000 L ÷ 7 000 L ≈ 3 passages. – Rudimentary  
8. Conclude that because one tanker load offsets roughly three boat passages—and typical traffic is lighter—the haulage contract is sufficient and therefore perfectly reasonable. – Creative

2. State that operating one lock requires releasing one lock-ful of water (≈ 7 000 L) from the pound immediately above the lock into the pound below. – Rudimentary  
3. Point out that the same 7 000 L becomes the working water for the next lock down, so after one whole flight only the summit pound is down one lock-ful and the bottom pound is up one; all intermediate pounds break even. – Creative

Question:
X statements below are true.
1. X is 3.
2. If X is 2, then the following statement is false.
3. If X is 2, then the previous statement is true.
4. X is less than 4.
5. X is a square number.
6. If X is less than 3, then the previous statement is false.
7. If X is greater than 2, then the previous statement is false.
Which statements are true?
Hint: All of the statements involve X in them, but some of the statements give direct information about whether they're true or not, and also potential hints for X.
Human Solution:
Because the sentence at the top says “X statements below are true”, the number X must equal the count of true statements among #1-#7.  
Let T(i) denote the truth value of statement i and let N be the number of true statements.

1. S₂ and S₃.  
   • If X ≠ 2 the antecedent “X is 2” is false, so both implications (S₂ and S₃) are automatically true.  
   • If X = 2 they contradict each other (one forces the other to be false and vice-versa).  
   Hence X ≠ 2 and S₂ = S₃ = true.

2. S₆ and S₇.  
   • For X > 2 the antecedent of S₆ (“X < 3”) is false, so S₆ is true.  
     Then S₇ (“If X > 2 then S₆ is false”) becomes false.  
   • For X < 3 the antecedent of S₆ is true, so S₆ is true exactly when S₅ is false; moreover the antecedent of S₇ is false, so S₇ is automatically true.  
   Trying X < 2 leads to at least three true statements (S₂,S₃,S₇) while X would be 0 or 1, impossible.  
   Therefore X > 2, S₆ = true, S₇ = false.

3. Up to now we have S₂,S₃,S₆ true, S₇ false.  Thus N ≥ 3 and X ≥ 3.

4. Check X = 3.  
   S₁ (“X is 3”) and S₄ (“X < 4”) would be true, giving 5 true statements—contradiction.

5. Check X = 4.  
   S₁ false, S₄ false.  
   S₅ (“X is a square number”) is true because 4 is a square.  
   True statements: S₂, S₃, S₅, S₆ → N = 4, matching X.  All statements are consistent.

6. Check X = 5,6,7.  They leave only the three always-true statements (S₂,S₃,S₆) true, so N = 3 ≠ X.

Hence the unique consistent value is X = 4, and the true statements are #2, #3, #5 and #6.

Final answer: Statements 2, 3, 5 and 6 are true.
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Recognize that the opening sentence means “X equals the number of true statements among #1–#7,” and introduce notation N = number of true statements, T(i) = truth value of statement i.  
2. (Creative) Analyze statements 2 and 3: observe that if X ≠ 2 their antecedent “X is 2” is false so both implications are automatically true, whereas if X = 2 they contradict; conclude X ≠ 2 and S₂ = S₃ = true.  
3. (Creative) Analyze statements 6 and 7 by splitting on X > 2 versus X < 3, showing S₆ must be true, S₇ must be false, and X must be greater than 2.  
4. (Rudimentary) Combine the results so far (S₂, S₃, S₆ true) to note at least three statements are true, hence X ≥ 3.  
5. (Rudimentary) Test X = 3: evaluate S₁ and S₄, find five statements would be true, contradicting X = 3; eliminate this case.  
6. (Rudimentary) Test X = 4: check S₁, S₄ are false, S₅ is true; total true statements S₂, S₃, S₅, S₆ gives N = 4, matching X, so this case is consistent.  
7. (Rudimentary) Test X = 5, 6, 7: observe only the always-true S₂, S₃, S₆ remain, giving N = 3 ≠ X, so these values are impossible.  
8. (Rudimentary) Conclude the only consistent value is X = 4 and the true statements are #2, #3, #5, and #6.

['Total Step Count: 8  
Creative ', ' 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Recognize that the opening sentence means “X equals the number of true statements among #1–#7,” and introduce notation N = number of true statements, T(i) = truth value of statement i.  
2. (Creative) Analyze statements 2 and 3: observe that if X ≠ 2 their antecedent “X is 2” is false so both implications are automatically true, whereas if X = 2 they contradict; conclude X ≠ 2 and S₂ = S₃ = true.  
3. (Creative) Analyze statements 6 and 7 by splitting on X > 2 versus X < 3, showing S₆ must be true, S₇ must be false, and X must be greater than 2.  
4. (Rudimentary) Combine the results so far (S₂, S₃, S₆ true) to note at least three statements are true, hence X ≥ 3.  
5. (Rudimentary) Test X = 3: evaluate S₁ and S₄, find five statements would be true, contradicting X = 3; eliminate this case.  
6. (Rudimentary) Test X = 4: check S₁, S₄ are false, S₅ is true; total true statements S₂, S₃, S₅, S₆ gives N = 4, matching X, so this case is consistent.  
7. (Rudimentary) Test X = 5, 6, 7: observe only the always-true S₂, S₃, S₆ remain, giving N = 3 ≠ X, so these values are impossible.  
8. (Rudimentary) Conclude the only consistent value is X = 4 and the true statements are #2, #3, #5, and #6.']

Question:
Your sister has jetted off to Europe on holiday and has left you to watch over her house and feed the cats. She is very protective over her precious cats and, hence, has a high-tech alarm system which requires a 10-digit code to deactivate it. Unfortunately, you have forgotten the code to disarm the alarm! Oddly however, you remember some mathematical facts about them...
Can you figure it out in time to feed the hungry cats?!?
* Each digit from 0 to 9 is used once only in the code.
* The sum of the numbers in the 3rd and 4th positions is equal to the product of the numbers in the 6th and 9th positions.
* The product of the numbers in the 5th and 10th positions is odd.
* The 2nd number (i.e. the number in the 2nd position) is larger than the 5th, which is larger than the 7th.
* The 8th number is larger than the 6th, which is larger than the 2nd.
* The sum of the 2nd, 6th, and 9th numbers is a perfect square.
* The sum of the 4th and 9th numbers is equal to the 10th number.
* The sum of the 1st and 5th numbers is equal to the sum of the 7th and 10th numbers.
* The number in the 9th position is even.
Hint: The number in the 9th position is 4.
Human Solution: Final answer: 8275130649

Question:
There was a new and very popular Emperor in a small country in the Pacific Ocean.  The country consisted of two small islands 3 miles apart.  The only way to get to the other island was an old, small ferry boat. The new Emperor was very progressive and wanted to shape up the community to attract tourists and hopefully new residents to stop the population from shrinking.
He decided to connect the islands by a new bridge.  Everyone knew the job would be difficult and dangerous, and when he put out the word only two companies were even willing to attempt it.
Company A was the first to offer and said they could do it for $800,000.  When the Emperor told the contractor of Company B what Company A offered, the contractor of Company B said they could not do it for less than $1,000,000. The Emperor took a while to think it over.  Contractor B, being very smart and confident, came back to the Emperor and said, "Sir, I will give you an offer you cannot refuse.  The decision is completely up to you in the end, but you can pay me $200,000, $750,000, or $1,000,000 for the job."  Contractor B proceeded with his details and the Emperor immediately accepted his offer.  Company B ended up being paid $1,000,000 for the job. Contractor B did not lie, cheat, or swindle the Emperor in any way.  He is a very honest businessman.
Why did Company B's offer sound so good to the Emperor, and more importantly, how did Company B end up with the highest amount?
Hint:
2 Hints:
1. Company A is part of Company B's idea.
2. Use your math and accounting skills
Human Solution:
Step-by-step reasoning  

1.  Company B really did need a million dollars to make a profit on such a dangerous job, so at first he truthfully told the Emperor that he “could not do it for less than $1 000 000”.  

2.  He realised, however, that the Emperor hesitated because another firm had quoted only $800 000.  
   The Emperor wanted the bridge but he also wanted to feel safe from being over-charged.

3.  So B framed the price in a different way.  
   He said: “I’ll build the whole bridge exactly to the specifications you gave both firms.  
   When I am finished you – and you alone – may decide what the work was worth and pay me

        • $200 000 if you think the work is poor,  
        • $750 000 if you think it is merely acceptable, or  
        • $1 000 000 if you think it is excellent.”

   In other words all the risk lay on B’s shoulders and all the power of decision lay with the Emperor.  
   From the Emperor’s point of view that was an “offer he could not refuse”: he could always pay less
   than Company A’s $800 000 if he felt disappointed.

4.  Contractor B then built an outstanding bridge – on time, on budget, beautifully finished and strong
    enough for heavy vehicles.  

5.  At the end the Emperor had to choose a payment.  
    – Paying only $200 000 would have been blatantly unfair.  
    – Paying $750 000 would still have meant under-paying a man who had taken a big risk and had succeeded brilliantly, and it would have broadcast to every other potential investor that the ruler of the islands
      was willing to short-change honest contractors.  
    – Paying the full $1 000 000 was the only honest choice and the best advertisement for the islands’ new, fair-dealing image.

6.  Because the Emperor was a fair and forward-looking ruler, he paid the million dollars.  
    Contractor B had neither lied nor cheated; he had simply relied on the Emperor’s integrity and on the
    value the Emperor put on his own reputation.

Thus the offer sounded irresistible because the Emperor seemed to hold all the cards, and Company B ended up with the highest amount because the Emperor, after seeing the finished product and thinking about his reputation, voluntarily chose to pay the full $1 000 000.

Final answer: Company B let the Emperor choose the payment after the bridge was finished ($200 000 if poor, $750 000 if merely adequate, $1 000 000 if excellent).  The risk-free offer sounded perfect, the bridge turned out superb, and the fair-minded Emperor paid the full $1 000 000, so B got the highest amount without any deceit at all.
Response:
Total Step Count: 6  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Company B honestly stated it needed $1 000 000 to profit, so that was its initial quote. – Rudimentary  
2. Company B noticed the Emperor’s hesitation because Company A’s bid was only $800 000 and the Emperor feared being over-charged. – Rudimentary  
3. Company B invented a risk-reversing price scheme: after the bridge was finished the Emperor alone could pay $200 000 (poor work), $750 000 (adequate work), or $1 000 000 (excellent work). This guaranteed the Emperor could never pay more than he felt the bridge was worth and could even pay less than $800 000. – Creative  
4. Company B then built an outstanding, on-time, high-quality bridge that met or exceeded all specifications. – Rudimentary  
5. When choosing the payment, the Emperor judged that $200 000 or $750 000 would be unfair and damage his reputation for fair dealing, whereas $1 000 000 matched the bridge’s quality and showed integrity. – Rudimentary  
6. The Emperor therefore paid the full $1 000 000, so Company B received the highest amount without any deceit. – Rudimentary

This guaranteed the Emperor could never pay more than he felt the bridge was worth and could even pay less than $800 000. – Creative

Question:
A group of Mad-Ade's friends, although fewer than 10, found a number of Golden kebab tokens which they were able to divide equally among them.
After this division had been done, Norha Bone - one of the friends, suggested that it would be more equitable to divide the Golden kebab tokens by families rather than by individuals. Among them, there were two groups with two sisters; of course Norha Bone was not in either group. The rest of the friends were unrelated to each other. A re-division by families would have meant that the Golden kebab tokens per family were 5 more than the Golden kebab tokens per friend.
The friends argued among themselves over this way of dividing the Golden kebab tokens. Before a final decision is made, Wendy Boatkumsin - one of the friends, decided that she did not want any Golden kebab tokens. Her share was equally divided (without breaking/cutting any Kebab token) among the other friends.
Finally, Norha Bone decided to withdraw her suggestion of dividing the Golden kebab tokens by families.
How many friends were there and how many Golden kebab tokens did each friend end up with?
Hint:
Let's assume that N is the number of Golden kebab tokens each friend received initially and G is the total number of friends.
Then, total number of Golden kebab tokens = NG. Continue from there by writing everything else mathematically
Human Solution:
Let  

n  = number of friends (n < 10)  
G  = total number of Golden kebab tokens  
q  = tokens each friend first received (so G = n q)  

1.  “By families” there would be two pairs of sisters (4 people) counted as two families, while every other friend is a one–person family.  
    Therefore  

        number of families  m = n – 2.

2.  The statement ­“tokens per family were 5 more than the tokens per friend’’ gives

        G / m  =  G / n  + 5
        n q /(n–2) = q + 5.

    Multiply by (n–2):

        n q = (q + 5)(n – 2)
        n q = q n + 5n – 2q – 10
        0   = 5n – 2q – 10
        2q  = 5(n – 2)
        q   = (5/2)(n – 2).

    Hence n – 2 must be even → n is even and < 10 ⇒ n = 6 or 8.

3.  If n = 6 then q = (5/2)(4) = 10, so G = 6·10 = 60.  
    If n = 8 then q = (5/2)(6) = 15, so G = 8·15 = 120.

4.  Wendy Boatkumsin gives up her q tokens, which have to be split equally among the remaining n–1 friends.  
    Thus q must be divisible by n–1.

        For n = 6:  n–1 = 5,  q = 10, and 10 ÷ 5 = 2  (works).  
        For n = 8:  n–1 = 7,  q = 15, and 15 ÷ 7 is not integral (fails).

    Therefore n = 6 is the only possible size of the group.

5.  Final division.  
    Wendy’s 10 tokens are shared 2 apiece among the other 5 friends, so each of those friends now holds

        10 + 2 = 12 tokens.

    Wendy keeps none.

So there were 6 friends in all, and after the final redistribution every friend who kept tokens ended up with 12 Golden kebab tokens.

Final answer: 6 friends, and (apart from Wendy, who took none) each friend finished with 12 Golden kebab tokens.
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 9  

Steps:  
1. Introduce variables: n = number of friends (<10); G = total Golden kebab tokens; q = tokens each friend first received, giving the relation G = n q.  
2. Translate the “by families” information into an equation: because two pairs of sisters become two families (instead of four separate people), the number of families is m = n – 2.  
3. Express “tokens per family were 5 more than the tokens per friend” as G/m = G/n + 5 and, substituting G = n q and m = n – 2, obtain n q/(n – 2) = q + 5.  
4. Manipulate the equation algebraically to get q = (5/2)(n – 2).  
5. Conclude that n – 2 must be even, and with n < 10 this forces n to be either 6 or 8.  
6. For n = 6, compute q = 10 and G = 60; for n = 8, compute q = 15 and G = 120.  
7. Use Wendy’s withdrawal (her share must split evenly among the other n – 1 friends) to require q divisible by n – 1; check the two cases and discover only n = 6 satisfies this condition.  
8. Perform the final redistribution for n = 6: Wendy’s 10 tokens are divided equally among the other 5 friends, adding 2 each, so each remaining friend now has 10 + 2 = 12 tokens.  
9. Summarize the result: there were 6 friends in total, and after all adjustments each friend who kept tokens ended with 12 Golden kebab tokens (Wendy kept none).

['Total Step Count: 9

3. Express “tokens per family were 5 more than the tokens per friend” as G/m = G/n + 5 and, substituting G = n q and m = n – 2, obtain n q/(n – 2) = q + 5.

Question:
Professor Abacus has scrambled the numerals 0 through 9 to form a 10-digit security code.  Each numeral is used only once.  Given the following clues, what is the security code?
1) The 4th and 5th digits form a triangle number.
2) The 5th and 6th digits form a prime number.
3) The 8th digit is three more than the 2nd digit.
4) The 10th digit is less than the 1st digit.
5) The sum of the 1st and 6th digits is twice the 9th digit.
6) The sum of the 3rd, 6th, and 9th digits equals 14.
7) There are three digits between the numerals 8 and 9.
8) There are no more than four digits between the numerals 1 and 4.
9) The numeral 5 is somewhere in the first five positions.
Hint: Start by combining hints 1 and 2
Human Solution: Final answer: 9452831760
Response:
Total Step Count: 1  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 1  

Steps:  
1. State the final 10-digit code as 9452831760.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 1  
Creative ', ' 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 1  

Steps:  
1. State the final 10-digit code as 9452831760.']

Question:
Hi. My name is mister Kvakk. I live in a very big house in the country. Outside my house I have a lot of big gardens. In one of them I have hundreds of beautiful, delicious, red flowers.
At my house, my dog is waiting. I have told him about this flower-heaven-garden with hundreds of flowers, and it really wants to find that garden to eat the flowers (yes, my dog eats flowers).
However, this flower-heaven is far away, and my dog wants to go there as soon as possible. It has to travel through some other gardens on its way, but it wants to travel between as few other gardens as possible.
Your mission is to find the best route for my dog, from my house to the flower-heaven. The dog wants to go through as few gardens as possible on its way.
Here are some facts about my gardens:
1. There are two gardens between my (mister Kvakk's) house and the house of my neighbour Quack, if you take the shortest route.
2. The only garden between The lawn and Soria is The field
3. It's one garden between The field and flower-heaven
4. One possible route (but not the shortest) from Kvakk to flower-heaven, is: The pool, Soria, Star, The mountain
5. To go from Kvakk to Quack as fast as possible, you don't need to go through The field, The forest, The angels valley or Star
6. You can go from The forest to The mountain by going through Longo
7. Duck country and The forest are my only two gardens that lie against Quack's house
8. From the garden The field, you can go directly to The lawn, Longo, The pool, Soria, Star and Kvakk's house
9. There are two gardens between Quack and flower-heaven. These are not the same gardens that are between Kvakk and Quack
10. Quack's house is to the east of Kvakk's house
11. Flower-heaven is south-west of Quack's house
12. Except for the two houses and flower-heaven, ten gardens of different size and shape are named in this teaser
13. You can go into flower-heaven from three different gardens
14. If you are at Star, you must go through one garden to come to flower-heaven
15. Star, The lawn, The mountain, The pool, Soria, The forest, Duck Country and the two houses lie beside the sea. It is not possible for the dog to travel through the sea. Luckily, no other gardens lie beside the sea.
16. The angel's valley is between flower-heaven and The forest
Through which gardens should my dog travel?
Hint: It's easiest to solve this if you try to draw a kind of map. You should maybe start by using the information points in this order: 1, 10, 7, 9, 11, 4, 5, 6, 8
Human Solution:
With all the conditions satisfied, the unique shortest route starts at Kvakk’s house, goes through only one garden – The Pool – and then enters flower-heaven.

Final answer: Kvakk’s house → The Pool → flower-heaven
Response:
Total Step Count: 3  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 1  

Steps:  
1. Observe that, when every given condition is taken into account, there is exactly one shortest path (in terms of “fewest gardens visited”) from Kvakk’s house to flower-heaven.  (Creative)  
2. Deduce that this unique shortest path leaves Kvakk’s house, passes through only the garden called “The Pool,” and from there enters flower-heaven.  (Creative)  
3. State the resulting route explicitly: Kvakk’s house → The Pool → flower-heaven.  (Rudimentary)

3. State the resulting route explicitly: Kvakk’s house → The Pool → flower-heaven.  (Rudimentary)']

Question:
In a far away land, it was known that if you drank poison, the only way to save yourself is to drink a stronger poison, which neutralizes the weaker poison. The king that ruled the land wanted to make sure that he possessed the strongest poison in the kingdom, in order to ensure his survival, in any situation. So the king called the kingdom's pharmacist and the kingdom's treasurer, he gave each a week to make the strongest poison. Then, each would drink the other one's poison, then his own, and the one that will survive, will be the one that had the stronger poison.
The pharmacist went straight to work, but the treasurer knew he had no chance, for the pharmacist was much more experienced in this field, so instead, he made up a plan to survive and make sure the pharmacist dies. On the last day the pharmacist suddenly realized that the treasurer would know he had no chance, so he must have a plan. After a little thought, the pharmacist realized what the treasurer's plan must be, and he concocted a counter plan, to make sure he survives and the treasurer dies. When the time came, the king summoned both of them. They drank the poisons as planned, and the treasurer died, the pharmacist survived, and the king didn't get what he wanted.
What exactly happened there?
Hint: Focus on the fact that stronger poison neutralizes weak poison
Human Solution:
Let ‘strength’ mean “ability to neutralize all poisons that are weaker than it”.  
Water has strength 0, and the bigger the number, the stronger the poison.

1.  The treasurer’s original idea  
   • He brews nothing more than water, but calls it his “poison”. (strength = 0)  
   • A short time before the audience he secretly swallows a minute dose of a very
     weak real poison T (strength = 1).  
   At the audience the order of drinks is

        (a) each man drinks the other one’s “poison”,
        (b) each man then drinks his own.

   – The pharmacist would drink the treasurer’s water (0) first.  
     No poison is in him yet.  
   – He would then drink his own very strong poison P (say strength = 100).  
     Because there was no weaker poison to neutralize, P would kill him.  

   – The treasurer would drink the pharmacist’s strong poison P (100) first.  
     P is stronger than the T = 1 already in his body, so it wipes T out and
     becomes harmless.  
   – He next drinks his own “poison” – which is only water (0); nothing further
     happens and he lives.  

   Thus, if nothing else happened, the treasurer would survive and the pharmacist
   would die.

2.  What the pharmacist realised and did  
   The pharmacist guessed exactly this ploy: the treasurer would come with water
   and would already have a very weak poison in his body.  
   So the pharmacist arranged a new hierarchy of strengths:

        water  = 0   <   his own ultra-weak poison P₁ = ½   <  
        treasurer’s weak poison T = 1   <   ordinary strong poisons …

   • A few hours before the meeting the pharmacist secretly drank an infinitesimal
     dose of an even weaker poison P₀ (strength = ¼).  
   • For the contest he prepared the barely-stronger poison P₁ (strength = ½) and
     handed that to the treasurer.

3.  The actual drinking

   Treasurer
     – Drinks P₁ (½) first.  
       P₁ is not strong enough to neutralize the T = 1 already in his body, so T
       keeps working.  
     – Drinks his own “poison” (water, 0).  
       Still nothing is stronger than T, so T kills him.

   Pharmacist
     – Drinks the treasurer’s “poison” (water, 0) first; nothing happens.  
     – Drinks his own P₁ (½).  
       P₁ is stronger than the P₀ = ¼ that he took beforehand, so it neutralizes
       P₀ and then becomes harmless.  
       He survives.

4.  Result  
   The treasurer dies, the pharmacist lives, and the king is left without the
   “strongest poison in the kingdom”.

Final answer:  
The treasurer planned to give the pharmacist plain water and to keep himself
alive by having swallowed a tiny dose of weak poison earlier; the pharmacist
guessed this, secretly swallowed an even weaker poison beforehand, and gave the
treasurer a poison just slightly stronger than that.  
When they drank, the treasurer’s earlier poison was never neutralized and killed
him, while the pharmacist’s slightly stronger poison neutralized the infinitesimally
weak dose he had taken and left him unharmed.
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Define “strength” of a poison as its ability to neutralize any weaker poison (water = strength 0, larger number = stronger). [Rudimentary]  

2. Treasurer’s plan: bring plain water as his official “poison” (strength 0) and secretly swallow a minute dose of a very weak real poison T (strength 1) shortly before the test. [Creative]  

3. Deduce the outcome if only the treasurer’s plan were executed: the pharmacist would first drink water (nothing happens) and then his own very strong poison P, which would kill him; the treasurer would first drink P, which neutralizes T, and then his own water, so he survives. [Rudimentary]  

4. Pharmacist anticipates exactly this stratagem by the treasurer. [Creative]  

5. Pharmacist’s counter-plan: he secretly takes an even weaker poison P₀ (strength ¼) beforehand and prepares a barely stronger poison P₁ (strength ½) to hand to the treasurer, setting up the order 0 < ¼ < ½ < 1. [Creative]  

6. Show what happens to the treasurer at the contest: he drinks P₁ (½) which is not strong enough to neutralize the T = 1 already in him; after he drinks his own water nothing stronger than T is present, so T kills him. [Rudimentary]  

7. Show what happens to the pharmacist: he drinks the treasurer’s water (0) and then his own P₁ (½), which wipes out the P₀ (¼) he had taken earlier and becomes harmless, so he survives. [Rudimentary]  

8. Conclude: the treasurer dies, the pharmacist lives, and the king still lacks the “strongest poison in the kingdom.” [Rudimentary]

['Total Step Count: 8

Rudimentary Steps: 5

2. Treasurer’s plan: bring plain water as his official “poison” (strength 0) and secretly swallow a minute dose of a very weak real poison T (strength 1) shortly before the test. [Creative]  

3. Deduce the outcome if only the treasurer’s plan were executed: the pharmacist would first drink water (nothing happens) and then his own very strong poison P, which would kill him; the treasurer would first drink P, which neutralizes T, and then his own water, so he survives. [Rudimentary]
