Question:
Use the numbers 1 to 4 in each column and row, and then add 0, 1, or 2 zeros after each number that needs it so that the numbers add up to the numbers listed below the grid.
X A B C D
1. _ _ _ _
2. _ _ _ _
3. _ _ _ _
4. _ _ _ _
Rows:
1. 640
2. 442
3. 55
4. 442
Columns:
A. 316
B. 433
C. 280
D. 550
Hint: Think digit-by-digit. Consider the ones digit first (look at all the 0's!)
Human Solution:
Let every entry of the 4 × 4 grid be

 digit × 10ᵏ  (digit = 1,2,3,4 and k = 0,1,2).

Because each row (and column) must contain every digit 1–4 exactly once, decide first which entry of each row will carry two zeros (hundreds), which will carry one zero (tens), and which will stay a one-digit number (units) so that every row total is met.

1. Row-sums analysis  
   • Row 3 is only 55 ⇒ it can contain no hundreds; it must consist of two tens and two units.  
     55 = 20 + 30 + 1 + 4 or 40 + 10 + 2 + 3.  
     Choose the first possibility (it will fit the column totals later).  
   • Row 2 and Row 4 are 442 each.  
     442 = 400 + 30 + 10 + 2 or 300 + 100 + 40 + 2.  
     Take one of each form so that we have a good mix of hundreds.  
   • Row 1 is 640.  
     640 = 400 + 200 + 30 + 10.

   Thus the four rows can be taken as

      {400,200, 30, 10}       (sum 640)  
      {400, 30, 10,  2}       (sum 442)  
      { 30, 20,  1,  4}       (sum 55)  
      {300,100, 40,  2}       (sum 442)

2. Put the 400 + 100 + 30 + 20 pattern into one column to reach the largest
   column total 550:

              D-column → 400, 30, 20, 100  (sum 550).

3. Fill the remaining numbers so that every column still gets one of each
   digit and the announced column sums (316, 433, 280) are reached.
   One consistent arrangement is

             A       B       C       D
      1   10(1)   30(3)  200(2)  400(4)   → 640
      2    2(2)  400(4)   10(1)   30(3)   → 442
      3    4(4)    1(1)   30(3)   20(2)   → 55
      4  300(3)    2(2)   40(4)  100(1)   → 442
          -------------------------------------
          316     433     280     550

   (The digit of each entry is written in parentheses; the zeros appended
   turn it into the shown value.)

• Every row and every column contains the digits 1, 2, 3, 4 once.
• Row totals are 640, 442, 55, 442.
• Column totals are 316, 433, 280, 550.

All conditions are satisfied.

Final answer:  

A  B  C  D  
10 30 200 400  
2  400 10  30  
4  1  30  20  
300 2  40 100
Response:
Total Step Count: 10  
Creative Steps: 5  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. (Creative)  Formalize each cell as  digit × 10ᵏ with digit ∈ {1,2,3,4} and k ∈ {0,1,2} (units, tens, hundreds), while keeping the rule that every row and column must contain each digit exactly once.  

2. (Creative)  Examine Row 3 (sum 55): since 55 has no hundreds, Row 3 must have exactly two tens and two units.  List the two feasible partitions, 20 + 30 + 1 + 4 and 40 + 10 + 2 + 3, and choose 20 + 30 + 1 + 4 because it will fit the column totals more easily later.  

3. (Creative)  Analyse Rows 2 and 4 (sum 442 each): the only partitions with the allowed digits are 400 + 30 + 10 + 2 and 300 + 100 + 40 + 2.  Decide to use one of each form so the set of hundreds (400,300,100) is nicely distributed.  

4. (Rudimentary)  Decompose Row 1 (sum 640) as 400 + 200 + 30 + 10, the only viable breakdown with digits 1–4.  

5. (Rudimentary)  Record the four row-value sets obtained so far:  
 {400,200,30,10}, {400,30,10,2}, {30,20,1,4}, {300,100,40,2}.  

6. (Creative)  Notice that the column total that has to reach 550 can be achieved neatly by combining 400 + 100 + 30 + 20; decide to place exactly those four numbers in the same column.  

7. (Rudimentary)  Choose Column D for that combination and slot 400, 30, 20, 100 into the four rows accordingly.  

8. (Creative)  Arrange the remaining numbers in Columns A, B, C so that (i) every column still has the digits 1–4 once each and (ii) the column sums hit 316, 433, 280.  A consistent placement is:  
 Row 1: 10, 30, 200 | Row 2: 2, 400, 10 | Row 3: 4, 1, 30 | Row 4: 300, 2, 40.  

9. (Rudimentary)  Check that all row totals (640, 442, 55, 442) and column totals (316, 433, 280, 550) are satisfied and that each digit appears exactly once in every row and column.  

10. (Rudimentary)  Present the final grid:  
 A  B  C  D  
 10  30  200 400  
 2   400  10  30  
 4   1   30  20  
 300 2   40  100

Question:
Mary Beem, who was a wife, mother of four and grandmother of nine, was shot to death by an angry relative. Find out the name of the relative it was by piecing together the relationships of each person with the clues below.
The killer's sister was suspicious of her sibling and confirmed her distrust by talking to three people: her grandfather Bob, her cousin Bo, and her uncle (blood relative) Bill. She called the police, and the suspect was apprehended at the victim's funeral service. Only the direct descendants and their spouses were present. (Note: None of Mary's grandchildren were married or had kids, and no two people have the same first name.)
1. Bill was talking with his brother-in-law Barry.
2. Bart, Buck, and Bruce (who were all brothers) were by their grandmother's casket.
3. Mary's daughter May, who was with her husband Ben, had their two children: Missy and Bernie.
4. Mo, Bob's son-in-law, was comforting his wife Robin, and both were keeping an eye on their sons.
5. Bo was by himself in a corner grieving, while his sister Molly was talking with their cousin Megan.
6. Myra was consoling one of her two children, Brad, who had been very close to his grandmother.
7. Bob was with his daughter Maria.
NOTE: Each of the 4 couples has at least 2 kids.
WHO IS THE KILLER?
Hint:
Draw a family tree.
Each of the 4 children of Mary Beem has a spouse, and each couple has children.  Since all must have at least two kids, only one couple has three kids (a total of 9 grandchildren).
Human Solution: Final answer: Bernie
Response:
Total Step Count: 1  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 1  

Steps:  
1. State the conclusion that the killer is Bernie.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 1  
Creative ', ' 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 1  

Steps:  
1. State the conclusion that the killer is Bernie.']

Question:
During one meeting with a clan of ninjas, it has been noticed that more ninjas have turned up to the meeting than usual. The ninjas realised that these infiltrators must be the enemy of the ninjas (the pirates). Each person dressed as a ninja at the meeting made a statement. The cunning ninjas lied about their fellow ninjas in order to remain secret and told the truth about the pirates. The pirates tried to mock the cunningness by lying about the pirates and telling the truth about the ninjas. From the following statements, can you identify the ninjas and pirates?
Ninja A: Ninja B is a ninja
Ninja B: Ninja C belongs to Ninja A's group
Ninja C: Ninja C doesn't belong to Ninja F's group
Ninja D: Ninja A belongs to Ninja B's group
Ninja E: Ninja B belongs to Ninja C's group
Ninja F: Ninja E belongs to Ninja A's group
Remember, the ninjas and pirates will lie about individual ninjas or pirates, not groups of ninjas or pirates.
Hint: Think about what Ninja A said, first.
Human Solution:
Final answer:  
Ninjas – B, C, F  
Pirates – A, D, E
Response:

Question:
T4 has a chart in his possession. On it says:
1 stands for O, U, D, or B
2 stands for S, K, Q, or T
3 stands for I, H, E, or N
4 stands for O, I, F, or W
5 stands for Z, U, Y, or S
6 stands for I, L, E, or C
Below that, he wrote the number "123456." This number, using the decryption method above, can mean two words that are antonyms. What are the two words?
Hint: One is the word "useful".
Human Solution:
The six-digit number 1 2 3 4 5 6 must be translated by choosing, for every digit, one of the four letters assigned to it:

1 → O / U / D / B  
2 → S / K / Q / T  
3 → I / H / E / N  
4 → O / I / F / W  
5 → Z / U / Y / S  
6 → I / L / E / C  

A word produced in this way has form  
(1)-(2)-(3)-(4)-(5)-(6).

Searching for ordinary English words that fit this pattern gives, among others,

U S E F U L  → USEFUL  
O T I O S E  → OTIOSE  

• U = 1, S = 2, E = 3, F = 4, U = 5, L = 6  
• O = 1, T = 2, I = 3, O = 4, S = 5, E = 6  

“Useful” and “otiose” are antonyms: useful means “serving a purpose,” while otiose means “serving no practical purpose; useless.”

Final answer: USEFUL and OTIOSE
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Copy the digit-to-letter chart so that each position of the six-digit code (1-2-3-4-5-6) is associated with its four possible letters. (Rudimentary)  

2. Realize that any valid decoding of 1-2-3-4-5-6 must be a six-letter English word whose first letter comes from the 1-set, second letter from the 2-set, and so on. (Rudimentary)  

3. Systematically search a word list (or mentally scan vocabulary) for ordinary English words matching this positional constraint; two such hits are “USEFUL” and “OTIOSE.” (Rudimentary)  

4. Observe that “useful” and “otiose” have opposite meanings—one denotes having a practical purpose, the other denotes having none—so they are antonyms and fulfill the puzzle’s requirement. (Creative)  

5. Verify that each letter of both words indeed corresponds to the correct digit in the original chart, then state the final answer. (Rudimentary)

Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Copy the digit-to-letter chart so that each position of the six-digit code (1-2-3-4-5-6) is associated with its four possible letters. (Rudimentary)  

2. Realize that any valid decoding of 1-2-3-4-5-6 must be a six-letter English word whose first letter comes from the 1-set, second letter from the 2-set, and so on. (Rudimentary)  

3. Systematically search a word list (or mentally scan vocabulary) for ordinary English words matching this positional constraint; two such hits are “USEFUL” and “OTIOSE.” (Rudimentary)

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
) stands for T, E, S, A, or L
< stands for F, E, C, R, or P
> stands for E, R, L, K, or S
[ stands for F, S, E, D, or R
] stands for W, M, J, U, or Y
( stands for N, A, H, O, or B
The six letter code word, <([])>, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Attire
Human Solution: Final answer: FORMAL and CASUAL

Question:
Mad Ade was looking after his two year old Nephew (He charges two Kebabs an hour if you are in need of a babysitter).
His Nephew had 4 play blocks each with 6 sides. Each side has a letter from the alphabet. No letters are ever repeated. By arranging the blocks in different ways Mad Ade's nephew managed (By complete and utter fluke) to spell all the words listed below:
BODY
MAZE
CURT
MOVE
DRAW
NOTE
FEAR
PICK
HUNT
QUIT
JOKE
SNOB
KNEW
TYPE
LIFE
Now Mad Ade is relatively simple and missed the potential teaser in the situation, his mind firmly fixed on the Kebabs he was earning.
Can you figure out how the letters are arranged on the 4 blocks?
Hint: There are 7 words with letter 'E' - MAZE, MOVE, NOTE, FEAR, JOKE, KNEW, TYPE, LIFE. It means that none of the letters in these 7 words can be on the same block as the letter 'E'. Hence, the other 5 letters must be from B, C, D, H, Q, S, U.
Human Solution:
First give every letter a “home cube”.  
The only rule is:  if two letters ever appear in the same word they must live on different cubes.  
Because 15 four-letter words are involved, every word must end up with its four letters on the four different cubes.

STEP 1 – put the letter E somewhere first.  
E occurs with fifteen different letters, so it can share a cube only with  
{B,C,D,H,I,Q,S,U}.  
Choose five of these that never meet each other in any of the words;  
the set {C,D,H,Q,S} works.  
So

Cube A :  C  D  E  H  Q  S

STEP 2 – colour the remaining 18 letters (they must occupy Cubes B, C, D, six per cube).

Start with the word BODY.  Put  
B on Cube B, O on Cube C, Y on Cube D.

Work through the words, using the fact that every word must be a “rainbow”
(one letter on each cube).  Each time a cube for one letter is fixed, the
other letters of the same word are forced onto the other two cubes.  
Proceeding word by word gives the unique consistent placements

Cube B :  B  T  K  A  L  V  
Cube C :  O  U  P  W  F  Z  
Cube D :  Y  N  I  J  R  M

STEP 3 – check every word:  

BODY (B,Cube B; O,C; D,A; Y,D) – four different cubes ✓  
MAZE (M,D; A,B; Z,C; E,A) ✓  
CURT (C,A; U,C; R,D; T,B) ✓  
… and similarly all the other twelve words – all use the four cubes once each.

Since every cube now holds exactly six different letters and every pair of
letters that ever appears together is on different cubes, the arrangement is
valid and, in fact, the only possible one.

Thus the four blocks must carry the following letters (order on the faces is
irrelevant – only the six letters per cube matter):

Block 1 :  C  D  E  H  Q  S  
Block 2 :  A  B  K  L  T  V  
Block 3 :  F  O  P  U  W  Z  
Block 4 :  I  J  M  N  R  Y

Final answer:  
Block 1 – C D E H Q S Block 2 – A B K L T V Block 3 – F O P U W Z Block 4 – I J M N R Y
Response:
Total Step Count: 6  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Derive the guiding rule: any two letters that ever appear together in a word must lie on different cubes, so every 4-letter word must be a “rainbow” (one letter per cube).  
2. (Creative) Pick a starting anchor: choose the highly connected letter E, list the few letters it never meets ({B,C,D,H,I,Q,S,U}), and pick five of those that also never meet one another ({C,D,H,Q,S}); place E and those five on Cube A.  
3. (Rudimentary) Begin colouring the remaining letters by selecting one word—BODY—and assigning B to Cube B, O to Cube C, Y to Cube D (since D is already on Cube A).  
4. (Rudimentary) Process the rest of the words sequentially, each time forcing their letters onto the only cubes still free for them, until every letter is placed, yielding  
   • Cube B: B T K A L V  
   • Cube C: O U P W F Z  
   • Cube D: Y N I J R M.  
5. (Rudimentary) Check every word against the finished cubes and verify each uses four distinct cubes.  
6. (Rudimentary) Conclude that all 24 letters are now assigned, the arrangement satisfies the rule, and—by exhaustion of alternatives—is unique; state the final block make-up.

['Total Step Count: 6  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Derive the guiding rule: any two letters that ever appear together in a word must lie on different cubes, so every 4-letter word must be a “rainbow” (one letter per cube).  
2. (Creative) Pick a starting anchor: choose the highly connected letter E, list the few letters it never meets ({B,C,D,H,I,Q,S,U}), and pick five of those that also never meet one another ({C,D,H,Q,S}); place E and those five on Cube A.  
3. (Rudimentary) Begin colouring the remaining letters by selecting one word—BODY—and assigning B to Cube B, O to Cube C, Y to Cube D (since D is already on Cube A).  
4. (Rudimentary) Process the rest of the words sequentially, each time forcing their letters onto the only cubes still free for them, until every letter is placed, yielding  
   • Cube B: B T K A L V  
   • Cube C: O U P W F Z  
   • Cube D: Y N I J R M.  
5. (Rudimentary) Check every word against the finished cubes and verify each uses four distinct cubes.  
6. (Rudimentary) Conclude that all 24 letters are now assigned, the arrangement satisfies the rule, and—by exhaustion of alternatives—is unique; state the final block make-up.']

Question:
Captain John is the captain of a pirate ship called the "Wasp".  He just heard about a lost treasure on a far away island.  He needs to get his two crew mates, and lead them to a ship, but there are guards around and he needs to do this without passing them, or they will throw him in the brig.  Can you help him get his two crew mates to the ship without getting sent to the brig?
The positions of everything are in a 3-by-3 grid (1 John, 1 ship, 2 crew mates, 2 guards, and 3 grass areas).  John may only move 1 space at a time, either vertically, horizontally, or diagonally.  He can only go to each space once.
But before he can figure out the right way to go, he must figure out where everything is.  This is what he knew:
1. The Wasp is not in the same row or column as John.
2.  John is not in the same row or column as either guard.
3.  Neither guard is in the third column.
4.  Both guards are vertically next to grass.
5.  The ship is in the same row as one guard, and the same column as the other guard.
6.  One of the grass spaces is diagonally next to both crew mates.
7.  One of the grass spaces is in the 2nd column, in the first row.
8.  The two guards are not in the same row or column.
Hint: Use paper and pencil.
Human Solution:
1.  Fix the square names  
   (row 1 is the top row, column 1 is the left column)

          (1,1) (1,2) (1,3)
          (2,1) (2,2) (2,3)
          (3,1) (3,2) (3,3)

2.  Translate the eight clues

   – Ship not in John’s row or column.  
   – John shares neither row nor column with a guard.  
   – Guards are only in columns 1 or 2 and in different rows/columns.  
   – Every guard has a grass square immediately above or below it.  
   – Ship’s row = row of one guard, ship’s column = column of the other guard.  
   – One grass square is diagonally adjacent to both crew-mates.  
   – (1,2) is grass.  
   – Two guards are in different rows and columns.

3.  Put the “special” grass square

   The grass that is diagonally adjacent to both crew-mates must have at least
   two diagonal neighbours, so it cannot be a corner and (1,2) cannot be that
   grass (one of its diagonal neighbours is already grass).  
   The only square that can work is the centre (2,2).  
   Hence  

        (1,2) = grass     (2,2) = grass

4.  Place the guards

   Each guard needs a vertical grass neighbour.
   Putting one guard in (3,2) satisfies this (its neighbour (2,2) is grass).
   The other guard must be in column 1 and a different row, and needs grass
   under it, so put it in (1,1) with another grass square at (2,1).  
   Guards are now

        Guard1 : (1,1)     Guard2 : (3,2)  
        Grasses : (1,2) , (2,1) , (2,2)

5.  Place the ship

   Ship must share the row of one guard (row 3) and the column of the other
   guard (column 1) → Ship at (3,1).

6.  Place John

   John must be in column 3 (he can’t be in columns 1 or 2) and in the one
   remaining row that is different from both guards’ rows (row 2) → John at
   (2,3).

7.  Place the two crew-mates

   They must be the two remaining corner squares diagonally touching the centre
   grass, i.e. (1,3) and (3,3).

The completed 3 × 3 board

          (1,1)  Guard     (1,2)  Grass     (1,3)  Crew
          (2,1)  Grass     (2,2)  Grass     (2,3)  John
          (3,1)  Ship      (3,2)  Guard     (3,3)  Crew

8.  A route for John

   Starting from (2,3) he may move one square at a time without revisiting a
   square or stepping on a guard:

        (2,3) John  →  (3,3) Crew  →  (2,2) Grass  →
        (1,3) Crew  →  (1,2) Grass →  (2,1) Grass →  (3,1) Ship

   Every rule is obeyed, both crew-mates are collected, and everyone reaches
   the Wasp safely.

Final answer:  

Row 1  Guard  Grass  Crew  
Row 2  Grass  Grass  John  
Row 3  Ship   Guard  Crew
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. Assign coordinate names to the 3 × 3 board squares so every position can be referred to unambiguously. (Rudimentary)  
2. Rewrite the eight narrative clues as precise coordinate constraints on John, the ship, the two guards, the two crew-mates and the three grass squares. (Rudimentary)  
3. Use the “one grass square is diagonally next to both crew-mates” clue to locate this special grass: show that no corner or the given grass at (1,2) can satisfy the requirement, leaving only (2,2). Declare (2,2) grass (along with the given grass at (1,2)). (Creative)  
4. Place the two guards by exploiting the need for a vertical grass neighbour, the ban on column 3, and the requirement that they share neither row nor column: choose (3,2) for one guard (supported by the grass at (2,2)), then put the other guard at (1,1) and add grass at (2,1). (Creative)  
5. Locate the ship using the rule “ship’s row = a guard’s row and ship’s column = the other guard’s column”, yielding the single square (3,1). (Rudimentary)  
6. Position John so he shares no row or column with any guard or the ship: the only remaining suitable square is (2,3). (Rudimentary)  
7. Place the two crew-mates in the only empty squares that are each diagonally adjacent to the centre grass, namely (1,3) and (3,3). (Rudimentary)  
8. Exhibit a legal path for John—(2,3) → (3,3) → (2,2) → (1,3) → (1,2) → (2,1) → (3,1)—that visits every required square once, avoids the guards, picks up both crew-mates and ends at the ship. (Rudimentary)

['Total Step Count: 8  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 6

2. Rewrite the eight narrative clues as precise coordinate constraints on John, the ship, the two guards, the two crew-mates and the three grass squares. (Rudimentary)  
3. Use the “one grass square is diagonally next to both crew-mates” clue to locate this special grass: show that no corner or the given grass at (1,2) can satisfy the requirement, leaving only (2,2). Declare (2,2) grass (along with the given grass at (1,2)). (Creative)  
4. Place the two guards by exploiting the need for a vertical grass neighbour, the ban on column 3, and the requirement that they share neither row nor column: choose (3,2) for one guard (supported by the grass at (2,2)), then put the other guard at (1,1) and add grass at (2,1). (Creative)

Question:
After days and days of placing things, taking things out of boxes, and arranging furniture, Ellen was set to decorate her new apartment.  She carefully unpacked the 18 prints of her favorite artists she had collected for a long time and decided to place them through the five rooms in her humble abode, displaying at least two prints in each room.  The prints show the works of four artists and Ellen owns no more than six prints of each artist's work.  Now that she's put together her new place, Ellen's living space finally feels like home!  From the information provided, can you figure out the number, if any, of Degas, Monet, Pissaro, and Sisley prints Ellen hung in each room?  This one will require a little math...
Rooms:  Kitchen, Parlor, Bedroom, Dining, Den
Artists:  Degas, Monet, Pissaro, Sisley
1.  Ellen mounted the same quantity of pictures in the kitchen as she did in the parlor.  She placed the same amount of Monet images in the bedroom as she did in the parlor.
2.  Ellen mounted at least one Pissaro picture in the dining room.  She didn't mount any prints by Degas or Sisley in the den.
3.  The sum of Sisley prints Ellen had acquired is the same amount as the sum of Degas prints she owns in addition to the sum of the prints she's placed in the den.
4.  The parlor contains fewer pictures than the only room in which three Sisley images were mounted but more prints than the only room in which two Degas prints were hung.
5.  The total number of Monet pictures Ellen owns is the same as the total number of paintings by Degas she owns plus the total number of prints she mounted in the kitchen.  Ellen didn't place any pictures by Monet or Degas in the kitchen.
6.  Ellen didn't mount any Sisley images in the kitchen or Degas pictures in the bedroom.
Hint: It might be easiest to draw out a chart (5 columns (room, Degas, Monet, Pissaro, Sisley) with 5 rows each to get your answer.
Human Solution:
Kitchen – Degas 0, Monet 0, Pissaro 4, Sisley 0  
Parlor – Degas 0, Monet 2, Pissaro 1, Sisley 1  
Bedroom – Degas 0, Monet 2, Pissaro 0, Sisley 3  
Dining Room – Degas 2, Monet 0, Pissaro 1, Sisley 0  
Den – Degas 0, Monet 2, Pissaro 0, Sisley 0  

Final answer: Kitchen 0 D 0 M 4 P 0 S; Parlor 0 D 2 M 1 P 1 S; Bedroom 0 D 2 M 0 P 3 S; Dining 2 D 0 M 1 P 0 S; Den 0 D 2 M 0 P 0 S.
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 5  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Translate the puzzle into variables: for every room/artist combination set an unknown, copy all six written clues, keep “at least two prints per room” and “exactly 18 prints in all” as global constraints.  (Rudimentary)

2. Combine “Parlor has the same number of pictures as Kitchen” (clue 1) with the “≥2-prints-per-room” and 18-print total to show the only feasible room-size pattern is  
 Kitchen = Parlor = 4, Bedroom = 5, Dining = 3, Den = 2.  (Creative)

3. Use clue 4: “Parlor holds fewer pictures than the only room with exactly three Sisleys but more than the only room with two Degas.”  
With the room sizes from step 2 this forces Bedroom to be the 3-Sisley room and Dining to be the 2-Degas room.  (Creative)

4. Apply clue 6 (no Sisley in Kitchen, none in Den) together with step 3.  
Consequently all three Sisleys go to Bedroom and the single remaining Sisley must go to Parlor.  (Creative)

5. From clue 2 (no Degas or Sisley in Den) and Den’s size of two, deduce that the Den’s two pictures can only be Monet (because Pissaro is still unrestricted and Monet is the only artist not barred).  Also record that Dining must have at least one Pissaro.  (Rudimentary)

6. Exploit clue 3: total Sisley = total Degas + total prints in Den.  
Total Sisley is now 4 and Den contains 2 prints, so the apartment must have exactly 2 Degas prints; those two are already known to sit in Dining.  (Creative)

7. Apply clue 5: total Monet = total Degas + total prints in Kitchen.  
Kitchen has 4 prints and there are 2 Degas prints, so total Monet = 6.  
Because Kitchen holds no Monet (clue 5) and Den already contains 2, the remaining 4 Monet prints must be placed equally in Parlor and Bedroom (equal-Monet condition from clue 1), giving 2 Monet in each of those rooms.  (Creative)

8. Fill in the still-vacant slots with Pissaro prints so each room reaches its required size and Dining has at least one Pissaro.  That yields: Kitchen 4 Pissaro, Parlor 1 Pissaro, Dining 1 Pissaro.  (Rudimentary)

9. Verify every clue and total:  
Kitchen 0 D 0 M 4 P 0 S; Parlor 0 D 2 M 1 P 1 S; Bedroom 0 D 2 M 0 P 3 S; Dining 2 D 0 M 1 P 0 S; Den 0 D 2 M 0 P 0 S.  
All constraints are met, so this is the unique solution.  (Rudimentary)

['Total Step Count: 9  
Creative ', ' 5

1. Translate the puzzle into variables: for every room/artist combination set an unknown, copy all six written clues, keep “at least two prints per room” and “exactly 18 prints in all” as global constraints.  (Rudimentary)

2. Combine “Parlor has the same number of pictures as Kitchen” (clue 1) with the “≥2-prints-per-room” and 18-print total to show the only feasible room-size pattern is  
 Kitchen = Parlor = 4, Bedroom = 5, Dining = 3, Den = 2.  (Creative)

3. Use clue 4: “Parlor holds fewer pictures than the only room with exactly three Sisleys but more than the only room with two Degas.”  
With the room sizes from step 2 this forces Bedroom to be the 3-Sisley room and Dining to be the 2-Degas room.  (Creative)

4. Apply clue 6 (no Sisley in Kitchen, none in Den) together with step 3.

Question:
In an attempt to further protect his secret chicken recipe, Colonel Sanders has locked it away in a safe with a 10-digit password. Unable to resist his crispy fried chicken, you'd like to crack the code. Try your luck using the following information:
All digits from 0 to 9 are used exactly once.
No digit is the same as the position which it occupies in the sequence.
The sum of the 5th and 10th digits is a square number other than 9.
The sum of the 9th and 10th digits is a cube.
The 2nd digit is an even number.
Zero is in the 3rd position.
The sum of the 4th, 6th and 8th digits is a single digit number.
The sum of the 2nd and 5th digits is a triangle number.
Number 8 is 2 spaces away from the number 9 (one in between).
The number 3 is next to the 9 but not the zero.
Hint: A triangle number is one which can be written with one number on the first line, 2 on the second, 3 on the third etc. Like ten-pin bowling style! (The first of these are 1, 3, 6)
Human Solution:
Reasoning:

1. Let the 10-digit code be d₁d₂…d₁₀ with every digit 0-9 used once and no digit equals its position (so 1 cannot be in place 1, 2 not in place 2, …, 9 not in place 9).

2. d₃ = 0 (given).

3. d₅ + d₁₀ must be a square ≠ 9.  The only possible unordered pairs of distinct digits satisfying this (and not using the already-placed 0) are {1,3} (sum 4) and {7,9} (sum 16).

4. d₉ + d₁₀ must be a cube (0,1 or 8).  Combining with step 3 yields three possible (d₅,d₉,d₁₀):
   (3,7,1) , (1,5,3) , (9,1,7).

   The second fails because 3 would not be next to 9 (rule 10); the first fails because rules 8 and 10 cannot be satisfied simultaneously.  Only (d₅,d₉,d₁₀) = (9,1,7) survives.

   Thus:
        position 5 → 9
        position 9 → 1
        position 10 → 7

5. Rule 10 (“3 is next to the 9 but not the zero”) forces 3 to be in position 6 (position 4 is disallowed because it also neighbours the zero at position 3).

6. Rule 9 (“8 is two spaces away from 9”) now puts 8 in position 7 (position 3 already contains 0).

7. Remaining unused digits: 2,4,5,6.  Rule 2 requires position 2 to be even, and rule 7 (sum of positions 4,6,8 ≤ 9) with d₆=3, d₈ unknown gives
      d₄ + d₈ + 3 ≤ 9  ⇒  d₄ + d₈ ≤ 6.
   The only pair from {2,4,5,6} adding to ≤ 6 is {2,4}.  Because digit 4 cannot sit in position 4, we must have
        position 4 → 2 , position 8 → 4.

8. Now the even digit still available for position 2 is 6, and rule 6 (d₂ + d₅ triangular) yields 6 + 9 = 15, which is indeed triangular.  Hence:
        position 2 → 6.

9. The only unused digit left is 5, so position 1 → 5.

10. Final check: every rule is satisfied and no digit equals its position.

The password is therefore 5602938417.

Final answer: 5602938417

Question:
There is a plot of land that is 16 square acres, arranged in a 4 X 4 grid.  There are 16 mammals, two each of the following: beaver, cat, dog, goat, horse, lion, tiger, and walrus.  There is one mammal in each acre.  The acres are labeled A through P, as shown below.
A B C D
E F G H
I J K L
M N O P
Given the following clues, determine where each mammal is located.  The terms "next to" and "connected together" mean vertically, horizontally, or diagonally.
1) A and D do not contain the same mammal, but one of them has a dog.
2) E and O do not contain the same mammal, but one of them has a horse.
3) B and L contain the same mammal, but not a tiger.
4) C and M contain the same mammal, but not a beaver.
5) F, K, N, and P are four different mammals.
6) The tigers are in different columns.
7) The goats are located in two of the following locations: B, C, K, and O.
8) The lions are located in two of the following locations: A, E, F, and M.
9) Cats don't get along with dogs, so neither cat is next to a dog.
10) Tigers have goats on their menu, so each tiger must be next to at least one goat and each goat must be next to at least one tiger.
11) The beavers and walruses live on the same body of water, so all four must be connected together in some fashion.
Hint: Look at hint 3, then 4, then 7 as the first three hints
Human Solution:
Final answer:  
A – Beaver  
B – Cat  
C – Lion  
D – Dog  
E – Horse  
F – Walrus  
G – Beaver  
H – Tiger  
I – Walrus  
J – Tiger  
K – Goat  
L – Cat  
M – Lion  
N – Dog  
O – Goat  
P – Horse

Question:
Three sportsmen, Tom, Jim and Sam, are standing in a row, and we can see their backs. Each of them wears a suit, which are red, yellow and blue in no particular order. Each suit has a different number, between 2 and 9, inclusive. Clues are:
1. In the order they stand, the three numbers form a perfect square.
2. Tom's number is smaller than the rightmost sportsman's number.
3. The yellow suit's number is odd.
4. The factorial of Sam's number, plus one, is divisible by the red suit's number.
Hint: One of the clues is very important.
Human Solution:
Step 1 – List the admissible 3-digit squares  
Every suit-number must be one of {2,…,9}.  
Three different digits, concatenated in Tom-Jim-Sam order, must be a perfect square.

3-digit squares:  
256, 289, 324, 361, 400, 441, 484, 529, 576, 625, 676, 729, 784, 961.  
Keeping only those with three distinct digits taken from 2–9 gives:  
256, 289, 324, 529, 576, 625, 729, 784.

Step 2 – Use Tom’s-vs-Sam’s size condition  
Tom’s (leftmost) digit < Sam’s (rightmost) digit.  
Apply to the list:

256 (2<6 ✔), 289 (2<9 ✔), 324 (3<4 ✔), 529 (5<9 ✔),  
576 (5<6 ✔), 625 (6<5 ✘), 729 (7<9 ✔), 784 (7<4 ✘).

Remaining: 256, 289, 324, 529, 576, 729.

Step 3 – Factorial clue  
Let n = Sam’s digit.  (n)! + 1 must be divisible by the red suit’s digit r.  
Compute (n)! + 1 for n = 2–9 and look for divisors 2–9:

n  (n)!+1   divisors 2–9  
2   3        3  
3   7        7  
4   25       5  
5   121      –  
6   721      7  
7   5041     –  
8   40321    –  
9   362881   –

Possible (Sam, red) pairs: (2,3), (3,7), (4,5), (6,7).

Step 4 – Check each candidate square

• 256: Sam=6 ⇒ red=7 but 7 not a digit here → reject.  
• 289: Sam=9 not in list → reject.  
• 324: Sam=4 ⇒ red=5, but 5 not a digit here → reject.  
• 529: Sam=9 not in list → reject.  
• 576: Sam=6 ⇒ red=7, and 7 is Jim’s digit – possible.  
• 729: Sam=9 not in list → reject.

Only 576 survives.

Digits / people: Tom = 5, Jim = 7, Sam = 6.

Step 5 – Assign colours

Red suit must carry the digit 7 ⇒ Jim wears red.

Yellow suit must carry an odd digit (3,5,7,9).  
Available odd digits now: 5 (Tom) and 7 (Jim).  
Jim’s suit is already red, so Tom’s suit must be yellow.

The remaining colour (blue) goes to Sam.

All clues satisfied:  
• Number order 576 is 24², a perfect square.  
• 5 < 6.  
• Yellow suit (Tom) bears odd digit 5.  
• (6)! + 1 = 721, divisible by Jim’s red-digit 7.

Final answer: Tom wears the yellow suit with number 5; Jim wears the red suit with number 7; Sam wears the blue suit with number 6.
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Enumerate all three–digit perfect squares, then keep only those whose three digits are distinct and each lies in the set {2,…,9}.  
2. Impose the condition “Tom’s digit < Sam’s digit” on that list to eliminate any square that violates it.  
3. For every possible value n = Sam’s digit (2–9), compute (n)! + 1, check which digits 2–9 divide that result, and record the admissible (Sam digit, red-suit digit) pairs.  
4. Take each surviving square and see whether its right-hand digit appears in the admissible (Sam, red) list and whether the corresponding red digit is actually one of the square’s digits; keep only those that pass—leaving just 576.  
5. From 576 assign people and colours: Jim gets the red suit because the red digit is 7; Tom, bearing the remaining odd digit 5, must be yellow; Sam takes the remaining colour, blue.

Question:
Fred Farley spent his summers up north in a cottage on Stoney Lake. There, he often debated with his friends what type of bait was best to use for the fish in the waters.  He decided one year to hold a fishing tournament with the best fishers on the lake, each using a different casting lure.  5 men competed (Fred Farley was NOT one of them) and points were awarded in four categories to determine a winner:
Greatest total Weight of fish caught: 4 points
Greatest Number of fish caught: 3 points
Largest Fish: 2 points
Second-largest fish: 1 point
Winning more than one category: 1 bonus point
Two fishermen did not win any of the categories and first place ended up being a tie between two men who received the same amount of points.
From the statements below, determine the first and last name of each of the contestants, what casting lure was used, and who won each category.
1. Mike (who was one of the category winners), Mr. Black (who is not Terry), and the one that used the plastic worm live near each other.
2. Vick, who did not win the total weight category, did not use the spinner bait; nor did Mr. McNess.
3. The one that used the weighted jig, who was not Terry, did not win any of the categories.
4. Neither Sam nor Mr. Larson live near any of the other three contestants, nor did either use a spinner bait or deep-running crank bait.
5. The fisherman who won the largest-fish category, who was not Mr. Smith, used spinner bait.
6. Mr. Jones, who caught the most fish, did not use a deep-running crank bait.
7. Both Mr. McNess (who did not use a deep running crank bait) and Terry (who did not use a plastic worm) had boat trouble and started after the others.
8. A wounded-minnow was used as one of the casting lures, and Kevin was one of the contestants.
Hint: Since only 3 of the contestants won the 4 categories, one of them won two and earned a bonus point.  Since there were two first places, the only possible outcome was that they both received 4 points. Therefore, one contestant won the total weight category (4 points), and another won the largest, second largest category and earned a bonus point (2 + 1 + 1 points).
Human Solution:
Kevin Black used a spinner-bait and won both the Largest-Fish and Second-Largest-Fish categories.  
Mike Jones used a wounded-minnow lure and won the Greatest-Number-of-Fish category.  
Terry Smith used a deep-running crank-bait and won the Greatest-Total-Weight category.  
Vick McNess used a plastic worm and did not win any category.  
Sam Larson used a weighted jig and did not win any category.

Final answer: Kevin Black – spinner bait – Largest & Second-largest; Mike Jones – wounded-minnow – Most fish; Terry Smith – deep-running crank bait – Total weight; Vick McNess – plastic worm – none; Sam Larson – weighted jig – none
Response:
Total Step Count: 15  
Creative Steps: 5  
Rudimentary Steps: 10  

Steps:  
1. List the five first names, five surnames, five lures, and four prize categories (plus the “bonus‐point” rule) that must be matched. (Rudimentary)

2. Notice that the only way two fishermen can tie for first place is if one of them wins the 4-point “Greatest Total Weight” prize while the other wins both the 2-point “Largest Fish” and the 1-point “Second-Largest Fish” prizes and also receives the 1-point bonus for winning more than one category (4 points each). This immediately fixes the overall scoring pattern:  
   • 4 points – Total Weight winner  
   • 4 points – Largest + Second-Largest winner  
   • 3 points – Most Fish winner  
   • 0 points – the remaining two contestants. (Creative)

3. Clue 3 says the weighted-jig user wins no categories, so he occupies one of the two 0-point positions identified in Step 2. (Rudimentary)

4. Clue 5 says the spinner-bait user wins the Largest-Fish category (and therefore, by Step 2, also the Second-Largest-Fish category) and is not Mr Smith. (Rudimentary)

5. Clue 6 states that Mr Jones caught the most fish and did not use a deep-running crank-bait; therefore Mr Jones is the 3-point “Most Fish” winner. (Rudimentary)

6. Clue 1 establishes the “live-near” trio: Mike, Mr Black, and the plastic-worm user, and adds that Mike is a category winner. Hence Mike must be the Total-Weight winner, the Most-Fish winner, or the Spinner-Bait/Largest-Fish winner. (Creative)

7. Clue 4 says Sam and Mr Larson (the same man, Sam Larson) live near none of the other three contestants and used neither spinner-bait nor deep-running crank-bait. That restricts Sam’s lure to weighted jig or wounded minnow. Because Sam must also be a non-winner (only two prizes remain unclaimed and both are already ascribed in Steps 2 and 5), Sam must be the weighted-jig/0-point fisherman described in Step 3. (Creative)

8. Clue 3 also states that the weighted-jig user is not Terry, confirming that Terry is not the weighted-jig fisherman and supporting the assignment of Sam Larson to that slot. (Rudimentary)

9. Clue 7 tells us Mr McNess does not use a deep-running crank-bait, and that Terry does not use a plastic worm. To be able to take the 4-point Total-Weight prize that is still unassigned, Terry therefore must be the deep-running crank-bait user. Since the deep-running crank-bait winner cannot be Mr McNess or Mr Black (for reasons already noted), Terry’s surname must be Smith, giving us Terry Smith as the Total-Weight winner. (Creative)

10. With Mr Jones already identified as the Most-Fish winner (Step 5) and Mike known to be a winner (Step 6), Mike must be Mr Jones. Thus Mike Jones is the Most-Fish winner. (Rudimentary)

11. The “live-near” trio is now partially filled: Mike Jones (Most Fish) and an as-yet-unknown Mr Black plus the plastic-worm user. (Rudimentary)

12. Clue 2 says Mr McNess did not use spinner-bait and did not win Total Weight. Since the two 0-point positions are the weighted-jig user (Sam Larson) and the plastic-worm user, Mr McNess must be the plastic-worm user. Therefore Vick McNess is the plastic-worm/0-point fisherman. (Creative)

13. The “live-near” trio is now complete: Mike Jones, Vick McNess (plastic worm), and Mr Black. The only unused first name is Kevin, so Kevin must be Mr Black. (Rudimentary)

14. The only prize not yet assigned is the Largest-Fish & Second-Largest-Fish combination, which by Step 4 must go to the spinner-bait user. Kevin Black is the only contestant without a lure or prize, so Kevin Black used spinner-bait and won both the Largest-Fish and Second-Largest-Fish categories, earning the bonus point. (Rudimentary)

15. Compile the complete set of matches:  
   • Kevin Black – spinner-bait – Largest & Second-Largest Fish  
   • Mike Jones – wounded-minnow – Most Fish  
   • Terry Smith – deep-running crank-bait – Total Weight  
   • Vick McNess – plastic worm – no category won  
   • Sam Larson – weighted jig – no category won. (Rudimentary)

Question:
Long ago, back before serious illness existed and the new inventions of today, there lived the Handy People. Their height was measured in hands, and they lived long lives.  From the statements below identify each of the 5 Handy people's height (12, 13, 14, 15 and 16 hands) and their ages (100, 110, 120, 130 and 140 years).
TWIST: One statement is FALSE.
1. Har was not the oldest, nor was he the shortest or tallest.
2. Winn was taller than Edvo, who was taller but younger than Frer.
3. Tolo, who was not the second oldest, was older than Har, and shorter than Frer.
4. The one who was 13 hands tall was the oldest.
5. Har was taller and older than Winn and Tolo.
6. The fourth oldest was taller than Tolo, but shorter than Edvo, who was older than Winn.
Hint: it is impossible that both 3 and 5 be true
Human Solution:
Let the five heights be 12, 13, 14, 15, 16 hands and the five ages be 100, 110, 120, 130, 140 years.

Because exactly one of the six statements is false, all the others must be true.

1. From (4) we know that the 13-hand person is the oldest (140 yr).  
2. Statement (1) is true, so Har is not the oldest and his height is neither the shortest (12) nor the tallest (16); therefore Har’s height is 14 or 15 and his age ≠ 140.  
3. Statements (2), (3) and (6) give the following true relations:

   Heights: Winn > Edvo > Frer and Edvo > (height of the 110-yr person) > Tolo, with Frer > Tolo.  
   Ages: Frer > Edvo > Winn and Tolo > Har (while Tolo is not 130) and (the 110-yr person) is 4th oldest.

4. Statements (3) and (5) contradict each other about the relative ages of Har and Tolo; hence one of them must be the single false statement.  
   Trying “(3) false” leads to an impossible height arrangement, so (3) must be true and (5) is the one false statement.

5. With (3) true, Har is younger than Tolo; therefore Har’s height cannot exceed Winn’s (otherwise statement (5) would be wholly true).  
   Working through the height inequalities, the only viable ordering of the five distinct heights is

        Winn 16  >  Edvo 15  >  Frer 13  >  Har 14  >  Tolo 12  (but 13 is fixed for the oldest)

   This places Frer at 13 hands, making him the 140-yr oldest.  
   The 110-yr person must then have height 14 hands, so Har is the 110-yr man.  
   Since Edvo is older than Winn but younger than Frer, Edvo must be 130 yr and Winn 100 yr, leaving 120 yr for Tolo (and satisfying “Tolo not second-oldest” because second-oldest is 130).

6. All true statements are now satisfied while statement (5) is partly violated (Har is not taller than Winn and not older than Tolo), so it is indeed the single false statement.

Final answer:  
Har – 14 hands, 110 years  
Winn – 16 hands, 100 years  
Edvo – 15 hands, 130 years  
Frer – 13 hands, 140 years  
Tolo – 12 hands, 120 years  

The false statement is statement 5.
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. Establish the basic data set (heights 12–16, ages 100–140) and the meta-rule that exactly one of the six given statements is false. [Rudimentary]  

2. Use statement (4) to conclude that the 13-hand person is the oldest and therefore 140 years old. [Rudimentary]  

3. Apply statement (1): Har is not the oldest, nor shortest, nor tallest, so Har’s height is 14 or 15 and his age is not 140. [Rudimentary]  

4. Translate statements (2), (3) and (6) into chains of inequalities for heights and ages:  
 Heights Winn > Edvo > Frer, Edvo > (110-yr person) > Tolo, and Frer > Tolo.  
 Ages Frer > Edvo > Winn, Tolo > Har (with Tolo ≠130), and the 110-yr person is 4th oldest. [Rudimentary]  

5. Notice that statements (3) and (5) assert opposite age relations between Har and Tolo; since only one statement is false, exactly one of these two must be the lone falsehood. Try making (3) false; this yields an impossible height arrangement, so (3) must be true and, consequently, (5) is the single false statement. [Creative]  

6. With (3) true and (5) false, tighten the height constraints: because Har is now younger than Tolo, Har cannot also outrank Winn in height without making (5) completely true. Working through all inequalities leaves only one feasible ordering:  
 Winn 16 > Edvo 15 > Frer 13 > Har 14 > Tolo 12, thereby fixing Frer as the 13-hand, 140-year oldest. [Creative]  

7. Identify the 110-year person (4th oldest) as the 14-hand height, so Har is 110 years old. Combine remaining age relations to set Edvo 130, Winn 100, and Tolo 120, while confirming Tolo is not second-oldest. [Rudimentary]  

8. Check every original statement: all are satisfied except for the now-designated false statement (5), which is indeed violated in both its “taller” and “older” claims. [Rudimentary]  

9. State the final assignments and name statement (5) as the sole falsehood:  
 Har – 14 hands, 110 years  
 Winn – 16 hands, 100 years  
 Edvo – 15 hands, 130 years  
 Frer – 13 hands, 140 years  
 Tolo – 12 hands, 120 years [Rudimentary]

['Total Step Count: 9  
Creative ', ' 2

1. Establish the basic data set (heights 12–16, ages 100–140) and the meta-rule that exactly one of the six given statements is false. [Rudimentary]  

2. Use statement (4) to conclude that the 13-hand person is the oldest and therefore 140 years old. [Rudimentary]  

3. Apply statement (1): Har is not the oldest, nor shortest, nor tallest, so Har’s height is 14 or 15 and his age is not 140. [Rudimentary]  

4. Translate statements (2), (3) and (6) into chains of inequalities for heights and ages:  
 Heights Winn > Edvo > Frer, Edvo > (110-yr person) > Tolo, and Frer > Tolo.  
 Ages Frer > Edvo > Winn, Tolo > Har (with Tolo ≠130), and the 110-yr person is 4th oldest. [Rudimentary]  

5. Notice that statements (3) and (5) assert opposite age relations between Har and Tolo; since only one statement is false, exactly one of these two must be the lone falsehood. Try making (3) false; this yields an impossible height arrangement, so (3) must be true and, consequently, (5) is the single false statement. [Creative]  

6. With (3) true and (5) false, tighten the height constraints: because Har is now younger than Tolo, Har cannot also outrank Winn in height without making (5) completely true. Working through all inequalities leaves only one feasible ordering:  
 Winn 16 > Edvo 15 > Frer 13 > Har 14 > Tolo 12, thereby fixing Frer as the 13-hand, 140-year oldest. [Creative]  

7. Identify the 110-year person (4th oldest) as the 14-hand height, so Har is 110 years old. Combine remaining age relations to set Edvo 130, Winn 100, and Tolo 120, while confirming Tolo is not second-oldest. [Rudimentary]  

8. Check every original statement: all are satisfied except for the now-designated false statement (5), which is indeed violated in both its “taller” and “older” claims. [Rudimentary]  

9. State the final assignments and name statement (5) as the sole falsehood:  
 Har – 14 hands, 110 years  
 Winn – 16 hands, 100 years  
 Edvo – 15 hands, 130 years  
 Frer – 13 hands, 140 years  
 Tolo – 12 hands, 120 years [Rudimentary]']

Question:
You have four kiddies' building blocks with a different letter on each side. You notice that by rearranging the blocks several times, the following list of words can be formed:
pink
jest
rope
quip
goal
cony
frog
dark
site
glum
wack
have
tiny
wish
bins
What letters appear on each block?
Hint: The letters n and e are on the same block.
Human Solution:
One possible labelling that lets every word be spelled with the four cubes (and that fills all 24 faces with different letters) is

Block 1: C I J L R V  
Block 2: D E G N Q W  
Block 3: A F M P S Y  
Block 4: B H K O T U

With these letters, each of the fifteen words

pink, jest, rope, quip, goal, cony, frog, dark, site, glum, wack, have, tiny, wish, bins

uses exactly one letter from each block, so they can all be formed by simply arranging the four blocks in the right order.
Response:
Total Step Count: 3  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 1  

Steps:  
1. Creative – Realize that a workable scheme must put the letters on the four cubes so that every word can be read with exactly one letter taken from each cube; therefore each cube must end up supplying precisely one of the four letters in every listed word.  
2. Creative – Find (by reasoning and/or systematic search) a concrete assignment of the 24 distinct letters to the four cubes that satisfies the above one-letter-per-cube condition; one such successful assignment is  
   • Block 1: C I J L R V  
   • Block 2: D E G N Q W  
   • Block 3: A F M P S Y  
   • Block 4: B H K O T U  
3. Rudimentary – Check that, with this assignment, every one of the fifteen words (pink, jest, rope, …, bins) indeed takes exactly one letter from each block and that no cube face is repeated, confirming the solution works.

Question:
Which is the odd one out?
Die
Day
Gee
Gun
Scale
Hint: Think about how these words all relate to a number
Human Solution:
Step-by-step reasoning  

1.  List the five words with their lengths  
   • Die – 3 letters  
   • Day – 3 letters  
   • Gee – 3 letters  
   • Gun – 3 letters  
   • Scale – 5 letters  

2.  Look for any other obvious shared property that singles out just one word (part of speech, pronunciation, meaning, etc.).  
    All five can function as nouns, several can also be verbs, nothing else uniquely separates only one of them.  

3.  The only characteristic that cleanly distinguishes one member of the set from the other four is the number of letters.  
    Four of them (Die, Day, Gee, Gun) have exactly three letters; one of them (Scale) does not.  

Therefore the word whose length breaks the pattern—and hence the odd one out—is “Scale.”  

Final answer: Scale
Response:
Total Step Count: 3  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 2  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) List the five words and record the number of letters in each: Die (3), Day (3), Gee (3), Gun (3), Scale (5).  
2. (Rudimentary) Check other obvious shared properties—part of speech, pronunciation, meaning—and note that none of these cleanly singles out only one word.  
3. (Creative) Realize that word length is the only property that uniquely distinguishes one member; since Scale is the only 5-letter word, declare it the odd one out.

['Total Step Count: 3  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 2

1. (Rudimentary) List the five words and record the number of letters in each: Die (3), Day (3), Gee (3), Gun (3), Scale (5).  
2. (Rudimentary) Check other obvious shared properties—part of speech, pronunciation, meaning—and note that none of these cleanly singles out only one word.  
3. (Creative) Realize that word length is the only property that uniquely distinguishes one member; since Scale is the only 5-letter word, declare it the odd one out.']

Question:
You are part of a group of 500 people who have been captured by an evil tribe. The tribe leader, who appreciates a person with good logic, decides that he will propose a challenge of many headband problems.
The first challenge is that each person will get a random headband of one of two colors, black or white. There are 500 of each (500 black and 500 white). If you look at yours or say a word after you have been given your headband and before you have guessed, the evil people will kill everybody. Also, if you make any movement with your body other than your eyes, you will ALL die.
At the count of 10, each person will shout out what color they think their headband is. If you or anyone else is right, you will survive for the next challenge.  If not, you will be killed immediately. You are given some time to discuss your strategy; then you are given your headbands.
How many survivors can you guarantee, assuming the tribe leader is not lying and that each person will follow your instructions? For example, if you tell everybody to guess, you can guarantee zero survivors because you have a slight chance of getting zero survivors.
Hint: You can guarantee a lot less than you think...
Human Solution:
Let us call the two possible colours B (black) and W (white) and label the 500 prisoners  
P1 , … , P500.

1.  A strategy that guarantees 250 survivors  

   • Before the hats are put on, divide the 500 prisoners into 250 ordered pairs  
     (P1 ,P2), (P3 ,P4), … , (P499 ,P500).  
   • In every pair agree that
         – the first prisoner of the pair (the “copier”) will shout the colour he sees on his
           partner’s head;  
         – the second prisoner of the pair (the “opposite-copier”) will shout the opposite
           colour of what he sees on his partner’s head.

   Check one pair, say (A,B).  There are four possible colourings for their hats:

            A-hat   B-hat   A’s shout (copies)   B’s shout (opposite)   correct shouts
            ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
             B       B            B                   W                  A
             B       W            W                   B                  B
             W       B            B                   B                  B
             W       W            W                   B                  A

   In every row at least one of the two shouts is correct.  
   Because each of the 250 pairs behaves independently, every pair
   contributes at least one correct guess, so at least 250 prisoners are
   guaranteed to survive.

2.  Why 250 is the best possible

   Consider all 2^500 possible assignments of black/white hats, each chosen
   with equal probability.  Fix any deterministic strategy (one rule per
   prisoner telling him what to shout after seeing the other 499 hats).

   For a particular prisoner i and for any fixed view of the other 499 hats,
   there are exactly two possible complete assignments consistent with that
   view: one in which i’s own hat is B and one in which it is W.  
   The prisoner’s rule can match at most one of those two possibilities, so
   – conditional on his view – his chance of being correct is 1/2.  
   Hence, over the uniform distribution of all assignments, the expected
   number of correct guesses is (1/2)·500 = 250.

   If a strategy could guarantee more than 250 correct guesses in every
   assignment, then the expected number of correct guesses would have to be
   greater than 250, contradicting the calculation above.  
   Therefore no strategy can guarantee more than 250 survivors.

Consequently the copier/opposite-copier strategy is optimal.

Final answer: 250
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Before hats are placed, partition the 500 prisoners into 250 ordered pairs. (Creative)  
2. Within each pair agree that the first prisoner will shout the colour he sees on his partner, while the second prisoner will shout the opposite colour he sees. (Creative)  
3. Examine the four possible colourings for a single pair and verify that under every colouring at least one of the two shouts is correct. (Rudimentary)  
4. Conclude that each pair guarantees one correct shout, so across 250 pairs at least 250 prisoners survive. (Rudimentary)  
5. To show optimality, view the hat assignment as uniformly random among 2^500 possibilities and fix an arbitrary deterministic strategy. (Creative)  
6. For any prisoner and any fixed view of the other 499 hats, observe there are exactly two consistent assignments for that prisoner’s own hat; a single shout can match at most one of them, so the conditional success probability is 1/2. (Rudimentary)  
7. Apply linearity of expectation to infer the expected number of correct shouts is 500 × 1/2 = 250. (Rudimentary)  
8. Argue that if a strategy could guarantee more than 250 correct shouts in every assignment, the expectation would exceed 250, contradicting Step 7; hence no strategy can guarantee more than 250 survivors. (Rudimentary)

['Total Step Count: 8  
Creative ', ' 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 5

2. Within each pair agree that the first prisoner will shout the colour he sees on his partner, while the second prisoner will shout the opposite colour he sees. (Creative)  
3. Examine the four possible colourings for a single pair and verify that under every colouring at least one of the two shouts is correct. (Rudimentary)  
4. Conclude that each pair guarantees one correct shout, so across 250 pairs at least 250 prisoners survive. (Rudimentary)  
5. To show optimality, view the hat assignment as uniformly random among 2^500 possibilities and fix an arbitrary deterministic strategy. (Creative)  
6. For any prisoner and any fixed view of the other 499 hats, observe there are exactly two consistent assignments for that prisoner’s own hat; a single shout can match at most one of them, so the conditional success probability is 1/2. (Rudimentary)  
7. Apply linearity of expectation to infer the expected number of correct shouts is 500 × 1/2 = 250. (Rudimentary)  
8. Argue that if a strategy could guarantee more than 250 correct shouts in every assignment, the expectation would exceed 250, contradicting Step 7; hence no strategy can guarantee more than 250 survivors. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
Captain John has escaped his home town onto his ship, the "Wasp", and now Captain John sits in his cabin reading his map. Standing up, he walks out the door into the middle of the deck and announces "we have made it this far, but next we need to find both shipwrecks in the right order to point us the right way, towards the island", followed by tons of "ehs".
There are reefs in the ocean and if Captain John passes over one, his ship sinks and he and his crew die.
With what Captain John knows about the sea, can you figure out where the nine things in a 3-by-3 grid(Wasp, sunken ship 1, sunken ship 2, 2 oceans, 3 reefs, and the island) and go in the right path to the first sunken ship, the second, then the island, without passing over a reef.
The ship can move 1 space horizontally, vertically, or diagonally, and it can only pass each space once.
1. The Wasp is in the same row or column as both sunken ships.
2. There are at least two reefs to the right of sunken ship 2, but the ship isn't in the same row as either of the reefs.
3. One of the oceans is diagonal to only two reefs.
4. The columns and rows of the Wasp and island together take up every single space except the 2nd row of the 3rd column.
5. The island is between two reefs.
6. One of the reefs is somewhere above the other two reefs.
Hint: The middle column has no reefs
Human Solution:
Place the nine objects in the 3 × 3 grid like this (rows numbered from the top 1-3, columns numbered from the left 1-3):

Row 1 :  Wasp   Sunken-ship 2  Ocean  
Row 2 :  Sunken-ship 1 Ocean   Reef  
Row 3 :  Reef   Island   Reef  

i.e.

(1,1) W  (1,2) S₂  (1,3) O  
(2,1) S₁ (2,2) O  (2,3) R  
(3,1) R  (3,2) I   (3,3) R  

All clues are satisfied:

1. The Wasp (1,1) shares its row with S₂ and its column with S₁.  
2. S₂ is in column 2; two reefs (2,3) and (3,3) lie to its right and neither is in row 1.  
3. Ocean (2,2) is diagonally adjacent to exactly the two reefs in (3,1) and (3,3).  
4. The Wasp’s row/column (row 1 & column 1) together with the Island’s row/column (row 3 & column 2) cover every square except (2,3).  
5. The Island (3,2) is horizontally between the reefs in (3,1) and (3,3).  
6. Reef (2,3) is above the other two reefs in row 3.

A reef-free path that visits each square only once and in the required order is:

A1 (Wasp) → B1 (S₁) → A2 (S₂) → B2 (Ocean) → C2 (Island).

Final answer: the arrangement shown above with the path Wasp → Sunken-ship 1 → Sunken-ship 2 → Island.
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Exploit clue 4 (“The columns and rows of the Wasp and island together take up every single space except the 2nd row of the 3rd column”) to choose positions that form a cross covering eight of the nine squares.  
   • Pick (1,1) for the Wasp and (3,2) for the Island; their row/column union indeed fills every square except (2,3).  
   → Creative  

2. Apply clue 1 (“The Wasp is in the same row or column as both sunken ships”) within that cross.  
   • Put Sunken-ship 1 in the Wasp’s column beneath it, (2,1).  
   • Put Sunken-ship 2 in the Wasp’s row to its right, (1,2).  
   → Creative  

3. Use clue 2 (“At least two reefs to the right of S₂, but S₂ isn’t in the same row as either reef”) plus clue 6 (one reef above the other two).  
   • Place reefs at (2,3) and (3,3) – both right of S₂ and not in row 1.  
   • Place the third reef in column 1, row 3, i.e. (3,1), satisfying “one reef above the other two.”  
   → Rudimentary  

4. Satisfy clue 3 (“One of the oceans is diagonal to only two reefs”).  
   • The only empty squares are (1,3) and (2,2); place an Ocean at (2,2) so it is diagonally adjacent to reefs at (3,1) and (3,3) only.  
   • Put the second Ocean at (1,3).  
   → Creative  

5. Check clue 5 (“The island is between two reefs”) – with Island at (3,2) and reefs at (3,1) and (3,3), the island lies horizontally between them.  
   → Rudimentary  

6. Verify every clue against the full grid; all are satisfied.  
   → Rudimentary  

7. Produce a reef‐free, non-repeating path visiting Wasp → S₁ → S₂ → Island:  
   (1,1) W → (2,1) S₁ → (1,2) S₂ → (2,2) O → (3,2) I.  
   → Rudimentary

   → Rudimentary']

Question: You are blindfolded before a table. On the table are a very large number of pennies. You are told 128 of the pennies are heads up and the rest are tails up. How can you create two subgroups of pennies, each with the same number of heads facing up, while remaining blindfolded?
Hint: You can flip some subgroup of the pennies!
Human Solution:
Reasoning step-by-step  
1. You cannot see which individual pennies are heads, but you do know the total number of heads: exactly 128.  
2. While blindfolded, select any 128 pennies at random from the table; call this collection Group A. Put every other penny into Group B.  
   • Because you chose purely by position, Group A might contain h heads (0 ≤ h ≤ 128).  
   • Then Group B contains the remaining heads, i.e. 128 − h heads.  
3. Still blindfolded, flip every coin in Group A over once.  

Why this works  
• Before flipping, Group A had h heads and (128 − h) tails.  
• Flipping turns each of those h heads into tails and turns each of the (128 − h) tails into heads.  
• After flipping, Group A now has (128 − h) heads.  
• Group B was never touched, so it still has (128 − h) heads as well.  

Thus the two subgroups now contain the same number of heads, even though you never saw any of the coins.
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. Recognize that, although individual coin orientations are unknown, the total number of heads on the table is known to be exactly 128. (Rudimentary)  
2. While blindfolded, arbitrarily select exactly 128 coins to form Group A and place all remaining coins into Group B. (Creative)  
3. Let h be the (unknown) number of heads that happened to end up in Group A; therefore Group B must contain 128 − h heads. (Rudimentary)  
4. Flip every coin in Group A once. (Creative)  
5. After the flip, the h heads in Group A become tails and the (128 − h) tails become heads, so Group A now has 128 − h heads—the same number as Group B—yielding two groups with an equal count of heads. (Rudimentary)

['Total Step Count: 5  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. Recognize that, although individual coin orientations are unknown, the total number of heads on the table is known to be exactly 128. (Rudimentary)  
2. While blindfolded, arbitrarily select exactly 128 coins to form Group A and place all remaining coins into Group B. (Creative)  
3. Let h be the (unknown) number of heads that happened to end up in Group A; therefore Group B must contain 128 − h heads. (Rudimentary)  
4. Flip every coin in Group A once. (Creative)  
5. After the flip, the h heads in Group A become tails and the (128 − h) tails become heads, so Group A now has 128 − h heads—the same number as Group B—yielding two groups with an equal count of heads. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
Mr. Simkin, the new math teacher at school, was impressed by his students' ability to solve logic puzzles. He pulled aside three more students, and handed them each a sealed envelope with a number written inside. He told them that they each have a positive integer, and the sum of their numbers was 14.
Manny, Moe, and Jack each opened their envelopes. Mr. Simkin asks Manny if he knows anything about the numbers the other two are holding, and Manny says, "I know that Moe and Jack are holding different numbers."
Moe answers, "IN THAT CASE, I know that all three of our numbers are different."
Jack thinks for a bit, and then says, "Now I know all of our numbers."
Mr. Simkin turns to the class and asks if anyone in the class knows the numbers. Gretchen's hand shoots up into the air, and after waiting for a while to see if anyone else will get the answer, Mr. Simkin calls on Gretchen.
What numbers does she say they each are holding?
Hint: Do casework on what Moe can have.
Human Solution:
Reasoning step-by-step

1.  Let Manny’s, Moe’s and Jack’s numbers be m, t and j.
    Public information: m+t+j = 14, all are positive integers.

2.  Manny says “I know Moe and Jack are holding different numbers.”
    Manny sees m.  
    The only way he can be SURE the remaining two numbers are different is if
          14 − m is odd,  
    because an odd number cannot be split into two equal positive integers.  
    Therefore m is odd.

3.  Moe now knows m is odd.  
    He says “In that case, I know that all three of our numbers are different.”
    Moe sees t.  
    For him to be certain his own number is different from Manny’s,
          t must be even                     (since Manny’s is odd).  
    Could Jack share Moe’s even number?  
    If j = t, then m = 14 − 2t, which would be even, contradicting m odd.  
    So with t even Moe can indeed be certain all three numbers are different.
    Conclusion: t is even.

4.  Hence the parities are
          m odd,  t even,  j odd,   all different,   m+t+j = 14.

5.  List all triples satisfying those conditions:

          (m,t,j) = (1,10,3) (1,8,5) (1,6,7) (1,4,9) (1,2,11)
                     (3,10,1) (3,6,5) (3,4,7) (3,2,9)
                     (5,8,1) (5,6,3) (5,2,7)
                     (7,6,1) (7,4,3) (7,2,5)
                     (9,4,1) (9,2,3)
                     (11,2,1)

6.  Jack now says “Now I know all of our numbers.”
    Jack knows j, and from the conversation he knows the list above.
    For him to be able to determine m and t uniquely, his own value j must
    appear in only one triple of the list.

    Counting appearances of each possible j:
        j = 1  … 5 triples
        j = 3  … 4 triples
        j = 5  … 3 triples
        j = 7  … 3 triples
        j = 9  … 2 triples
        j = 11 … 1 triple

    Therefore Jack must be holding 11, and the unique corresponding triple is
          (m,t,j) = (1,2,11).

7.  Gretchen hears everything.  She knows the same list and that Jack could
    deduce the numbers; hence she too narrows it down to the sole possible
    triple (1,2,11).

Final answer: Manny has 1, Moe has 2, Jack has 11.
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Introduce notation m, t, j for Manny’s, Moe’s, and Jack’s numbers and use the public information m + t + j = 14 with all numbers positive integers. (Rudimentary)  

2. Analyze Manny’s statement: the only way Manny can be absolutely sure Moe and Jack have different numbers is if 14 − m is odd, so m must be odd. (Creative)  

3. Analyze Moe’s statement given m is odd: to be certain all three numbers are different, Moe reasons his own number t must be even, and if j equaled t then m would be even—contradiction—so t is even and j is automatically different from both. (Creative)  

4. Collect the parity information obtained so far: m odd, t even, j odd, all distinct, still summing to 14. (Rudimentary)  

5. Enumerate every (m, t, j) triple of positive integers satisfying those conditions: (1,10,3), (1,8,5), … , (11,2,1). (Rudimentary)  

6. Realize what Jack’s final remark implies: for Jack to know everyone’s numbers, his own value j must appear in exactly one triple of the enumerated list. (Creative)  

7. Tally the frequency of each possible j in the list; find that only j = 11 occurs once, giving the unique triple (1, 2, 11). (Rudimentary)  

8. Note that Gretchen hears the same conversation and therefore restricts the possibilities the same way, so she too concludes the numbers are 1, 2, 11 for Manny, Moe, and Jack respectively. (Rudimentary)

3. Analyze Moe’s statement given m is odd: to be certain all three numbers are different, Moe reasons his own number t must be even, and if j equaled t then m would be even—contradiction—so t is even and j is automatically different from both. (Creative)

5. Enumerate every (m, t, j) triple of positive integers satisfying those conditions: (1,10,3), (1,8,5), … , (11,2,1). (Rudimentary)  

6. Realize what Jack’s final remark implies: for Jack to know everyone’s numbers, his own value j must appear in exactly one triple of the enumerated list. (Creative)  

7. Tally the frequency of each possible j in the list; find that only j = 11 occurs once, giving the unique triple (1, 2, 11). (Rudimentary)  

8. Note that Gretchen hears the same conversation and therefore restricts the possibilities the same way, so she too concludes the numbers are 1, 2, 11 for Manny, Moe, and Jack respectively. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
To solve this puzzle, take the last two letters of the first word described to make the first two letters of the second word, the last two letters of the second word to make the first two letters of the third word, and so on. The last two letters of the tenth word will make the first two letters of the first word and bring you back to where you started. Ready?
1. To prevent by fear
2. One of the muses
3. Often on the breakfast table
4. Steps for passing over a fence
5. Lawful
6. Solitary
7. A musical Roman emperor
8. A bird
9. To bury
10. To eat into
Hint: Find the most obvious one first
Human Solution:
We need ten words that form a “last-two / first-two” chain and match the given clues, with the last two letters of the 10th word looping back to the first two letters of the 1st word.

1. “To prevent by fear” → DETER  
   last two letters: ER

2. Must start with ER; a Muse beginning with ER is ERATO  
   last two letters: TO

3. Must start with TO; something often on the breakfast table is TOAST  
   last two letters: ST

4. Must start with ST; steps for passing over a fence are a STILE  
   last two letters: LE

5. Must start with LE; “lawful” is LEGAL  
   last two letters: AL

6. Must start with AL; “solitary” is ALONE  
   last two letters: NE

7. Must start with NE; the “musical” Roman emperor is NERO  
   last two letters: RO

8. Must start with RO; a bird beginning with RO is ROBIN  
   last two letters: IN

9. Must start with IN; “to bury” is INTER  
   last two letters: ER

10. Must start with ER; “to eat into” is ERODE  
    last two letters: DE

Finally, DE (from ERODE) matches the first two letters of DETER, closing the loop.

The complete chain is:
DETER → ERATO → TOAST → STILE → LEGAL → ALONE → NERO → ROBIN → INTER → ERODE

Final answer: DETER, ERATO, TOAST, STILE, LEGAL, ALONE, NERO, ROBIN, INTER, ERODE
Response:
Total Step Count: 12  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 11  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Recognize that the puzzle can be solved sequentially by choosing the first word, then repeatedly using the last two letters of each solution as the required first two letters of the next answer, and finally checking that the 10th word’s ending loops back to the 1st word’s beginning.  
2. (Rudimentary) Solve clue 1 with no prefix restriction: “To prevent by fear” → DETER; record the ending ER.  
3. (Rudimentary) Solve clue 2 with prefix ER: “One of the muses” → ERATO; record the ending TO.  
4. (Rudimentary) Solve clue 3 with prefix TO: “Often on the breakfast table” → TOAST; record the ending ST.  
5. (Rudimentary) Solve clue 4 with prefix ST: “Steps for passing over a fence” → STILE; record the ending LE.  
6. (Rudimentary) Solve clue 5 with prefix LE: “Lawful” → LEGAL; record the ending AL.  
7. (Rudimentary) Solve clue 6 with prefix AL: “Solitary” → ALONE; record the ending NE.  
8. (Rudimentary) Solve clue 7 with prefix NE: “A musical Roman emperor” → NERO; record the ending RO.  
9. (Rudimentary) Solve clue 8 with prefix RO: “A bird” → ROBIN; record the ending IN.  
10. (Rudimentary) Solve clue 9 with prefix IN: “To bury” → INTER; record the ending ER.  
11. (Rudimentary) Solve clue 10 with prefix ER: “To eat into” → ERODE; record the ending DE.  
12. (Rudimentary) Verify that the final DE matches the starting letters of DETER, confirming the closed loop.

Question:
There is a ten-digit mystery number, represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) A * F = CE
2) B * H = JI
3) D * G = BH
4) G * I = CF
Hint: A) If a number has 5 as a units digit, then one of its factors must also have 5 as a units digit.  Therefore, the following can not be 5: E, F, H, I.
Human Solution:
Reasoning  

1.  From D × G = BH, the two-digit product BH must have tens digit B, ones digit H, and be attainable by multiplying two distinct digits (2–9).  
   Enumerating such products and requiring B*H to be two-digit eliminates every case with B = 0 or 1.  
   The viable (B,H) pairs together with D,G and the product B × H = JI are  

   (B,H)  BH  D,G      B×H = JI  
   2,7    27  3,9      14  
   2,8    28  4,7      16  
   3,5    35  5,7      15  
   3,6    36  4,9      18  
   4,5    45  9,5      20  
   4,8    48  6,8      32  
   4,9    49  —        —   (rejected: needs 7 × 7)  
   5,4    54  6,9      20  
   5,6    56  7,8      30  
   6,3    63  7,9      18  
   6,4    64  —        —   (rejected: needs 8 × 8)  
   7,2    72  8,9      14  

2.  Equation G × I = CF must give a two-digit result whose tens digit C is new and whose ones digit equals F (also a factor in A × F = CE).  
3.  Working case-by-case and enforcing uniqueness of digits quickly eliminates every pair except (B,H) = (7,2):

   •  B = 7, H = 2  
   •  BH = 72, so D × G = 8 × 9 (D = 8, G = 9).  
   •  B × H = 7 × 2 = 14 ⇒ J = 1, I = 4.  
   •  G × I = 9 × 4 = 36 ⇒ C = 3, F = 6.  
   •  Digits used so far: {1,2,3,4,6,7,8,9}.  Remaining digits: {0,5}.  

4.  Finally, A × F = CE means A × 6 = 3E.  
   With digits 0 and 5 left, 6×5 = 30 fits: C = 3, E = 0, A = 5.  
   All ten digits 0–9 are now used exactly once.

5.  Check all equations:  
   A × F = 5 × 6 = 30 = CE ✔  
   B × H = 7 × 2 = 14 = JI ✔  
   D × G = 8 × 9 = 72 = BH ✔  
   G × I = 9 × 4 = 36 = CF ✔  

The assignments are  
A=5, B=7, C=3, D=8, E=0, F=6, G=9, H=2, I=4, J=1, giving

Final answer: 5738069241
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Focus on the relation D × G = BH and exploit the fact that BH must itself be a two-digit product whose tens digit is B and ones digit is H.  Enumerate every two-digit product of two different digits 2–9 that meets this description, discard impossible repeats (B = 0 or 1, or cases requiring equal factors), and record for each survivor the implied digits D, G and the accompanying value of JI = B × H.  → (table of candidates) (Creative)

2. Note that the second product G × I must equal CF, so the result must be a fresh two-digit number whose tens digit C is unused so far and whose ones digit equals F (which also appears in A × F).  This observation supplies a cross-check for eliminating candidates. (Rudimentary)

3. Test each (B,H) pair from the table against the uniqueness of all digits and the G × I = CF condition; every pair fails except (B,H) = (7, 2).  From this single surviving case deduce D = 8, G = 9, J = 1, I = 4, C = 3, F = 6, leaving the unused digits {0, 5}. (Rudimentary)

4. Apply the last equation A × F = CE with F = 6 and the leftover digits {0, 5}.  Since 6 × 5 = 30, set A = 5 and E = 0. (Rudimentary)

5. Verify all four original equations with the assignments A=5, B=7, C=3, D=8, E=0, F=6, G=9, H=2, I=4, J=1, confirming that each digit 0–9 appears exactly once; hence the mystery number is 5738069241. (Rudimentary)

Enumerate every two-digit product of two different digits 2–9 that meets this description, discard impossible repeats (B = 0 or 1, or cases requiring equal factors), and record for each survivor the implied digits D, G and the accompanying value of JI = B × H.  → (table of candidates) (Creative)

2. Note that the second product G × I must equal CF, so the result must be a fresh two-digit number whose tens digit C is unused so far and whose ones digit equals F (which also appears in A × F).  This observation supplies a cross-check for eliminating candidates. (Rudimentary)

3. Test each (B,H) pair from the table against the uniqueness of all digits and the G × I = CF condition; every pair fails except (B,H) = (7, 2).  From this single surviving case deduce D = 8, G = 9, J = 1, I = 4, C = 3, F = 6, leaving the unused digits {0, 5}. (Rudimentary)
