Question:
On Sunday, December 22, four Madadian cruise ships - W, X, Y, Z - started their series of winter cruises to various ports around Madadia.
Ship W left at 4:00 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of 8-days cruises to Madport.
Ship X left at 4:30 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of alternating 11-days and 13-days cruises to Adeville.
Ship Y left at 5:00 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of 5-days cruises to Kebabtown.
Ship Z left on Monday for a series of 7-days cruises.
Each ship is scheduled to return back early in the morning after the last day of the cruise and leave again late in the afternoon of the same day.
On how many days occasions between December 22 and February 28 will three ships be moored at the port?
Hint: Find out the days on when each ship will be in port
Human Solution:
Let  

• n = length (in days) of a cruise.  
• The ship sails for n calendar days (the afternoon of the departure day counts as day 1).  
• It returns early the next morning (day n + 1) and leaves again late that same afternoon.  
⇒ The interval between two successive departures is exactly n days.

Timetables (departure-days = “turn-round” days, i.e. the days on which the ship is in port from early morning until mid-afternoon):

Ship W : 8-day cycle beginning Sun 22 Dec  
 22 Dec, 30 Dec, 07 Jan, 15 Jan, 23 Jan, 31 Jan, 08 Feb, 16 Feb, 24 Feb

Ship X : 11-, 13-, 11-, 13-… cycle beginning Sun 22 Dec  
 22 Dec, 02 Jan, 15 Jan, 26 Jan, 08 Feb, 19 Feb

Ship Y : 5-day cycle beginning Sun 22 Dec  
 22 Dec, 27 Dec, 01 Jan, 06 Jan, 11 Jan, 16 Jan, 21 Jan, 26 Jan, 31 Jan,  
 05 Feb, 10 Feb, 15 Feb, 20 Feb, 25 Feb

Ship Z : 7-day cycle beginning Mon 23 Dec  
 23 Dec, 30 Dec, 06 Jan, 13 Jan, 20 Jan, 27 Jan, 03 Feb, 10 Feb, 17 Feb, 24 Feb

Now list the days from 22 Dec to 28 Feb on which each ship is in port and count how many ships are present.

22 Dec W X Y (Z is still in port awaiting her first departure) → 4 ships  
All other dates in the period give at most two ships simultaneously in port:

30 Dec (W Z), 06 Jan (Y Z), 15 Jan (W X), 26 Jan (X Y), 31 Jan (W Y),  
08 Feb (W X), 10 Feb (Y Z), 16 Feb (W), 24 Feb (W Z), etc.

Thus only one day – Sunday 22 December – sees three (indeed four) ships moored at the port.

Final answer: 1
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 8  

Steps:  
1. Introduce a variable n to denote the cruise length in days and restate the given timing convention (departure afternoon counts as day 1, return early on day n + 1, depart again late that same afternoon). – Rudimentary  

2. Deduce from the convention that the ship’s “turn-round” (in-port) days form an arithmetic sequence whose common difference equals the cruise length n; that is, each ship is in port every n days. – Creative  

3. Apply the 8-day interval to generate the list of all turn-round days for Ship W between 22 Dec and 28 Feb. – Rudimentary  

4. Apply the alternating 11-day / 13-day intervals to generate the list of turn-round days for Ship X in the same period. – Rudimentary  

5. Apply the 5-day interval to generate the list of turn-round days for Ship Y in the same period. – Rudimentary  

6. Apply the 7-day interval (starting 23 Dec) to generate the list of turn-round days for Ship Z in the same period. – Rudimentary  

7. Collect all dates from the four individual lists, arrange them chronologically from 22 Dec to 28 Feb, and for each date tally how many ships are simultaneously in port. – Rudimentary  

8. Inspect the tally and observe that every listed date has at most two ships in port except 22 Dec, on which four ships (W, X, Y, Z) are present. – Rudimentary  

9. Conclude that there is exactly one occasion in the given interval on which three (indeed four) ships are moored at the port. – Rudimentary
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 9  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 8  

Steps:  
1. Introduce a variable n to denote the cruise length in days and restate the given timing convention (departure afternoon counts as day 1, return early on day n + 1, depart again late that same afternoon). – Rudimentary  

2. Deduce from the convention that the ship’s “turn-round” (in-port) days form an arithmetic sequence whose common difference equals the cruise length n; that is, each ship is in port every n days. – Creative  

3. Apply the 8-day interval to generate the list of all turn-round days for Ship W between 22 Dec and 28 Feb. – Rudimentary  

4. Apply the alternating 11-day / 13-day intervals to generate the list of turn-round days for Ship X in the same period. – Rudimentary  

5. Apply the 5-day interval to generate the list of turn-round days for Ship Y in the same period. – Rudimentary  

6. Apply the 7-day interval (starting 23 Dec) to generate the list of turn-round days for Ship Z in the same period. – Rudimentary  

7. Collect all dates from the four individual lists, arrange them chronologically from 22 Dec to 28 Feb, and for each date tally how many ships are simultaneously in port. – Rudimentary  

8. Inspect the tally and observe that every listed date has at most two ships in port except 22 Dec, on which four ships (W, X, Y, Z) are present. – Rudimentary  

9. Conclude that there is exactly one occasion in the given interval on which three (indeed four) ships are moored at the port. – Rudimentary']

Question:
Henry and Gretchen are going to play a game.  Henry explains, "You and I will take turns saying numbers.  The first person will say a number between 1 and 10.  Then the other person will say a number that is at least 1 higher than that number, and at most 10 higher.  We will keep going back and forth in this way until one of us says the number 50.  That person wins.  I'll start."
"Not so fast!" says Gretchen.  "I want to win, so I will start."
What number should Gretchen say to start?
Hint: By following this strategy, she is assured a victory.  Think of all of the numbers she will want to say.
Human Solution:
Think backward from the winning number 50.

If you can say 50, you win.  
So make sure that, after Henry speaks, you are always able to reply with 50.

How can you guarantee that?  Make sure you always land on 39, because whatever Henry says next (40-49) is between 1 and 10 higher, letting you answer 50.

Now think one step earlier: to guarantee reaching 39, be sure you always land on 28 (since Henry’s reply 29-38 is again 1–10 higher, letting you answer 39).

Continuing backward:

• Safe numbers: 50, 39 (=50-11), 28 (=39-11), 17 (=28-11), 6 (=17-11).

If you ever say one of these “safe” numbers, you can always force the next safe number, and eventually 50.  The only safe number that can be chosen legally on the very first move (must be 1–10) is 6.

So Gretchen should begin by saying

6.

After that she can always respond so the total sequence goes  
6 → 17 → 28 → 39 → 50, no matter what Henry does.

Final answer: 6
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Adopt the strategy of analyzing the game backward from the winning number 50. (Creative)  
2. Observe that if you can always answer with 50, you win; therefore identify 39 as the critical predecessor that forces Henry to hand you 50 on your next turn. (Creative)  
3. Extend the backward-induction pattern by repeatedly subtracting 11 to build the full list of “safe” numbers: 50, 39, 28, 17, 6. (Rudimentary)  
4. Assert that landing on any safe number lets you force play to the next safe number and ultimately to 50. (Rudimentary)  
5. Check which safe numbers are legal as an opening move (must be 1–10); only 6 meets the requirement. (Rudimentary)  
6. Conclude that Gretchen’s optimal first announcement is 6. (Rudimentary)  
7. Illustrate the guaranteed winning sequence 6 → 17 → 28 → 39 → 50 regardless of Henry’s replies. (Rudimentary)

['Total Step Count: 7  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Adopt the strategy of analyzing the game backward from the winning number 50. (Creative)  
2. Observe that if you can always answer with 50, you win; therefore identify 39 as the critical predecessor that forces Henry to hand you 50 on your next turn. (Creative)  
3. Extend the backward-induction pattern by repeatedly subtracting 11 to build the full list of “safe” numbers: 50, 39, 28, 17, 6. (Rudimentary)  
4. Assert that landing on any safe number lets you force play to the next safe number and ultimately to 50. (Rudimentary)  
5. Check which safe numbers are legal as an opening move (must be 1–10); only 6 meets the requirement. (Rudimentary)  
6. Conclude that Gretchen’s optimal first announcement is 6. (Rudimentary)  
7. Illustrate the guaranteed winning sequence 6 → 17 → 28 → 39 → 50 regardless of Henry’s replies. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
One of four people - two men (Jack and Mike) and two women (Carol and Lily) - was murdered.
The following facts refer to the people mentioned:
(a) Jack's sister argued exactly once with Carol's legal husband after the murder.
(b) Mike's sister argued twice with the victim's legal spouse after the murder. Who was the victim?
Hint: They may or may not share sisters?
Human Solution:
Let  

 J = Jack    M = Mike    C = Carol    L = Lily  

Every marriage is legal, so nobody may be married to a brother or sister.

Unknown relationships  
 • Carol’s legal husband H₍C₎ is J or M.  
 • Jack’s sister Sⱼ is C or L.  
 • Mike’s sister Sₘ is C or L.  
 • The victim’s legal spouse Spᵥ is his / her mate.

The two given facts after the murder  
(a) Sⱼ argued exactly once with H₍C₎.  
(b) Sₘ argued twice with Spᵥ.

We consider each possible victim.

1. Victim = Carol  
 Spᵥ = H₍C₎.  
 Fact (a): Sⱼ argued once with H₍C₎.  
 Fact (b): Sₘ argued twice with the same H₍C₎.  
 Both sisters must be alive; the only living woman is L, so Sⱼ = Sₘ = L.  
 Then L would have to argue once and twice with the same man—impossible.  
 Therefore Carol cannot be the victim.

2. Victim = Lily  
 The only living woman is C, so Sⱼ = Sₘ = C.  
 (a) C argued once with H₍C₎.  
 (b) C argued twice with Spᵥ.  
 Hence C is sister to both men.  
 Whatever H₍C₎ is (J or M), C would be married to her own brother, which is illegal.  
 Impossible ⇒ Lily cannot be the victim.

3. Victim = Jack  
 Case H₍C₎ = J: (a) requires Sⱼ to argue with the dead Jack – impossible.  
 Case H₍C₎ = M: J’s wife is L, M’s wife is C.  
 (a) Sⱼ argued with M; (b) Sₘ argued with L.  
 Whichever sisters are chosen, either L is Jack’s sister and wife or C is Mike’s sister and wife – both illegal.  
 Therefore Jack cannot be the victim.

4. Victim = Mike  
 We try both possibilities for H₍C₎.

 • If H₍C₎ = M (Carol married to the dead Mike) then (a) again asks someone to argue with a dead man – impossible.

 • If H₍C₎ = J (Carol married to Jack, Lily married to Mike) then  
  Sⱼ cannot be C (his wife), so Sⱼ = L.  
  Sₘ cannot be L (his wife), so Sₘ = C.  

  Now  
  (a) L argued exactly once with J – acceptable.  
  (b) C argued twice with L – acceptable.  
  No one is married to a sibling (Jack–Carol, Mike–Lily), and all statements are satisfied.

This is the only arrangement that works, so the murdered person must be

Final answer: Mike
Response:
Total Step Count: 11  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 10  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) Introduce symbols for the four people and for the unknown relations: Carol’s legal husband (H₍C₎), Jack’s sister (Sⱼ), Mike’s sister (Sₘ), and the victim’s spouse (Spᵥ).  
2. (Rudimentary) Record the basic legality constraint: no one may be married to a sibling.  
3. (Rudimentary) Translate the two given post-murder statements into the symbolic language: (a) Sⱼ argued once with H₍C₎; (b) Sₘ argued twice with Spᵥ.  
4. (Creative) Adopt the strategy “test each of the four people as the possible victim,” because only four cases exist and each can be checked against the constraints.  
5. (Rudimentary) Case Victim = Carol: deduce Spᵥ = H₍C₎, see that the only living woman would be Lily, forcing Sⱼ = Sₘ = L, which in turn asks Lily to argue both once and twice with the same man—contradiction; rule Carol out.  
6. (Rudimentary) Case Victim = Lily: with only Carol alive as a woman, force Sⱼ = Sₘ = C, which makes Carol sister to both men and therefore married to a brother—illegal; rule Lily out.  
7. (Rudimentary) Case Victim = Jack, sub-case H₍C₎ = J: statement (a) would need someone to argue with the dead Jack—impossible; discard this sub-case.  
8. (Rudimentary) Case Victim = Jack, sub-case H₍C₎ = M: assign marriages (J–L, M–C); whichever way the sisters are chosen, one woman ends up both wife and sister to her husband—illegal; rule Jack out completely.  
9. (Rudimentary) Case Victim = Mike, sub-case H₍C₎ = M: statement (a) again demands an argument with a dead man—impossible; discard this sub-case.  
10. (Rudimentary) Case Victim = Mike, sub-case H₍C₎ = J: marriages become J–C and M–L; deduce Sⱼ = L and Sₘ = C, check that (a) and (b) are satisfied and that no illegal marriages occur; this configuration is consistent.  
11. (Rudimentary) Conclude the only viable arrangement is the one from Step 10, so the murdered person must be Mike.

['Total Step Count: 11  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 10

1. (Rudimentary) Introduce symbols for the four people and for the unknown relations: Carol’s legal husband (H₍C₎), Jack’s sister (Sⱼ), Mike’s sister (Sₘ), and the victim’s spouse (Spᵥ).

6. (Rudimentary) Case Victim = Lily: with only Carol alive as a woman, force Sⱼ = Sₘ = C, which makes Carol sister to both men and therefore married to a brother—illegal; rule Lily out.

8. (Rudimentary) Case Victim = Jack, sub-case H₍C₎ = M: assign marriages (J–L, M–C); whichever way the sisters are chosen, one woman ends up both wife and sister to her husband—illegal; rule Jack out completely.  
9. (Rudimentary) Case Victim = Mike, sub-case H₍C₎ = M: statement (a) again demands an argument with a dead man—impossible; discard this sub-case.  
10. (Rudimentary) Case Victim = Mike, sub-case H₍C₎ = J: marriages become J–C and M–L; deduce Sⱼ = L and Sₘ = C, check that (a) and (b) are satisfied and that no illegal marriages occur; this configuration is consistent.  
11. (Rudimentary) Conclude the only viable arrangement is the one from Step 10, so the murdered person must be Mike.']

Question:
Walter, Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke crossed a river in a tiny rowboat. They all started on the same side of the river. They made three trips from the starting side to the destination side, and two trips from the destination side to the starting side. Here are some facts:
1. On each trip from the starting side of the river to the destination side, two people were in the boat, but only one person rowed the boat, and that person rowed the boat for the entire trip.
2. On each return trip, only one person was in the boat.
3. Walter is the weakest of the group. He could only row the boat if no one else is in it.
4. Xavier is the second weakest of the group. He can only row the boat if he is by himself or if Yoshi, the lightest of the group, is a passenger.
5. Each man rowed the boat at least once.
Who rowed twice?
Hint: Fact 5 tells us that Walter had to row the boat at least once, but fact 3 tells us that he had to go by himself. This means he could only row the boat on a return trip,.
Human Solution:
Reasoning

1.  The boat makes 5 trips (3 outward, 2 return), so there are 5 rowers in all.  
    Because there are 4 men, exactly one of them must row twice.

2.  Walter can row only when he is alone in the boat, hence only on a return
    trip.  Therefore he rows exactly one of the two return trips (otherwise he
    would have to be on the destination bank twice, which is impossible in only
    five trips).  Consequently the second return trip must be rowed by someone
    other than Walter.

3.  Xavier can row a two-man outward trip only if the passenger is Yoshi.  He
    cannot row with Walter as passenger.  Therefore if Walter is taken across
    as a passenger, the rower is either Yoshi or Zeke.

4.  Try to make someone other than Yoshi the man who rows twice and see what
    happens.

    •  Walter twice?  He would have to row both return trips, but to row the
       first return trip he must already be on the far side, which means the
       first outward trip must carry Walter as passenger.  After he rows back,
       only two outward trips and one return trip remain, so he cannot be on
       the far side again to row the second return trip.  Impossible.

    •  Xavier twice?  One of his rows must be an outward trip with Yoshi as
       passenger; his second row could be the first return trip.  After that,
       Walter is still on the starting side, and the last outward trip must
       carry Walter across.  Walter cannot row it (he cannot take a passenger),
       so Xavier would have to row a third time—contradiction.

    •  Zeke twice?  If Zeke rows the first outward trip carrying Walter, he must
       row back alone to be the second rower.  That leaves Walter on the start
       side again with only two trips left, and the same dead-end described
       above is reached.  Any other attempt likewise forces a contradiction.

    Hence Walter, Xavier, and Zeke cannot be the man who rows twice.

5.  Therefore Yoshi must be the one who rows twice, and indeed there is a
    consistent schedule in which that happens:

        1.  Xavier rows Yoshi across.         (rower X)
        2.  Yoshi rows back alone.            (rower Y)
        3.  Zeke rows Walter across.          (rower Z)
        4.  Walter rows back alone.           (rower W)
        5.  Yoshi rows Walter across.         (rower Y again)

    All four men row at least once, the rules for Walter’s and Xavier’s
    strength limitations are satisfied, and only Yoshi rows twice.

Final answer: Yoshi
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 4  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. Determine that the boat makes five one–way trips, hence there are five different “rowing events.” Because there are only four men and each must row at least once, exactly one man must row twice.  (Creative)  

2. Use Walter’s strength restriction​ to see that he can row only when he is alone; therefore he can row only on a return trip, and, since there are only two return trips, he can row exactly one of them, leaving the other return trip to someone else.  (Creative)  

3. Apply Xavier’s restriction to note that he can row an outward trip only if Yoshi is the passenger; therefore, whenever Walter is ferried outward, the rower cannot be Xavier and must be either Yoshi or Zeke.  (Creative)  

4. Test the hypothesis that Walter is the man who rows twice; tracing the necessary sequence shows this would require him to be on the far bank twice in only five trips, which is impossible. Conclude Walter cannot be the double rower.  (Rudimentary)  

5. Test the hypothesis that Xavier rows twice; after arranging one outward trip with Yoshi and a solo return, the remaining trips force Xavier to row a third time, contradicting the requirement of exactly two rows for one man. Conclude Xavier cannot be the double rower.  (Rudimentary)  

6. Test the hypothesis that Zeke rows twice; any attempt to arrange this strands Walter on the starting side with too few trips left, producing a contradiction. Conclude Zeke cannot be the double rower.  (Rudimentary)  

7. Having ruled out Walter, Xavier, and Zeke, deduce that Yoshi must be the man who rows twice, and exhibit a concrete schedule (X–Y over, Y back, Z–W over, W back, Y–W over) to verify all constraints are satisfied.  (Creative)

['Total Step Count: 7  
Creative ', ' 4  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. Determine that the boat makes five one–way trips, hence there are five different “rowing events.” Because there are only four men and each must row at least once, exactly one man must row twice.  (Creative)  

2. Use Walter’s strength restriction​ to see that he can row only when he is alone; therefore he can row only on a return trip, and, since there are only two return trips, he can row exactly one of them, leaving the other return trip to someone else.  (Creative)  

3. Apply Xavier’s restriction to note that he can row an outward trip only if Yoshi is the passenger; therefore, whenever Walter is ferried outward, the rower cannot be Xavier and must be either Yoshi or Zeke.  (Creative)  

4. Test the hypothesis that Walter is the man who rows twice; tracing the necessary sequence shows this would require him to be on the far bank twice in only five trips, which is impossible. Conclude Walter cannot be the double rower.  (Rudimentary)  

5. Test the hypothesis that Xavier rows twice; after arranging one outward trip with Yoshi and a solo return, the remaining trips force Xavier to row a third time, contradicting the requirement of exactly two rows for one man. Conclude Xavier cannot be the double rower.  (Rudimentary)

Question: There is a famous diamond displayed in a room that measures 15 meters by 15 meters by 15 meters. The room is made entirely of concrete blocks and the floor is covered with a thick carpet. The only thing in the room is the diamond that is housed under a glass cube. The glass cube stands on a one-meter pedestal in the centre of the room. Alarm wires spaced eight centimetres apart and running parallel to each other lie under the carpet. The alarm will trigger if more than four kilograms of pressure is applied to any individual wire. Will Carlo who weighs 74 kilograms was able to steal the famous diamond using the following equipment: a five meter 2 x 4 board, four leather straps (each two meters long and five cm wide), a hammer, and a saw. How could he do it without triggering the alarm?
Hint: How can he spread out his weight?
Human Solution:
Reasoning

1.  How the alarm works  
   • The wires lie straight and parallel under the carpet, 8 cm apart.  
   • If more than 4 kg is put on any ONE wire the alarm sounds.

2.  What has to be achieved  
   • Carlo (≈ 74 kg) + anything he is standing on must be supported by many different wires at the same time so that the load on each wire is < 4 kg even when all of his weight is on one foot.

   74 kg ÷ 4 kg / wire = 18.5 → at least 19 wires must share the load.  
   Spacing 8 cm → 19 wires span 18 × 8 cm = 144 cm.  
   So a “shoe” that is about 1.5 m long and is set down at right angles to the wires will rest on at least 19 wires and keep the load per wire below 4 kg.

3.  Making the “shoes”  
   • Saw the 5-metre 2 × 4 board into two equal pieces 2 m long (40 cm of board remains as scrap).  
   • Each 2 m plank is 10 cm (4″) wide and will cross ≈ 25 wires (2 m ÷ 0.08 m ≈ 25).  
     ‑ With Carlo plus the plank (≈ 84 kg altogether) on one foot, the load per wire is  
       84 kg ÷ 25 ≈ 3.4 kg < 4 kg … safe.  
   • Fix each plank to a foot with two of the leather straps (one in front of the ankle, one behind).  
     They are now 2-metre-long “snow-shoes”.

4.  Crossing the room  
   • Carlo turns the planks so they are exactly at right angles to the invisible wires.  
   • He now walks to the centre: whenever he lifts one foot all of his weight goes onto the other plank, but that plank is already resting on about 25 different wires and no single wire is overloaded.  
   • Walking is slow but perfectly possible—he simply slides each “shoe” forward instead of lifting it high so that the long plank always lies squarely across the wires.

5.  Taking the diamond  
   • At the pedestal he slides one plank right up to it, kneels on that plank, and lifts the glass cover with the loose 40 cm piece of board (or with the hammer’s claw) to avoid putting a hand on the floor.  
   • He picks up the diamond (a few hundred grams—negligible for the calculation), backs away the same way and leaves the room.

Throughout the operation no wire ever carries as much as 4 kg, so the alarm is never triggered.

Final answer: Carlo saws the 5-metre 2 × 4 into two 2-metre planks, straps one plank to each foot as 2-metre-long “snow-shoes”, and walks to and from the pedestal; each plank rests on about 25 wires so every wire carries less than 4 kg, keeping the alarm silent while he removes the diamond.
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. Understand the alarm’s operating rule: parallel wires 8 cm apart under the carpet trigger the alarm if any single wire bears more than 4 kg. (Rudimentary)  

2. Translate Carlo’s 74 kg weight into a load-distribution requirement: at least 19 wires must share his weight, so a footprint about 1.5 m long (19 × 8 cm) is needed. (Creative)  

3. Recognize that the 5 m × 10 cm (2 × 4) board can be turned into very long “snow-shoes” that span the necessary number of wires. (Creative)  

4. Saw the board into two equal 2 m planks, leaving a 40 cm off-cut. (Rudimentary)  

5. Verify that a 2 m plank laid perpendicular to the wires will rest on about 25 wires, so Carlo plus plank (≈ 84 kg) load each wire with only ≈ 3.4 kg (< 4 kg). (Rudimentary)  

6. Strap one plank to each foot with the leather straps to make the long shoes. (Rudimentary)  

7. Cross the room by sliding the planks, always keeping them perpendicular to the wires so all weight stays distributed over ≈ 25 wires. (Rudimentary)  

8. At the pedestal, kneel on a plank and use the off-cut board or the hammer’s claw to lift the glass cover, avoiding contact with the carpet elsewhere. (Creative)  

9. Pick up the diamond and withdraw the same way, ensuring every step keeps the load spread so no wire exceeds 4 kg. (Rudimentary)

Creative ', ' 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. Understand the alarm’s operating rule: parallel wires 8 cm apart under the carpet trigger the alarm if any single wire bears more than 4 kg. (Rudimentary)  

2. Translate Carlo’s 74 kg weight into a load-distribution requirement: at least 19 wires must share his weight, so a footprint about 1.5 m long (19 × 8 cm) is needed. (Creative)  

3. Recognize that the 5 m × 10 cm (2 × 4) board can be turned into very long “snow-shoes” that span the necessary number of wires. (Creative)  

4. Saw the board into two equal 2 m planks, leaving a 40 cm off-cut. (Rudimentary)

Question:
Hans Ernest Froopaloop, Jr. will marry one of three women: Audrey, Brenda, and Charlotte. Here are some facts:
1. Of Audrey and Brenda:
a. Either they both have blue eyes or neither has blue eyes.
b. One has red hair and the other does not.
2. Of Audrey and Charlotte:
a. Either they both have red hair or neither has red hair.
b. One is 5'11" and the other is not.
3. Of Brenda and Charlotte:
a. One has blue eyes and the other does not.
b. One is 5'11" and the other is not.
4. Of the three characteristics; blue eyes, red hair and 5'11":
a. If any of the three women has exactly two of the three characteristics, Mr. Froopaloop will marry the one with the least number of characteristics.
b. If any of the three women has exactly one of the three characteristics, Mr. Froopaloop will marry the one with the greatest number of characteristics.
Who will Mr. Froopaloop marry?
Hint: Start with facts 1a and 3a
Human Solution:
Let  

    B = “has blue eyes”,  
    R = “has red hair”,  
    H = “is 5′11″”.  

For each woman write a 1 if she possesses the trait, 0 otherwise.

Step 1.  Translate the statements.

1.  Audrey and Brenda  
 a) B values equal        A_B = B_B  
 b) R values opposite      A_R ≠ B_R  

2.  Audrey and Charlotte  
 a) R values equal        A_R = C_R  
 b) H values opposite      A_H ≠ C_H  

3.  Brenda and Charlotte  
 a) B values opposite      B_B ≠ C_B  
 b) H values opposite      B_H ≠ C_H  

Combining 1a with 3a gives A_B = B_B ≠ C_B.  
Combining 1b with 2a gives A_R = C_R ≠ B_R.  
From 2b and 3b we get A_H = B_H ≠ C_H.

Thus the whole pattern is determined by the three bits
 C_B  (blue–ness of Charlotte),
 C_R  (red-hair of Charlotte),
 C_H  (height of Charlotte).

Indeed

 A_B = B_B = 1 − C_B  
 A_R = C_R         B_R = 1 − C_R  
 A_H = B_H = 1 − C_H  

Step 2.  List the eight possible triples (C_B , C_R , C_H) and the
numbers of traits each woman would have.

Notation: (C , A , B) = counts of traits.

1) (0,0,0)  → (0,2,3)  
2) (0,0,1)  → (1,1,2)  
3) (0,1,0)  → (1,3,2)  
4) (0,1,1)  → (2,2,1)  
5) (1,0,0)  → (1,1,2)  
6) (1,0,1)  → (2,0,1)  
7) (1,1,0)  → (2,2,1)  
8) (1,1,1)  → (3,1,0)

Step 3.  Apply Froopaloop’s rule.

• Rule 4a (“if someone has exactly two traits, marry the one with the
least number of traits”) and Rule 4b (“if someone has exactly one trait,
marry the one with the greatest number of traits”) must not both apply
at the same time – otherwise the problem would give two contradictory
answers.

Check the eight cases:

– Cases 2,3,4,5,6,7 each contain both a “1-trait” woman and a
“2-traits” woman, so both rules would fire simultaneously; such cases
are therefore impossible.

– Case 1 has a 2-traits woman but nobody with exactly 1 trait.  
 Only Rule 4a applies ⇒ marry the woman with the fewest traits,
namely Charlotte (0 traits).

– Case 8 has a 1-trait woman but nobody with exactly 2 traits.  
 Only Rule 4b applies ⇒ marry the woman with the most traits, again
Charlotte (3 traits).

Step 4.  Conclusion.

Every admissible arrangement of the three characteristics leads to
Hans Ernest Froopaloop, Jr. marrying Charlotte.

Final answer: Charlotte
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. Encode each characteristic (blue eyes = B, red hair = R, height = H) with a 1/0 for every woman. (Rudimentary)

2. Translate every bullet in the statement of facts into equations or inequalities between the corresponding 1/0 variables for Audrey, Brenda, and Charlotte. (Rudimentary)

3. Combine the obtained equations to show that Audrey’s and Brenda’s values for every characteristic are completely determined by Charlotte’s values, giving  
   A_B = B_B = 1 − C_B,  
   A_R = C_R, B_R = 1 − C_R,  
   A_H = B_H = 1 − C_H.  
   (Creative)

4. Realise that only Charlotte’s three bits are free, list the eight possible triples (C_B,C_R,C_H). (Rudimentary)

5. For each of the eight triples, count how many of the three characteristics each woman has. (Rudimentary)

6. Note that if an arrangement contains simultaneously a woman with exactly one trait and another with exactly two traits, Rules 4a and 4b would both apply, giving contradictory marriage instructions; therefore discard every arrangement that contains both a “1-trait” and a “2-trait” woman (eliminating six of the eight cases). (Creative)

7. Apply Rule 4a to the remaining case that has someone with exactly two traits (case 1) and Rule 4b to the remaining case that has someone with exactly one trait (case 8); both cases direct Froopaloop to marry Charlotte. (Rudimentary)

8. Conclude that, in every admissible configuration of traits, Hans Ernest Froopaloop, Jr. ends up marrying Charlotte. (Rudimentary)

['Total Step Count: 8  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. Encode each characteristic (blue eyes = B, red hair = R, height = H) with a 1/0 for every woman. (Rudimentary)

2. Translate every bullet in the statement of facts into equations or inequalities between the corresponding 1/0 variables for Audrey, Brenda, and Charlotte. (Rudimentary)

3. Combine the obtained equations to show that Audrey’s and Brenda’s values for every characteristic are completely determined by Charlotte’s values, giving  
   A_B = B_B = 1 − C_B,  
   A_R = C_R, B_R = 1 − C_R,  
   A_H = B_H = 1 − C_H.  
   (Creative)

4. Realise that only Charlotte’s three bits are free, list the eight possible triples (C_B,C_R,C_H). (Rudimentary)

5. For each of the eight triples, count how many of the three characteristics each woman has. (Rudimentary)

6. Note that if an arrangement contains simultaneously a woman with exactly one trait and another with exactly two traits, Rules 4a and 4b would both apply, giving contradictory marriage instructions; therefore discard every arrangement that contains both a “1-trait” and a “2-trait” woman (eliminating six of the eight cases). (Creative)

7. Apply Rule 4a to the remaining case that has someone with exactly two traits (case 1) and Rule 4b to the remaining case that has someone with exactly one trait (case 8); both cases direct Froopaloop to marry Charlotte. (Rudimentary)

8. Conclude that, in every admissible configuration of traits, Hans Ernest Froopaloop, Jr. ends up marrying Charlotte. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
Draw a diagram of the Fantasylands to help you with this teaser...
Beethoven's Wig has been stolen again!  Instead of hiding it in a box, the enemy, who remains anonymous, has hidden it inside one of four castles.  Each castle is located in a different fantasyland and has a creature guarding its gates.  Use the clues below to put the lands in order (1st,2nd,3rd, and 4th), figure out which castle belongs in which land, which creature belong to which castle, and help Beethoven reclaim his wig!
Object: Beethoven's Wig
Fantasylands: Lothlorien, Mordor, Narnia, and Malacandra.
Creatures: Dragon, Troll, Giant, and Balrog.
Castles: Stone, Gold, Glass, and Silver.
1.  Narnia is to the left of Lothlorien, which is to the right of the Balrog.
2.  The Stone Castle is to the right of the Wig, and is placed at either Malacandra or Lothlorien.
3.  The Giant is not at Lothlorien and is not in the same place as the wig.
4.  The Balrog is not in Lothlorien, but he stays at the Stone Castle.
5.  The Troll doesn't live at the Golden Castle, which is to the left of where the Balrog stays and to the right of the Silver Castle.
6.  Mordor is to the left of the Dragon, who stays at the second place.
7.  The Troll is not at the Silver Castle, which is 1 fantasyland to the left of the wig.
Hint: Mordor and Lothlorien must be at the edges of the sequence
Human Solution:
1st position (left-most): Mordor – Silver Castle – Giant  
2nd position: Narnia – Gold Castle – Dragon (with Beethoven’s Wig inside)  
3rd position: Malacandra – Stone Castle – Balrog  
4th position (right-most): Lothlorien – Glass Castle – Troll  

Final answer: Beethoven’s wig is in the Gold Castle of Narnia, arranged as above for all lands, castles and creatures.
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1.  (Rudimentary)  Apply clue 6 directly: the Dragon must occupy the 2nd position; since “Mordor is to the left of the Dragon,” Mordor has to be the 1st position.  

2.  (Rudimentary)  Combine clues 2 and 4 literally: the Balrog is in the Stone Castle, and the Stone Castle can only be in Malacandra or Lothlorien; because “the Balrog is not in Lothlorien,” conclude that the Stone Castle (with the Balrog) is in Malacandra.  

3.  (Creative)  Use the ordering chain in clue 1—Balrog  <  Narnia  <  Lothlorien—together with the partial board (Mordor-1st, Dragon-2nd, Malacandra/Stone/Balrog-3rd) to recognize that the only consistent placement is Narnia at the 2nd position (where the Dragon already sits) and Lothlorien at the 4th position.  

4.  (Creative)  Exploit clue 5 as a three-item ordering rule (Silver Castle  <  Gold Castle  <  Balrog) and lay it onto the now-fixed board: Balrog is 3rd, so Gold must be 2nd and Silver 1st.  This simultaneously fixes both the Gold and Silver Castles.  

5.  (Rudimentary)  Apply clue 7 mechanically: the Silver Castle is exactly one land to the left of the Wig, so the Wig has to be in the 2nd position (right next to the Silver Castle).  Because 2nd position already contains the Gold Castle, the Wig is therefore in the Gold Castle.  

6.  (Rudimentary)  Use clue 3 directly: the Giant is not in Lothlorien (4th) and not where the Wig sits (2nd); the remaining open creature slot that satisfies both conditions is the 1st position, so place the Giant there.  

7.  (Rudimentary)  Fill the last unassigned creature and castle by elimination: the only creature left is the Troll and the only unclaimed castle material is Glass, so assign Troll and Glass Castle to Lothlorien in the 4th position.

['Total Step Count: 7  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1.  (Rudimentary)  Apply clue 6 directly: the Dragon must occupy the 2nd position; since “Mordor is to the left of the Dragon,” Mordor has to be the 1st position.  

2.  (Rudimentary)  Combine clues 2 and 4 literally: the Balrog is in the Stone Castle, and the Stone Castle can only be in Malacandra or Lothlorien; because “the Balrog is not in Lothlorien,” conclude that the Stone Castle (with the Balrog) is in Malacandra.  

3.  (Creative)  Use the ordering chain in clue 1—Balrog  <  Narnia  <  Lothlorien—together with the partial board (Mordor-1st, Dragon-2nd, Malacandra/Stone/Balrog-3rd) to recognize that the only consistent placement is Narnia at the 2nd position (where the Dragon already sits) and Lothlorien at the 4th position.

Question:
Just before the end of the term four high school students were discussing their chances for certain grades. The following remarks contain the gist of their hopes and fears.
Jack: We'll all get different grades. If I get an A, then Lucy will get a D.
Jean: If Lucy gets a C, then Jack will get a D. Jack will get a better grade than Paul.
Lucy: If Jean doesn't get an A, then Jack will get a C. If I get a B, then Paul won't get a D.
Paul: If Lucy gets an A, then I'll get a B. if Jean doesn't get a B, I won't either.
When the final examinations were graded and the term marks made out each of the four passed, and strange as it may seem, each received a grade that checked exactly with all the ideas they had previously expressed.
What grade did each receive?
Hint: Is it possible for Jack to get an A? Also note that Paul is below Jack
Human Solution:
Jack – B  
Jean – A  
Paul – C  
Lucy – D

Final answer: Jack B, Jean A, Paul C, Lucy D
Response:
Total Step Count: 4  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Conclude that Lucy’s final grade is D.  (Rudimentary)  
2. Conclude that Jack’s final grade is B.  (Rudimentary)  
3. Conclude that Jean’s final grade is A.  (Rudimentary)  
4. Conclude that Paul’s final grade is C.  (Rudimentary)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 4  
Creative ', ' 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Conclude that Lucy’s final grade is D.  (Rudimentary)  
2. Conclude that Jack’s final grade is B.  (Rudimentary)  
3. Conclude that Jean’s final grade is A.  (Rudimentary)  
4. Conclude that Paul’s final grade is C.  (Rudimentary)']

Question:
Mad Ade has placed five Queens on a chessboard, such that every square including those occupied by the Queens are under attack.
Imagine the chessboard is set out with reference points 1 to 8 on the vertical and A to H across the horizontal.
At what positions would the five Queens need to be?
Hint: A couple queens next to each other can cover a lot.
Human Solution:
One concrete way to do it is to put the queens on  

A1 , C5 , F3 , E8 and H6.  

Why this works  

1.  Every row or column that contains a queen is obviously covered completely.  
   – Rows 1, 3, 5, 6 and 8 are occupied, hence entirely attacked.  
   – Columns A, C, E, F and H are occupied, hence entirely attacked.  

2.  What remains are rows 2, 4, 7 and columns B, D, G.  
    • Row 2 :  
      A2 (col A), B2 (diagonal from A1), C2 (col C), D2 (diagonal from H6),  
      E2 (diagonal from F3), F2 (diagonal from C5), G2 (diagonal from F3),  
      H2 (col H) – all attacked.  
    • Row 4 :  
      A4 (diagonal from E8), B4 (diagonal from C5), C4 (col C), D4 (diagonal from A1),  
      E4 (col E), F4 (diagonal from H6), G4 (diagonal from F3), H4 (col H) – all attacked.  
    • Row 7 :  
      A7 (diagonal from C5), B7 (diagonal from C5), C7 (col C), D7 (diagonal from E8),  
      E7 (col E), F7 (diagonal from E8), G7 (diagonal from A1), H7 (col H) – all attacked.  

3.  The four corner squares are definitely attacked:  
    – A1 is occupied.  
    – H8 lies in column H (queen on H6).  
    – A8 lies in column A (queen on A1).  
    – H1 lies in column H (queen on H6).  

Thus every single square, including the ones where the queens stand, is either occupied by a queen or attacked by at least one queen.

Final answer: A1, C5, F3, E8 and H6.
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. Select the specific arrangement of queens at A1, C5, F3, E8, and H6 so that, intuitively, their lines of attack criss-cross the whole board. (Creative)  
2. Observe that every row or column containing one of these queens is automatically fully attacked, giving full coverage of rows 1, 3, 5, 6, 8 and columns A, C, E, F, H. (Rudimentary)  
3. Identify the only rows and columns still to be checked for coverage: rows 2, 4, 7 and columns B, D, G. (Rudimentary)  
4. Verify row 2 square-by-square, showing each is attacked either vertically or diagonally by one of the chosen queens. (Rudimentary)  
5. Verify row 4 square-by-square in the same way, confirming full coverage. (Rudimentary)  
6. Verify row 7 square-by-square in the same way, confirming full coverage. (Rudimentary)  
7. Check the four corner squares (A1, H8, A8, H1) explicitly and confirm that each is either occupied by a queen or attacked by one. (Rudimentary)  
8. Conclude that every square on the chessboard is either occupied or attacked, so the arrangement satisfies the requirement. (Rudimentary)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 8  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. Select the specific arrangement of queens at A1, C5, F3, E8, and H6 so that, intuitively, their lines of attack criss-cross the whole board. (Creative)  
2. Observe that every row or column containing one of these queens is automatically fully attacked, giving full coverage of rows 1, 3, 5, 6, 8 and columns A, C, E, F, H. (Rudimentary)  
3. Identify the only rows and columns still to be checked for coverage: rows 2, 4, 7 and columns B, D, G. (Rudimentary)  
4. Verify row 2 square-by-square, showing each is attacked either vertically or diagonally by one of the chosen queens. (Rudimentary)  
5. Verify row 4 square-by-square in the same way, confirming full coverage. (Rudimentary)  
6. Verify row 7 square-by-square in the same way, confirming full coverage. (Rudimentary)  
7. Check the four corner squares (A1, H8, A8, H1) explicitly and confirm that each is either occupied by a queen or attacked by one. (Rudimentary)  
8. Conclude that every square on the chessboard is either occupied or attacked, so the arrangement satisfies the requirement. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
You are stuck in a room. All that is there is a slip of paper on a table, and many bottles. The only exit is guarded by a heat sensor that will not let you out. The only way out is to drink one of the bottles' contents, and the liquid will cool down your body heat (with no harm to yourself) enough so that the heat sensor doesn't detect you anymore. There are nine bottles on the ground beyond the table. The content of the slip of paper will tell you what each of the bottles are. Find out what all the bottles are, and then find out which one to drink to get out.
Three of me are poison, and will kill you if you drink.
Two of me are water, nothing bad will happen with these.
Two of me are wine, and it will only get you drunk.
One will heat you up forever, and this room will never let you out. (hinder)
Only one here will help you, it will cool down your body heat.
No medium bottles are poison.
Wine is bad in large doses, so none are large.
Each of the end bottles have the same contents.
No matter how help hides, it will be on poison's left side, but its left side is safe.
No two small bottles are the same.
The hinderer is harder, for it resides between wine and water.
The hinder bottle is large, so it works forever.
Neither big nor medium will save your life.
Poison is all you will get from the bottle on the far right.
Water is next to the helper.
Bottle Order:
Large--Small--Large--Medium--Small--Large--Medium--Large--Small
Hint: Use the fact that help must be small.
Human Solution:
Let us label the nine bottles 1-9 from left to right and note their sizes:

1 (L) – 2 (S) – 3 (L) – 4 (M) – 5 (S) – 6 (L) – 7 (M) – 8 (L) – 9 (S)

Key to contents:  
P = poison (3 bottles)  
W = water (2 bottles)  
V = wine  (2 bottles)  
H = hinderer (heats you) (1 bottle)  
C = cooler ‑ the helper (1 bottle)

Rules translated into logic
1. Bottles 1 and 9 are the same and rule 14 says the far-right bottle is poison ⇒ 1=9=P.  
2. There are exactly 3 poisons, so only one other P remains.  
3. “Neither big nor medium will save your life” ⇒ the helper C is small ⇒ C is bottle 2 or 5 (the only small bottles not already P).  
4. “No matter how help hides, it will be on poison’s left side” ⇒ C is immediately left of a P, and the bottle to C’s left is not poison.  
 • If C were bottle 2, bottle 3 would be P but then one neighbour of C must be water (rule “Water is next to the helper”).  Bottle 1 is already P, so impossible.  
 • Therefore C is bottle 5, and bottle 6 is the third (and last) poison. Bottle 4, the other neighbour of C, must be water.  
5. No medium bottle is poison ⇒ bottles 4 and 7 cannot be P (consistent).  
6. “Wine is bad in large doses, so none are large” ⇒ bottles 1,3,6,8 cannot be wine.  
7. “The hinderer… resides between wine and water” and “The hinder bottle is large” ⇒ some large bottle whose two immediate neighbours are wine and water is H.  

 Candidates for a large bottle with two neighbours: 3 and 6.  
 • Bottle 6’s neighbours are 5(C) and 7(M) – not wine & water.  
 • Bottle 3’s neighbours are 2(S) and 4(M).  We already have 4=W, so if 3 is H then 2 must be wine.  This fits every rule.

Thus: 2=V, 3=H, 4=W.

8. Counts so far  
P: 1,6,9  W: 4  V: 2  H: 3  C: 5  
We still need one more W and one more V, and bottles left undecided are 7(M) and 8(L).

 • Bottle 8 is large and cannot be wine ⇒ 8=W.  
 • Bottle 7 (medium, not poison) becomes the remaining wine ⇒ 7=V.

9. Check all rules – every one is satisfied.

Final layout
1 (L) P  2 (S) V  3 (L) H  4 (M) W  5 (S) C  6 (L) P  7 (M) V  8 (L) W  9 (S) P

The only bottle that cools you is number 5, the small bottle in the middle.

Final answer: Drink bottle 5 (the small fifth bottle); the other bottles are, in order, P-V-H-W-C-P-V-W-P.
Response:
Total Step Count: 11  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 9  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary)  Number and size the bottles 1-9 from left to right: L–S–L–M–S–L–M–L–S.  
2. (Rudimentary)  Apply “each end bottle is the same” together with “the far-right bottle is poison” to set bottles 1 and 9 as poison, leaving one poison still unassigned.  
3. (Rudimentary)  Use “neither big nor medium will save your life” to note the helper must be small; since 9 is already poison, the helper can only be bottle 2 or 5.  
4. (Creative)  Combine the three adjacency rules  
   • “help is on poison’s left side,”  
   • “its own left side is safe,” and  
   • “water is next to the helper”  
   to test the two helper candidates: placing the helper at 2 contradicts the water requirement, so the helper is at 5, forcing bottle 6 to be the third poison and bottle 4 to be water.  
5. (Rudimentary)  Confirm consistency with “no medium bottle is poison,” keeping bottles 4 and 7 non-poison.  
6. (Rudimentary)  Apply “none of the large bottles are wine” to mark bottles 1, 3, 6, 8 as not wine.  
7. (Creative)  Use the compound rule “the hinderer is large and lies between wine and water” to search large bottles with two neighbors: bottle 6 fails; bottle 3 succeeds if bottle 2 is wine, so fix 3 = hinderer and 2 = wine.  
8. (Rudimentary)  Tally remaining counts (one water, one wine still missing) and use “large ≠ wine” to set bottle 8 = water and bottle 7 = wine.  
9. (Rudimentary)  Verify that all numerical totals and adjacency conditions now match every rule.  
10. (Rudimentary)  Record the final content sequence: P–V–H–W–C–P–V–W–P.  
11. (Rudimentary)  Conclude the only cooling bottle is number 5; drink bottle 5 to escape.

   • “its own left side is safe,” and

   to test the two helper candidates: placing the helper at 2 contradicts the water requirement, so the helper is at 5, forcing bottle 6 to be the third poison and bottle 4 to be water.

11. (Rudimentary)  Conclude the only cooling bottle is number 5; drink bottle 5 to escape.']

Question:
You have the following equations:
a + c = a
b - c = c
c / b = c
a * a = b
You also know that a, b, c have the values 0, 1 and 2, but not necessarily in that order.
But to make matters more complicated the symbols + - * / have been mixed up: all you know is that each represents a different arithmetical operation (addition, subtraction, multiplication or division).
Can you work out the values of a, b and c, and what each of the symbols actually mean?
Hint: The only thing you should assume about the arithmetical symbols is that no two represent the same operation.
Human Solution:
Step 1.  Give names to the real operations  
Let  
⊕ = ordinary addition  
⊖ = ordinary subtraction  
⊗ = ordinary multiplication  
⊘ = ordinary division  

The four printed symbols ‘+ – * /’ are to be matched bijectively with ⊕, ⊖, ⊗, ⊘.

Step 2.  Use the fourth equation to pin down ‘*’  
a * a = b.  
If ‘*’ were ⊖ we would get b = 0, forcing a, c to be 1, 2; that
soon proves impossible (division by 0 in the third equation), so ‘*’ is
not ⊖.  
If ‘*’ were ⊗ then b = a²; with the allowed values 0, 1, 2 this would
give the duplicate value pair (0, 0) or the impossible value 4.  
If ‘*’ were ⊘ we would get b = 1, forcing a = 1 and duplicating a, b.  
Therefore ‘*’ must be ⊕.

Then a ⊕ a = b ⇒ b = 2a.  
With the distinct values 0, 1, 2 the only possibility is a = 1, b = 2,
so c = 0.

Step 3.  Determine what ‘+’ must be  
Equation (1): a + c = a → 1 + 0 = 1.  
With a = 1, c = 0 this is true only if ‘+’ is ⊖ (since 1 ⊖ 0 = 1, but
1 ⊗ 0 = 0 and 1 ⊘ 0 is impossible).  
Thus ‘+’ is ⊖.

Step 4.  Determine what ‘–’ must be  
Equation (2): b – c = c → 2 – 0 = 0.  
With b = 2, c = 0 this is true only if ‘–’ is ⊗, because 2 ⊗ 0 = 0,
whereas 2 ⊕ 0 = 2 and 2 ⊘ 0 is undefined.  
Thus ‘–’ is ⊗.

Step 5.  The remaining symbol ‘/’  
The bijection leaves only ⊘ unused, so ‘/’ must be ⊘.

Step 6.  Check the remaining equation  
Equation (3): c / b = c → 0 / 2 = 0.  
With ‘/’ = ⊘ this is 0 ⊘ 2 = 0, which is correct.

Everything is now consistent.

Conclusion  
Variables: a = 1, b = 2, c = 0  
Symbol meanings: 
* means ordinary addition (⊕)  
+ means ordinary subtraction (⊖)  
– means ordinary multiplication (⊗)  
/ means ordinary division (⊘)

Final answer: a = 1, b = 2, c = 0;  ‘*’ = +, ‘+’ = –, ‘–’ = ×, ‘/’ = ÷
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) Assign distinct “real” operation symbols (⊕, ⊖, ⊗, ⊘) to stand for ordinary +, –, ×, ÷ so the scrambled symbols can later be matched to them.  

2. (Creative) Use the fourth given equation a * a = b to test each possible real operation for ‘*’; rule out ⊖, ⊗, ⊘ by contradiction, leaving ‘*’ = ⊕ (ordinary addition).  

3. (Rudimentary) From a ⊕ a = b and the requirement a, b, c are 0, 1, 2 in some order and distinct, deduce the only consistent assignment a = 1, b = 2, c = 0.  

4. (Rudimentary) Substitute a = 1, c = 0 into a + c = a to identify ‘+’ as ⊖ (ordinary subtraction).  

5. (Rudimentary) Substitute b = 2, c = 0 into b – c = c to identify ‘–’ as ⊗ (ordinary multiplication).  

6. (Rudimentary) Note that the only unassigned real operation left for ‘/’ is ⊘ (ordinary division).  

7. (Rudimentary) Verify consistency with the remaining equation c / b = c (0 ⊘ 2 = 0), confirming all assignments.

['Total Step Count: 7  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) Assign distinct “real” operation symbols (⊕, ⊖, ⊗, ⊘) to stand for ordinary +, –, ×, ÷ so the scrambled symbols can later be matched to them.  

2. (Creative) Use the fourth given equation a * a = b to test each possible real operation for ‘*’; rule out ⊖, ⊗, ⊘ by contradiction, leaving ‘*’ = ⊕ (ordinary addition).  

3. (Rudimentary) From a ⊕ a = b and the requirement a, b, c are 0, 1, 2 in some order and distinct, deduce the only consistent assignment a = 1, b = 2, c = 0.  

4. (Rudimentary) Substitute a = 1, c = 0 into a + c = a to identify ‘+’ as ⊖ (ordinary subtraction).  

5. (Rudimentary) Substitute b = 2, c = 0 into b – c = c to identify ‘–’ as ⊗ (ordinary multiplication).  

6. (Rudimentary) Note that the only unassigned real operation left for ‘/’ is ⊘ (ordinary division).  

7. (Rudimentary) Verify consistency with the remaining equation c / b = c (0 ⊘ 2 = 0), confirming all assignments.']

Question:
You are in a game show with four other contestants.  The objective is to crack the combination of the safe using the clues, and the first person to do so will win $500,000.
The safe combination looks like this:
??-??-??-??
A digit can be used more than once in the code, and there are no leading zeroes.
Here are the clues:
1. The third set of two numbers is the same as the first set reversed.
2. There are no 2's, 3's, 4's or 5's in any of the combination.
3. If you multiply 4 by the third set of numbers, you will get the fourth set of numbers.
4. If you add the first number in the first set with the first number in the second set you will get 8.
5. The second set of numbers is not greater than 20.
6. The second number in the second set multiplied by the second number in the fourth set equals one higher than the numbers in the first set.
And get moving, I think another contestant has almost figured it out!
Hint: Clue 3 says if you multiply 4 by the third set of numbers you will get the fourth set of numbers.  From this, you can tell a 1 is the first number in the third set - any other number would be too high.
Human Solution:
Reasoning:

Let the four two-digit sets be
  First set = AB,
  Second set = CD,
  Third set = EF,
  Fourth set = GH,
where A,C,E,G are the tens digits and B,D,F,H are the units digits.

1. “The third set … is the same as the first set reversed.”
   ⇒ EF = BA.  Thus E = B and F = A.

2. “No 2’s, 3’s, 4’s or 5’s” ⇒ allowed digits are 0,1,6,7,8,9 (and no leading 0).

3. “4 × (third set) = fourth set”
   ⇒ 4 × (10E + F) = 10G + H.

   But E=B and F=A, so
   4 × (10B + A) = 10G + H.                        (★)

4. “First number of first set + first number of second set = 8”
   ⇒ A + C = 8.                                    (†)

5. “Second set is not greater than 20.”
   ⇒ C must be 1 (because the only two-digit numbers ≤20 start with 1).

   From (†) we get A = 7.

   So the first set is 7B and the third set is B7.

6. “Second number of second set × second number of fourth set = one higher than the numbers in the first set”
   ⇒ D × H = 71 + 1 = 72.                         (‡)

Now use (★).  With A = 7,

   4 × (10B + 7) = 10G + H.

Because the product must still be two digits, 4 × (10B+7) ≤ 99
⇒ 10B + 7 ≤ 24.75 ⇒ B ≤ 1 (and B ≠ 0 because that would give a leading 0 in the third set).

Hence B = 1.

Then
   Third set = 17,
   4 × 17 = 68  ⇒ fourth set = 68, so H = 8.

From (‡), D × 8 = 72 ⇒ D = 9.

The second set (with C = 1) is therefore 19, which satisfies “not greater than 20”.

All conditions are now met:

  First set: 71
  Second set: 19
  Third set: 17 (71 reversed)
  Fourth set: 68 (4 × 17)

Digits used: 7,1,9,6,8 (none of 2,3,4,5); all clues verified.

Final answer: 71-19-17-68
Response:
Total Step Count: 14  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 12  

Steps:  
1. Introduce notation: call the four two-digit parts AB, CD, EF, GH (tens digits A,C,E,G and units digits B,D,F,H). (Rudimentary)  

2. Apply Clue 1 (“third set is the first set reversed”) to get EF = BA, hence E = B and F = A. (Rudimentary)  

3. Apply Clue 2 (“no 2’s, 3’s, 4’s or 5’s”) to list the admissible digits: 0, 1, 6, 7, 8, 9 (with no leading 0). (Rudimentary)  

4. Translate Clue 3 (“4 × third set = fourth set”) into 4 × (10E + F) = 10G + H and, using E = B and F = A, obtain 4 × (10B + A) = 10G + H. (Rudimentary)  

5. Translate Clue 4 (“first digit of first set + first digit of second set = 8”) to get A + C = 8. (Rudimentary)  

6. Use Clue 5 (“second set ≤ 20”) together with the allowed-digit list to conclude the tens digit of that set is forced to be 1, i.e. C = 1. (Creative)  

7. Combine A + C = 8 with C = 1 to obtain A = 7. (Rudimentary)  

8. Record what is now known: first set is 7B, third set (its reverse) is B7. (Rudimentary)  

9. Translate Clue 6 (“second units digit × fourth units digit = one higher than the first set”) into D × H = (71) + 1 = 72. (Rudimentary)  

10. Note that 4 × (10B + 7) must still be a two-digit number; hence 4 × (10B + 7) ≤ 99, giving 10B + 7 ≤ 24.75 → B ≤ 1.  Because B ≠ 0 (leading-zero rule), deduce B = 1. (Creative)  

11. With B = 1, fix the third set as 17 and calculate 4 × 17 = 68, so the fourth set is 68 and H = 8. (Rudimentary)  

12. Use D × 8 = 72 to solve for D = 9. (Rudimentary)  

13. Assemble the second set from C = 1, D = 9 → 19, confirming it is indeed ≤ 20. (Rudimentary)  

14. Collect all pieces: first set 71, second set 19, third set 17, fourth set 68; verify every clue, producing the final safe combination 71-19-17-68. (Rudimentary)

Creative ', ' 2

Question:
Five men at a board games club meet once a week to play their favourite board game 'Hollywood Quest'. In this game each space is colour coded one of five colours, each one representing a category of questions.
The five categories are Books, Celebrities, Films, Music, Television.
The five colours are blue, green, grey, orange and purple.
Can you name all five men, their favorite categories and the colours represented by those categories?
CLUES
1. Mr Everett prefers the purple coloured squares.
2. Mr Harper likes Films category best, which is not the blue nor the orange squares.
3. Johns Sanders doesn't like literature-based questions.
4. Patrick's favourite colour is the blue (this is not the colour of the TV questions).
5. The grey squares indicate a player must answer a question about books, and Mr Erwin won't land on these if he can help it.
6. Graham prefers the celebrities category.
7. James avoids the green and orange squares.
8. Kendal is the fifth surname, and Paul the missing first name.
Hint:
Clues 1,2 and 5 should help you work out the colour Mr Harper likes.
Work out Johns Sanders' favourite colour.
You should now be able to work out the colours of all five subjects.
Human Solution:
Graham Everett – Celebrities – Purple  
Paul Harper – Films – Green  
John Sanders – Television – Orange  
Patrick Erwin – Music – Blue  
James Kendal – Books – Grey  

Final answer: Graham Everett with Celebrities on purple; Paul Harper with Films on green; John Sanders with Television on orange; Patrick Erwin with Music on blue; James Kendal with Books on grey.
Response:
Total Step Count: 13  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 13  

Steps:  
1. List the five first-name slots (unknown), the five surnames (Everett, Harper, Sanders, Erwin, Kendal), the five colours (blue, green, grey, orange, purple) and the five categories (Books, Celebrities, Films, Music, Television) to form the basic grid for the logic puzzle.  
2. From clue 1, fix Mr Everett’s colour as purple.  
3. From clue 5, fix the relationship Books ↔ grey squares.  
4. Still from clue 5, note that Mr Erwin “won’t land on” grey, so Mr Erwin’s colour is not grey and his category is not Books.  
5. From clue 6, fix Graham’s favourite category as Celebrities.  
6. From clue 2, fix Mr Harper’s favourite category as Films and note that his colour is neither blue nor orange.  
7. From clue 4, fix Patrick’s favourite colour as blue and note that blue is not the Television colour.  
8. From clue 7, note that James’s colour cannot be green or orange.  
9. Use clue 8 to complete the name pairs: Kendal is the fifth surname and Paul is the unused first name, giving the five complete names—Graham Everett, Paul Harper, John Sanders, Patrick Erwin, James Kendal.  
10. Assign the grey/Books combination to the only person who can take it: James Kendal (he is not barred from grey by any clue, and John Sanders cannot have Books).  
11. With grey used, the only colour open to Paul Harper that is neither blue nor orange is green, so assign green to Paul Harper.  
12. The remaining unused colour is orange; assign it to John Sanders (James cannot take orange, and all others already have colours).  
13. The remaining unassigned categories are Music and Television; clue 4 forbids Patrick Erwin’s blue square from being Television, so assign Music to Patrick Erwin and Television to John Sanders, completing the grid.

Question:
In Major League Baseball, the World Series is a best of seven series.  The first team to win four games is the champion.  The Series is scheduled so that one team hosts the first two games and the last two games, while the other team hosts the middle three games.  The World Series ends as soon as one team wins four games, so the Series could be completed in as few as four games.
In this fantasy Series, the New York Yankees played the Los Angeles Dodgers.  Los Angeles hosted the first two games.  The final scores of the games were:
Game 1:  4 to 3
Game 2:  6 to 5 (11 innings)
Game 3:  11 to 7
Game 4:  16 to 9
Game 5:  9 to 6 (10 innings)
Game 6:  2 to 1
Game 7:  13 to 8 (13 innings)
Which team won the World Series?
Hint: In baseball, the home team bats last.
Human Solution:
We know which park each game was played in:

• Los Angeles was the home team for Games 1, 2, 6, 7.  
• New York was the home team for Games 3, 4, 5.

Because seven scores are listed, the Series lasted the maximum seven games; therefore each club had three wins after six games and the Game 7 winner became champion.

To decide who won Game 7 (and thus the Series) we use a basic rule of baseball scoring:

– The home team bats last.  
– In an extra-inning game, play stops the moment the home team scores the go-ahead run, so the home team can win by at most four runs (a walk-off grand slam) in extra innings.

Game 7 went 13 innings and ended 13–8, a margin of five runs.  
A five-run margin is impossible for the home team in extra innings, so the visiting team must have scored the 13 runs and then retired the home team scoreless in the bottom of the 13th.

The visiting team in Game 7 was New York (Los Angeles was hosting).  
Therefore New York won Game 7 and collected its fourth victory.

Final answer: The New York Yankees won the World Series.
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Identify which games each club hosted from the 2-3-2 scheduling format, concluding Los Angeles was home in Games 1, 2, 6, 7 and New York was home in Games 3, 4, 5. (Rudimentary)  

2. Note that seven game scores are given, so the Series went the full seven games; therefore both teams had three wins after six games and the Game 7 winner is the champion. (Rudimentary)  

3. Invoke the key baseball insight: in extra innings the home team can win by at most four runs because play stops the instant the home team scores the go-ahead run (walk-off rule). (Creative)  

4. Observe that Game 7 lasted 13 innings and ended 13–8, a five-run margin, which exceeds the maximum possible margin for the home team; hence the visiting team must have scored the 13 runs. (Rudimentary)  

5. Recognize that New York was the visiting team in Game 7 (Los Angeles was hosting), so New York won that game and thus won the World Series. (Rudimentary)

Question:
A tourist group of 86 people broke up into two groups. The smaller group went to the beach, and the bigger group went to see a water mill. The following statements are all true. How many people were in each group?
a) A quarter of the people in one of the groups is more than the number of people in the other group.
b) One of the groups contains 6 times as many women as men.
c) One of the groups contains only married couples.
d) The number of people in one of the groups is divisible by 4.
e) One of the groups contains 8 times as many people who are younger than 50 as those who are at least 50 years old.
Hint: Set up an equation.
Human Solution:
Let  
x = number of tourists that went to the beach (the smaller group)  
y = number of tourists that went to the water-mill (the larger group)

We have  
x + y = 86  (1)  
x < y.  

-------------------------------------------------
1.  Statement (a):  “A quarter of the people in one of the groups is more than the number of people in the other group.”

If ¼ of a group is larger than the other group, that group must be the larger one.  
So

¼ y > x  ⇒  y > 4x  (2)

From (1) and (2): 86 – x > 4x  ⇒  86 > 5x  ⇒  x ≤ 17.          (3)
Hence the beach group has at most 17 people.

-------------------------------------------------
2.  Statement (b):  “One of the groups contains 6 times as many women as men.”

If a group has M men and 6M women, its size is 7M, i.e. a multiple of 7.  
So one of x, y is divisible by 7.          (4)

-------------------------------------------------
3.  Statement (c):  “One of the groups contains only married couples.”

That group must consist of pairs, so its size is an even number 2C, with C men and C women.          (5)

-------------------------------------------------
4.  Statement (d):  “The number of people in one of the groups is divisible by 4.”

Hence one of x, y is a multiple of 4.          (6)

-------------------------------------------------
5.  Statement (e):  “One of the groups contains 8 times as many people under 50 as at least 50.”

If a group has O people aged 50 + and 8O younger people, its size is 9O, i.e. a multiple of 9.  
So one of x, y is divisible by 9.          (7)

-------------------------------------------------
Because there are only two groups, the “6 : 1” group of (b) and the “all married couples” group of (c) must be different groups (they cannot both describe the same group).  Two cases are possible.

–––––––––––––––––––––––––
CASE 1   (The 6 : 1 group is the larger group)

Let the larger group be the 6 : 1 group.  Let its size be 7k (k men, 6k women).  
The smaller group (all couples) then has size 2c.

7k + 2c = 86  
and from (2) 7k > 8c ⇒ 2c ≤ 17 ⇒ c ≤ 8.

Trying c = 1 … 8 shows that the only integral possibilities are  
(c, k) = (1,12) giving sizes (2,84) or (8,10) giving sizes (16,70),  
but neither 2,84 nor 16,70 is divisible by 9, so (e) cannot be satisfied.  
Hence Case 1 is impossible.

–––––––––––––––––––––––––
CASE 2   (The “all-couples” group is the larger group)

Let the larger group (all couples) have size 2c.  
Let the smaller group (6 : 1) have size 7k.

7k + 2c = 86  (1′)

From (2): 2c > 28k ⇒ c > 14k.          (2′)

Try small integer k (remember x ≤17 so 7k ≤17 ⇒ k ≤2).

• k = 1: 2c = 79, impossible.  
• k = 2: 7k = 14, so 2c = 72 ⇒ c = 36, and indeed c > 14k (36 > 28).

Thus

smaller group size  = 7k = 14  
larger group size   = 2c = 72.

Check every statement:

a) ¼·72 = 18 > 14 ✔  
b) Small group 14 = 2 men + 12 women (ratio 6 : 1) ✔  
c) Large group 72 = 36 married couples ✔  
d) 72 is divisible by 4 ✔  
e) 72 = 9·8, so choose 8 people aged 50 +, 64 under 50 (ratio 1 : 8) ✔

All conditions are met.

Therefore the only possible split is  

Beach group: 14 people  
Water-mill group: 72 people.

Final answer: 14 people went to the beach and 72 people went to the water mill.
Response:
Total Step Count: 12  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 10  

Steps:  
1. Introduce variables x (beach) and y (water-mill) with the relations x + y = 86 and x < y. (Rudimentary)  

2. Use statement (a): “¼ of one group exceeds the other” to reason that the larger group must be the one being quartered, derive y > 4x, combine with x + y = 86 to obtain x ≤ 17. (Creative)  

3. Translate statement (b) into the fact that the size of the “6 : 1 (women : men)” group must be a multiple of 7. (Rudimentary)  

4. Translate statement (c) into the fact that the “all-married-couples” group size must be an even number 2C. (Rudimentary)  

5. Translate statement (d) into the condition that one group size is divisible by 4. (Rudimentary)  

6. Translate statement (e) into the condition that one group size is divisible by 9. (Rudimentary)  

7. Observe that the group described in (b) and the group described in (c) cannot be the same group because there are only two groups in total. (Creative)  

8. Case 1: Assume the larger group is the “6 : 1” group (size 7k) and the smaller is the “couples” group (size 2c); set up 7k + 2c = 86 and y > 4x ⇒ 7k > 8c, giving c ≤ 8. (Rudimentary)  

9. Test c = 1 … 8, find the only integral pairs (c, k) = (1, 12) and (8, 10) produce sizes (2, 84) and (16, 70), neither divisible by 9, hence Case 1 is impossible. (Rudimentary)  

10. Case 2: Assume the larger group is the “couples” group (size 2c) and the smaller is the “6 : 1” group (size 7k); set up 7k + 2c = 86, apply 2c > 28k, and use x ≤ 17 ⇒ 7k ≤ 17 ⇒ k ≤ 2; test k = 1, 2 and obtain k = 2, c = 36 leading to sizes 14 and 72. (Rudimentary)  

11. Verify that the pair (14, 72) satisfies all conditions (a)–(e). (Rudimentary)  

12. State the final result: 14 tourists went to the beach and 72 went to the water mill. (Rudimentary)

Question:
This teaser is a mixture of logic and math. In a number pyramid, the numbers 0-9 are each used once and formed into a pyramid, with one digits at the top, and right below it two digits, below those three digits, and below those four, all arranged in pyramid form. I can not show you a pyramid due to formatting issues.
In this puzzle, you will follow the clues given, and using these clues, create a number pyramid. There is only one answer.
Clues:
1. The number at the apex, or top, of the pyramid minus the leftmost number in the fourth row equals 7.
2. The middle, or second, number in the third row minus the rightmost number in the third row equals 4.
3. The four numbers in row 4 sum to 8.
4. In the second row, the rightmost number minus the leftmost number equals 1.
5. The four rightmost numbers in each row sum to 25.
6. The numbers 1 and 2 are not adjacent to each other.
Hint: The apex of this pyramid is 9.
Human Solution:
Label the ten places in the pyramid as

Row 1 : A  
Row 2 : B  C  
Row 3 : D  E  F  
Row 4 : G  H  I  J

so that

A  
B C  
D E F  
G H I J  

and each of the digits 0–9 is used exactly once.

Translate the clues:

1. A – G = 7.  
2. E – F = 4.  
3. G + H + I + J = 8.  
4. C – B = 1.  
5. A + C + F + J = 25.  
6. 1 and 2 are not in adjacent positions.

------------------------------------------------
Step 1 – Find the four bottom digits  
Clue 3 demands four distinct digits that total 8.  
Distinct quadruples from 0–9 that work are {0, 1, 2, 5} and {0, 1, 3, 4}.

------------------------------------------------
Step 2 – Use clue 1 to locate G  
Because A – G = 7 and digits are at most 9, G can only be 0, 1, 2.  
If the bottom set were {0, 1, 3, 4}, the digit 2 is missing, so G could be only 0 or 1.  
Both of those possibilities fail when the other clues are imposed (every branch soon violates
clues 2, 4 or 5).  
Hence the bottom row must be {0, 1, 2, 5}.

------------------------------------------------
Step 3 – Try the three possibilities for G

a) G = 0 → A = 7   fails (cannot satisfy clue 5).

b) G = 1 → A = 8   fails (cannot satisfy clues 2 & 5 simultaneously).

c) G = 2 → A = 9   possible, keep exploring.

So we keep G = 2 and A = 9.  
The remaining bottom digits are 0, 1, 5.

------------------------------------------------
Step 4 – Apply clue 5  
A + C + F + J = 25 ⇒ C + F + J = 16.

Test the three choices for J (the right-most bottom digit):

• J = 0 → C + F = 16 impossible (F ≤ 5 by clue 2).  
• J = 1 → C + F = 15 impossible.  
• J = 5 → C + F = 11 possible.

Thus J = 5, leaving H and I to be 0 and 1.

------------------------------------------------
Step 5 – Work upwards with clues 2 and 4

Clue 2: E – F = 4  ⇒ E = F + 4 and F ≤ 5.

Clue 4: C – B = 1  ⇒ C = B + 1.

We already have C + F = 11, so
(B + 1) + F = 11  ⇒  B + F = 10.

Try the admissible values of F (0–5, not yet used 0,1,5):

F = 4 gives B = 6 and C = 7  (all unused and distinct).  
F = 5 is impossible (5 already used as J).  
F ≤ 3 makes B ≥ 7 which would repeat a digit.

Hence F = 4, E = 8 (because E = F + 4), B = 6, C = 7.

------------------------------------------------
Step 6 – Place the last two bottom digits

The bottom row now is 2 H I 5 with {H, I} = {0, 1}.  
To obey clue 6 (1 and 2 not adjacent) the 1 must not go next to the 2, so

Row 4 : 2 0 1 5  (G = 2, H = 0, I = 1, J = 5).

------------------------------------------------
Step 7 – The only unused digit is 3  
The single remaining position is D, so D = 3.

------------------------------------------------
Step 8 – Verify every clue

A = 9, B = 6, C = 7, D = 3, E = 8, F = 4, G = 2, H = 0, I = 1, J = 5.

1) 9 – 2 = 7 ✔  
2) 8 – 4 = 4 ✔  
3) 2 + 0 + 1 + 5 = 8 ✔  
4) 7 – 6 = 1 ✔  
5) 9 + 7 + 4 + 5 = 25 ✔  
6) Digits 1 (row 4 col 3) and 2 (row 4 col 1) are separated by 0, so not adjacent ✔

------------------------------------------------
The unique number pyramid is therefore

        9  
    6     7  
  3    8     4  
2    0    1    5

Final answer: 9 / 6 7 / 3 8 4 / 2 0 1 5
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary)  Use clue 3 (G + H + I + J = 8) to enumerate all distinct 4-digit sets from 0–9 whose sum is 8, obtaining {0, 1, 2, 5} and {0, 1, 3, 4}.  

2. (Creative)  Combine clue 1 (A – G = 7) with the digit range 0–9 to deduce G ∈ {0, 1, 2}.  Observe that if the bottom set were {0, 1, 3, 4}, the digit 2 would be missing, forcing G = 0 or 1; trying either value quickly contradicts other clues, so the only viable bottom row is {0, 1, 2, 5}.  

3. (Rudimentary)  Test the three remaining possibilities for G in that set:  
 a) G = 0 → A = 7 (fails).  
 b) G = 1 → A = 8 (fails).  
 c) G = 2 → A = 9 (works, so keep G = 2, A = 9).  

4. (Rudimentary)  Apply clue 5 (A + C + F + J = 25): with A = 9 get C + F + J = 16.  Test J = 0, 1, 5; only J = 5 allows C + F = 11, so fix J = 5 and leave H, I = 0, 1.  

5. (Creative)  Use clues 2 (E – F = 4) and 4 (C – B = 1) together with C + F = 11 to form B + F = 10.  Explore admissible F (≤5 and unused): F = 4 gives B = 6, C = 7, and E = 8, all distinct and unused—this satisfies every condition; all other F’s fail.  

6. (Rudimentary)  Place the remaining bottom digits H = 0 and I = 1 so that 1 is not adjacent to 2, giving Row 4 = 2 0 1 5.  

7. (Rudimentary)  Assign the only unused digit, 3, to the only empty position D.  

8. (Rudimentary)  Check every clue against the completed assignment (A = 9, B = 6, C = 7, D = 3, E = 8, F = 4, G = 2, H = 0, I = 1, J = 5) to confirm all are satisfied, establishing the unique pyramid.

2. (Creative)  Combine clue 1 (A – G = 7) with the digit range 0–9 to deduce G ∈ {0, 1, 2}.  Observe that if the bottom set were {0, 1, 3, 4}, the digit 2 would be missing, forcing G = 0 or 1; trying either value quickly contradicts other clues, so the only viable bottom row is {0, 1, 2, 5}.

Question:
Mad Ade, Daft Derrick, Sue Denim, two pieces of Madadian "Kebabrie" Cheese, two pieces of Madadian "Chillirella" Cheese, and "Beef Curry" the dog were on their way to the annual Madadian combined Cheese and Dog show (it's Madadian, these things happen).
Mad Ade's "Kebabretta" scooter can only carry two objects at a time.
Mad Ade, Daft Derrick and Sue Denim can all drive the scooter. If Mad Ade is not around, Daft Derrick will eat the "Kebabrie"; if Daft Derrick is not around, Mad Ade will eat the "Chillirella". If Sue Denim is not around, "Beef Curry" will eat the cheese and bite Mad Ade and Daft Derrick.
Can they all get to the Cheese/Dog show without anything bad happening?
If so, what's the smallest number of trips needed (each way counts as one trip)?
Hint: Sue Denim should go first with someone
Human Solution:
Label  
A = Mad Ade, D = Daft Derrick, S = Sue Denim, B = “Beef Curry”  
K1,K2 = two pieces of Kebabrie, C1,C2 = two pieces of Chillirella.  
The scooter always contains exactly two “objects”, one of which must be the driver.  
Left bank = start, Right bank = dog/cheese show.

Forbidden situations  
1.  (¬A) & (D with any K) ⇒ K is eaten.  
2.  (¬D) & (A with any C) ⇒ C is eaten.  
3.  (¬S) & (B with cheese or with A or with D) ⇒ B eats/ bites.  
B on his own is harmless.

Idea  
First get B to the right, then leave S on the right for the rest of the journey – she keeps B quiet while D shuttles the remaining objects across.  
Before D can start shuttling, every Chillirella must be removed from the left bank (otherwise A would be left alone with C and eat it when D departs).  
With the capacity constraint that is the best we can do; it yields the minimal possible number of crossings.

Crossing schedule (10 trips)

 1. S + B → R   (L: A D K1 K2 C1 C2) (R: S B)  
 2. S ←      (L: A D K1 K2 C1 C2 S) (R: B)  
 3. S + C1 → R  (L: A D K1 K2 C2)   (R: S B C1) – S now stays on R  
 4. D + C2 → R  (L: A K1 K2)     (R: S B C1 C2 D)  
 5. D ←     (L: A D K1 K2)    (R: S B C1 C2)  
 6. D + K1 → R  (L: A K2)      (R: S B C1 C2 D K1)  
 7. D ←     (L: A D K2)     (R: S B C1 C2 K1)  
 8. D + K2 → R  (L: A)       (R: S B C1 C2 D K1 K2)  
 9. D ←     (L: A D)      (R: S B C1 C2 K1 K2)  
10. D + A → R  (L: – )      (R: A D S B C1 C2 K1 K2)

Check after every move: all forbidden combinations are avoided (Sue is always present with B when cheese or the men are there; A is never left alone with Chillirella; Derrick is never left with Kebabrie unless A is also present).

Optimality  
After trip 3 Sue must stay with B forever. Five objects (D, A, K1, K2, C2) remain on the left bank.  
D is the only driver available there, so:

• last outward trip brings two new objects (D and one other);  
• the other three objects each cost a return-and-outward pair.

Hence the minimum number of trips after Sue settles on the right is 2·3 + 1 = 7.  
Adding the first three trips (to place S and B and one C on the right) gives 7 + 3 = 10.  
Therefore 10 trips is the absolute minimum.

Final answer: Yes – they can all arrive safely in exactly 10 scooter trips.
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. Assign symbols to every person, dog and cheese piece, and restate the scooter-capacity rule. (Rudimentary)  

2. Translate the “eating/biting” clauses into three explicit forbidden situations that must never occur on either river bank. (Rudimentary)  

3. Produce the core strategy: first transport the dog with Sue, then keep Sue permanently on the destination side so she can guard the dog while the remaining transfers take place. (Creative)  

4. Notice the extra precaution that both Chillirella pieces must leave the start side before Derrick begins shuttling, otherwise Ade would ever be left alone with Chillirella and eat it. (Creative)  

5. Observe that with the scooter holding exactly two objects, the strategy in Steps 3–4 is feasible within the capacity limits. (Rudimentary)  

6. Work out and list a concrete 10-trip crossing schedule that obeys all the constraints produced in Steps 2–4. (Rudimentary)  

7. Check after every move of that schedule that none of the forbidden situations is ever realised. (Rudimentary)  

8. Prove optimality: argue that once Sue is marooned with the dog, five objects remain, Derrick is the sole driver left on the start side, and this forces at least seven more crossings; adding the first three crossings gives a lower bound of ten, so the schedule is minimal. (Creative)  

9. State the final result: everyone and everything can arrive safely in exactly ten trips, which is the smallest possible number. (Rudimentary)
