3. Produce the core strategy: first transport the dog with Sue, then keep Sue permanently on the destination side so she can guard the dog while the remaining transfers take place. (Creative)  

4. Notice the extra precaution that both Chillirella pieces must leave the start side before Derrick begins shuttling, otherwise Ade would ever be left alone with Chillirella and eat it. (Creative)

Question:
The answer I give is yes, but what I mean is no.
What was the question?
Human Solution:
We need a yes-or-no question whose ordinary English usage makes the meanings of its possible answers run opposite to the literal words “yes” and “no.”

The classic example is a permission question of the form  
“Do you mind if I … ?”

• If you reply “Yes,” you are literally saying “Yes, I DO mind,”
  which is the same as refusing permission—in other words, “No, please don’t.”

• If you reply “No,” you are literally saying “No, I DON’T mind,”
  which grants permission—in other words, “Yes, go ahead.”

Thus, when you answer “Yes,” what you really mean regarding the requested action is “No.”

So the question was:  
“Do you mind?” (or, more fully, “Do you mind if I … ?”)

Final answer: Do you mind (if I … )?
Response:
Total Step Count: 4  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. Restate the task: we must find a yes-or-no question whose answers invert the literal meanings of “yes” and “no.” (Rudimentary)  
2. Recall/recognize that the permission-seeking form “Do you mind if I …?” is a standard English construction with just that inversion property. (Creative)  
3. Demonstrate the inversion: “Yes” → “Yes, I do mind” → refusal (effectively “No”); “No” → “No, I don’t mind” → permission (effectively “Yes”). (Rudimentary)  
4. Conclude that the original question must have been “Do you mind?” or, more fully, “Do you mind if I …?” (Rudimentary)

4. Conclude that the original question must have been “Do you mind?” or, more fully, “Do you mind if I …?” (Rudimentary)']

Question:
Recently, Snow White's seven dwarfs met up with three of their friends and went to the cinema to see Bambi. From the clues below, can you determine the order in which they stood in the ticket queue?
Grumpy was in front of Dopey. Stumpy was behind Sneezy and Doc. Doc was in front of Droopy and Happy.
Sleepy was behind Stumpy, Smelly and Happy.
Happy was in front of Sleepy, Smelly and Bashful.
Bashful was behind Smelly, Droopy and Sleepy.
Sneezy was in front of Dopey. Smelly was in front of Grumpy, Stumpy and Sneezy.
Dopey was in front of Droopy.
Sleepy was in front of Grumpy and Bashful.
Dopey was behind Sneezy, Doc and Sleepy.
Stumpy was in front of Dopey. Smelly was behind Doc.
Hint: Lots of people must be behind Doc...
Human Solution:
Let us denote the ten people by the initials  

 Dc (Doc) Hp (Happy) Sm (Smelly) Sn (Sneezy) St (Stumpy)  
 Sl (Sleepy) Gr (Grumpy) Dp (Dopey) Dr (Droopy) Ba (Bashful)

Every statement in the problem gives a “ in-front/behind ” relation, i.e. a strict ordering relation “ > ” (a > b means a is farther forward in the queue than b).  
Translating every clue we obtain

1 Gr > Dp  
2 Sn > St  Dc > St  
3 Dc > Dr  Dc > Hp  
4 St > Sl  Sm > Sl  Hp > Sl  
5 Hp > Sm  Hp > Ba  
6 Sm > Ba  Dr > Ba  Sl > Ba  
7 Sn > Dp  
8 Sm > Gr  Sm > St  Sm > Sn  
9 Dp > Dr  
10 Sl > Gr  Sl > Ba  
11 Dc > Dp  Sl > Dp  
12 St > Dp  
13 Dc > Sm  

Now we look for people who have no one in front of them (no predecessors).  
Only Doc is never said to be behind anyone, so Doc must head the queue:

 1. Doc

Doc is in front of Happy (clue 3) and of Smelly (clue 13).  
Happy is stated to be in front of Smelly (clue 5), so the next two places must be

 2. Happy  3. Smelly

Smelly is in front of Sneezy (clue 8); Sneezy is in front of Stumpy (clue 2); Stumpy is in front of Sleepy (clue 4), and Sleepy is in front of Grumpy (clue 10).  
Laying these pieces consecutively gives

 4. Sneezy 5. Stumpy 6. Sleepy 7. Grumpy

Grumpy is in front of Dopey (clue 1), and Dopey is in front of Droopy (clue 9):

 8. Dopey 9. Droopy

Finally, Bashful has to be behind Smelly, Sleepy and Droopy (clues 5 & 6).  
All three of those are already in front of position 10, so the only place left for Bashful is

 10. Bashful

List obtained:
1 Doc  
2 Happy  
3 Smelly  
4 Sneezy  
5 Stumpy  
6 Sleepy  
7 Grumpy  
8 Dopey  
9 Droopy  
10  Bashful

A quick check shows every original clause is satisfied, and every place has been fixed uniquely. Therefore the queue was exactly in the order written above.

Final answer: Doc, Happy, Smelly, Sneezy, Stumpy, Sleepy, Grumpy, Dopey, Droopy, Bashful
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. Translate every verbal clue into strict “is in front of” inequalities, producing a complete list of pair-wise relations among the ten names. (Rudimentary)  

2. Look for a person that never appears on the “behind” side of any inequality; observe that only Doc satisfies this, so Doc must head the queue. (Creative)  

3. Use the relations Doc > Happy, Doc > Smelly and Happy > Smelly to deduce the only possible ordering of the next two positions: 2nd = Happy, 3rd = Smelly. (Rudimentary)  

4. Chain the relations Smelly > Sneezy, Sneezy > Stumpy, Stumpy > Sleepy and Sleepy > Grumpy to form a linear subsequence and place them consecutively as positions 4 through 7. (Rudimentary)  

5. Apply Grumpy > Dopey and Dopey > Droopy to extend the queue, fixing positions 8 (Dopey) and 9 (Droopy). (Rudimentary)  

6. Note that Bashful must be behind Smelly, Sleepy and Droopy; with all earlier spots already occupied, the only remaining place is 10th, so Bashful is last. (Rudimentary)  

7. Verify that the completed list 1 Doc, 2 Happy, 3 Smelly, 4 Sneezy, 5 Stumpy, 6 Sleepy, 7 Grumpy, 8 Dopey, 9 Droopy, 10 Bashful satisfies every original inequality, confirming the solution is unique and correct. (Rudimentary)

2. Look for a person that never appears on the “behind” side of any inequality; observe that only Doc satisfies this, so Doc must head the queue. (Creative)  

3. Use the relations Doc > Happy, Doc > Smelly and Happy > Smelly to deduce the only possible ordering of the next two positions: 2nd = Happy, 3rd = Smelly. (Rudimentary)  

4. Chain the relations Smelly > Sneezy, Sneezy > Stumpy, Stumpy > Sleepy and Sleepy > Grumpy to form a linear subsequence and place them consecutively as positions 4 through 7. (Rudimentary)  

5. Apply Grumpy > Dopey and Dopey > Droopy to extend the queue, fixing positions 8 (Dopey) and 9 (Droopy). (Rudimentary)  

6. Note that Bashful must be behind Smelly, Sleepy and Droopy; with all earlier spots already occupied, the only remaining place is 10th, so Bashful is last. (Rudimentary)  

7. Verify that the completed list 1 Doc, 2 Happy, 3 Smelly, 4 Sneezy, 5 Stumpy, 6 Sleepy, 7 Grumpy, 8 Dopey, 9 Droopy, 10 Bashful satisfies every original inequality, confirming the solution is unique and correct. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
You are a spy trying to gain access to a high profile building that contains very classified information. The only thing standing between you and those secrets is a keypunch security system containing the digits 1-9 that will open the door to the building. Your spy agency has provided you details about the order of the keys you need to enter:
1. Each digit is pressed once and only once.
2. No two consecutive digits are pressed consecutively.
3. The digits 2 and 4 are pressed 2nd and 4th in some order; the digits 6 and 8 are pressed 6th and 8th in some order.
4. The sum of the first 5 digits pressed is 19; the sum of the last 5 digits pressed is 27.
As you wonder why your agency couldn't just write down the sequence for you, you crack the code and enter the building.
What sequence of keys did you press on the security system to get into the building?
Hint: You can figure out the 5th digit to enter from clue 4 and some algebra.
Human Solution:
Step 1 – position 5  
Let a₁a₂ … a₉ be the 9-digit key-press order.  
The first five digits sum to 19 and the last five to 27, while the total of all digits 1–9 is 45.

19 + 27 = 46 = 45 + a₅  (because a₅ is counted in both partial sums)  
⇒ a₅ = 1.

Step 2 – positions 2 and 4  
Digits 2 and 4 occupy positions 2 and 4.  
Since a₅ = 1, the digit next to 1 cannot be 2 (consecutive rule).  
Therefore a₄ = 4 and a₂ = 2.

Step 3 – positions 1 and 3  
Let the still-unknown digits in positions 1 and 3 be x and y.  
x + y + 2 + 4 + 1 = 19 ⇒ x + y = 12.  
From the unused digits {3,5,6,7,8,9} the pairs summing to 12 are (3,9) and (5,7).

• (3,9): 3 would be adjacent to 2, which is forbidden → discard.  
• (5,7): 5 cannot be next to 4, so the only possibility is a₁ = 5, a₃ = 7.

Step 4 – positions 6 and 8  
Digits 6 and 8 must be in positions 6 and 8.  Possible orders:

Case A  a₆ = 8, a₈ = 6  
Then a₇ must avoid being consecutive with 8, so a₇ = 3 (not 9).  
The remaining digit 9 goes to a₉.  
Check consecutive differences:  …1–8–3–6–9 → none are consecutive.  
All conditions are satisfied.

Case B  a₆ = 6, a₈ = 8  
Whichever way 3 and 9 are placed in positions 7 and 9, 8 will touch 9 (consecutive) → impossible.

Hence Case A is the only valid arrangement.

Step 5 – the full sequence  
a₁  a₂  a₃  a₄  a₅  a₆  a₇  a₈  a₉  
5   2   7   4   1   8   3   6   9

• Each digit 1–9 appears once.  
• No adjacent pressed digits are consecutive numbers.  
• 2nd and 4th digits are 2 and 4; 6th and 8th are 8 and 6.  
• First five digits sum to 19; last five sum to 27.

Final answer: 527418369
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Use the fact that the first-five sum (19) and the last-five sum (27) overlap in the middle digit to write 19 + 27 = 45 + a₅, immediately giving a₅ = 1.  
2. (Rudimentary) Place the required digits 2 and 4 in positions 2 and 4; since 1 is in position 5 and cannot sit next to 2, set a₄ = 4 and a₂ = 2.  
3. (Rudimentary) Let the unknown digits in positions 1 and 3 be x and y. From x + y + 2 + 4 + 1 = 19 obtain x + y = 12; list the unused digits and the pairs summing to 12, reject the pair (3,9) because 3 would adjoin 2, accept (5,7) and assign a₁ = 5, a₃ = 7.  
4. (Rudimentary) Place the required digits 6 and 8 in positions 6 and 8, test the two possible orders. Order (8,6) works with a₇ = 3 and a₉ = 9 (no consecutive touches); order (6,8) fails because 8 would neighbor 9.  
5. (Rudimentary) Compile the full sequence 5 2 7 4 1 8 3 6 9 and verify that it meets all given conditions.

['Total Step Count: 5  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Use the fact that the first-five sum (19) and the last-five sum (27) overlap in the middle digit to write 19 + 27 = 45 + a₅, immediately giving a₅ = 1.  
2. (Rudimentary) Place the required digits 2 and 4 in positions 2 and 4; since 1 is in position 5 and cannot sit next to 2, set a₄ = 4 and a₂ = 2.

Question:
In a mathematics contest, A, B, C, D, E, F, G and H got the top eight places. The teacher asked them to guess who got first.
A said: "Either F or H is first."
B said: "I'm first."
C said: "G is first."
D said: "B is not first."
E said: "A is wrong."
F said: "Neither I nor H is the first."
G said: "C is not first."
H said: "I agree with A."
The teacher told them that exactly three of them guessed correctly. Then, who got first?
Hint: It's OK to use trial and error, however, there might be better methods.
Human Solution:
We test each possible winner and count how many of the eight statements are true.  
(Statement numbering corresponds to the students’ names.)

Truth conditions  
1 A: First is F or H.  
2 B: First is B.  
3 C: First is G.  
4 D: First is not B.  
5 E: A is wrong.  
6 F: First is neither F nor H.  
7 G: First is not C.  
8 H: Same as A (first is F or H).

Case-by-case count of true statements

• First = A → true: 4 (D,E,F,G)  
• First = B → true: 4 (B,E,F,G)  
• First = C → true: 3 (D,E,F)  
• First = D → true: 4 (D,E,F,G)  
• First = E → true: 4 (D,E,F,G)  
• First = F → true: 4 (A,D,G,H)  
• First = G → true: 5 (C,D,E,F,G)  
• First = H → true: 4 (A,D,G,H)

Exactly three statements are true only when C is the winner.

Final answer: C
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Translate each student’s guess into an explicit logical condition about who the first-place student is.  
2. Decide to test every possible winner (A through H) because there are only eight candidates.  
3. For each assumed winner, check the eight logical conditions and record which statements come out true.  
4. Compare the tally for each candidate with the requirement that exactly three statements must be true and see that only the “winner = C” case meets it.  
5. State the conclusion that C is therefore the first-place student.

['Total Step Count: 5  
Creative ', ' 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 5

1. Translate each student’s guess into an explicit logical condition about who the first-place student is.  
2. Decide to test every possible winner (A through H) because there are only eight candidates.  
3. For each assumed winner, check the eight logical conditions and record which statements come out true.  
4. Compare the tally for each candidate with the requirement that exactly three statements must be true and see that only the “winner = C” case meets it.  
5. State the conclusion that C is therefore the first-place student.']

Question:
The warden meets with 23 new prisoners when they arrive. He tells them, "You may meet today and plan a strategy. But after today, you will be in isolated cells and will have no communication with one another.
"In the prison there is a switch room which contains two light switches labeled A and B, each of which can be in either the 'on' or the 'off' position. BOTH SWITCHES ARE IN THEIR OFF POSITIONS NOW.*  The switches are not connected to anything.
"After today, from time to time whenever I feel so inclined, I will select one prisoner at random and escort him to the switch room. This prisoner will select one of the two switches and reverse its position. He must move one, but only one of the switches. He can't move both but he can't move none either. Then he'll be led back to his cell."
"No one else will enter the switch room until I lead the next prisoner there, and he'll be instructed to do the same thing. I'm going to choose prisoners at random. I may choose the same guy three times in a row, or I may jump around and come back."
"But, given enough time, everyone will eventually visit the switch room as many times as everyone else. At any time any one of you may declare to me, 'We have all visited the switch room.'
"If it is true, then you will all be set free. If it is false, and somebody has not yet visited the switch room, you will be fed to the alligators."
*note - the only difference from Scenario B, the original position of the 2 switches are known.
Hint:
Assuming that:
A) There is no restriction on the amount of time the prisoners could take before sending the notice to the warden that everyone has been to the switch room at least once.
B) There is no restriction on the number of time each prisoner can visit the switch room
C) The warden will not attempt any foul moves, such as intentionally not bringing a certain prisoner to the switch room forever.
Human Solution:
Strategy

(1)  During the preliminary meeting the prisoners give themselves fixed rôles.

•  One single prisoner is appointed the COUNTER.  
•  The remaining 22 prisoners are called ORDINARY prisoners.  
•  Switch A is the “signal” switch, switch B is an otherwise useless “dummy” switch.  
  (Both switches are known to start in the OFF position.)

(2)  Rules to be followed every time a prisoner is taken to the switch room.

ORDINARY PRISONER  
a)  If he has never before moved switch A and, on entering, finds A = OFF, he turns A to ON.  
b)  In every other case he moves switch B (from ON to OFF or from OFF to ON, whichever its state happens to be).

Thus an ordinary prisoner will turn A from OFF to ON exactly once in his life; on all other visits he merely flips B to satisfy the warden’s requirement that a switch be moved.

COUNTER  
a)  If on entering he finds A = ON, he turns A to OFF and adds 1 to his private count.  
b)  If he finds A = OFF, he flips B instead.  
c)  As soon as his count reaches 22 he tells the warden:  
   “All of us have visited the switch room.”

Why the declaration is certainly correct

•  The only person who ever turns A from OFF to ON is an ordinary prisoner doing so for the first (and only) time in his life.  
•  Therefore each ordinary prisoner causes the COUNTER’s tally to rise by exactly one.  
•  Since there are 22 ordinary prisoners, the COUNTER’s count can reach 22 only after every ordinary prisoner has already been in the room at least once.  
•  The COUNTER himself has obviously visited (he is the one who makes the announcement), so at that moment every one of the 23 prisoners has visited.  
•  Hence the statement “We have all visited the switch room” is true when it is finally uttered, and it can never be uttered prematurely.

All requirements of the warden are met (exactly one switch is moved on every visit), and sooner or later the COUNTER’s count inevitably reaches 22 because the warden’s random selection is assumed to give each prisoner infinitely many visits in the long run.

Final answer:  Have one designated COUNTER use switch A to count first-time visits of the other 22 prisoners while everyone else uses switch B as a harmless dummy; when the COUNTER’s tally reaches 22 he announces that all prisoners have been in the switch room, and this announcement is guaranteed to be correct.
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1.  Devise the key idea: pick one prisoner to act as a COUNTER, use switch A as a “signal” that can be counted, and use switch B as a harmless “dummy” that can always be flipped to satisfy the warden’s rule.  (Creative)  

2.  In the initial meeting, assign the roles formally: 1 COUNTER and 22 ORDINARY prisoners; announce that both switches start OFF and that everyone will follow the agreed-upon rules.  (Rudimentary)  

3.  Rule for an ORDINARY prisoner: if this is his first opportunity to move switch A and he finds A = OFF, he flips A to ON; in every other circumstance he flips switch B instead.  (Rudimentary)  

4.  Observation that follows from Step 3: each ORDINARY prisoner will turn A from OFF to ON exactly once in his lifetime; on every later visit he touches only B.  (Rudimentary)  

5.  Rule for the COUNTER on every visit: if A = ON, he flips A back to OFF and adds 1 to his private tally; if A = OFF, he flips B instead.  (Rudimentary)  

6.  Stopping rule: whenever the COUNTER’s tally reaches 22 he immediately tells the warden, “All of us have visited the switch room.”  (Rudimentary)  

7.  Correctness proof, part 1: the only way A ever becomes ON is through an ORDINARY prisoner’s first visit, so each increment of the COUNTER’s tally corresponds to a distinct ORDINARY prisoner.  After the tally reaches 22, every ORDINARY prisoner has visited at least once.  (Rudimentary)  

8.  Correctness proof, part 2: the COUNTER himself is present to make the announcement; therefore all 23 prisoners have visited.  Because exactly one switch is flipped on every visit and the warden eventually selects each prisoner infinitely often, the tally is guaranteed to reach 22, and the announcement can never be made prematurely.  (Rudimentary)

Question:
There is a ten-digit mystery number (no leading 0), represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) A + B + C + D + E is a multiple of 6.
2) F + G + H + I + J is a multiple of 5.
3) A + C + E + G + I is a multiple of 9.
4) B + D + F + H + J is a multiple of 2.
5) AB is a multiple of 3.
6) CD is a multiple of 4.
7) EF is a multiple of 7.
8) GH is a multiple of 8.
9) IJ is a multiple of 10.
10) FE, HC, and JA are all prime numbers.
Hint: Notice that when combining clues 1 and 2, you have information about the sum of digits. You can do the same for clues 3 and 4.
Human Solution:
We denote the ten–digit pandigital number by  

A B C D E F G H I J  (no leading 0, the ten symbols 0–9 are used once).

Throughout, expressions such as AB, CD, … mean the two–digit numbers 10·A + B, 10·C + D, … (as is customary in divisibility puzzles).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Condition (9):  IJ is a multiple of 10
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A two–digit multiple of 10 must end in 0, hence  

  J = 0.  

Tens–digit I is still unknown.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Conditions (7) and (10) on the block E F
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• EF (the two–digit number 10E+F) is a multiple of 7.  
• FE (the two–digit number 10F+E) is prime.  
The multiples of 7 between 10 and 98 are

14, 21, 28, 35, 42, 49, 56, 63, 70, 77, 84, 91, 98.

Trying each and keeping only those whose reversal is prime gives

EF = 14  ⇒ FE = 41  (prime)  
EF = 35  ⇒ FE = 53  (prime)  
EF = 91  ⇒ FE = 19  (prime)  
EF = 98  ⇒ FE = 89  (prime)

Thus the only admissible (E , F) pairs are

(1, 4),  (3, 5),  (9, 1),  (9, 8).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Conditions on the block G H C
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• GH is a multiple of 8.  
• HC is prime.

The two–digit multiples of 8 are 16, 24, 32, 40, 48, 56, 64, 72, 80, 88, 96.  
Discarding those that repeat digits already fixed later, and for each
remaining GH writing the primes beginning with H gives

GH = 16  → H = 6  → HC = 61, 67  
GH = 24  → H = 4  → HC = 41, 43, 47  
GH = 32  → H = 2  → HC = 23, 29  
GH = 48  → H = 8  → HC = 83, 89  
GH = 56  → H = 6  → HC = 61, 67  
GH = 64  → H = 4  → HC = 41, 43, 47  
GH = 72  → H = 2  → HC = 23, 29  
GH = 96  → H = 6  → HC = 61, 67

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Start testing the (E , F) cases
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A quick parity check with condition (2)

  F + G + H + I + J ≡ 0   (mod 5)  (since J = 0)

shows that F must be congruent to 0 mod 5 or else G + H + I must supply
the complementary residue.  
Among the four (E , F) pairs only F = 1 or 4 (first and third pairs) give
a remainder of 1 or 4 modulo 5, which forces a very tight condition on
G + H + I.  These two pairs fail that requirement after a few elementary
checks, so we abandon them.

The pair (E , F) = (3, 5) gives F ≡ 0 (mod 5), hence we need
G + H + I ≡ 0 (mod 5).  Trying all admissible GH and HC combinations
one finds that no choice of I can satisfy this, so (3, 5) is impossible.

Finally we examine (E , F) = (9, 1).  Here F ≡ 1 (mod 5) and we need  

  G + H + I ≡ 4 (mod 5).           (∗)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Fixing G H C D with E = 9, F = 1
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Choose GH = 24 (so G = 2, H = 4).  
Among the admissible HC primes we take HC = 43, hence C = 3.

Condition (6) demands CD to be a multiple of 4.
With C = 3 the possibilities are 32 or 36; we must avoid repeating G = 2,
so we take D = 6 and obtain CD = 36 (indeed 36 ≡ 0 mod 4).

Digits fixed so far:  
A, B,    C=3, D=6, E=9, F=1, G=2, H=4, I, J=0.

Used digits: 0,1,2,3,4,6,9.

Remaining digits to place: 5,7,8.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Placing A, B, I
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because J = 0, condition (10) makes JA = 0A = A itself; hence A must be
one of the one–digit primes: 2, 3, 5, 7.  The only available such digits
are 5 and 7.

Take A = 5.

Condition (5): AB is a multiple of 3.  
Since 10·5 ≡ 2  (mod 3), we need B ≡ 1  (mod 3).  
Among the unused digits {7, 8} only 7 has remainder 1 modulo 3, so

  B = 7.

The last unused digit is therefore I = 8.

Check (∗):  G + H + I = 2 + 4 + 8 = 14 ≡ 4 (mod 5) ✓

--------------------------------------------------------------------
7.  Verifying all global conditions
--------------------------------------------------------------------
(1)  A + B + C + D + E = 5+7+3+6+9 = 30,   30 divisible by 6 ✓  
(2)  F + G + H + I + J = 1+2+4+8+0 = 15,   15 divisible by 5 ✓  
(3)  A + C + E + G + I = 5+3+9+2+8 = 27,   27 divisible by 9 ✓  
(4)  B + D + F + H + J = 7+6+1+4+0 = 18,   even ✓  
(5)  AB = 57,           57 divisible by 3 ✓  
(6)  CD = 36,           36 divisible by 4 ✓  
(7)  EF = 91,           91 divisible by 7 ✓  
(8)  GH = 24,           24 divisible by 8 ✓  
(9)  IJ = 80,           80 divisible by 10 ✓  
(10) FE = 19 (prime),   HC = 43 (prime),   JA = 05 = 5 (prime) ✓  

All ten requirements are met, every digit 0–9 is used exactly once, and
there is no contradiction.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Therefore the unique mystery number is

  A B C D E F G H I J = 5 7 3 6 9 1 2 4 8 0

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer: 5736912480
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 4  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) Apply “IJ is a multiple of 10”; any such two–digit number must end in 0 ⇒ J = 0.  

2. (Creative) Use the pair of conditions “EF is a multiple of 7” and “FE is prime”.  List the multiples of 7 between 10 and 98, reverse each, and keep only those whose reversals are prime, leaving the four admissible (E,F) pairs: (1,4), (3,5), (9,1), (9,8).  

3. (Rudimentary) Apply “GH is a multiple of 8” together with “HC is prime”.  List two-digit multiples of 8, and for each possible H compile the primes HC that start with that H, producing the catalogue of admissible GH–HC combinations.  

4. (Creative) Bring in “F+G+H+I+J is a multiple of 5” (with J = 0).  Work modulo 5 to test each of the four (E,F) pairs from Step 2 against every admissible GH from Step 3.  Three pairs fail; the only workable one is (E,F) = (9,1), which further imposes G+H+I ≡ 4 (mod 5).  

5. (Creative) With E = 9 and F = 1, choose an admissible GH–HC combination that keeps digits distinct: take GH = 24 so G = 2, H = 4, and HC = 43 giving C = 3.  Impose “CD is a multiple of 4”; with C = 3 the allowed CDs are 32 or 36.  Avoiding repetition of G = 2 selects D = 6, hence CD = 36.  

6. (Creative) Use “JA is prime”.  Since J = 0, this forces A to be a one-digit prime; among unused digits that means A = 5 or 7.  Pick A = 5.  Impose “AB is a multiple of 3”; because 10·5 ≡ 2 (mod 3) we need B ≡ 1 (mod 3), giving B = 7.  The only unused digit left is I = 8, and G+H+I = 2+4+8 = 14 ≡ 4 (mod 5) as required.  

7. (Rudimentary) Check every original condition with the assembled digits A = 5, B = 7, C = 3, D = 6, E = 9, F = 1, G = 2, H = 4, I = 8, J = 0; all are satisfied, so the mystery number is 5736912480.

['Total Step Count: 7  
Creative ', ' 4  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) Apply “IJ is a multiple of 10”; any such two–digit number must end in 0 ⇒ J = 0.  

2. (Creative) Use the pair of conditions “EF is a multiple of 7” and “FE is prime”.  List the multiples of 7 between 10 and 98, reverse each, and keep only those whose reversals are prime, leaving the four admissible (E,F) pairs: (1,4), (3,5), (9,1), (9,8).  

3. (Rudimentary) Apply “GH is a multiple of 8” together with “HC is prime”.  List two-digit multiples of 8, and for each possible H compile the primes HC that start with that H, producing the catalogue of admissible GH–HC combinations.  

4. (Creative) Bring in “F+G+H+I+J is a multiple of 5” (with J = 0).  Work modulo 5 to test each of the four (E,F) pairs from Step 2 against every admissible GH from Step 3.  Three pairs fail; the only workable one is (E,F) = (9,1), which further imposes G+H+I ≡ 4 (mod 5).  

5. (Creative) With E = 9 and F = 1, choose an admissible GH–HC combination that keeps digits distinct: take GH = 24 so G = 2, H = 4, and HC = 43 giving C = 3.  Impose “CD is a multiple of 4”; with C = 3 the allowed CDs are 32 or 36.  Avoiding repetition of G = 2 selects D = 6, hence CD = 36.  

6. (Creative) Use “JA is prime”.  Since J = 0, this forces A to be a one-digit prime; among unused digits that means A = 5 or 7.  Pick A = 5. 7. (Rudimentary) Check every original condition with the assembled digits A = 5, B = 7, C = 3, D = 6, E = 9, F = 1, G = 2, H = 4, I = 8, J = 0; all are satisfied, so the mystery number is 5736912480.']

Question:
There is a ten-digit mystery number (no leading 0), represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) Either A = B / 3 or A = G + 3.
2) Either B = I - 4 or B = E + 4.
3) Either C = J + 2 or C = F * 3.
4) Either D = G * 4 or D = E / 3.
5) Either E = J - 1 or E = D / 4.
6) Either F = B * 2 or F = A - 4.
7) Either G = F + 1 or G = I - 3.
8) Either H = A / 2 or H = C * 3.
9) Either I = H + 3 or I = D / 2.
10) Either J = H - 2 or J = C * 2.
Hint: Check each letter for any value that it can not be on the left side of an equation.  For example, A can not be 0, as B would also have to be 0 or G would have to be negative.
Human Solution:
Reasoning step-by-step  

1.  Rule 4 gives only two ways to obtain an integer digit D.

   •  4a  D = G·4  ⇒ G ∈ {1,2} and (G , D) is (1 ,4) or (2 ,8).  
   •  4b  D = E/3  ⇒ E ∈ {3,6,9} and (E , D) is (3 ,1), (6 ,2) or (9 ,3).

   The pair (G , D) = (1 ,4) is immediately impossible:  
   G = 1 forces (rule 7) F = 0, thence (rule 6) A = 4, duplicating the digit 4 already used by D.  
   Hence the only viable choice in 4a is  

          G = 2 , D = 8 .                        (1)

2.  Because D = 8, rule 5 cannot use “E = D/4” (it would give E = 2, duplicating G).  
    Consequently rule 5 must use “E = J – 1”.                     (2)

3.  With G = 2, rule 7 allows

       a)  G = F + 1 ⇒ F = 1,  or  
       b)  G = I – 3 ⇒ I = 5.

    Choice b fails: if I = 5, rule 9 would have to satisfy 5 = H + 3 or 5 = 8/2; neither works without duplicating a digit.  
    Therefore

          F = 1 .                                (3)

4.  Rule 6 now cannot use “F = B·2” (1 is odd), so it must use “F = A – 4”, giving

          A = 5 .                                (4)

5.  Verify rule 1: with A = 5 and G = 2 we have A = G + 3, so rule 1 is obeyed and B remains unknown.  

6.  Rule 3: F = 1 makes C = F·3 = 3 (the alternative C = J + 2 would duplicate digits later).  

          C = 3 .                                (5)

7.  Rule 8 cannot use H = A/2 (5/2 is not an integer), so it must use H = C·3, giving

          H = 9 .                                (6)

8.  Rule 10 offers J = H – 2 = 7 or J = C·2 = 6.  
    Because E = J – 1 (step 2), choosing J = 6 would give E = 5, duplicating A.  
    Hence

          J = 7 , E = 6 .                       (7)

9.  Rule 9 cannot use I = H + 3 (12 is not a digit).  
    Therefore it must use I = D/2, so

          I = 8/2 = 4 .                         (8)

10. Rule 2 now uses B = I – 4 = 0 (the alternative B = E + 4 would be 10, impossible).  

          B = 0 .                               (9)

11.  We have assigned every digit 0–9 exactly once:

          A  B  C  D  E  F  G  H  I  J
          5  0  3  8  6  1  2  9  4  7

12.  A quick check shows that, with the chosen branch of each “either/or”, all ten rules are satisfied and no digit repeats.

Therefore the unique ten-digit mystery number is

5038612947

Final answer: 5038612947
Response:
Total Step Count: 11  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 9  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Start with Rule 4.  List the only integer possibilities for D: either D = G·4 with (G,D) = (1,4) or (2,8), or D = E/3 with (E,D) = (3,1), (6,2), (9,3).  Eliminate (1,4) because G = 1 forces F = 0 and A = 4, duplicating digit 4.  Conclude G = 2 and D = 8.  

2. (Rudimentary) Since D = 8, Rule 5 cannot take E = D/4 (would give E = 2, duplicating G), so Rule 5 must take E = J − 1.  

3. (Creative) With G = 2, Rule 7 gives either F = 1 or I = 5.  Test I = 5 against Rule 9 and see neither branch works without repetition, so discard it and fix F = 1.  

4. (Rudimentary) Rule 6 cannot use F = B·2 (F is odd) and must use F = A − 4, giving A = 5.  

5. (Rudimentary) Check Rule 1: A = 5 and G = 2 satisfy A = G + 3, leaving B still undetermined.  

6. (Rudimentary) Apply Rule 3: with F = 1, the viable branch is C = F·3, so C = 3.  

7. (Rudimentary) Apply Rule 8: A/2 is not an integer, so use H = C·3 to get H = 9.  

8. (Rudimentary) Rule 10 offers J = H − 2 = 7 or J = C·2 = 6.  Because E = J − 1, choosing J = 6 would duplicate A = 5, so take J = 7 and E = 6.  

9. (Rudimentary) Rule 9 cannot use I = H + 3 (would exceed 9), so take I = D/2 = 4.  

10. (Rudimentary) Rule 2 now gives B = I − 4 = 0 (the other branch would yield 10).  

11. (Rudimentary) All digits 0–9 are now assigned exactly once and every chosen branch satisfies its rule; read off the mystery number as 5038612947.

Question:
Typical "stars" are drawn in connected, but not repeated, line segments. For example, a 5-point star is drawn as such - line segments AC, CE, EB, BD, DA. The segments must always alternate a constant number of points (in the above case, skipping 1 point in between).
Given the information that there is only 1 way to draw a 5-point star, and that there is NO way to draw a 6-point star (in continuous lines, that is), and there are 2 ways to draw a 7-point star, how many different ways are there to draw a 1000-point star?
Hint: It's not guess work. Think of factors and mirror images.  Try drawing out examples.
Human Solution:
Label the 1000 equally–spaced points on the circle  

0,1,2,…,999   (arithmetic is done modulo 1000).

To draw the “star” we choose a fixed step length k (1≤k≤999) and join  

0→k→2k→3k→⋯ (mod 1000)  

until we return to 0.  
The drawing will be one single continuous 1000-edge figure iff every vertex is hit exactly once, i.e. iff

gcd(k, 1000)=1.                                                        (1)

If gcd(k, 1000)≠1 we return to 0 before visiting all the points and obtain several smaller polygons, not a single star.

Which of the coprime step lengths actually give a “star”, as opposed to the ordinary 1000-gon?

•  k=1 produces the ordinary 1000-gon (no points are skipped), so it is not counted.  
•  If k>500, stepping by k clockwise is the same drawing as stepping by 1000−k counter-clockwise. Hence every figure that can be obtained with such a k is already obtained with the step 1000−k lying in the interval 1≤1000−k≤499.  
•  k=500 itself is not coprime with 1000 (gcd=500), so it is impossible.

Therefore each distinct “star” corresponds uniquely to a step length k satisfying

2 ≤ k ≤ 500  and gcd(k, 1000)=1.                                  (2)

Counting such k.

All integers coprime to 1000 in the complete set {1,2,…,999} form φ(1000) numbers, where  
φ(1000)=1000·(1−1/2)·(1−1/5)=1000·½·4/5=400.

Because 1000−k is coprime to 1000 whenever k is, these 400 numbers split into 200 complementary pairs {k,1000−k}.  
Exactly one member of every pair lies in 1≤k≤499 (never at k=500, which is not coprime), so

|{k | 1≤k≤499, gcd(k,1000)=1}| = 200.

Removing k=1 (the ordinary 1000-gon) leaves

200−1 = 199

allowable step lengths, and hence 199 different ways to draw a continuous 1000-point star.

Final answer: 199
Response:
Total Step Count: 13  
Creative Steps: 4  
Rudimentary Steps: 9  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary)  Label the 1000 equally–spaced points on the circle with the integers 0, 1, 2, …, 999 and agree to do all arithmetic modulo 1000.  

2. (Creative)  Observe that any “star” produced by straight, connected, non-repeating segments can be generated by fixing a step length k, then successively joining the vertices 0 → k → 2k → 3k → … (mod 1000).  

3. (Creative)  Establish that the drawing is one single 1000-edge figure exactly when every vertex is visited once, i.e. when gcd(k, 1000) = 1.  

4. (Rudimentary)  Note that if gcd(k, 1000) ≠ 1 the path returns to 0 prematurely, breaking the drawing into several smaller polygons, hence not forming a single star.  

5. (Rudimentary)  Recognize that k = 1, although coprime to 1000, produces the ordinary 1000-gon (no points skipped) and therefore should not be counted as a “star.”  

6. (Creative)  Use rotational symmetry: for k > 500, stepping clockwise by k gives exactly the same figure as stepping counter-clockwise by 1000 − k. Thus any figure obtainable with such a k is already represented by the complementary step 1000 − k lying in 1 ≤ 1000 − k ≤ 499.  

7. (Rudimentary)  Observe that k = 500 is excluded because gcd(500, 1000) = 500 ≠ 1.  

8. (Rudimentary)  Conclude that each distinct star corresponds uniquely to a step length k satisfying 2 ≤ k ≤ 500 and gcd(k, 1000) = 1.  

9. (Rudimentary)  Reformulate the task as counting all such admissible k.  

10. (Rudimentary)  Compute φ(1000) to find that there are 400 integers between 1 and 999 that are coprime to 1000 (φ(1000) = 1000·(1 − 1⁄2)·(1 − 1⁄5) = 400).  

11. (Creative)  Pair each coprime k with its complement 1000 − k; because coprimality is preserved under this complementation, the 400 numbers split into 200 distinct pairs, exactly one member of each lying in 1 ≤ k ≤ 499.  

12. (Rudimentary)  Remove k = 1 (the ordinary 1000-gon) from those 200 admissible k to obtain 199 remaining step lengths.  

13. (Rudimentary)  Report that these 199 step lengths correspond to 199 different continuous 1000-point stars; hence the final answer is 199.

Question:
Five friends spend every Monday night eating Chinese food from the Golden Dragon. Howard has Mu Shu Pork, Leonard has Spicy Szechuan Tofu, Penny has Shrimp with Lobster Sauce, Raj has Beef with String Beans, and Sheldon has Chicken and Broccoli: diced, not shredded, with brown rice, not white, low-sodium soy sauce and the good hot mustard from the Korean grocery.
After dinner, they play a role-playing game called World of Nerds.
In this game, each player takes on a character belonging to a different race of creature, has a different occupation, uses a different sort of weapon, specializes in fighting a particular kind of monster, and has a different skill level.
Can you determine the characteristics of each player's character from the following clues before someone sits in Sheldon's spot?
Players: Howard, Leonard, Penny, Raj and Sheldon
Races: elf, gremlin, halfling, hobbit and ogre
Occupations: archbishop, merchant, paladin, sorcerer and thief
Weapons: bolo, crossbow, dagger, fireballs and mace
Monsters: chimeras, giants, harpies, kobolds and orcs
Skill levels: range from 10-32
Clues:
1. The five characters in the game are Penny's, the 24th-level ogre, the thief, the fireball user, and the one skilled at fighting orcs.
2. The paladin isn't an elf.
3. The bolo user has a skill level twice that of the halfling.
4. Raj's character has a skill level eight levels higher than the paladin, who in turn is eight levels higher than the crossbow user.
5. The hobbit is no good at fighting giants.
6. The elf (who doesn't care for crossbows) is ten levels higher than the one who fights kobolds.
7. The one who is adept at fighting chimeras is four levels higher than Leonard's character (who isn't the archbishop).
8. The character at the lowest level (who isn't Penny) is at level ten and uses a dagger.
9. Neither the archbishop nor the merchant belongs to the race of gremlins.
10. The giant fighter never uses a mace in battle.
11. Raj's character isn't the elf.
12. Penny's character doesn't use the crossbow.
13. Howard's character is not particularly adept at fighting harpies.
Hint: Start by determining the 5 skill levels.
Human Solution:
Howard – 10th-level Halfling thief, armed with a dagger, expert against kobolds  
Leonard – 16th-level Hobbit merchant, armed with a crossbow, expert against orcs  
Penny – 20th-level Elf archbishop, armed with a bolo, expert against chimeras  
Raj – 32nd-level Gremlin sorcerer, hurls fireballs, expert against giants  
Sheldon – 24th-level Ogre paladin, brandishes a mace, expert against harpies  

Final answer: Howard 10 Halfling Thief Dagger Kobolds; Leonard 16 Hobbit Merchant Crossbow Orcs; Penny 20 Elf Archbishop Bolo Chimeras; Raj 32 Gremlin Sorcerer Fireballs Giants; Sheldon 24 Ogre Paladin Mace Harpies
Response:
Total Step Count: 23  
Creative Steps: 6  
Rudimentary Steps: 17  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) Set up a five-by-five logic grid listing the players, races, occupations, weapons, monsters and skill-levels 10-32.  
2. (Rudimentary) Apply clue 8: there is a single 10-level character who uses a dagger and is not Penny.  
3. (Creative) Use clue 4.  Because the crossbow user is 8 levels below the paladin and 16 below Raj, the only level-triple that fits 10-32 is Crossbow 16 / Paladin 24 / Raj 32.  
4. (Rudimentary) Record: Raj is level 32; the paladin is level 24; the crossbow user is level 16.  
5. (Creative) From clue 6 the elf is 10 levels above the kobold-fighter.  The only level pair still possible is 20/10, so Elf 20 and Kobold-fighter 10.  
6. (Rudimentary) Therefore the 10-level dagger user (step 2) is also the kobold-fighter.  
7. (Creative) Clue 3 says the bolo user’s level is twice the halfling’s.  The only workable pair left is 10/20, so Halfling 10 and Bolo 20.  
8. (Rudimentary) Combine steps 5 & 7: the 20-level elf is the bolo user.  
9. (Creative) Clue 7: the chimera-fighter is 4 levels higher than Leonard.  The only available 4-level gap is 16/20, so Leonard is the 16-level crossbow user and the 20-level elf fights chimeras.  
10. (Rudimentary) Clue 7 also says Leonard is not the archbishop.  
11. (Rudimentary) Clue 12 keeps Penny off the crossbow, so Penny cannot be Leonard’s 16-level character.  
12. (Rudimentary) Penny is therefore the remaining 20-level elf who uses a bolo and fights chimeras.  
13. (Rudimentary) The 10-level halfling dagger-wielding kobold-fighter (not Penny, step 2) must be Howard.  
14. (Rudimentary) Clue 13 is satisfied, since Howard does not fight harpies.  
15. (Rudimentary) Clue 1 includes “the 24-level ogre”; the only 24-level figure is the paladin, so the paladin must be the ogre.  
16. (Rudimentary) The only player left to take that role is Sheldon, so Sheldon is the 24-level ogre paladin.  
17. (Rudimentary) Occupations still open: archbishop, merchant, sorcerer.  Penny (not Leonard) can now be archbishop; Leonard becomes merchant; Raj becomes sorcerer.  
18. (Creative) Clue 9 says neither the archbishop nor the merchant can be gremlins, leaving gremlin as the only race available for Raj; Leonard therefore becomes the hobbit.  
19. (Creative) Clue 5 forbids the hobbit from fighting giants; clue 10 forbids the giant-fighter from using a mace.  Since Sheldon already holds the mace, Raj (not a hobbit and not using a mace) must be the giant-fighter.  
20. (Creative) From clue 1 the fireball user is distinct from the 24-level ogre and others; with Raj already level 32 and sorcerer, assign him the fireballs, which also keeps the giant-fighter away from the mace (clue 10).  
21. (Rudimentary) Sheldon, the only weaponless character left, therefore takes the mace.  
22. (Rudimentary) Monsters not yet allocated are orcs and harpies.  “Orcs” is still needed for clue 1, so give orcs to Leonard; Sheldon takes harpies.  
23. (Rudimentary) A final cross-check shows every clue is now satisfied, giving the solution:  
   • Howard – 10-level Halfling thief, dagger, kobolds  
   • Leonard – 16-level Hobbit merchant, crossbow, orcs  
   • Penny – 20-level Elf archbishop, bolo, chimeras  
   • Raj – 32-level Gremlin sorcerer, fireballs, giants  
   • Sheldon – 24-level Ogre paladin, mace, harpies

Question:
Sailing through a thick fog, you come upon a mysterious island shrouded in mist. A towering volcano in the center of the island pierces the clouds, billowing smoke into the sky. You land your boat and set out to ascend the peak. After an arduous climb, you approach the volcano summit, where lava glows red within a vast crater.
Here, you are approached by three gods and their herald.
Problem
On the summit of this remote volcano, the herald proclaims that you have been selected for a trial. He then lays out the rules for you.
First, you know that one of the three gods always tells the truth, another always lies, and the third will respond to questions randomly. Therefore, let us call the gods True, False, and Random.
Second, the gods speak a different language. They understand all languages perfectly well, but only answer questions with either ja or da, the words for yes and no. You do not know which god is which, and you do not know which word means yes and which word means no.
Finally, you have an existential problem on your hands. You may ask three yes-or-no questions, each one directed to only one god, and only that god will answer with either ja or da. If you can determine the identities of the three gods, they will send you on your way with their blessing, and you can be assured of a prosperous and fulfilled life. If you fail to determine the identities of the gods, however, they will be less generous in their treatment. The volcano pit smokes and glows red beside you.
With your three questions, how do you figure out which god is True, which is False, and which is Random?
Hint: Can you phrase a question so that both True and False have to say the same thing?
Human Solution:
Label the three divinities A, B and C.  
Throughout the solution we shall use the following form of question  

  (*) “If I asked you P, would you say ja?”    

(where P is any yes-or-no statement about the gods).

Fact about (*)  
If the god addressed is True or False then his answer to (*) is
 ja iff P is true,  
 da iff P is false,  
independently of (i) whether he is the truth-teller or the liar and  
(ii) which of the two words, ja or da, means “yes”.  
(The easy verification is given at the end; Random of course may say either
word.)

Thus, as long as we can make sure that a question of the form (*) is put to a
non-Random god, we can read his reply in the ordinary way: ‘ja’ means
“P is true”, ‘da’ means “P is false”.

Step 1 – pick out (or identify) the Random god  
Ask A the ordinary yes-or-no question

 Q₁: “Does ja mean ‘yes’ if and only if you are the truthful
    god?”

Analyse Q₁.  
• If A is True, then the biconditional is true precisely when ja really
means yes; True therefore answers “yes”, i.e. the word ja.  
• If A is False, the biconditional has the same truth-value; False must
answer “no”, which is again the word ja (because he lies).  
Hence every non-Random god necessarily answers ja.  
Therefore

 • If the reply to Q₁ is da, A is Random.  
 • If the reply to Q₁ is ja, A is not Random (he is True or False).

We split the remainder of the procedure according to these two possibilities.

--------------------------------------------------
Case I (the answer to Q₁ was da) ⇒ A is Random
--------------------------------------------------

The two remaining gods, B and C, are True and False in some order.

Q₂ (to B): “If I asked you ‘Are you the truthful god?’, would you say ja?”

Because B is not Random we may decode the answer by the fact above:

 • ja ⇒ B is True, C is False.  
 • da ⇒ B is False, C is True.

We already know A is Random, so the trial is finished after two questions
(third question unused or used for curiosity only).

--------------------------------------------------
Case II (the answer to Q₁ was ja) ⇒ A is not Random
--------------------------------------------------

Now ask A another question of the reliable form (*).

Q₂ (to A): “If I asked you ‘Is B Random?’, would you say ja?”

Because A is non-Random we may decode the reply:

 • ja ⇒ B is Random, C is non-Random.  
 • da ⇒ C is Random, B is non-Random.

We still have to distinguish True from False among the two
non-Random gods left.  
Whichever of B or C is non-Random, we already know that A is
non-Random too, so simply ask A:

Q₃ (to A): “If I asked you ‘Are you the truthful god?’, would you say ja?”

 • ja ⇒ A is True (and the other non-Random god is False).  
 • da ⇒ A is False (and the other non-Random god is True).

At this point the identity of every god is determined.

--------------------------------------------------
Why question (*) works for non-Random gods
--------------------------------------------------

Let Y be the word that really means “yes”.  
Suppose the inner question P is true.

• If the god is True, his honest answer to P would be “yes”, i.e. Y.
 Asked “Would you say ja?”, he answers “yes” iff Y is the word ja,
 which is exactly what the meta-question demands – hence he says ja.

• If the god is False, his actual answer to P would be the opposite of
 the truth.  Thus he would utter Y if and only if P is false.  When he
 is asked whether he would say ja, the truthful reply would equal the
 situation just analysed – but he must lie about that reply, so he ends
 up giving the same ‘ja’/‘da’ outcome as the truth-teller.

A completely similar check shows that, when P is false, both True and False
reply da.  Therefore for any non-Random god, ja means “P is true” and da
means “P is false”, exactly as stated.

With these three (or occasionally two) carefully chosen questions one can
always unerringly identify which god is True, which is False, and which is
Random.

Final answer: The three questions are

1. To god A: “Does ja mean ‘yes’ if and only if you are the truthful god?”
   – if the reply is da, A is Random; otherwise A is not Random.

2. (a) If A is Random: to god B “If I asked you ‘Are you the truthful god?’, would you say ja?”
      (ja → B is True, da → B is False; C is the other.)
   (b) If A is not Random: to god A “If I asked you ‘Is B Random?’, would you say ja?”
      (ja → B is Random, C not; da → C is Random, B not.)

3. If still needed: to god A “If I asked you ‘Are you the truthful god?’, would you say ja?”
   (ja → A is True, other non-Random god is False; da → A is False, other is True.)

These answers uniquely determine the identities of True, False and Random in every possible situation.
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary)  Label the three gods as A, B, and C to allow concise reference in later questions.  

2. (Creative)  Introduce the meta-question format (*) — “If I asked you P, would you say ja?” — and observe the crucial decoding rule that, for any non-Random god, ja means “P is true” and da means “P is false,” regardless of the word–meaning mapping or whether the speaker is the truth-teller or the liar.  

3. (Rudimentary)  Verify formally that rule (*) really does produce ja for a true inner statement P and da for a false one whenever the respondent is True or False.  

4. (Creative)  Design and ask the first real question, Q₁ to god A: “Does ja mean ‘yes’ if and only if you are the truthful god?”  Show that every non-Random god must answer ja, so a reply of da identifies A as Random, while ja guarantees A is non-Random.  

5. (Rudimentary)  Case I (A is Random): Direct Q₂ to B — “If I asked you ‘Are you the truthful god?’, would you say ja?” — and, using rule (*), decode ja ⇒ B is True (C False) and da ⇒ B is False (C True).  

6. (Rudimentary)  Conclude Case I: with A already known to be Random and B/C now distinguished, all three identities are fixed (third question is unnecessary or optional).  

7. (Rudimentary)  Case II (A is not Random): Pose Q₂ to A — “If I asked you ‘Is B Random?’, would you say ja?” — and decode ja ⇒ B is Random (C non-Random) or da ⇒ C is Random (B non-Random).  

8. (Rudimentary)  Still in Case II, ask Q₃ to A — “If I asked you ‘Are you the truthful god?’, would you say ja?” — to separate True from False among the two remaining non-Random gods by interpreting ja as “A is True” and da as “A is False.”  

9. (Rudimentary)  Conclude Case II: combine results of Q₁–Q₃ to pin down the exact roles of True, False, and Random for all three gods.

Question:
Mad Ade went on an eight day fly fishing trip around the purple ridged mountains of Madadia and got to fish seven days of it last May. On every day, from May 14 to the 21st, except the 16th, when a severe thunderstorm kept him in his tent, he fished around Madadia. Though he caught many fish--all of which he released--each day, one special fish stood out. Each special fish was of a different variety: Monkey Trout, Brookside Trout, Cut Throat, Dolly Varden, Humpback, Lake Trout, and Rainbow, and a different size: 8 inches, 16 inches, 17 inches, 19 inches, 22 inches, 24 inches, and 27 inches. Every day, Mad Ade tried a different secret fishing spot: Big Little Falls, Bottle Well, Deep Channel, Old Cutbank, Big Rock Isle, Dish Creek, and Little Curl. And each special fish was caught on a different fly that Mad Ade tied himself: a Parachute Adams, an Elk Hair Caddis, a Humpy, a MayFly, Mad Ade's Little Mouse, a Stonefly Nymph, and a Yuk Bug. Three of the flies, Mad Ade's little Mouse, the Yuk Bug, and Stonefly Nymph, were fished as wet flies, the rest were fished as dry flies.
1) Mad Ade caught the smallest of his special fish, a little Brookside, after he caught the fish on his Elk Hair Caddis, but before he caught the fish in Deep Channel. His shiny Dolly Varden was not the fish lured from the depths of Bottle Well. Mad Ade caught either the smallest or his second to largest fish on his third fishing day.
2) Mad Ade caught a fish off Big Rock Isle on the 19th. He fought either the Humpback or the 24 inch monster on the 21st. On the fourth day of his trip, Mad Ade landed a fish over twenty inches long by the Old Cutbank on a wet fly. The fish Mad Ade landed with a net at Little Curl was larger than the one he worked onto shore at Dish Creek, but it was not as large as the one he lifted from the water at Big Little Falls.
3) Mad Ade caught the 24 inch fish on his Little Mouse after he caught the Dolly Varden, but before he hooked a real jumper with his Parachute Adams. Because he preferred dry flies, Mad Ade only used dry flies after using a wet fly on the 19th. Mad Ade used a Mayfly to fish Dish Creek. Mad Ade caught his fish on the Mayfly three calendar days (two fishing days) after he caught a fish with the Stonefly Nymph.
4) Mad Ade's five mile hike, along a mountain trail to Big Little Falls, paid off on his last day with a prized Humpback trout. At least four fishing days passed between the time that Mad Ade used the Stonefly Nymph and his Humpy. The Monkey Trout Mad Ade caught on the 17th was longer than the Rainbow he caught, but smaller than his Lake Trout.
5) The deep hole of Bottle Well yielded Mad Ade a 19 incher on the first or second day of his trip. With one exception, Mad Ade caught fish of even sizes on even number days and fish of odd sizes on odd days. Although they both jumped and splashed over the water the same way, the Rainbow Mad Ade caught was bigger than his Cut Throat.
Hint:
Mad Ade caught a fish off Big Rock Isle on the 19th (2).
The Monkey Trout Mad Ade caught on the 17th (4).
Mad Ade caught either the smallest or his second to largest fish on his third fishing day. (1)
17th is 8 or 24.
Response:
Total Step Count: 16  
Creative Steps: 6  
Rudimentary Steps: 10  

Steps:  
1. Creative – Translate the calendar dates (May 14–21 with no fishing on the 16th) into two parallel indices – “trip-day” (counting the thunder-storm day) and “fishing-day” (skipping it) – so the phrases “third fishing day,” “fourth day of his trip,” “three calendar days (two fishing days),” etc. can be interpreted unambiguously.  

2. Rudimentary – Enter the straight statement that Mad Ade fished off Big Rock Isle on May 19.  

3. Rudimentary – Enter the straight statement that the last day, May 21, was spent at Big Little Falls.  

4. Rudimentary – Combine clue 4 with step 3 to fix the May 21 fish as a Humpback.  

5. Rudimentary – Since the May 21 fish is the Humpback, use clue 2 to eliminate the possibility that the 24-inch fish was caught that day.  

6. Rudimentary – From “the fourth day of his trip” (trip-day 4 = May 17) fix Old Cutbank on May 17, specify it was taken on a wet fly, and note the length must exceed 20 inches.  

7. Rudimentary – Record the ordering chain from clue 1:  
   Elk Hair Caddis < Brookside 8″ < Deep Channel.  

8. Rudimentary – Record the ordering chain from clue 3:  
   Dolly Varden < 24″ & Little Mouse < Parachute Adams.  

9. Creative – Use “because he preferred dry flies, Mad Ade only used dry flies after using a wet fly on the 19th” to lock May 19 as wet and force every fly on May 20 and May 21 to be dry, while May 14–18 may be wet or dry.  

10. Creative – Combine “Mayfly at Dish Creek” with “three calendar days (two fishing days) after the Stonefly Nymph,” and with the requirement that at least four fishing days separate the Stonefly Nymph from the Humpy on May 21.  
   • If the Stonefly were on May 14, the Mayfly would fall on May 17, but May 17 is already Old Cutbank on a wet fly → impossible (Mayfly is dry).  
   • Therefore Stonefly Nymph = May 15, which makes Mayfly = May 18 at Dish Creek and leaves ≥4 fishing-day gap before the Humpy on May 21.  

11. Rudimentary – Note that the Stonefly Nymph on May 15 is a wet fly, fitting naturally before the “all dry after the wet on the 19th” rule.  

12. Rudimentary – Apply “Bottle Well yielded a 19-incher on the first or second day”; May 14 is already constrained by other chains, so attach Bottle Well 19″ to May 15, giving that day its location and size.  

13. Creative – Impose “even lengths on even days, odd lengths on odd days with one exception,” together with the lengths now known (8″ on May 18, 19″ on May 15, >20″ for May 17, etc.) to settle the full length pattern:  
   May 14 – 16″, May 15 – 19″, May 17 – 24″ (the one odd-day exception), May 18 – 8″, May 19 – 27″, May 20 – 22″, May 21 – 17″.  

14. Creative – Use the size-ordering clues “Monkey > Rainbow > Cut-Throat”, “Rainbow bigger than Cut-Throat,” and the known lengths to map species to sizes (e.g., Cut-Throat 19″, Rainbow 22″, Monkey 24″, Lake Trout the remaining 27″, etc.).  

15. Creative – Interweave the two ordering chains from steps 7 and 8 with the partial placements from steps 12–14 to pin down the remaining pairings, e.g.  
   • Dolly Varden must precede the 24″ Little Mouse catch and therefore fits May 14 with the Elk Hair Caddis.  
   • The Parachute Adams must follow that 24″ catch and falls on May 20, etc.  

16. Rudimentary – Fill the last empty cells of the grid (flies, wet/dry flags, and any fish varieties not yet placed), verify that every original clue is satisfied, and read off the completed schedule:  
   May 14 (Little Curl) – Dolly Varden, 16″, Elk Hair Caddis (dry)  
   May 15 (Bottle Well) – Cut-Throat, 19″, Stonefly Nymph (wet)  
   May 17 (Old Cutbank) – Monkey Trout, 24″, Little Mouse (wet)  
   May 18 (Dish Creek) – Brookside Trout, 8″, Mayfly (dry)  
   May 19 (Big Rock Isle) – Lake Trout, 27″, Yuk Bug (wet)  
   May 20 (Deep Channel) – Rainbow Trout, 22″, Parachute Adams (dry)  
   May 21 (Big Little Falls) – Humpback Trout, 17″, Humpy (dry)

Question:
Professor Abacus is purchasing a ticket for the Deca Lotto.  The lotto number has ten digits, using the numerals 0 through 9, each numeral used once.  The clerk asked what number he wanted to pick.  Professor Abacus handed the clerk a piece of paper with nine statements, saying "If you can correctly figure out the number, I will give you half of whatever I win."   What is the number?
1) The sum of the first five digits is a prime number.
2) The sum of the last five digits is a triangle number*.
3) The sum of the digits in the odd positions is an odd number.
4) The sum of the middle two digits is a square number.
5) The sum of the middle four digits is a cube number.
6) The difference between the 1st and 10th digits is two.
7) The difference between the 2nd and 9th digits is three.
8) The difference between the 3rd and 8th digits is four.
9) The numeral 4 is somewhere in the first five positions.
* You can form a triangle arrangement by building it in the pattern row 1 = 1, row 2 = 2, row 3 = 3 etc. eg. 10 is a classic triangle number as per ten pin bowling. They are arranged in a triangle 1, 2, 3, 4.
Hint: The sum of all digits must be 45. Combine this with hints 1 and 2 to reduce to a few prime/triangle options
Human Solution:
Let the ten-digit lotto number be  

d₁ d₂ d₃ d₄ d₅ d₆ d₇ d₈ d₉ d₁₀ ,

each dᵢ being a different digit 0–9.

1.  The total of all ten digits is 0+1+2+…+9 = 45.  
    Put S₁ = d₁+…+d₅ and S₂ = d₆+…+d₁₀ ;  
    S₁ + S₂ = 45.

2.  Statement 1 says S₁ is prime, statement 2 says S₂ is triangular.  
    The triangular numbers ≤45 are 1,3,6,10,15,21,28,36,45.  
    Only 45 – 28 = 17 is prime, so

            S₁ = 17      and      S₂ = 28.                     (A)

3.  Put A = d₄+d₅ , B = d₆+d₇ .  
    Statement 5 says A+B = d₄+d₅+d₆+d₇ is a cube ≤30, so it is 8 or 27.

------------------------------------------------------------
CASE I :  A + B = 8
------------------------------------------------------------
The least possible sum of four different digits is 0+1+2+3 = 6,  
so to get 8 the four digits must be

        {0,1,2,5}  or  {0,1,3,4} .

Statement 4 (d₅+d₆ is a square 1,4,9 or 16) eliminates the second set,  
because in {0,1,3,4} no two digits add to a square.  
Thus the digits {0,1,2,5} occupy positions 4-7 and the only square they
can form is 0+1 = 1.  Hence

        {d₄,d₅,d₆,d₇} = {2,0,1,5}  with d₅+d₆ = 1.            (B)

The two possible orders inside (B) are

        (i) d₄d₅d₆d₇ = 2 0 1 5 ,     (ii) d₄d₅d₆d₇ = 5 1 0 2.

Compute the consequences of each.

(i)  d₄+d₅ = 2, so by (A)       d₁+d₂+d₃ = 15.
     d₆+d₇ = 1+5 = 6, so         d₈+d₉+d₁₀ = 22.

(ii) d₄+d₅ = 6  ⇒  d₁+d₂+d₃ = 11;
     d₆+d₇ = 0+2 = 2  ⇒  d₈+d₉+d₁₀ = 26.

We now use the “difference” conditions 6-8:  

d₁ and d₁₀ differ by 2,  
d₂ and d₉ differ by 3,  
d₃ and d₈ differ by 4.

Write the signs of the differences:

d₁₀ = d₁ ±2,   d₉ = d₂ ±3,   d₈ = d₃ ±4.

Therefore

(d₁+d₂+d₃) + (±2±3±4) = d₁₀+d₉+d₈ = 22   in sub-case (i)  
                                             26   in sub-case (ii).

The triple (±2,±3,±4) can sum only to –9, –5, –3, –1, 1, 3, 5 or 9.
Thus 22 is possible (need +9) but 26 is impossible.
So we keep sub-case (i).

To reach 22 we must have  

        d₁+d₂+d₃ = 15  and  ±2±3±4 = +7,

and +7 occurs only for (+2,+3,+4).  Hence

        d₁₀ = d₁+2 ,   d₉ = d₂+3 ,   d₈ = d₃+4.              (C)

The unused digits are {3,4,6,7,8,9}.  
Because of statement 9, 4 must be in the first five places, i.e. among d₁,d₂,d₃.

Try the possible choices for d₁:

d₁=3 ⇒ d₁₀=5 (5 already used)  – impossible  
d₁=4 ⇒ d₁₀=6  works  
d₁=6 ⇒ d₁₀=8  works  
d₁=7 ⇒ d₁₀=9  works  
(the options with d₁=8 or 9 overshoot 9.)

Take d₁=7.  Then d₁₀=9 and the digits left are {3,4,6,8}.  
To get d₂+3 = d₉ with unused digits, set

        d₂ = 3 ,  d₉ = 6.

The remaining first-five digit is d₃ = 4 (satisfying statement 9),  
and then (C) gives d₈ = 4+4 = 8, which is still unused.

We have arrived at the ten digits

d₁ … d₁₀ = 7 3 4 2 1 0 5 8 6 9 .

A direct check shows that every one of the nine statements is satisfied.

------------------------------------------------------------
CASE II :  A + B = 27
------------------------------------------------------------
Then d₅+d₆ must be 16 (the only square that leaves two digits
totalling 11), so {d₅,d₆} = {7,9}.  
But exhaustive parity and size checks show that none of the
possible arrangements of the remaining digits can meet the
difference conditions 6-8.  Hence Case II is impossible.

------------------------------------------------------------
Therefore the unique 10-digit number satisfying all nine clues is

        7 3 4 2 1 0 5 8 6 9.

Final answer: 7342105869
Response:
Total Step Count: 17  
Creative Steps: 6  
Rudimentary Steps: 11  

Steps:  
1. (R) Introduce variables d₁–d₁₀ for the ten distinct digits of the lotto number.  
2. (R) Note that the sum of all ten digits 0–9 equals 45; define S₁ = d₁+…+d₅ and S₂ = d₆+…+d₁₀ so that S₁ + S₂ = 45.  
3. (R) Translate Statements 1 and 2 into “S₁ is prime” and “S₂ is triangular.”  
4. (C) List triangular numbers ≤ 45, subtract each from 45, and observe that the only triangular–prime pairing is 28 & 17; conclude S₁ = 17 and S₂ = 28.  
5. (C) Let A = d₄+d₅ and B = d₆+d₇; from Statement 5 (A+B is a cube ≤ 30) deduce A+B can only be 8 or 27, creating two main cases.  
6. (C) In Case I (A+B = 8) find that the only quadruples of distinct digits totalling 8 are {0,1,2,5} or {0,1,3,4}; use Statement 4 (d₅+d₆ is a square) to eliminate {0,1,3,4} and fix {0,1,2,5} in positions 4–7 with d₅+d₆=1.  
7. (R) Enumerate the two possible internal orders of these digits: (i) 2 0 1 5 and (ii) 5 1 0 2.  
8. (R) For order (i) compute d₄+d₅=2 → d₁+d₂+d₃=15 and d₆+d₇=6 → d₈+d₉+d₁₀=22.  
9. (R) For order (ii) compute d₄+d₅=6 → d₁+d₂+d₃=11 and d₆+d₇=2 → d₈+d₉+d₁₀=26.  
10. (C) Apply the difference rules (Statements 6–8) to the two sub-cases; show that sub-case (ii) is impossible while sub-case (i) can work because the needed sign pattern is (+2,+3,+4).  
11. (C) From the accepted sign pattern deduce the relations d₁₀ = d₁+2, d₉ = d₂+3, d₈ = d₃+4.  
12. (C) List the six unused digits {3,4,6,7,8,9}; invoke Statement 9 to put 4 among d₁–d₃ and test possible values of d₁, narrowing the search.  
13. (R) Select d₁ = 7 (giving d₁₀ = 9); pick d₂ = 3 and d₉ = 6 so that all digits remain distinct.  
14. (R) Assign the remaining first-block digit d₃ = 4, which forces d₈ = 8, completing all ten digits.  
15. (R) Compile the tentative lotto number 7 3 4 2 1 0 5 8 6 9 and verify that it satisfies all nine statements.  
16. (R) Examine Case II (A+B = 27, requiring d₅+d₆ = 16) and, by parity/size checks, determine that no arrangement of the remaining digits can satisfy the difference statements, eliminating this case.  
17. (R) Conclude that the unique lotto number meeting every condition is 7342105869.

7. (R) Enumerate the two possible internal orders of these digits: (i) 2 0 1 5 and (ii) 5 1 0 2.  
8. (R) For order (i) compute d₄+d₅=2 → d₁+d₂+d₃=15 and d₆+d₇=6 → d₈+d₉+d₁₀=22.  
9. (R) For order (ii) compute d₄+d₅=6 → d₁+d₂+d₃=11 and d₆+d₇=2 → d₈+d₉+d₁₀=26.  
10. (C) Apply the difference rules (Statements 6–8) to the two sub-cases; show that sub-case (ii) is impossible while sub-case (i) can work because the needed sign pattern is (+2,+3,+4).  
11. (C) From the accepted sign pattern deduce the relations d₁₀ = d₁+2, d₉ = d₂+3, d₈ = d₃+4.  
12. (C) List the six unused digits {3,4,6,7,8,9}; invoke Statement 9 to put 4 among d₁–d₃ and test possible values of d₁, narrowing the search.  
13. (R) Select d₁ = 7 (giving d₁₀ = 9); pick d₂ = 3 and d₉ = 6 so that all digits remain distinct.  
14. (R) Assign the remaining first-block digit d₃ = 4, which forces d₈ = 8, completing all ten digits.  
15. (R) Compile the tentative lotto number 7 3 4 2 1 0 5 8 6 9 and verify that it satisfies all nine statements.  
16. (R) Examine Case II (A+B = 27, requiring d₅+d₆ = 16) and, by parity/size checks, determine that no arrangement of the remaining digits can satisfy the difference statements, eliminating this case.  
17. (R) Conclude that the unique lotto number meeting every condition is 7342105869.']

Question:
There is a ten digit mystery number (no leading 0), represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) If A > B, then C = 5 or 7, else C = 0 or 1.
2) If B > C, then D = 1 or 2, else D = 4 or 9.
3) If C > D, then E = 6 or 9, else E = 3 or 5.
4) If D > E, then F = 2 or 4, else F = 1 or 6.
5) If E > F, then G = 5 or 6, else G = 0 or 7.
6) If F > G, then H = 1 or 4, else H = 8 or 9.
7) If G > H, then I = 0 or 8, else I = 6 or 7.
8) If H > I, then J = 3 or 8, else J = 2 or 5.
9) If I > J, then A = 3 or 7, else A = 4 or 8.
10) If J > A, then B = 0 or 9, else B = 2 or 3.
Hint: For example, assign 8 to H.  I can not exceed H, so J would have to be 3 (8 already assigned to H).
Human Solution:
We work strictly through the ten clues, never guessing and always keeping the digits 0–9 all different.  

(1)  If A > B, then C = 5 or 7.  
(9)  A is one of 3,4,7,8.  
(10) B is one of 0,2,3,9.  

We will determine all letters successively from the back of the chain, because the later clues feed back into the earlier ones.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 1 – begin with clue 7  
If G > H then I = 0 or 8, else I = 6 or 7.  
Take the sub-case I = 0.  
Then G > H must hold.

Step 2 – clue 6 (uses F and G)  
If F > G then H = 1 or 4, else H = 8 or 9.  
Because G > H and G can only be 0,5,6,7, the option H = 8 or 9 is impossible (G cannot exceed 8 or 9).  
Hence F > G and H is 1 or 4.

Step 3 – clue 5 (uses E and F)  
If E > F then G = 5 or 6, else G = 0 or 7.  
We already know G ≠ 0 (G > H) and G ≠ 7 (otherwise F > G would fail).  
Therefore G must be 5 or 6, and thus E > F.

Step 4 – clue 4 (uses D and E)  
If D > E then F = 2 or 4, else F = 1 or 6.  
We need F > G (clue 6).  The only choice large enough to exceed G = 5 is F = 6.  
Consequently F = 6 and therefore D ≤ E (so F came from the “else” part).  
We now have G = 5, F = 6, E = 9 (E must exceed 6 and be one of 3,5,6,9).

Step 5 – clue 3 (uses C and D)  
E = 9 lies in {6,9}, so we must be in the branch “C > D”.  

Step 6 – clue 2 (uses B and C)  
If B > C then D = 1 or 2, else D = 4 or 9.  
Because C must exceed D (from Step 5) and 9 is already used, the only possible D is 4.  
Hence B ≤ C and D = 4.

Step 7 – clue 1 (uses A and B)  
To make C > D with D = 4, C cannot be 0 or 1, so C must be 7.  
Thus we are in the branch A > B, and A belongs to {3,4,7,8}\{7}= {3,4,8}.  
B is 0,2,3,9 but must stay below 7, so B is 2 or 3.

We have now fixed  
C = 7, D = 4, E = 9, F = 6, G = 5, H = 1, I = 0 and used digits {0,1,4,5,6,7,9}.  
Left digits: {2,3,8}.  These will be A, B, J.

Step 8 – clue 8 (uses H and I)  
H (=1) > I (=0) so J = 3 or 8.

Step 9 – clue 9 (uses I and J)  
I (=0) > J is false, therefore A = 4 or 8.  But 4 is already used, so A = 8.

Step 10 – clue 8 again gives J  
Since A = 8, J cannot equal 8 (no repeats).  Hence J = 3.

Step 11 – clue 10 (uses J and A)  
J (=3) > A (=8) is false, so B = 2 or 3.  Digit 3 is taken by J, hence B = 2.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
All letters are fixed:

A = 8  
B = 2  
C = 7  
D = 4  
E = 9  
F = 6  
G = 5  
H = 1  
I = 0  
J = 3  

Quick verification against every clue shows each condition satisfied and every digit 0-9 used exactly once.

Therefore the ten-digit mystery number is 8274965103.

Final answer: 8274965103
Response:
Total Step Count: 13  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 12  

Steps:  
1. Creative – Observe that each clue (7 → 10) feeds information back into earlier clues and adopt the strategy of working backward from the end of the chain toward the beginning.  

2. Rudimentary – Apply clue 7.  Choose the sub-case I = 0, which forces G > H.  

3. Rudimentary – Apply clue 6.  Because G > H, the option H = 8 or 9 is impossible, so F > G and H = 1 or 4.  

4. Rudimentary – Apply clue 5.  With F > G, the branch G = 0 or 7 is ruled out; hence G = 5 or 6 and E > F.  

5. Rudimentary – Apply clue 4.  To keep F > G when G is 5 or 6, F must be 6.  This triggers the “else” branch (D ≤ E) and fixes G = 5, F = 6, and because E must exceed 6 and lie in the set {6,9,3,5}, E = 9.  

6. Rudimentary – Use clue 3.  Since E = 9 belongs to {6, 9}, the active branch is C > D.  

7. Rudimentary – Use clue 2 together with C > D.  Because 9 is already taken, the only value that lets C exceed D is D = 4, which also gives B ≤ C.  

8. Rudimentary – Use clue 1.  With D = 4 the options C = 0 or 1 fail (they would not exceed 4), so C = 7.  This places us in A > B, so A ∈ {3,4,8} and B ∈ {0,2,3,9} with B < 7.  

9. Rudimentary – Apply clue 8.  Because H = 1 > I = 0, we obtain J = 3 or 8.  

10. Rudimentary – Apply clue 9.  I (=0) is not greater than J, so use the “else” branch: A = 4 or 8; but 4 is already used, hence A = 8.  

11. Rudimentary – Return to clue 8.  A = 8 rules out J = 8, leaving J = 3.  

12. Rudimentary – Apply clue 10.  J (=3) is not greater than A (=8), so B = 2 or 3; 3 is taken, thus B = 2.  

13. Rudimentary – All letters are fixed: A = 8, B = 2, C = 7, D = 4, E = 9, F = 6, G = 5, H = 1, I = 0, J = 3.  Verify that every clue is satisfied and all ten digits 0–9 are present exactly once, giving the mystery number 8274965103.

Question:
There is a ten-digit mystery number (no leading 0), represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) Digit A is either a square number or a triangle number, but not both.
2) Digit B is either an even number or a cube number, but not both.
3) Digit C is either a cube number or a triangle number, but not both.
4) Digit D is either an odd number or a square number, but not both.
5) Digit E is either an odd number or a cube number, but not both.
6) Digit F is either an odd number or a triangle number, but not both.
7) Digit G is either an odd number or a prime number, but not both.
8) Digit H is either an even number or a square number, but not both.
9) Digit I is either a square number or a cube number, but not both.
10) Digit J is either a prime number or a triangle number, but not both.
11) A < B, C < D, E < F, G < H, I < J
12) A + B + C + D + E < F + G + H + I + J
Hint: A) First, determine what two subsets of numbers qualify for each digit.  However, each digit can only be in one of the subsets, not both.
Human Solution:
I was unable to construct a ten–digit number that simultaneously satisfies

• every “either … or … but not both’’ condition,
• the five pair–wise inequalities A < B, C < D, E < F, G < H, I < J,
• the requirement that each of the ten different digits 0–9 be used exactly once, and
• the final inequality A+B+C+D+E < F+G+H+I+J.

Carefully re–examining every possible assignment shows that the very first two constraints force

 A = 3 and B = 6,

while the third and fourth constraints then force

 C = 8  and  D > 8,

yet no single digit 0–9 can be placed in D that is simultaneously (i) greater than 8 and (ii) “either odd or square, but not both.”  This contradiction arises no matter how one interprets “square,” “cube,” or “triangle” among the one–digit numbers.

Hence, under the statement of the problem exactly as given, no such ten–digit number exists.
Response:
Total Step Count: 4  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 2  

Steps:  
1. Combine the first two “either … or … but not both’’ rules with the requirement that each digit 0–9 appear exactly once; this forces the unique assignments A = 3 and B = 6.  (Creative)  
2. Use the third and fourth exclusive–or rules together with the already–chosen digits to deduce that C = 8 and therefore D must be a digit greater than 8.  (Creative)  
3. Examine the only remaining digit larger than 8 (namely 9) and show it fails D’s rule because 9 is both odd and a square, violating the exclusive–or condition.  (Rudimentary)  
4. Note that no permissible value exists for D, so the entire set of constraints is contradictory; hence no ten–digit number satisfying all conditions can exist.  (Rudimentary)

Question:
Einstein's Riddle:
Einstein wrote the following riddle. He said that 98% of the world could not solve it. But several NIEHS scientists were able to solve it, and they said it's not all that hard if you pay attention and are very patient. Give it a try:
There are 5 houses in 5 different colors in a row. In each house lives a person with a different nationality. The 5 owners drink a certain type of beverage, smoke a certain brand of cigar, and keep a certain pet. No owners have the same pet, smoke the same brand of cigar, or drink the same beverage. Other facts:
1.	The Brit lives in the red house.
2.	The Swede keeps dogs as pets.
3.	The Dane drinks tea.
4.	The green house is on the immediate left of the white house.
5.	The green house's owner drinks coffee.
6.	The owner who smokes Pall Mall rears birds.
7.	The owner of the yellow house smokes Dunhill.
8.	The owner living in the center house drinks milk.
9.	The Norwegian lives in the first house.
10.	The owner who smokes Blends lives next to the one who keeps cats.
11.	The owner who keeps the horse lives next to the one who smokes Dunhill.
12.	The owner who smokes Bluemasters drinks beer.
13.	The German smokes Prince.
14.	The Norwegian lives next to the blue house.
15.	The owner who smokes Blends lives next to the one who drinks water.
The question is: WHO OWNS THE FISH?
Hint: Just take your time. This one should take you some time and is probably one of the harder riddles you see.
Human Solution: Final answer: German

Question:
Zachary has a private zoo.  He has five groups of animals in his zoo:  snakes, birds, mammals, insects, and spiders.  Assume that, typically:  animals have 1 head, snakes have 0 legs, birds have 2 legs, mammals have 4 legs, insects have 6 legs, and spiders have 8 legs.  Zachary has some unusual animals in his zoo.  He has:  a snake with 3 heads, a bird with 2 heads, a mammal with 3 legs, an insect with 4 legs, and a spider with 7 legs.  From the following information, determine how many of each group of animals that Zachary has in his menagerie.
1) There are a total of 100 heads and 376 legs.
2) Each group has a different quantity of animals.
3) The most populous group has 10 more members than the least populous group.
4) There are twice as many insect legs as there are bird legs.
5) There are as many snake heads as there are spider heads.
Hint: Since there are 3 extra heads (2 snake and 1 bird), there are only 97 animals (clue 1).  Find a set of five different numbers whose sum is 97 (clue 2) and whose size difference between the least populous and most populous group is 10 (clue 3).
Human Solution:
Snakes : 19  
Birds  : 25  
Mammals: 15  
Insects: 17  
Spiders: 21  

Final answer: 19 snakes, 25 birds, 15 mammals, 17 insects, and 21 spiders.
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Conclude that there are 19 snakes. (Rudimentary)  
2. Conclude that there are 25 birds. (Rudimentary)  
3. Conclude that there are 15 mammals. (Rudimentary)  
4. Conclude that there are 17 insects. (Rudimentary)  
5. Conclude that there are 21 spiders. (Rudimentary)
