Question:
In a forest somewhere in Scotland lives a group of 100 dwarves. Each night they meet in the middle of the forest for a grand feast.  When morning comes, they all go home.  Each dwarf is wearing either a red hat or a blue hat. Curiously, there are no mirrors in the forest, so no dwarf knows the color of his own hat. A dwarf would never take off his hat to see its color, and a major dwarf faux pas is to comment on the color of another dwarf's hat.  The dwarves know, however, that there is at least one red hatted dwarf and one blue hatted dwarf. One day, the master dwarf announces that the nightly feast will only be intended for blue hatted dwarves, and as soon as a dwarf knows that he is wearing a red hat, he should not come back the next day, and he should never return.
How many days does it take before there are no dwarves left with red hats at the party? (Assume all the dwarves are equally capable of figuring it out, in other words, there are no smart dwarves, and no stupid dwarves...)
Hint: The number of days depends on the number of red hats.
Human Solution:
Let R be the (unknown to us) number of red-hatted dwarves present on the day of the announcement.  
We show that all R red hats leave together on the R-th morning, and that no red hat can leave earlier.  
Hence there are exactly R days of mixed feasts, and after the R-th night no red-hatted dwarf is ever seen at the party again.

Step 1 – One red hat (R = 1).  
Every dwarf knows “there is at least one red hat”.  
The lone red-hatted dwarf sees only blue hats.  
Therefore he alone can satisfy the condition “there is at least one red hat”, so he knows at once that his own hat is red.  
He stays away the very next night.  
Thus, if R = 1, all red hats disappear after 1 day.

Step 2 – Two red hats (R = 2).  
Each of the two red-hatted dwarves sees exactly one red hat (the other’s).  
Each thinks: “If there were only that one red hat, he would discover it to-night (by Step 1 reasoning) and stay away to-morrow.”  
When both red hats see that no one is absent the next morning, each realises the other could not have been the sole red hat; so there must be (at least) two, and therefore his own hat must be red as well.  
Both stay away after the second night.  
Hence, if R = 2, all red hats disappear after 2 days.

Step 3 – Inductive step.  
Assume that whenever there are k (< R) red hats, they all stay away after exactly k days.  
Now suppose there are R red hats.  
Every red-hatted dwarf sees R − 1 red hats.  
Each reasons:

“If there were only those R − 1 red hats, then by the induction hypothesis they would all leave after R − 1 days.  
If, after R − 1 days, at least one red hat is still present, there must be more than R − 1 red hats, so my own hat must also be red.”

For the first R − 1 days everyone waits.  
When the R − 1-st morning arrives, all R red-hatted dwarves still see at least one red hat at the feast; thus each concludes that the number of red hats exceeds R − 1 and therefore must be R, forcing the realisation that his own hat is red.  
Consequently every red-hatted dwarf stays away after the R-th night.

No red hat can leave earlier, since the above reasoning shows all red hats require the information contained in the first R − 1 mornings to deduce the total.  
Therefore R days are necessary and sufficient.

Step 4 – Bound on R.  
Because the statement of the problem guarantees at least one blue hat, R ≤ 99.  
Hence the last possible morning on which a red hat can still appear is the 99-th; by the 100-th dwarf gathering the feast is entirely blue.

Conclusion.  
If the original number of red-hatted dwarves is R, then:

• The first night after the announcement still includes all R red hats.  
• After exactly R nights all R red-hatted dwarves have departed and none ever return.  

Thus the number of days until there are no red hats at the party is precisely the initial number R of red-hatted dwarves (never more than 99 in this situation).

Final answer: After exactly as many days as there were red-hatted dwarves to begin with (at most 99 days).
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. Introduce the unknown number R of red-hatted dwarves and announce the overall goal: prove all R red hats leave together on the R-th morning and cannot leave sooner. (Rudimentary)

2. Analyse the base case R = 1.  
   – The single red-hatted dwarf sees only blue hats, recalls that “there is at least one red hat,” and therefore deduces immediately that his own hat is red; he stays away the very next night. (Rudimentary)

3. Analyse the case R = 2.  
   – Each red-hatted dwarf sees exactly one red hat.  
   – Each reasons that if that single hat were the only red hat, its wearer would depart after the first night (by the R = 1 logic).  
   – When nobody is absent the next morning, each concludes a second red hat must exist—hence his own—and both depart after the second night. (Creative)

4. State the induction hypothesis: assume for every k < R that k red hats always depart together on the k-th morning. (Rudimentary)

5. Prove the inductive step for an arbitrary R ≥ 3.  
   – Each red-hatted dwarf sees R – 1 red hats.  
   – He reasons: “If there were only those R – 1 red hats, they would all leave after R – 1 days by the induction hypothesis.”  
   – All dwarves therefore watch the first R – 1 mornings pass.  
   – When the R – 1-st morning still shows at least one red hat present, each dwarf realises there must be R red hats in total and therefore that his own hat is red; all red hats stay away after the R-th night. (Creative)

6. Justify minimality: none of the red hats could have left earlier, because each needed the information contained in the first R – 1 mornings to complete his deduction. (Rudimentary)

7. Combine the base cases and the inductive step to conclude (by mathematical induction) that whenever the initial number of red hats is R, they all depart simultaneously on the R-th morning. (Rudimentary)

8. Use the problem’s guarantee of at least one blue hat to bound R ≤ 99, hence the departure of the last red hat can occur no later than the 99-th morning. (Rudimentary)

9. Summarise: the number of days until no red-hatted dwarf remains at the feast is exactly the initial number R (never exceeding 99 in this scenario). (Rudimentary)

['Total Step Count: 9  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 7

2. Analyse the base case R = 1.  
   – The single red-hatted dwarf sees only blue hats, recalls that “there is at least one red hat,” and therefore deduces immediately that his own hat is red; he stays away the very next night. (Rudimentary)

3. Analyse the case R = 2.  
   – Each red-hatted dwarf sees exactly one red hat.  
   – Each reasons that if that single hat were the only red hat, its wearer would depart after the first night (by the R = 1 logic).  
   – When nobody is absent the next morning, each concludes a second red hat must exist—hence his own—and both depart after the second night. (Creative)

4. State the induction hypothesis: assume for every k < R that k red hats always depart together on the k-th morning. (Rudimentary)

5. Prove the inductive step for an arbitrary R ≥ 3.

8. Use the problem’s guarantee of at least one blue hat to bound R ≤ 99, hence the departure of the last red hat can occur no later than the 99-th morning. (Rudimentary)

9. Summarise: the number of days until no red-hatted dwarf remains at the feast is exactly the initial number R (never exceeding 99 in this scenario). (Rudimentary)']

Question:
Please do Military Fun and Military Fun 2 first before doing this teaser. This teaser continues on from the first and second times the friends got together, and will give away the answer to Military Fun and Military Fun 2. So, please do those teasers first.
This time the same 10 friends are going to go through a training camp so that they can be ready for their next pretend battle. More friends are finding out about this military fun and want to join, Private Brianna and Private Ben have come into this group too. Today the friends will be running 3 laps around the park. At the end of the race, the friends will move up or down in ranks according on how they did. If you can't move up or down any ranks, you will stay in the same rank that you are currently in. The scoring will be as follows
1st Place- Move up 5 ranks
2nd Place- Move up 4 ranks
3rd Place- Move up 3 ranks
4th and 5th Places- Move up 1 rank each
6th and 7th Places- Stay the same rank
8th and 9th Places- Move down 1 rank each
10th and 11th Places- Move down 2 ranks each
12th Place- Move down 3 ranks
The ranks people have right now:
Lieutenant General Stephen
Colonel Anna
Major Felicia
Captain Clark
Sergeant Abby
Sergeant Brad
Corporal Jessica
Private Paul
Private Kelsey
Private Luke
Private Brianna
Private Ben
This is a list of the ranks again, just in case anyone forgot it.
Ranks
1. Lieutenant General
2. Brigadier General
3. Colonel
4. Lieutenant Colonel
5. Major
6. Captain
7. First Lieutenant
8. Second Lieutenant
9. First Sergeant
10. Sergeant
11. Corporal
12. Private
The First Lap:
Stephen, Ben, Paul, and Jessica took off sprinting taking the top 4 spots. Felicia and Brianna aren't far behind though. Kelsey, Anna and Abby were bringing up the back as they had a late start.
In the top 4 runners, the bottom two ranked people were doing the best and the top ranked person was doing the worst. The Major was in 6th place as Brianna passed her for 5th. Luke was just about to pass Felicia, but tripped and fell back to 9th place as Clark and Brad passed him in that order. The back three girls were in their places according to their rank, the highest rank being 10th place and the lowest rank being 12th place.
The Second Lap:
Paul slipped on a water puddle and fell back to third place, leaving the person he was right by, way in front. Clark moved up 2 spots, pushing those two people back one place each. Then, Felicia and Anna switched places, and Luke and Brad switched places. The people in 11th and 12th ended up switching places just before the third lap as well.
The Third Lap:
The two people in 10th and 11th place switched spots, the two people in 5th and 6th places switched spots, and the two people in 7th and 8th places switched spots. Brad ended up getting passed by the two people directly behind him, and Jessica was passed by the person directly behind her. Everyone then finished in the order that they are currently in.
Can you figure out which place everyone is in, and what rank they will be after this race?
Hint: On the first lap the top 4 runners were Stephen, Ben, Paul, and Jessica. Felicia and Brianna weren't far behind which means they were in 5th and 6th place. With Kelsey, Anna, and Abby in the back (10th, 11th, and 12th places), that means Luke, Brad, and Clark were in 7th, 8th, and 9th.
Human Solution:
Finishing order lap-by-lap

FIRST LAP  
1 Ben, 2 Paul, 3 Jessica, 4 Stephen, 5 Brianna, 6 Felicia,  
7 Clark, 8 Brad, 9 Luke, 10 Anna, 11 Abby, 12 Kelsey  
(conditions in the statement force that exact order).

SECOND LAP  
• Paul slips to 3rd ⇒ Ben 1, Jessica 2, Paul 3.  
• Clark moves up two places (passes Brianna and Felicia) ⇒ Clark 5, Brianna 6, Felicia 7.  
• Felicia ↔ Anna; Luke ↔ Brad; Abby ↔ Kelsey.  
End of lap-2:  
1 Ben, 2 Jessica, 3 Paul, 4 Stephen, 5 Clark, 6 Brianna,  
7 Anna, 8 Luke, 9 Brad, 10 Felicia, 11 Kelsey, 12 Abby.

THIRD (FINAL) LAP  
• 10th ↔ 11th ⇒ Kelsey 10, Felicia 11.  
• 5th ↔ 6th ⇒ Brianna 5, Clark 6.  
• 7th ↔ 8th ⇒ Luke 7, Anna 8.  
• Brad (9th) is passed by Kelsey and Felicia ⇒ Kelsey 9, Felicia 10, Brad 11.  
• Paul (3rd) passes Jessica (2nd).  
Final finishing order  
1 Ben, 2 Paul, 3 Jessica, 4 Stephen, 5 Brianna, 6 Clark,  
7 Luke, 8 Anna, 9 Kelsey, 10 Felicia, 11 Brad, 12 Abby.

Rank changes

Position → change ⇒ new rank  
1st  +5  Ben: Private(12) → First Lieutenant(7)  
2nd  +4  Paul: Private(12) → Second Lieutenant(8)  
3rd  +3  Jessica: Corporal(11) → Second Lieutenant(8)  
4th  +1  Stephen: already Lieutenant General(1) ⇒ remains  
5th  +1  Brianna: Private(12) → Corporal(11)  
6th   0  Clark: remains Captain(6)  
7th   0  Luke: remains Private(12)  
8th  −1  Anna: Colonel(3) → Lieutenant Colonel(4)  
9th  −1  Kelsey: already lowest rank ⇒ remains Private(12)  
10th −2  Felicia: Major(5) → First Lieutenant(7)  
11th −2  Brad: Sergeant(10) → Private(12)  
12th −3  Abby: Sergeant(10) → Private(12)   (cannot go below 12)

Final standings and ranks

1. Ben – First Lieutenant  
2. Paul – Second Lieutenant  
3. Jessica – Second Lieutenant  
4. Stephen – Lieutenant General  
5. Brianna – Corporal  
6. Clark – Captain  
7. Luke – Private  
8. Anna – Lieutenant Colonel  
9. Kelsey – Private  
10. Felicia – First Lieutenant  
11. Brad – Private  
12. Abby – Private  

Final answer: Ben 1st (First Lieutenant); Paul 2nd (Second Lieutenant); Jessica 3rd (Second Lieutenant); Stephen 4th (Lieutenant General); Brianna 5th (Corporal); Clark 6th (Captain); Luke 7th (Private); Anna 8th (Lieutenant Colonel); Kelsey 9th (Private); Felicia 10th (First Lieutenant); Brad 11th (Private); Abby 12th (Private).
Response:
Total Step Count: 14  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 13  

Steps:  
1. Deduce the exact finishing order for Lap 1 from all narrative constraints (placing Ben, Paul, Jessica, Stephen, etc. in positions 1-12). – Creative  
2. Apply Paul’s slip in Lap 2, moving him from 1st to 3rd and adjusting the two runners ahead accordingly. – Rudimentary  
3. Apply Clark’s two-place advance past Brianna and Felicia during Lap 2. – Rudimentary  
4. Execute the three stated pairwise swaps in Lap 2: Felicia↔Anna, Luke↔Brad, Abby↔Kelsey. – Rudimentary  
5. Compile and record the complete Lap 2 finishing order after all changes. – Rudimentary  
6. In Lap 3 swap the racers in 10th and 11th positions (Kelsey and Felicia). – Rudimentary  
7. Swap the racers in 5th and 6th positions (Brianna and Clark). – Rudimentary  
8. Swap the racers in 7th and 8th positions (Luke and Anna). – Rudimentary  
9. Update positions when Brad (now 9th) is passed by Kelsey and Felicia, pushing Brad to 11th. – Rudimentary  
10. Update positions when Paul passes Jessica, switching 2nd and 3rd. – Rudimentary  
11. Record the final finishing order at the end of Lap 3. – Rudimentary  
12. List the race-to-rank conversion table (+5 for 1st, +4 for 2nd, etc.). – Rudimentary  
13. Apply the appropriate rank change to each runner, respecting upper and lower rank limits. – Rudimentary  
14. Present the final standings with each person’s place and new rank. – Rudimentary

Question:
In Numberrangements, you are given an arrangement of letters. The letters represent all of the whole numbers from 1 to the total number of letters used. Each letter represents a different number. Using the clues given, find which number each letter represents.
ABC
DEF
GHI
1. The sum of the top row is greater than the sum of the middle row, which is greater than the sum of the bottom row.
2. E is a prime factor of G.
3. F is greater than A.
4. The sum of B and G is equal to H.
5. I is not 1.
Hint: Start with casework on clue 2.
Human Solution:
Let the nine different whole numbers 1-9 be placed as  

ABC  
DEF  
GHI  

and keep the five clues in view.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  E is a prime factor of G
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Among 1-9 the primes are 2, 3, 5, 7.  
If E = 5 or 7, no number 1-9 is a multiple of 5 or 7, so these two are
impossible.  
Hence   E = 2 or 3.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  If E = 3
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Then G must be 6 or 9.

•  G = 9 is impossible because B + 9 = H would exceed 9.  
•  G = 6 forces B ≤ 3.  
  –  If B = 3 it clashes with E = 3.  
  –  B = 1 gives H = 7, B = 2 gives H = 8.  
  In either sub-case try every legal value of I and
  compute the three row-sums.  
  In every instance the required inequalities
         (top) > (middle) > (bottom)
  fail (the middle row cannot be made larger than the bottom row while
  still staying smaller than the top row).  

Therefore E cannot be 3.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Hence E = 2
--------------------------------------------------------------------
G must now be a multiple of 2, i.e. 4, 6 or 8.

Because H = B + G must not exceed 9, list the admissible ordered triples
(B, G, H):

        (1,4,5) , (3,4,7) , (5,4,9)
        (1,6,7) , (3,6,9)
        (1,8,9)

Examine each triple in turn, always enforcing

   top-row   >   middle-row   >   bottom-row ,

together with F > A and I ≠ 1.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3a. (B, G, H) = (3,4,7) or (5,4,9)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
With G = 4 the bottom row already contains 4+H ≥ 11 before I is chosen,
so (middle) > (bottom) cannot be satisfied; both triples are impossible.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3b. (B, G, H) = (1,6,7) or (3,6,9)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Put the values into the bottom row (6, 7, I) and complete the
remaining six places with the unused numbers.
Whatever value I is given, a direct check of all possible top- and
middle-row fillings shows that
(middle) > (bottom) fails.  Hence both triples are impossible.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3c. (B, G, H) = (1,4,5)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Now the bottom row is 4 + 5 + I = 9+I, the smallest possible so far.
Choose I from the remaining numbers {3,6,7,8,9}, but note that a larger
I makes the bottom row too big, so try the smallest admissible I, namely
I = 3.

Numbers now used: 1,2,3,4,5.  
Numbers left for A, C, D, F: 6,7,8,9.

Total of all rows is 45, hence

   (top) + (middle) = 45 − (bottom)  
                    = 45 − 12  
                    = 33.

Let the two unused numbers assigned to the top row be X and Y, and the
two given to the middle row be U and V.  Then

   top-row   = 1 + X + Y,  
   mid-row   = 2 + U + V,  
   (X,Y,U,V distinct and taken from 6,7,8,9).

All possible choices for {X,Y} and the corresponding sums are

   {6,7}: 1+6+7 = 14
   {6,8}: 15
   {6,9}: 16
   {7,8}: 16
   {7,9}: 17   ← possible
   {8,9}: 18   ← possible

If {X,Y} = {7,9} the middle row sum is 33 − 17 = 16;
if {X,Y} = {8,9} the middle row sum is 33 − 18 = 15.
Only the first of these respects top > middle > bottom (17 > 16 > 12).

So   {X,Y} = {7,9}  and {U,V} = {6,8}.

Place them so that F > A (F is the third letter of the middle row,
A is the first letter of the top row):

   choose A = 7, C = 9, D = 6, F = 8  (since 8 > 7).

This assignment uses every number exactly once and
satisfies every given clue:

   A = 7    B = 1    C = 9  
   D = 6    E = 2    F = 8  
   G = 4    H = 5    I = 3

Check:

• Row sums: 7+1+9 = 17,  6+2+8 = 16,  4+5+3 = 12  ⇒ 17 > 16 > 12 ✔  
• E = 2 is a prime factor of G = 4 ✔  
• F = 8 greater than A = 7 ✔  
• B + G = 1 + 4 = 5 = H ✔  
• I = 3 ≠ 1 ✔  

No other (B, G, H) triple survives the earlier eliminations, so this
solution is unique.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer:  
A = 7, B = 1, C = 9, D = 6, E = 2, F = 8, G = 4, H = 5, I = 3
Response:
Total Step Count: 10  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) Note that the only primes in 1-9 are 2, 3, 5, 7; because no number 1-9 is a multiple of 5 or 7, conclude E can only be 2 or 3.  

2. (Rudimentary) Examine the case E = 3: G must be 6 or 9.  G = 9 is ruled out since B + 9 = H would exceed 9; G = 6 demands B ≤ 3.  Testing the legal B and I values shows the required row-sum inequality (top > middle > bottom) can never hold, so E ≠ 3.  

3. (Rudimentary) Deduce that E = 2.  

4. (Rudimentary) With E = 2, list all G that are multiples of 2 (4, 6, 8) and, using H = B + G ≤ 9, enumerate every admissible ordered triple (B, G, H):  
 (1,4,5), (3,4,7), (5,4,9), (1,6,7), (3,6,9), (1,8,9).  

5. (Creative) Eliminate the triples (3,4,7) and (5,4,9) by observing that with G = 4 the bottom-row partial sum 4 + H is already ≥ 11, making it impossible for the middle row to be larger than the bottom row but still smaller than the top row.  

6. (Rudimentary) Test the triples (1,6,7) and (3,6,9) systematically; for every placement of the remaining numbers the inequality middle > bottom fails, so these options are discarded.  

7. (Creative) Focus on the remaining triple (1,4,5).  To keep the bottom row as small as possible, select the smallest still-available value for I, namely 3, giving bottom-row sum 9 + I = 12.  

8. (Creative) Use the fact that the total of all numbers is 45, so the combined top- and middle-row sum must be 33.  With unused numbers 6, 7, 8, 9, enumerate the possible pairs {X,Y} for the top row and their sums; only {7,9} (sum = 17) leaves a middle-row sum (16) that fits 17 > 16 > 12.  

9. (Rudimentary) Place the remaining four numbers so that F > A: choose A = 7, C = 9 for the top row and D = 6, F = 8 for the middle row (since 8 > 7).  

10. (Rudimentary) Present the full assignment  
 A = 7, B = 1, C = 9, D = 6, E = 2, F = 8, G = 4, H = 5, I = 3,  
and verify that every given clue and the row-sum inequality are satisfied, establishing the unique solution.

Question:
MADADIA has been chosen to host the latest United Nations Kebab Annual Liaisons (U.N.K.A.L).
Madadia's mayoress, Madka Owdiseez, has invited several wives of delegates of UNKAL for an informal luncheon.
She plans to seat her 9 guests in a row such that each lady will be able to converse with the person directly to her left and right. She has prepared the following list.
Mrs. F speaks English only.
Mrs. G speaks English and French.
Mrs. H speaks English and Russian.
Mrs. J speaks Russian only.
Mrs. K speaks English only.
Mrs. L speaks French only.
Mrs. M speaks French and German.
Mrs. N speaks English and German.
Mrs. O speaks English only.
How many distinct seating arrangements are possible? Give all possible seating arrangements. Bear in mind that Madka Owdiseez is not one of the 9 to be seated in a row.
Note that ABCD and DCBA are the same
Hint: FKO are interchangeable, and can be arranged 6 ways. FKO stays together unless N is next to M outside GLM (more on that below).
Human Solution:
First note the languages spoken.

English (E) : F , G , H , K , N , O  
French (FR): G , L , M  
Russian (R) : H , J  
German (GE): M , N  

Every lady must share at least one language with each neighbour in the row.

Step 1.  Forced positions.

•  Mrs J speaks only Russian, therefore every neighbour of J must speak Russian.  
  The only other Russian speaker is H, so J can have at most one neighbour –  
  J must be seated at an end with H next to her.

•  Mrs L speaks only French, therefore both of her neighbours must speak French.  
  The only two other French speakers are G and M; hence L must be placed
  between G and M.  Thus the block G-L-M or the reversed block M-L-G must
  occur consecutively.

Step 2.  Fix the orientation.

Because the statement declares that the arrangement read from the right
(…DCBA) is regarded as the same as its reverse (…ABCD), we may fix one
orientation and count each seating only once.  
Place J at the extreme left.  Then H must be in the second seat:

  J  H  _ _ _ _ _ _ _

The seven remaining places are to be filled with

 G , L , M , N  and F , K , O (the three English-only ladies).

Recall the remaining compatibilities:

 •  F , K , O are English-only; they cannot sit next to J, L or M.  
 •  N (E+GE) may sit next to anyone that speaks English or German.  
 •  G (E+FR) may sit next to anyone that speaks English or French.  
 •  M may sit only beside G, L, N.  
 •  L may sit only beside G and M.

Step 3.  Put the French block and count possibilities.

A.  Block G-L-M (in that order)

  i.   starting at seat 3 : J H G L M N ( F,K,O in any order )  
       ⇒ 6 arrangements.

  ii.  starting at seat 4 : J H X G L M N ( Y,Z the other two English-only )  
       (X = any of F,K,O) ⇒ 3·2 = 6 arrangements.

  iii. starting at seat 5 : J H A B G L M N C (A,B,C a permutation of F,K,O)  
       ⇒ 6 arrangements.

  iv.  starting at seat 6 : J H A B C G L M N (A,B,C a permutation of F,K,O)  
       ⇒ 6 arrangements.

  v.   starting at seat 7 : J H ( permutation of F,K,O,N in seats 3–6 ) G L M  
       ⇒ 4! = 24 arrangements.

  Total with G-L-M = 6+6+6+6+24 = 48.

B.  Block M-L-G

  (H is not allowed beside M or L, so the block cannot start at seat 3.)

  i.   starting at seat 4 : J H N M L G ( F,K,O in any order ) ⇒ 6.

  ii.  starting at seat 5 : J H X N M L G Y Z (X,Y,Z a permutation of F,K,O) ⇒ 6.

  iii. starting at seat 6 : J H A B N M L G C (A,B,C a permutation of F,K,O) ⇒ 6.

  iv.  starting at seat 7 : J H A B C N M L G (A,B,C a permutation of F,K,O) ⇒ 6.

  Total with M-L-G = 24.

Hence the number of different seatings (up to reversal) is  

  48 + 24 = 72.

Step 4.  List all arrangements (J fixed at the left-hand end)

1.  J H G L M N F K O    2.  J H G L M N F O K  
3.  J H G L M N K F O    4.  J H G L M N K O F  
5.  J H G L M N O F K    6.  J H G L M N O K F  

7.  J H F G L M N K O    8.  J H F G L M N O K  
9.  J H K G L M N F O   10.  J H K G L M N O F  
11.  J H O G L M N F K  12.  J H O G L M N K F  

13. J H F K G L M N O  14. J H F O G L M N K  
15. J H K F G L M N O  16. J H K O G L M N F  
17. J H O F G L M N K  18. J H O K G L M N F  

19. J H F K O G L M N  20. J H F O K G L M N  
21. J H K F O G L M N  22. J H K O F G L M N  
23. J H O F K G L M N  24. J H O K F G L M N  

25. J H N M L G F K O  26. J H N M L G F O K  
27. J H N M L G K F O  28. J H N M L G K O F  
29. J H N M L G O F K  30. J H N M L G O K F  

31. J H F N M L G K O  32. J H F N M L G O K  
33. J H K N M L G F O  34. J H K N M L G O F  
35. J H O N M L G F K  36. J H O N M L G K F  

37. J H F K N M L G O  38. J H F O N M L G K  
39. J H K F N M L G O  40. J H K O N M L G F  
41. J H O F N M L G K  42. J H O K N M L G F  

43. J H F K O N M L G  44. J H F O K N M L G  
45. J H K F O N M L G  46. J H K O F N M L G  
47. J H O F K N M L G  48. J H O K F N M L G  

49. J H F K O N G L M  50. J H F K N O G L M  
51. J H F O K N G L M  52. J H F O N K G L M  
53. J H F N K O G L M  54. J H F N O K G L M  

55. J H K F O N G L M  56. J H K F N O G L M  
57. J H K O F N G L M  58. J H K O N F G L M  
59. J H K N F O G L M  60. J H K N O F G L M  

61. J H O F K N G L M  62. J H O F N K G L M  
63. J H O K F N G L M  64. J H O K N F G L M  
65. J H O N F K G L M  66. J H O N K F G L M  

67. J H N F K O G L M  68. J H N F O K G L M  
69. J H N K F O G L M  70. J H N K O F G L M  
71. J H N O F K G L M  72. J H N O K F G L M  

Because reversing any row produces the same arrangement in the sense of the
problem, these 72 rows comprise every possible seating of the nine ladies.

Final answer: 72 distinct seating arrangements (listed above).
Response:
Total Step Count: 10  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) Record, for each of the nine ladies, the set of languages she speaks, producing the four language groups (English, French, Russian, German).  

2. (Rudimentary) Restate the problem’s requirement that neighbours must share at least one language, turning the linguistic data into “compatibility” information.  

3. (Creative) Observe that Mrs J speaks only Russian and that the only other Russian speaker is Mrs H; conclude that J must occupy an end-seat with H immediately beside her.  

4. (Creative) Observe that Mrs L speaks only French and that the only other French speakers are G and M; deduce that L must sit between G and M, forming the compulsory consecutive block G-L-M (or its reverse M-L-G).  

5. (Creative) Use the symmetry condition “ABCD = DCBA” to fix one orientation for counting; decide to place J at the extreme left, forcing H into the second seat, so that only one representative of each reversible arrangement is counted.  

6. (Rudimentary) List the remaining seven ladies, separate them into the block {G,L,M}, the mixed-language speaker N, and the three English-only speakers {F,K,O}, and write down their pairwise compatibility rules (e.g., English-only ladies cannot sit next to J, L or M, etc.).  

7. (Rudimentary) Place the block G-L-M (in that order) in every permitted starting seat (3 through 7), compute for each placement how many ways the other four positions can be filled, and sum the counts to obtain 48 arrangements for the orientation G-L-M.  

8. (Rudimentary) Repeat the previous enumeration for the reversed block M-L-G (possible starting seats 4 through 7), producing 24 arrangements for the orientation M-L-G.  

9. (Rudimentary) Add the two subtotals 48 + 24 to obtain 72 distinct seatings up to reversal.  

10. (Rudimentary) Explicitly list all 72 seatings that satisfy the constraints with J fixed on the left, confirming that each arrangement appears once and only once.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 10  
Creative ', ' 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) Record, for each of the nine ladies, the set of languages she speaks, producing the four language groups (English, French, Russian, German).  

2. (Rudimentary) Restate the problem’s requirement that neighbours must share at least one language, turning the linguistic data into “compatibility” information.  

3. (Creative) Observe that Mrs J speaks only Russian and that the only other Russian speaker is Mrs H; conclude that J must occupy an end-seat with H immediately beside her.  

4. (Creative) Observe that Mrs L speaks only French and that the only other French speakers are G and M; deduce that L must sit between G and M, forming the compulsory consecutive block G-L-M (or its reverse M-L-G).  

5. (Creative) Use the symmetry condition “ABCD = DCBA” to fix one orientation for counting; decide to place J at the extreme left, forcing H into the second seat, so that only one representative of each reversible arrangement is counted.  

6. (Rudimentary) List the remaining seven ladies, separate them into the block {G,L,M}, the mixed-language speaker N, and the three English-only speakers {F,K,O}, and write down their pairwise compatibility rules (e.g., English-only ladies cannot sit next to J, L or M, etc.).  

7. (Rudimentary) Place the block G-L-M (in that order) in every permitted starting seat (3 through 7), compute for each placement how many ways the other four positions can be filled, and sum the counts to obtain 48 arrangements for the orientation G-L-M.  

8. (Rudimentary) Repeat the previous enumeration for the reversed block M-L-G (possible starting seats 4 through 7), producing 24 arrangements for the orientation M-L-G.  

9. (Rudimentary) Add the two subtotals 48 + 24 to obtain 72 distinct seatings up to reversal.  

10. (Rudimentary) Explicitly list all 72 seatings that satisfy the constraints with J fixed on the left, confirming that each arrangement appears once and only once.']

Question: A man named Stewart is traveling all over the world. First he travels to Cape Town in South Africa. Then to Jakarta in Indonesia. Then to Canberra in Australia. Then to Rome in Italy. Then to Panama City in Panama. Where does he travel next?
Hint: Each time he travels to a continent he has not traveled to.
Human Solution:
Identify the pattern.

1.  Cape Town – on the continent of Africa  
2.  Jakarta – on the continent of Asia  
3.  Canberra – on the continent of Australia/Oceania  
4.  Rome – on the continent of Europe  
5.  Panama City – on the continent of North America  

The five successive stops list the inhabited continents in strict alphabetical order:

Africa, Asia, Australia (Oceania), Europe, North America.

The only inhabited continent that has not yet appeared – and that alphabetically follows North America – is South America.

Hence Stewart’s next destination must be a city in South America.  
Taking the obvious choice of a well-known capital, he will go to

Buenos Aires, Argentina.

Final answer: Buenos Aires, Argentina
Response:
Total Step Count: 6  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Associate each of the five given cities with its continent: Cape Town → Africa, Jakarta → Asia, Canberra → Australia/Oceania, Rome → Europe, Panama City → North America. (Rudimentary)  
2. Notice that the sequence of continents is in strict alphabetical order: Africa, Asia, Australia/Oceania, Europe, North America. (Creative)  
3. Identify that South America is the only inhabited continent not yet listed and is the next one alphabetically after North America. (Rudimentary)  
4. Conclude that the sixth stop must therefore be a city located in South America. (Rudimentary)  
5. Choose a well-known South American capital—e.g., Buenos Aires, Argentina—as the likely destination. (Rudimentary)  
6. State the final answer: Buenos Aires, Argentina. (Rudimentary)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 6  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Associate each of the five given cities with its continent: Cape Town → Africa, Jakarta → Asia, Canberra → Australia/Oceania, Rome → Europe, Panama City → North America. (Rudimentary)  
2. Notice that the sequence of continents is in strict alphabetical order: Africa, Asia, Australia/Oceania, Europe, North America. (Creative)  
3. Identify that South America is the only inhabited continent not yet listed and is the next one alphabetically after North America. (Rudimentary)  
4. Conclude that the sixth stop must therefore be a city located in South America. (Rudimentary)  
5. Choose a well-known South American capital—e.g., Buenos Aires, Argentina—as the likely destination. (Rudimentary)  
6. State the final answer: Buenos Aires, Argentina. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
The boffins from NASA have received and decoded a digital message from the Galactic Council, informing them that four alien ambassadors from the solar system are due to visit Earth in the next 24 hours. The aliens are Agurgle from Uranus, Wym-Inar from Venus, ChimChim from Pluto and Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn. 24 hours later, they receive a mystery message saying that if any alien comes off the ship that is green, tentacled and slimy, then they are actually an undercover assassin from Neptune. By then, however, the aliens have all landed and are in adjacent decontamination booths, waiting to be let in to NASA Headquarters. One alien turns out to be green, tentacled and slimy!
From the clues below, who is the Neptunian Assassin?
1) Wym-Inar from Venus is the only ambassador in a booth next to exactly one tentacled alien.
2). Two of the ambassadors who are not green, are each in booths next to Agurgle from Uranus.
3) ChimChim from Pluto is the only ambassador not in a booth next to exactly one Un-slimy alien.
Who do the NASA boffins not let out of the booth?
Hint: Don't get too confused with the Un-slimy bit.
Human Solution: Final answer: ChimChim from Pluto is the Neptunian assassin.
Response:
Total Step Count: 1  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 1  

Steps:  
1. State that ChimChim from Pluto is the Neptunian assassin.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 1  
Creative ', ' 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 1  

Steps:  
1. State that ChimChim from Pluto is the Neptunian assassin.']

Question:
Four men are in a line at the Madadian Police station, charged with unlicensed kebab breeding.
The men are Mad Ade, Buster Artery, Cliff Hedge and Donny Moe - and they are standing in a straight line.
One man is fair, handsome and unscarred.
Two men who are not fair, are each standing next to Mad Ade
Buster Artery is the only man standing next to exactly one handsome man.
Cliff Hedge is the only man not standing next to exactly one scarred man.
Who is fair, handsome and unscarred?
Hint: From (2), both the men standing next to Mad Ade are not fair. Also, exactly one man is fair, handsome and unscarred. Hence, there are two cases:
Human Solution:
Let  

Mad Ade  = A , Buster Artery = B , Cliff Hedge = C , Donny Moe = D  

and let the four positions in the straight line be  

1 – 2 – 3 – 4  (left-to-right).  

For every man we note whether he is  

F  (fair) / ¬F (not fair)  
H  (handsome) / ¬H (not handsome)  
S  (scarred) / ¬S (un-scarred).

----------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Where is Mad Ade?

“Two men who are not fair are each standing next to Mad Ade.”
Mad Ade therefore has two neighbours, hence he occupies
one of the two interior places.  Fix him at 2 for definiteness
(the reasoning is symmetric if he is put at 3):

          1 –  A(2)  – 3 – 4  

The neighbours in places 1 and 3 are both ¬F.

----------------------------------------------------------------------  
2.  The scar-neighbour condition (Cliff Hedge)

“Cliff Hedge is the only man not standing next to exactly one scarred
man.”  
So every man except C has exactly one scarred neighbour;
C has either 0 or 2 scarred neighbours.

----------------------------------------------------------------------  
3.  The handsome-neighbour condition (Buster Artery)

“Buster Artery is the only man standing next to exactly one handsome
man.”  
So B has exactly one handsome neighbour, while each of A, C, D has
either 0 or 2 handsome neighbours (never exactly 1).

----------------------------------------------------------------------  
4.  Put Buster at the left end

If B were in an interior place, at least one end–man would
also have exactly one handsome neighbour (he has only one neighbour),
contradicting the uniqueness of B.  
Hence B is at an end; call it place 1.

          B(1) – A(2) – 3 – 4

Because B has exactly one handsome neighbour, A is handsome (H).

----------------------------------------------------------------------  
5.  Handsomeness of the others

•  If the man in place 3 were handsome while the man in place 4 were
not, he would have exactly one handsome neighbour (A) and would rival
B.  
•  If the man in place 3 were the only non-handsome man, A would then
have exactly one handsome neighbour, again contradicting B’s
uniqueness.

The only possibility that avoids a second “exactly one” is  

          H            ¬H            H
          B(1) –  A(2) –  D(3) –  C(4)
(i.e. A and C are handsome, B and D are not).

Now the handsome-neighbour counts are

B : 1  (A)  
A : 0  (neighbours not handsome)  
D : 2  (A and C)  
C : 0  (neighbour not handsome)

So B is indeed the only man with exactly one handsome neighbour.

----------------------------------------------------------------------  
6.  Fixing the scars

Because the two end–men (B and C) are not Cliff (C is at 4), each of
them must have exactly one scarred neighbour.
Therefore A is scarred (to give B his single scarred neighbour) and D
is un-scarred (so that C has 0 scarred neighbours and is the exceptional
man of the statement).

To make A have exactly one scarred neighbour, his
other neighbour D must be un-scarred, and to give D exactly one scarred
neighbour B must be scarred.  Summarising:

B : S   A : S   D : ¬S   C : ¬S  

Counting scarred neighbours:

B : 1  (A)  
A : 1  (B)  
D : 1  (A)  
C : 0  (D)

So Cliff really is the only man whose number of scarred neighbours is
not 1.

----------------------------------------------------------------------  
7.  Fair or not-fair?

The neighbours of A (positions 1 and 3) have to be ¬F by the very first
statement, so B and D are not fair.  No condition forbids anyone else
from being fair, so we may (and do) take A and C to be fair.

----------------------------------------------------------------------  
8.  Who is fair, handsome and un-scarred?

Attributes obtained:

B : ¬F, ¬H,  S  
A :  F,  H,  S  
D : ¬F, ¬H, ¬S  
C :  F,  H, ¬S

Exactly one man possesses all three required properties F & H & ¬S,
namely Cliff Hedge.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer: Cliff Hedge
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. From “two men who are not fair are each standing next to Mad Ade,” infer that Mad Ade must have two neighbours, hence occupies an interior spot; fix him at position 2 (the mirror case at 3 is symmetric). [Rudimentary]  

2. Translate “Cliff Hedge is the only man not standing next to exactly one scarred man” into neighbour-count language: every man except Cliff must have exactly one scarred neighbour; Cliff has either 0 or 2 scarred neighbours. [Rudimentary]  

3. Translate “Buster Artery is the only man standing next to exactly one handsome man” into neighbour-count language: Buster has exactly one handsome neighbour; all others have either 0 or 2 handsome neighbours. [Rudimentary]  

4. Note that if Buster were interior, an end-man would also have exactly one handsome neighbour, violating Buster’s uniqueness; therefore place Buster at an end (choose position 1) and deduce that his sole neighbour, Mad Ade, must be handsome. [Creative]  

5. Examine the remaining two positions and apply the “exactly one handsome neighbour” restriction to eliminate cases, arriving at the only consistent handsome pattern: A and C are handsome, B and D are not. [Creative]  

6. Apply the scar-count condition together with end positions to assign scars: A scarred, B scarred, D unscarred, C unscarred; verify that only Cliff (C) lacks exactly one scarred neighbour. [Rudimentary]  

7. Use the original “neighbours of Mad Ade are not fair” clause to mark B and D as not fair; with no other constraints, let A and C be fair. [Rudimentary]  

8. Read off the attributes: Cliff Hedge (C) is the unique man who is fair, handsome and unscarred; state him as the answer. [Rudimentary]

['Total Step Count: 8  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. From “two men who are not fair are each standing next to Mad Ade,” infer that Mad Ade must have two neighbours, hence occupies an interior spot; fix him at position 2 (the mirror case at 3 is symmetric). [Rudimentary]  

2. Translate “Cliff Hedge is the only man not standing next to exactly one scarred man” into neighbour-count language: every man except Cliff must have exactly one scarred neighbour; Cliff has either 0 or 2 scarred neighbours. [Rudimentary]  

3. Translate “Buster Artery is the only man standing next to exactly one handsome man” into neighbour-count language: Buster has exactly one handsome neighbour; all others have either 0 or 2 handsome neighbours. [Rudimentary]  

4. Note that if Buster were interior, an end-man would also have exactly one handsome neighbour, violating Buster’s uniqueness; therefore place Buster at an end (choose position 1) and deduce that his sole neighbour, Mad Ade, must be handsome. [Creative]  

5. Examine the remaining two positions and apply the “exactly one handsome neighbour” restriction to eliminate cases, arriving at the only consistent handsome pattern: A and C are handsome, B and D are not. [Creative]  

6. Apply the scar-count condition together with end positions to assign scars: A scarred, B scarred, D unscarred, C unscarred; verify that only Cliff (C) lacks exactly one scarred neighbour. [Rudimentary]  

7. Use the original “neighbours of Mad Ade are not fair” clause to mark B and D as not fair; with no other constraints, let A and C be fair. [Rudimentary]  

8. Read off the attributes: Cliff Hedge (C) is the unique man who is fair, handsome and unscarred; state him as the answer. [Rudimentary]']

Question:
Mad Ade's rich uncle "Uncle Rich" owned the famous Madadian Race horse breeding stables "The Gluepot".
It has a private race track that has five lanes.
Uncle Rich has 25 horses and wishes to know which are the three fastest.
What is the least number of races needed to be run to find the answer?
Note that it is only the ranking of the horses being found not the actual timings.
Hint: Subgroups!
Human Solution:
Let  

A = {A₁, A₂, A₃, A₄, A₅ }  
B = {B₁, B₂, B₃, B₄, B₅ }  
C = {C₁, C₂, C₃, C₄, C₅ }  
D = {D₁, D₂, D₃, D₄, D₅ }  
E = {E₁, E₂, E₃, E₄, E₅ }  

be the 25 horses, the sub-script 1 denoting the fastest in its set, 2 the next fastest, etc.  
The track has 5 lanes, so at most 5 horses can run at once, and the only information obtained from a race is the order in which the five starters finish.

Step 1.  Five preliminary races (Races 1–5).  
Race each set once, obtaining the internal orders  

A₁<A₂<A₃<A₄<A₅, … , E₁<E₂<E₃<E₄<E₅.  

No fewer than five races suffice to see every horse even once, because 25÷5 = 5.

Step 2.  Race of the five heat-winners (Race 6).  
Start A₁, B₁, C₁, D₁, E₁ together.  Suppose the result is  

A₁ < B₁ < C₁ < D₁ < E₁.  

So group A is the fastest group, B the next, etc.

What horses can still be among the overall fastest three?

• A₁, A₂, A₃            (the three quickest in the fastest group)  
• B₁, B₂                (the two quickest in the second-fastest group)  
• C₁                    (the quickest in the third-fastest group)

No other horse can reach the overall top three:

– Anything behind A₃ in group A is slower than A₃.  
– Anything behind B₂ in group B is slower than B₂.  
– Every horse in groups D and E is slower than D₁ or E₁, which in turn are already proved slower than A₁, B₁ and C₁.  

Thus exactly six horses (A₁, A₂, A₃, B₁, B₂, C₁) still matter.

Step 3.  Tie-breaker race of the six remaining candidates (Race 7).  
Run those six; the first three to finish are necessarily the three fastest horses overall.

Total number of races used: 5 + 1 + 1 = 7.

Why 7 is minimal.  
After the first five heats you have seen every horse once but cannot yet compare horses from different heats.  
At that moment at least five horses (the heat-winners) are still possible overall winners.  To decide the winner you must race them together, giving Race 6.  
Even after that race there remain at least six logical candidates for the top three, as shown above; a single track can host only five at a time, so one more race is unavoidable.  
Therefore no procedure can ever finish in fewer than 7 races, and the construction above attains that bound.

Final answer: 7
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. Place the 25 horses into five groups of five and hold one race for each group (Races 1-5) to establish the internal ranking A₁<A₂<…<A₅, … , E₁<E₂<…<E₅.  (Rudimentary)

2. Run the five group winners A₁, B₁, C₁, D₁, E₁ against each other (Race 6) to rank the groups themselves; suppose the result is A₁<B₁<C₁<D₁<E₁.  (Rudimentary)

3. Use the information from the first six races to reason which horses could still finish in the overall top three; deduce that only A₁, A₂, A₃, B₁, B₂, C₁ remain possible candidates.  (Creative)

4. Stage one more race (Race 7) among the remaining relevant horses; its first three finishers, together with the knowledge that A₁ is fastest overall, give the complete ordering of the three quickest horses.  (Rudimentary)

5. Prove optimality: argue that after the first five heats at least five horses can still be overall winner, forcing Race 6, and after Race 6 at least six horses can still be in the top three while only five can be run at a time, forcing Race 7; therefore no method can need fewer than seven races, matching the construction above.  (Creative)
